00385|     """Runs a local development server for the Flask application.

00387|     This local server is recommended for development purposes only but it
00388|     can also be used for simple intranet deployments.  By default it will

00399|     if debugger is None:

00401|     if eager_loading is None:

00417|

00431|     """
00432|     import code

00434|     app = _app_ctx_stack.top.app
00435|     banner = 'Python %s on %s\nApp: %s%s\nInstance: %s' % (
00436|         sys.version,
00437|         sys.platform,
00438|         app.import_name,
00439|         app.debug and ' [debug]' or '',
00440|         app.instance_path,
00441|     )
00442|     ctx = {}
00443| 
00444|     # Support the regular Python interpreter startup script if someone
00445|     # is using it.
00446|     startup = os.environ.get('PYTHONSTARTUP')
00447|     if startup and os.path.isfile(startup):
00448|         with open(startup, 'r') as f:
00449|             eval(compile(f.read(), startup, 'exec'), ctx)
00450| 
00451|     ctx.update(app.make_shell_context())

def test_multi_route_class_views():
    class View(object):

        def __init__(self, app):
            app.add_url_rule('/', 'index', self.index)
            app.add_url_rule('/<test>/', 'index', self.index)

        def index(self, test='a'):
            return test

    app = flask.Flask(__name__)
    _ = View(app)
    rv = app.test_client().open('/')
    assert rv.data == b'a'
    rv = app.test_client().open('/b/')
    assert rv.data == b'b'

00009| 
00010| 
00011| A Minimal Application
00012| ---------------------
00013| 
00014| A minimal Flask application looks something like this::
00015| 
00016|     from flask import Flask
00017|     app = Flask(__name__)
00018| 
00019|     @app.route('/')
00020|     def hello_world():
00021|         return 'Hello World!'
00022| 
00023| Just save it as `hello.py` (or something similar) and run it with your Python
00024| interpreter.  Make sure to not call your application `flask.py` because this
00025| would conflict with Flask itself.
00026| 
00027| To run the application you can either use the ``flask`` command or
00028| python's ``-m`` switch with Flask::
00029| 
00030|     $ flask -a hello run
00031|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/
00032| 
00033| or alternatively::
00034| 
00035|     $ python -m flask -a hello run
00036|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/
00037| 
00038| Now head over to `http://127.0.0.1:5000/ <http://127.0.0.1:5000/>`_, and you
00039| should see your hello world greeting.
00040| 
00041| So what did that code do?
00042| 
00043| 1. First we imported the :class:`~flask.Flask` class.  An instance of this
00044|    class will be our WSGI application.
00045| 2. Next we create an instance of this class. The first argument is the name of
00046|    the application's module or package.  If you are using a single module (as
00047|    in this example), you should use `__name__` because depending on if it's
00048|    started as application or imported as module the name will be different
00049|    (``'__main__'`` versus the actual import name). This is needed so that
00050|    Flask knows where to look for templates, static files, and so on. For more
00051|    information have a look at the :class:`~flask.Flask` documentation.
00052| 3. We then use the :meth:`~flask.Flask.route` decorator to tell Flask what URL
00053|    should trigger our function.
00054| 4. The function is given a name which is also used to generate URLs for that
00055|    particular function, and returns the message we want to display in the
00056|    user's browser.
00057| 5. Finally we use the Flask development server to run the local server
00058|    with our application.
00059| 
00060| To stop the server, hit control-C.
00061| 
00062| .. _public-server:
00063| 
00064| .. admonition:: Externally Visible Server
00065| 
00066|    If you run the server you will notice that the server is only accessible
00067|    from your own computer, not from any other in the network.  This is the
00068|    default because in debugging mode a user of the application can execute
00069|    arbitrary Python code on your computer.
00070| 
00071|    If you have the debugger disabled or trust the users on your network,
00072|    you can make the server publicly available simply by adding
00073|    ``--host=0.0.0.0`` to the command line::
00074| 
00075|        flask -a hello run --host=0.0.0.0
00076| 
00077|    This tells your operating system to listen on all public IPs.
00078| 
00079| What to do if the Server does not Start
00080| ---------------------------------------
00081| 
00082| In case the ``python -m flask`` fails or ``flask`` does not exist,
00083| there are multiple reasons this might be the case.  First of all you need
00084| to look at the error message.
00085| 
00086| Old Version of Flask
00087| ````````````````````
00088| 
00089| Versions of Flask older than 1.0 use to have different ways to start the
00090| application.  In short, the ``flask`` command did not exist, and
00091| neither did ``python -m flask``.  In that case you have two options:
00092| either upgrade to newer Flask versions or have a look at the :ref:`server`
00093| docs to see the alternative method for running a server.
00094| 
00095| Python older 2.7
00096| ````````````````
00097| 
00098| In case you have a version of Python older than 2.7 ``python -m flask``
00099| does not work.  You can either use ``flask`` or ``python -m
00100| flask.cli`` as an alternative.  This is because Python before 2.7 does no
00101| permit packages to act as executable modules.  For more information see
00102| :ref:`cli`.
00103| 
00104| Invalid Import Name
00105| ```````````````````
00106| 
00107| The ``-a`` argument to ``flask`` is the name of the module to import.  In
00108| case that module is incorrectly named you will get an import error upon
00109| start (or if debug is enabled when you navigate to the application).  It
00110| will tell you what it tried to import and why it failed.
00111| 
00112| The most common reason is a typo or because you did not actually create an
00113| ``app`` object.
00114| 
00115| .. _debug-mode:
00116| 
00117| Debug Mode
00118| ----------
00119| 
00120| The ``flask`` script is nice to start a local development server, but
00121| you would have to restart it manually after each change to your code.

Quickstart
==========

Eager to get started?  This page gives a good introduction to Flask.  It
assumes you already have Flask installed.  If you do not, head over to the
:ref:`installation` section.


A Minimal Application
---------------------

A minimal Flask application looks something like this::

    from flask import Flask
    app = Flask(__name__)

    @app.route('/')
    def hello_world():
        return 'Hello World!'","truncated":true},"time":{"start":1770026344513,"end":1770026344567}}}}

00246| 
00247| Configuring from Files
00248| ----------------------
00249| 
00250| Configuration becomes more useful if you can store it in a separate file,
00251| ideally located outside the actual application package. This makes
00252| packaging and distributing your application possible via various package
00253| handling tools (:ref:`distribute-deployment`) and finally modifying the
00254| configuration file afterwards.
00255| 
00256| So a common pattern is this::
00257| 
00258|     app = Flask(__name__)
00259|     app.config.from_object('yourapplication.default_settings')
00260|     app.config.from_envvar('YOURAPPLICATION_SETTINGS')
00261| 
00262| This first loads the configuration from the
00263| `yourapplication.default_settings` module and then overrides the values
00264| with the contents of the file the :envvar:`YOURAPPLICATION_SETTINGS`
00265| environment variable points to.  This environment variable can be set on
00266| Linux or OS X with the export command in the shell before starting the
00267| server::
00268| 
00269|     $ export YOURAPPLICATION_SETTINGS=/path/to/settings.cfg
00270|     $ python run-app.py
00271|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/
00272|      * Restarting with reloader...
00273| 
00274| On Windows systems use the `set` builtin instead::
00275| 
00276|     >set YOURAPPLICATION_SETTINGS=\path\to\settings.cfg
00277| 
00278| The configuration files themselves are actual Python files.  Only values
00279| in uppercase are actually stored in the config object later on.  So make
00280| sure to use uppercase letters for your config keys.
00281| 
00282| Here is an example of a configuration file::
00283| 
00284|     # Example configuration
00285|     DEBUG = False
00286|     SECRET_KEY = '?\xbf,\xb4\x8d\xa3"<\x9c\xb0@\x0f5\xab,w\xee\x8d$0\x13\x8b83'
00287| 
00288| Make sure to load the configuration very early on, so that extensions have
00289| the ability to access the configuration when starting up.  There are other
00290| methods on the config object as well to load from individual files.  For a
00291| complete reference, read the :class:`~flask.Config` object's
00292| documentation.
00293| 
00294| 
00295| Configuration Best Practices
00296| ----------------------------
00297| 
00298| The downside with the approach mentioned earlier is that it makes testing
00299| a little harder.  There is no single 100% solution for this problem in
00300| general, but there are a couple of things you can keep in mind to improve
00301| that experience:
00302| 
00303| 1.  Create your application in a function and register blueprints on it.
00304|     That way you can create multiple instances of your application with
00305|     different configurations attached which makes unittesting a lot
00306|     easier.  You can use this to pass in configuration as needed.
00307| 
00308| 2.  Do not write code that needs the configuration at import time.  If you
00309|     limit yourself to request-only accesses to the configuration you can
00310|     reconfigure the object later on as needed.
00311| 
00312| 
00313| Development / Production
00314| ------------------------
00315| 
00316| Most applications need more than one configuration.  There should be at
00317| least separate configurations for the production server and the one used
00318| during development.  The easiest way to handle this is to use a default
00319| configuration that is always loaded and part of the version control, and a
00320| separate configuration that overrides the values as necessary as mentioned

00002| 
00003| Development Server
00004| ==================
00005| 
00006| .. currentmodule:: flask
00007| 
00008| Starting with Flask 1.0 there are multiple built-in ways to run a
00009| development server.  The best one is the ``flask`` command line utility
00010| but you can also continue using the :meth:`Flask.run` method.
00011| 
00012| Command Line
00013| ------------
00014| 
00015| The ``flask`` command line script (:ref:`cli`) is strongly recommende for
00016| development because it provides a superior reload experience due to how it
00017| loads the application.  The basic usage is like this::
00018| 
00019|     $ flask -a my_application --debug run
00020| 
00021| This will enable the debugger, the reloader and then start the server on 
00022| *http://localhost:5000/*.
00023| 
00024| The individual features of the server can be controlled by passing more
00025| arguments to the ``run`` option.  For instance the reloader can be
00026| disabled::
00027| 
00028|     $ flask -a my_application --debug run --no-reload
00029| 
00030| In Code
00031| -------
00032| 
00033| The alternative way to start the application is through the
00034| :meth:`Flask.run` method.  This will immediately launch a local server
00035| exactly the same way the ``flask`` script does.
00036| 
00037| Example::
00038| 
00039|     if __name__ == '__main__':
00040|         app.run()
00041| 
00042| This works well for the common case but it does not work well for
00043| development which is why from Flask 1.0 onwards the ``flask`` method is
00044| recommended.  The reason for this is that due to how the reload mechanism
00045| works there are some bizarre side-effects (like executing certain code
00046| twice, sometimes crashing without message or dying when a syntax or
00047| import error happens).
00048| 
00049| It is however still a perfectly valid method for invoking a non automatic
00050| reloading application.
00051|

Development Server
==================

.. currentmodule:: flask

Starting with Flask 1.0 there are multiple built-in ways to run a
development server.  The best one is the ``flask`` command line utility
but you can also continue using the :meth:`Flask.run` method.

Command Line
------------

The ``flask`` command line script (:ref:`cli`) is strongly recommende for
development because it provides a superior reload experience due to how it
loads the application.  The basic usage is like this::

    $ flask -a my_application --debug run

00002| 
00003| Larger Applications
00004| ===================
00005| 
00006| For larger applications it's a good idea to use a package instead of a
00007| module.  That is quite simple.  Imagine a small application looks like
00008| this::
00009| 
00010|     /yourapplication
00011|         /yourapplication.py
00012|         /static
00013|             /style.css
00014|         /templates
00015|             layout.html
00016|             index.html
00017|             login.html
00018|             ...
00019| 
00020| Simple Packages
00021| ---------------
00022| 
00023| To convert that into a larger one, just create a new folder
00024| `yourapplication` inside the existing one and move everything below it.
00025| Then rename `yourapplication.py` to `__init__.py`.  (Make sure to delete
00026| all `.pyc` files first, otherwise things would most likely break)
00027| 
00028| You should then end up with something like that::
00029| 
00030|     /yourapplication
00031|         /yourapplication
00032|             /__init__.py
00033|             /static
00034|                 /style.css
00035|             /templates
00036|                 layout.html
00037|                 index.html
00038|                 login.html
00039|                 ...
00040| 
00041| But how do you run your application now?  The naive ``python
00042| yourapplication/__init__.py`` will not work.  Let's just say that Python
00043| does not want modules in packages to be the startup file.  But that is not
00044| a big problem, just add a new file called `runserver.py` next to the inner
00045| `yourapplication` folder with the following contents::
00046| 
00047|     from yourapplication import app
00048|     app.run(debug=True)
00049| 
00050| What did we gain from this?  Now we can restructure the application a bit
00051| into multiple modules.  The only thing you have to remember is the
00052| following quick checklist:
00053| 
00054| 1. the `Flask` application object creation has to be in the
00055|    `__init__.py` file.  That way each module can import it safely and the
00056|    `__name__` variable will resolve to the correct package.
00057| 2. all the view functions (the ones with a :meth:`~flask.Flask.route`
00058|    decorator on top) have to be imported in the `__init__.py` file.
00059|    Not the object itself, but the module it is in. Import the view module
00060|    **after the application object is created**.
00061| 
00062| Here's an example `__init__.py`::
00063| 
00064|     from flask import Flask
00065|     app = Flask(__name__)
00066| 
00067|     import yourapplication.views
00068| 
00069| And this is what `views.py` would look like::
00070| 
00071|     from yourapplication import app
00072| 
00073|     @app.route('/')
00074|     def index():
00075|         return 'Hello World!'
00076| 
00077| You should then end up with something like that::
00078| 
00079|     /yourapplication
00080|         /runserver.py
00081|         /yourapplication
00082|             /__init__.py
00083|             /views.py
00084|             /static
00085|                 /style.css
00086|             /templates
00087|                 layout.html
00088|                 index.html
00089|                 login.html
00090|                 ...
00091| 
00092| .. admonition:: Circular Imports
00093| 
00094|    Every Python programmer hates them, and yet we just added some:
00095|    circular imports (That's when two modules depend on each other.  In this
00096|    case `views.py` depends on `__init__.py`).  Be advised that this is a
00097|    bad idea in general but here it is actually fine.  The reason for this is
00098|    that we are not actually using the views in `__init__.py` and just
00099|    ensuring the module is imported and we are doing that at the bottom of
00100|    the file.
00101| 
00102|    There are still some problems with that approach but if you want to use
00103|    decorators there is no way around that.  Check out the
00104|    :ref:`becomingbig` section for some inspiration how to deal with that.
00105| 
00106| 
00107| .. _working-with-modules:
00108| 
00109| Working with Blueprints
00110| -----------------------
00111| 
00112| If you have larger applications it's recommended to divide them into
00113| smaller groups where each group is implemented with the help of a
00114| blueprint.  For a gentle introduction into this topic refer to the
00115| :ref:`blueprints` chapter of the documentation.
00116| 

(End of file - total 116 lines)

00201|     To integrate applications, :class:`Flask` has a hook to intercept URL build
00202|     errors through :attr:`Flask.url_build_error_handlers`.  The `url_for`
00203|     function results in a :exc:`~werkzeug.routing.BuildError` when the current
00204|     app does not have a URL for the given endpoint and values.  When it does, the
00205|     :data:`~flask.current_app` calls its :attr:`~Flask.url_build_error_handlers` if
00206|     it is not `None`, which can return a string to use as the result of
00207|     `url_for` (instead of `url_for`'s default to raise the
00208|     :exc:`~werkzeug.routing.BuildError` exception) or re-raise the exception.
00209|     An example::
00210| 
00211|         def external_url_handler(error, endpoint, values):
00212|             "Looks up an external URL when `url_for` cannot build a URL."
00213|             # This is an example of hooking the build_error_handler.
00214|             # Here, lookup_url is some utility function you've built
00215|             # which looks up the endpoint in some external URL registry.
00216|             url = lookup_url(endpoint, **values)
00217|             if url is None:
00218|                 # External lookup did not have a URL.
00219|                 # Re-raise the BuildError, in context of original traceback.
00220|                 exc_type, exc_value, tb = sys.exc_info()
00221|                 if exc_value is error:
00222|                     raise exc_type, exc_value, tb
00223|                 else:
00224|                     raise error
00225|             # url_for will use this result, instead of raising BuildError.
00226|             return url
00227|

00023| def make_test_environ_builder(app, path='/', base_url=None, *args, **kwargs):
00024|     """Creates a new test builder with some application defaults thrown in."""
00025|     http_host = app.config.get('SERVER_NAME')
00026|     app_root = app.config.get('APPLICATION_ROOT')
00027|     if base_url is None:
00028|         url = url_parse(path)
00029|         base_url = 'http://%s/' % (url.netloc or http_host or 'localhost')
00030|         if app_root:
00031|             base_url += app_root.lstrip('/')
00032|         if url.netloc:
00033|             path = url.path
00034|             if url.query:
00035|                 path += '?' + url.query
00036|     return EnvironBuilder(path, base_url, *args, **kwargs)

00039| class FlaskClient(Client):
00040|     """Works like a regular Werkzeug test client but has some knowledge about
00041|     how Flask works to defer the cleanup of the request context stack to the
00042|     end of a with body when used in a with statement.  For general information
00043|     about how to use this class refer to :class:`werkzeug.test.Client`.
00044| 
00045|     Basic usage is outlined in the :ref:`testing` chapter.
00046|     """
00047| 
00048|     preserve_context = False
00049| 
00050|     @contextmanager
00051|     def session_transaction(self, *args, **kwargs):
00052|         """When used in combination with a with statement this opens a
00053|         session transaction.  This can be used to modify the session that
00054|         the test client uses.  Once the with block is left the session is
00055|         stored back.
00056| 
00057|         ::
00058| 
00059|             with client.session_transaction() as session:
00060|                 session['value'] = 42
00061| 
00062|         Internally this is implemented by going through a temporary test
00063|         request context and since session handling could depend on
00064|         request variables this function accepts the same arguments as
00065|         :meth:`~flask.Flask.test_request_context` which are directly
00066|         passed through.
00067|         """
00068|         if self.cookie_jar is None:
00069|             raise RuntimeError('Session transactions only make sense '
00070|                                'with cookies enabled.')
00071|         app = self.application
00072|         environ_overrides = kwargs.setdefault('environ_overrides', {})
00073|         self.cookie_jar.inject_wsgi(environ_overrides)
00074|         outer_reqctx = _request_ctx_stack.top
00075|         with app.test_request_context(*args, **kwargs) as c:
00076|             sess = app.open_session(c.request)
00077|             if sess is None:
00078|                 raise RuntimeError('Session backend did not open a session. '
00079|                                    'Check the configuration')
00080| 
00081|             # Since we have to open a new request context for the session
00082|             # handling we want to make sure that we hide out own context
00083|             # from the caller.  By pushing the original request context
00084|             # (or None) on top of this and popping it we get exactly that
00085|             # behavior.  It's important to not use the push and pop
00086|             # methods of the actual request context object since that would
00087|             # mean that cleanup handlers are called
00088|             _request_ctx_stack.push(outer_reqctx)
00089|             try:
00090|                 yield sess
00091|             finally:
00092|                 _request_ctx_stack.pop()
00093| 
00094|             resp = app.response_class()
00095|             if not app.session_interface.is_null_session(sess):
00096|                 app.save_session(sess, resp)
00097|             headers = resp.get_wsgi_headers(c.request.environ)
00098|             self.cookie_jar.extract_wsgi(c.request.environ, headers)
00099| 
00100|     def open(self, *args, **kwargs):
00101|         kwargs.setdefault('environ_overrides', {}) \
00102|             ['flask._preserve_context'] = self.preserve_context
00103| 
00104|         as_tuple = kwargs.pop('as_tuple', False)
00105|         buffered = kwargs.pop('buffered', False)
00106|         follow_redirects = kwargs.pop('follow_redirects', False)
00107|         builder = make_test_environ_builder(self.application, *args, **kwargs)
00108| 
00109|         return Client.open(self, builder,
00110|                            as_tuple=as_tuple,
00111|                            buffered=buffered,
00112|                            follow_redirects=follow_redirects)
00113| 
00114|     def __enter__(self):
00115|         if self.preserve_context:
00116|             raise RuntimeError('Cannot nest client invocations')
00117|         self.preserve_context = True
00118|         return self
00119| 
00120|     def __exit__(self, exc_type, exc_value, tb):
00121|         self.preserve_context = False

00020| 
00021| 
00022| PROD_LOG_FORMAT = '[%(asctime)s] %(levelname)s in %(module)s: %(message)s'
00023| DEBUG_LOG_FORMAT = (
00024|     '-' * 80 + '\n' +
00025|     '%(levelname)s in %(module)s [%(pathname)s:%(lineno)d]:\n' +
00026|     '%(message)s\n' +
00027|     '-' * 80
00028| )
00029| 
00030| 
00031| @LocalProxy
00032| def _proxy_stream():
00033|     """Finds the most appropriate error stream for the application.  If a
00034|     WSGI request is in flight we log to wsgi.errors, otherwise this resolves
00035|     to sys.stderr.
00036|     """
00037|     ctx = _request_ctx_stack.top
00038|     if ctx is not None:
00039|         return ctx.request.environ['wsgi.errors']
00040|     return sys.stderr
00041| 
00042| 
00043| def _should_log_for(app, mode):
00044|     policy = app.config['LOGGER_HANDLER_POLICY']
00045|     if policy == mode or policy == 'always':
00046|         return True
00047|     return False
00048| 
00049| 
00050| def create_logger(app):
00051|     """Creates a logger for the given application.  This logger works
00052|     similar to a regular Python logger but changes the effective logging
00053|     level based on the application's debug flag.  Furthermore this
00054|     function also removes all attached handlers in case there was a
00055|     logger with the log name before.
00056|     """
00057|     Logger = getLoggerClass()
00058| 
00059|     class DebugLogger(Logger):
00060|         def getEffectiveLevel(self):
00061|             if self.level == 0 and app.debug:
00062|                 return DEBUG
00063|             return Logger.getEffectiveLevel(self)
00064| 
00065|     class DebugHandler(StreamHandler):
00066|         def emit(self, record):
00067|             if app.debug and _should_log_for(app, 'debug'):
00068|                 StreamHandler.emit(self, record)
00069| 
00070|     class ProductionHandler(StreamHandler):
00071|         def emit(self, record):
00072|             if not app.debug and _should_log_for(app, 'production'):
00073|                 StreamHandler.emit(self, record)
00074| 
00075|     debug_handler = DebugHandler()
00076|     debug_handler.setLevel(DEBUG)
00077|     debug_handler.setFormatter(Formatter(DEBUG_LOG_FORMAT))
00078| 
00079|     prod_handler = ProductionHandler(_proxy_stream)
00080|     prod_handler.setLevel(ERROR)
00081|     prod_handler.setFormatter(Formatter(PROD_LOG_FORMAT))
00082| 
00083|     logger = getLogger(app.logger_name)
00084|     # just in case that was not a new logger, get rid of all the handlers
00085|     # already attached to it.
00086|     del logger.handlers[:]
00087|     logger.__class__ = DebugLogger
00088|     logger.addHandler(debug_handler)
00089|     logger.addHandler(prod_handler)
00090| 
00091|     # Disable propagation by default
00092|     logger.propagate = False
00093| 
00094|     return logger

00040| def find_best_app(script_info, module):
00041|     """Given a module instance this tries to find the best possible
00042|     application in the module or raises an exception.
00043|     """
00044|     from . import Flask
00045| 
00046|     # Search for the most common names first.
00047|     for attr_name in ('app', 'application'):
00048|         app = getattr(module, attr_name, None)
00049|         if isinstance(app, Flask):
00050|             return app
00051| 
00052|     # Otherwise find the only object that is a Flask instance.
00053|     matches = [
00054|         v for k, v in iteritems(module.__dict__) if isinstance(v, Flask)
00055|     ]
00056| 
00057|     if len(matches) == 1:
00058|         return matches[0]
00059|     elif len(matches) > 1:
00060|         raise NoAppException(
00061|             'Auto-detected multiple Flask applications in module "{module}".'
00062|             ' Use "FLASK_APP={module}:name" to specify the correct'
00063|             ' one.'.format(module=module.__name__)
00064|         )
00065| 
00066|     # Search for app factory functions.
00067|     for attr_name in ('create_app', 'make_app'):
00068|         app_factory = getattr(module, attr_name, None)
00069| 
00070|         if inspect.isfunction(app_factory):
00071|             try:
00072|                 app = call_factory(app_factory, script_info)
00073|                 if isinstance(app, Flask):
00074|                     return app
00075|             except TypeError:
00076|                 raise NoAppException(
00077|                     'Auto-detected "{function}()" in module "{module}", but '
00078|                     'could not call it without specifying arguments.'.format(
00079|                         function=attr_name, module=module.__name__
00080|                     )
00081|                 )
00082| 
00083|     raise NoAppException(
00084|         'Failed to find application in module "{module}". Are you sure '
00085|         'it contains a Flask application? Maybe you wrapped it in a WSGI '
00086|         'middleware.'.format(module=module.__name__)
00087|     )
00088| 
00089| 
00090| def call_factory(app_factory, script_info, arguments=()):
00091|     """Takes an app factory, a ``script_info` object and  optionally a tuple
00092|     of arguments. Checks for the existence of a script_info argument and calls
00093|     the app_factory depending on that and the arguments provided.
00094|     """
00095|     args_spec = getargspec(app_factory)
00096|     arg_names = args_spec.args
00097|     arg_defaults = args_spec.defaults
00098| 
00099|     if 'script_info' in arg_names:
00100|         return app_factory(*arguments, script_info=script_info)
00101|     elif arguments:
00102|         return app_factory(*arguments)
00103|     elif not arguments and len(arg_names) == 1 and arg_defaults is None:
00104|         return app_factory(script_info)
00105|     return app_factory()

00108| def find_app_by_string(string, script_info, module):
00109|     """Checks if the given string is a variable name or a function. If it is
00110|     a function, it checks for specified arguments and whether it takes
00111|     a ``script_info`` argument and calls the function with the appropriate
00112|     arguments."""
00113|     from . import Flask
00114|     function_regex = r'^(?P<name>\w+)(?:\((?P<args>.*)\))?$'
00115|     match = re.match(function_regex, string)
00116|     if match:
00117|         name, args = match.groups()
00118|         try:
00119|             if args is not None:
00120|                 args = args.rstrip(' ,')
00121|                 if args:
00122|                     args = ast.literal_eval(
00123|                         "({args}, )".format(args=args))
00124|                 else:
00125|                     args = ()
00126|                 app_factory = getattr(module, name, None)
00127|                 app = call_factory(app_factory, script_info, args)
00128|             else:
00129|                 attr = getattr(module, name, None)
00130|                 if inspect.isfunction(attr):
00131|                     app = call_factory(attr, script_info)
00132|                 else:
00133|                     app = attr
00134| 
00135|             if isinstance(app, Flask):
00136|                 return app
00137|             else:
00138|                 raise NoAppException('Failed to find application in module '
00139|                                    '"{name}"'.format(name=module))
00140|         except TypeError as e:
00141|             new_error = NoAppException(
00142|                 '{e}\nThe app factory "{factory}" in module "{module}" could'
00143|                 ' not be called with the specified arguments (and a'
00144|                 ' script_info argument automatically added if applicable).'
00145|                 ' Did you make sure to use the right number of arguments as'
00146|                 ' well as not using keyword arguments or'
00147|                 ' non-literals?'.format(e=e, factory=string, module=module))
00148|             reraise(NoAppException, new_error, sys.exc_info()[2])
00149|     else:
00150|         raise NoAppException(
00151|             'The provided string "{string}" is not a valid variable name'
00152|             'or function expression.'.format(string=string))

00155| def prepare_import(path):
00156|     """Given a filename this will try to calculate the python path, add it
00157|     to the search path and return the actual module name that is expected.
00158|     """
00159|     path = os.path.realpath(path)
00160| 
00161|     if os.path.splitext(path)[1] == '.py':
00162|         path = os.path.splitext(path)[0]
00163| 
00164|     if os.path.basename(path) == '__init__':
00165|         path = os.path.dirname(path)
00166| 
00167|     module_name = []
00168| 
00169|     # move up until outside package structure (no __init__.py)
00170|     while True:
00171|         path, name = os.path.split(path)
00172|         module_name.append(name)
00173| 
00174|         if not os.path.exists(os.path.join(path, '__init__.py')):
00175|             break
00176| 
00177|     if sys.path[0] != path:
00178|         sys.path.insert(0, path)
00179| 
00180|     return '.'.join(module_name[::-1])

00183| def locate_app(script_info, module_name, app_name, raise_if_not_found=True):
00184|     """Attempts to locate the application."""
00185|     __traceback_hide__ = True
00186| 
00187|     try:
00188|         __import__(module_name)
00189|     except ImportError:
00190|         # Reraise the ImportError if it occurred within the imported module.
00191|         # Determine this by checking whether the trace has a depth > 1.
00192|         if sys.exc_info()[-1].tb_next:
00193|             raise NoAppException(
00194|                 'While importing "{name}", an ImportError was raised:'
00195|                 '\n\n{tb}'.format(name=module_name, tb=traceback.format_exc())
00196|             )
00197|         elif raise_if_not_found:
00198|             raise NoAppException(
00199|                 'Could not import "{name}"."'.format(name=module_name)
00200|             )
00201|         else:
00202|             return
00203| 
00204|     module = sys.modules[module_name]
00205| 
00206|     if app_name is None:
00207|         return find_best_app(script_info, module)
00208|     else:
00209|         return find_app_by_string(app_name, script_info, module)

00228| class DispatchingApp(object):
00229|     """Special application that dispatches to a Flask application which
00230|     is imported by name in a background thread.  If an error happens
00231|     it is recorded and shown as part of the WSGI handling which in case
00232|     of the Werkzeug debugger means that it shows up in the browser.
00233|     """
00234| 
00235|     def __init__(self, loader, use_eager_loading=False):
00236|         self.loader = loader
00237|         self._app = None
00238|         self._lock = Lock()
00239|         self._bg_loading_exc_info = None
00240|         if use_eager_loading:
00241|             self._load_unlocked()
00242|         else:
00243|             self._load_in_background()
00244| 
00245|     def _load_in_background(self):
00246|         def _load_app():
00247|             __traceback_hide__ = True
00248|             with self._lock:
00249|                 try:
00250|                     self._load_unlocked()

00256|     def _flush_bg_loading_exception(self):
00257|         __traceback_hide__ = True
00258|         exc_info = self._bg_loading_exc_info

00260|             self._bg_loading_exc_info = None

00263|     def _load_unlocked(self):
00264|         __traceback_hide__ = True
00265|         self._app = rv = self.loader()

00268| 
00269|     def __call__(self, environ, start_response):
00270|         __traceback_hide__ = True
00271|         if self._app is not None:
00272|             return self._app(environ, start_response)
00273|         self._flush_bg_loading_exception()
00274|         with self._lock:
00275|             if self._app is not None:
00276|                 rv = self._app
00277|             else:
00278|                 rv = self._load_unlocked()

00282| class ScriptInfo(object):
00283|     """Help object to deal with Flask applications.  This is usually not
00284|     necessary to interface with as it's used internally in the dispatching
00285|     to click.  In future versions of Flask this object will most likely play
00286|     a bigger role.  Typically it's created automatically by the
00287|     :class:`FlaskGroup` but you can also manually create it and pass it
00288|     onwards as click object.
00289|     """
00290| 
00291|     def __init__(self, app_import_path=None, create_app=None):
00292|         #: Optionally the import path for the Flask application.
00293|         self.app_import_path = app_import_path or os.environ.get('FLASK_APP')
00294|         #: Optionally a function that is passed the script info to create
00295|         #: the instance of the application.
00296|         self.create_app = create_app
00297|         #: A dictionary with arbitrary data that can be associated with
00298|         #: this script info.
00299|         self.data = {}
00300|         self._loaded_app = None
00301| 
00302|     def load_app(self):
00303|         """Loads the Flask app (if not yet loaded) and returns it.  Calling
00304|         this multiple times will just result in the already loaded app to
00305|         be returned.
00306|         """
00307|         __traceback_hide__ = True
00308| 
00309|         if self._loaded_app is not None:
00310|             return self._loaded_app
00311| 
00312|         app = None
00313| 
00314|         if self.create_app is not None:
00315|             app = call_factory(self.create_app, self)
00316|         else:
00317|             if self.app_import_path:
00318|                 path, name = (self.app_import_path.split(':', 1) + [None])[:2]
00319|                 import_name = prepare_import(path)
00320|                 app = locate_app(self, import_name, name)
00321|             else:
00322|                 for path in ('wsgi.py', 'app.py'):
00323|                     import_name = prepare_import(path)
00324|                     app = locate_app(
00325|                         self, import_name, None, raise_if_not_found=False
00326|                     )
00327| 
00328|                     if app:
00329|                         break
00330| 
00331|         if not app:
00332|             raise NoAppException(
00333|                 'Could not locate a Flask application. You did not provide '
00334|                 'the "FLASK_APP" environment variable, and a "wsgi.py" or '
00335|                 '"app.py" module was not found in the current directory.'
00336|             )
00337| 
00338|         debug = get_debug_flag()
00339| 
00340|         if debug is not None:
00341|             app._reconfigure_for_run_debug(debug)
00342| 
00343|         self._loaded_app = app
00344|         return app

00350| def with_appcontext(f):
00351|     """Wraps a callback so that it's guaranteed to be executed with the
00352|     script's application context.  If callbacks are registered directly
00353|     to the ``app.cli`` object then they are wrapped with this function
00354|     by default unless it's disabled.
00355|     """
00356|     @click.pass_context
00357|     def decorator(__ctx, *args, **kwargs):
00358|         with __ctx.ensure_object(ScriptInfo).load_app().app_context():
00359|             return __ctx.invoke(f, *args, **kwargs)
00360|     return update_wrapper(decorator, f)

00363| class AppGroup(click.Group):
00364|     """This works similar to a regular click :class:`~click.Group` but it
00365|     changes the behavior of the :meth:`command` decorator so that it
00366|     automatically wraps the functions in :func:`with_appcontext`.
00367| 
00368|     Not to be confused with :class:`FlaskGroup`.
00369|     """
00370| 
00371|     def command(self, *args, **kwargs):
00372|         """This works exactly like the method of the same name on a regular
00373|         :class:`click.Group` but it wraps callbacks in :func:`with_appcontext`
00374|         unless it's disabled by passing ``with_appcontext=False``.
00375|         """
00376|         wrap_for_ctx = kwargs.pop('with_appcontext', True)
00377|         def decorator(f):
00378|             if wrap_for_ctx:
00379|                 f = with_appcontext(f)
00380|             return click.Group.command(self, *args, **kwargs)(f)
00381|         return decorator
00382| 
00383|     def group(self, *args, **kwargs):
00384|         """This works exactly like the method of the same name on a regular
00385|         :class:`click.Group` but it defaults the group class to
00386|         :class:`AppGroup`.
00387|         """
00388|         kwargs.setdefault('cls', AppGroup)
00389|         return click.Group.group(self, *args, **kwargs)
00390|

00392| class FlaskGroup(AppGroup):
00393|     """Special subclass of the :class:`AppGroup` group that supports
00394|     loading more commands from the configured Flask app.  Normally a
00395|     developer does not have to interface with this class but there are
00396|     some very advanced use cases for which it makes sense to create an
00397|     instance of this.
00398| 
00399|     For information as of why this is useful see :ref:`custom-scripts`.
00400| 
00401|     :param add_default_commands: if this is True then the default run and
00402|         shell commands wil be added.
00403|     :param add_version_option: adds the ``--version`` option.
00404|     :param create_app: an optional callback that is passed the script info and
00405|         returns the loaded app.
00406|     :param load_dotenv: Load the nearest :file:`.env` and :file:`.flaskenv`
00407|         files to set environment variables. Will also change the working
00408|         directory to the directory containing the first file found.
00409| 
00410|     .. versionchanged:: 1.0
00411|         If installed, python-dotenv will be used to load environment variables
00412|         from :file:`.env` and :file:`.flaskenv` files.
00413|     """
00414| 
00415|     def __init__(
00416|         self, add_default_commands=True, create_app=None,
00417|         add_version_option=True, load_dotenv=True, **extra
00418|     ):
00419|         params = list(extra.pop('params', None) or ())
00420| 
00421|         if add_version_option:
00422|             params.append(version_option)
00423| 
00424|         AppGroup.__init__(self, params=params, **extra)
00425|         self.create_app = create_app
00426|         self.load_dotenv = load_dotenv
00427| 
00428|         if add_default_commands:
00429|             self.add_command(run_command)
00430|             self.add_command(shell_command)
00431|             self.add_command(routes_command)
00432| 
00433|         self._loaded_plugin_commands = False
00434| 
00435|     def _load_plugin_commands(self):
00436|         if self._loaded_plugin_commands:
00437|             return
00438|         try:
00439|             import pkg_resources
00440|         except ImportError:
00441|             self._loaded_plugin_commands = True
00442|             return
00443| 
00444|         for ep in pkg_resources.iter_entry_points('flask.commands'):
00445|             self.add_command(ep.load(), ep.name)
00446|         self._loaded_plugin_commands = True
00447| 
00448|     def get_command(self, ctx, name):
00449|         self._load_plugin_commands()
00450| 
00451|         # We load built-in commands first as these should always be the
00452|         # same no matter what the app does.  If the app does want to
00453|         # override this it needs to make a custom instance of this group
00454|         # and not attach the default commands.
00455|         #
00456|         # This also means that the script stays functional in case the
00457|         # application completely fails.
00458|         rv = AppGroup.get_command(self, ctx, name)
00459|         if rv is not None:
00460|             return rv
00461| 
00462|         info = ctx.ensure_object(ScriptInfo)
00463|         try:
00464|             rv = info.load_app().cli.get_command(ctx, name)
00465|             if rv is not None:
00466|                 return rv
00467|         except NoAppException:
00468|             pass
00469| 
00470|     def list_commands(self, ctx):
00471|         self._load_plugin_commands()
00472| 
00473|         # The commands available is the list of both the application (if
00474|         # available) plus the builtin commands.
00475|         rv = set(click.Group.list_commands(self, ctx))
00476|         info = ctx.ensure_object(ScriptInfo)
00477|         try:
00478|             rv.update(info.load_app().cli.list_commands(ctx))
00479|         except Exception:
00480|             # Here we intentionally swallow all exceptions as we don't
00481|             # want the help page to break if the app does not exist.
00482|             # If someone attempts to use the command we try to create
00483|             # the app again and this will give us the error.
00484|             # However, we will not do so silently because that would confuse
00485|             # users.
00486|             traceback.print_exc()
00487|         return sorted(rv)

00489|     def main(self, *args, **kwargs):
00490|         # Set a global flag that indicates that we were invoked from the
00491|         # command line interface. This is detected by Flask.run to make the
00492|         # call into a no-op. This is necessary to avoid ugly errors when the
00493|         # script that is loaded here also attempts to start a server.
00494|         os.environ['FLASK_RUN_FROM_CLI'] = 'true'
00495| 
00496|         if self.load_dotenv:
00497|             load_dotenv()
00498| 
00499|         obj = kwargs.get('obj')
00500| 
00501|         if obj is None:
00502|             obj = ScriptInfo(create_app=self.create_app)
00503| 
00504|         kwargs['obj'] = obj
00505|         kwargs.setdefault('auto_envvar_prefix', 'FLASK')
00506|         return super(FlaskGroup, self).main(*args, **kwargs)

00509| def _path_is_ancestor(path, other):
00510|     """Take ``other`` and remove the length of ``path`` from it. Then join it
00511|     to ``path``. If it is the original value, ``path`` is an ancestor of
00512|     ``other``."""
00513|     return os.path.join(path, other[len(path):].lstrip(os.sep)) == other
00514|

00516| def load_dotenv(path=None):
00517|     """Load "dotenv" files in order of precedence to set environment variables.
00518| 
00519|     If an env var is already set it is not overwritten, so earlier files in the
00520|     list are preferred over later files.
00521| 
00522|     Changes the current working directory to the location of the first file
00523|     found, with the assumption that it is in the top level project directory
00524|     and will be where the Python path should import local packages from.
00525| 
00526|     This is a no-op if `python-dotenv`_ is not installed.
00527| 
00528|     .. _python-dotenv: https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv#readme
00529| 
00530|     :param path: Load the file at this location instead of searching.
00531|     :return: ``True`` if a file was loaded.
00532| 
00533|     .. versionadded:: 1.0
00534|     """
00535| 
00536|     if dotenv is None:
00537|         return
00538| 
00539|     if path is not None:
00540|         return dotenv.load_dotenv(path)
00541| 
00542|     new_dir = None
00543| 
00544|     for name in ('.env', '.flaskenv'):
00545|         path = dotenv.find_dotenv(name, usecwd=True)
00546| 
00547|         if not path:
00548|             continue
00549| 
00550|         if new_dir is None:
00551|             new_dir = os.path.dirname(path)
00552| 
00553|         dotenv.load_dotenv(path)
00554| 
00555|     if new_dir and os.getcwd() != new_dir:
00556|         os.chdir(new_dir)
00557| 
00558|     return new_dir is not None  # at least one file was located and loaded

00567|               help='Enable or disable the reloader.  By default the reloader '

00570|               help='Enable or disable the debugger.  By default the debugger '
00571|               'is active if debug is enabled.')
00572| @click.option('--eager-loading/--lazy-loader', default=None,
00573|               help='Enable or disable eager loading.  By default eager '

00575| @click.option('--with-threads/--without-threads', default=False,
00576|               help='Enable or disable multithreading.')
00577| @pass_script_info
00578| def run_command(info, host, port, reload, debugger, eager_loading,
00579|                 with_threads):
00580|     """Runs a local development server for the Flask application.
00581| 
00582|     This local server is recommended for development purposes only but it
00583|     can also be used for simple intranet deployments.  By default it will
00584|     not support any sort of concurrency at all to simplify debugging.  This
00585|     can be changed with the --with-threads option which will enable basic
00586|     multithreading.
00587| 
00588|     The reloader and debugger are by default enabled if the debug flag of
00589|     Flask is enabled and disabled otherwise.
00590|     """
00591|     from werkzeug.serving import run_simple
00592| 
00593|     debug = get_debug_flag()
00594|     if reload is None:
00595|         reload = bool(debug)
00596|     if debugger is None:
00597|         debugger = bool(debug)
00598|     if eager_loading is None:
00599|         eager_loading = not reload
00600| 
00601|     app = DispatchingApp(info.load_app, use_eager_loading=eager_loading)
00602| 
00603|     # Extra startup messages.  This depends a bit on Werkzeug internals to
00604|     # not double execute when the reloader kicks in.
00605|     if os.environ.get('WERKZEUG_RUN_MAIN') != 'true':
00606|         # If we have an import path we can print it out now which can help
00607|         # people understand what's being served.  If we do not have an
00608|         # import path because the app was loaded through a callback then
00609|         # we won't print anything.
00610|         if info.app_import_path is not None:
00611|             print(' * Serving Flask app "%s"' % info.app_import_path)
00612|         if debug is not None:
00613|             print(' * Forcing debug mode %s' % (debug and 'on' or 'off'))
00614| 
00615|     run_simple(host, port, app, use_reloader=reload,
00616|                use_debugger=debugger, threaded=with_threads)

00620| @with_appcontext
00621| def shell_command():
00622|     """Runs an interactive Python shell in the context of a given
00623|     Flask application.  The application will populate the default
00624|     namespace of this shell according to it's configuration.
00625| 
00626|     This is useful for executing small snippets of management code
00627|     without having to manually configuring the application.
00628|     """
00629|     import code
00630|     from flask.globals import _app_ctx_stack
00631|     app = _app_ctx_stack.top.app
00632|     banner = 'Python %s on %s\nApp: %s%s\nInstance: %s' % (
00633|         sys.version,
00634|         sys.platform,
00635|         app.import_name,
00636|         app.debug and ' [debug]' or '',
00637|         app.instance_path,
00638|     )
00639|     ctx = {}
00640| 
00641|     # Support the regular Python interpreter startup script if someone
00642|     # is using it.
00643|     startup = os.environ.get('PYTHONSTARTUP')
00644|     if startup and os.path.isfile(startup):
00645|         with open(startup, 'r') as f:
00646|             eval(compile(f.read(), startup, 'exec'), ctx)
00647| 
00648|     ctx.update(app.make_shell_context())
00649| 
00650|     code.interact(banner=banner, local=ctx)

00670|     """Show all registered routes with endpoints and methods."""

00672|     rules = list(current_app.url_map.iter_rules())
00673|     ignored_methods = set(() if all_methods else ('HEAD', 'OPTIONS'))
00674| 
00675|     if sort in ('endpoint', 'rule'):
00676|         rules = sorted(rules, key=attrgetter(sort))
00677|     elif sort == 'methods':
00678|         rules = sorted(rules, key=lambda rule: sorted(rule.methods))
00679| 
00680|     rule_methods = [
00681|         ', '.join(sorted(rule.methods - ignored_methods)) for rule in rules
00682|     ]
00683| 
00684|     headers = ('Endpoint', 'Methods', 'Rule')
00685|     widths = (
00686|         max(len(rule.endpoint) for rule in rules),
00687|         max(len(methods) for methods in rule_methods),
00688|         max(len(rule.rule) for rule in rules),
00689|     )
00690|     widths = [max(len(h), w) for h, w in zip(headers, widths)]
00691|     row = '{{0:<{0}}}  {{1:<{1}}}  {{2:<{2}}}'.format(*widths)
00692| 
00693|     click.echo(row.format(*headers).strip())
00694|     click.echo(row.format(*('-' * width for width in widths)))
00695| 
00696|     for rule, methods in zip(rules, rule_methods):
00697|         click.echo(row.format(rule.endpoint, methods, rule.rule).rstrip())

00060| .. _upgrading-to-011:
00061| 
00062| Version 0.11
00063| ------------
00064| 
00065| 0.11 is an odd release in the Flask release cycle because it was supposed
00066| to be the 1.0 release.  However because there was such a long lead time up
00067| to the release we decided to push out a 0.11 release first with some
00068| changes removed to make the transition easier.  If you have been tracking
00069| the master branch which was 1.0 you might see some unexpected changes.
00070| 
00071| In case you did track the master branch you will notice that :command:`flask --app`
00072| is removed now.  You need to use the environment variable to specify an
00073| application.
00074| 
00075| Debugging
00076| `````````
00077| 
00078| Flask 0.11 removed the ``debug_log_format`` attribute from Flask
00079| applications.  Instead the new ``LOGGER_HANDLER_POLICY`` configuration can
00080| be used to disable the default log handlers and custom log handlers can be
00081| set up.
00082| 
00083| Error handling
00084| ``````````````
00085| 
00086| The behavior of error handlers was changed.
00087| The precedence of handlers used to be based on the decoration/call order of
00088| :meth:`~flask.Flask.errorhandler` and
00089| :meth:`~flask.Flask.register_error_handler`, respectively.
00090| Now the inheritance hierarchy takes precedence and handlers for more
00091| specific exception classes are executed instead of more general ones.
00092| See :ref:`error-handlers` for specifics.
00093| 
00094| Trying to register a handler on an instance now raises :exc:`ValueError`.
00095| 
00096| .. note::
00097| 
00098|     There used to be a logic error allowing you to register handlers
00099|     only for exception *instances*. This was unintended and plain wrong,
00100|     and therefore was replaced with the intended behavior of registering
00101|     handlers only using exception classes and HTTP error codes.
00102| 
00103| Templating
00104| ``````````
00105| 
00106| The :func:`~flask.templating.render_template_string` function has changed to
00107| autoescape template variables by default. This better matches the behavior
00108| of :func:`~flask.templating.render_template`.
00109| 
00110| Extension imports
00111| `````````````````
00112| 
00113| Extension imports of the form ``flask.ext.foo`` are deprecated, you should use
00114| ``flask_foo``.
00115| 
00116| The old form still works, but Flask will issue a
00117| ``flask.exthook.ExtDeprecationWarning`` for each extension you import the old
00118| way. We also provide a migration utility called `flask-ext-migrate
00119| <https://github.com/pallets/flask-ext-migrate>`_ that is supposed to
00120| automatically rewrite your imports for this.
00121| 
00122| .. _upgrading-to-010:
00123| 
00124| Version 0.10
00125| ------------
00126| 
00127| The biggest change going from 0.9 to 0.10 is that the cookie serialization
00128| format changed from pickle to a specialized JSON format.  This change has
00129| been done in order to avoid the damage an attacker can do if the secret
00130| key is leaked.  When you upgrade you will notice two major changes: all
00131| sessions that were issued before the upgrade are invalidated and you can
00132| only store a limited amount of types in the session.  The new sessions are
00133| by design much more restricted to only allow JSON with a few small
00134| extensions for tuples and strings with HTML markup.
00135| 
00136| In order to not break people's sessions it is possible to continue using
00137| the old session system by using the `Flask-OldSessions`_ extension.
00138| 
00139| Flask also started storing the :data:`flask.g` object on the application
00140| context instead of the request context.  This change should be transparent

misleading ``name`` attribute. Silently swallowing errors in such cases was not

Additionally the default of falling back to ``application/octet-stream`` has
been restricted. If Flask can't guess one or the user didn't provide one, the
function fails if no filename information was provided.

.. _upgrading-to-011:

------------

to be the 1.0 release.  However because there was such a long lead time up
to the release we decided to push out a 0.11 release first with some
changes removed to make the transition easier.  If you have been tracking
the master branch which was 1.0 you might see some unexpected changes.

00002| 
00003| Command Line Interface
00004| ======================
00005| 
00006| .. versionadded:: 0.11
00007| 
00008| .. currentmodule:: flask
00009| 
00010| One of the nice new features in Flask 0.11 is the built-in integration of
00011| the `click <http://click.pocoo.org/>`_ command line interface.  This
00012| enables a wide range of new features for the Flask ecosystem and your own
00013| applications.
00014| 
00015| Basic Usage
00016| -----------
00017| 
00018| After installation of Flask you will now find a :command:`flask` script
00019| installed into your virtualenv.  If you don't want to install Flask or you
00020| have a special use-case you can also use ``python -m flask`` to accomplish
00021| exactly the same.
00022| 
00023| The way this script works is by providing access to all the commands on
00024| your Flask application's :attr:`Flask.cli` instance as well as some
00025| built-in commands that are always there.  Flask extensions can also
00026| register more commands there if they desire so.
00027| 
00028| For the :command:`flask` script to work, an application needs to be discovered.
00029| Flask looks for a module named :file:`wsgi.py` or :file:`app.py` by default,
00030| and if it finds one it assumes the application is defined in it.
00031| 
00032| You can instruct Flask to look for the application in a different module by
00033| exporting the ``FLASK_APP`` environment variable. It can be either set to an
00034| import path or to a filename of a Python module that contains a Flask
00035| application.
00036| 
00037| In that imported file the name of the app needs to be called ``app`` or
00038| optionally be specified after a colon.  For instance
00039| ``mymodule:application`` would tell it to use the `application` object in
00040| the :file:`mymodule.py` file.
00041| 
00042| Given a :file:`hello.py` file with the application in it named ``app``
00043| this is how it can be run.
00044| 
00045| Environment variables (On Windows use ``set`` instead of ``export``)::
00046| 
00047|     export FLASK_APP=hello
00048|     flask run
00049| 
00050| Or with a filename::
00051| 
00052|     export FLASK_APP=/path/to/hello.py
00053|     flask run
00054| 
00055| Virtualenv Integration
00056| ----------------------
00057| 
00058| If you are constantly working with a virtualenv you can also put the
00059| ``export FLASK_APP`` into your ``activate`` script by adding it to the
00060| bottom of the file.  That way every time you activate your virtualenv you
00061| automatically also activate the correct application name.
00062| 
00063| Edit the activate script for the shell you use. For example:
00064| 
00065| Unix Bash: ``venv/bin/activate``::
00066| 
00067|     FLASK_APP=hello
00068|     export FLASK_APP
00069| 
00070| Windows CMD.exe: ``venv\Scripts\activate.bat``::
00071| 
00072|     set "FLASK_APP=hello"
00073|     :END
00074| 
00075| Debug Flag
00076| ----------
00077| 
00078| The :command:`flask` script can also be instructed to enable the debug
00079| mode of the application automatically by exporting ``FLASK_DEBUG``.  If
00080| set to ``1`` debug is enabled or ``0`` disables it::
00081| 
00082|     export FLASK_DEBUG=1
00083| 
00084| Running a Shell
00085| ---------------
00086| 
00087| To run an interactive Python shell you can use the ``shell`` command::
00088| 
00089|     flask shell
00090| 
00091| This will start up an interactive Python shell, setup the correct
00092| application context and setup the local variables in the shell.  This is
00093| done by invoking the :meth:`Flask.make_shell_context` method of the
00094| application.  By default you have access to your ``app`` and :data:`g`.
00095| 
00096| Custom Commands
00097| ---------------
00098| 
00099| If you want to add more commands to the shell script you can do this
00100| easily. For instance if you want a shell command to initialize the database you
00101| can do this::
00102| 
00103|     import click
00104|     from flask import Flask
00105| 
00106|     app = Flask(__name__)
00107| 
00108|     @app.cli.command()
00109|     def initdb():
00110|         """Initialize the database."""
00111|         click.echo('Init the db')
00112| 
00113| The command will then show up on the command line::
00114| 
00115|     $ flask initdb
00116|     Init the db
00117| 
00118| Application Context
00119| -------------------
00120| 
00121| Most commands operate on the application so it makes a lot of sense if
00122| they have the application context setup.  Because of this, if you register
00123| a callback on ``app.cli`` with the :meth:`~flask.cli.AppGroup.command` the
00124| callback will automatically be wrapped through :func:`cli.with_appcontext`
00125| which informs the cli system to ensure that an application context is set
00126| up.  This behavior is not available if a command is added later with
00127| :func:`~click.Group.add_command` or through other means.
00128| 
00129| It can also be disabled by passing ``with_appcontext=False`` to the
00130| decorator::
00131| 
00132|     @app.cli.command(with_appcontext=False)
00133|     def example():
00134|         pass
00135| 
00136| 
00137| .. _dotenv:
00138| 
00139| Loading Environment Variables From ``.env`` Files
00140| -------------------------------------------------
00141| 
00142| If `python-dotenv`_ is installed, running the :command:`flask` command will set
00143| environment variables defined in the files :file:`.env` and :file:`.flaskenv`.
00144| This can be used to avoid having to set ``FLASK_APP`` manually every time you
00145| open a new terminal, and to set configuration using environment variables
00146| similar to how some deployment services work.
00147| 
00148| Variables set on the command line are used over those set in :file:`.env`,
00149| which are used over those set in :file:`.flaskenv`. :file:`.flaskenv` should be
00150| used for public variables, such as ``FLASK_APP``, while :file:`.env` should not
00151| be committed to your repository so that it can set private variables.
00152| 
00153| Directories are scanned upwards from the directory you call :command:`flask`
00154| from to locate the files. The current working directory will be set to the
00155| location of the file, with the assumption that that is the top level project
00156| directory.
00157| 
00158| The files are only loaded by the :command:`flask` command or calling
00159| :meth:`~flask.Flask.run`. If you would like to load these files when running in
00160| production, you should call :func:`~flask.cli.load_dotenv` manually.
00161| 
00162| .. _python-dotenv: https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv#readme
00163| 
00164| 
00165| Factory Functions
00166| -----------------
00167| 
00168| In case you are using factory functions to create your application (see
00169| :ref:`app-factories`) you will discover that the :command:`flask` command
00170| cannot work with them directly.  Flask won't be able to figure out how to
00171| instantiate your application properly by itself.  Because of this reason
00172| the recommendation is to create a separate file that instantiates
00173| applications.  This is not the only way to make this work.  Another is the
00174| :ref:`custom-scripts` support.
00175| 
00176| For instance if you have a factory function that creates an application
00177| from a filename you could make a separate file that creates such an
00178| application from an environment variable.
00179| 
00180| This could be a file named :file:`autoapp.py` with these contents::
00181| 
00182|     import os
00183|     from yourapplication import create_app
00184|     app = create_app(os.environ['YOURAPPLICATION_CONFIG'])
00185| 
00186| Once this has happened you can make the :command:`flask` command automatically
00187| pick it up::
00188| 
00189|     export YOURAPPLICATION_CONFIG=/path/to/config.cfg
00190|     export FLASK_APP=/path/to/autoapp.py
00191| 
00192| From this point onwards :command:`flask` will find your application.
00193| 
00194| .. _custom-scripts:
00195| 
00196| Custom Scripts
00197| --------------
00198| 
00199| While the most common way is to use the :command:`flask` command, you can
00200| also make your own "driver scripts".  Since Flask uses click for the
00201| scripts there is no reason you cannot hook these scripts into any click

00781| does not get enough feedback they will probably end up hating the
00782| application.  Flask provides a really simple way to give feedback to a
00783| user with the flashing system.  The flashing system basically makes it
00784| possible to record a message at the end of a request and access it on the next
00785| (and only the next) request.  This is usually combined with a layout
00786| template to expose the message.
00787| 
00788| To flash a message use the :func:`~flask.flash` method, to get hold of the
00789| messages you can use :func:`~flask.get_flashed_messages` which is also
00790| available in the templates.  Check out the :ref:`message-flashing-pattern`
00791| for a full example.
00792| 
00793| Logging
00794| -------
00795| 
00796| .. versionadded:: 0.3
00797| 
00798| Sometimes you might be in a situation where you deal with data that
00799| should be correct, but actually is not.  For example you may have some client-side
00800| code that sends an HTTP request to the server but it's obviously
00801| malformed.  This might be caused by a user tampering with the data, or the
00802| client code failing.  Most of the time it's okay to reply with ``400 Bad
00803| Request`` in that situation, but sometimes that won't do and the code has
00804| to continue working.
00805| 
00806| You may still want to log that something fishy happened.  This is where
00807| loggers come in handy.  As of Flask 0.3 a logger is preconfigured for you
00808| to use.
00809| 
00810| Here are some example log calls::
00811| 
00812|     app.logger.debug('A value for debugging')
00813|     app.logger.warning('A warning occurred (%d apples)', 42)
00814|     app.logger.error('An error occurred')
00815| 
00816| The attached :attr:`~flask.Flask.logger` is a standard logging
00817| :class:`~logging.Logger`, so head over to the official `logging
00818| documentation <https://docs.python.org/library/logging.html>`_ for more
00819| information.
00820| 
00821| Read more on :ref:`application-errors`.
00822| 
00823| Hooking in WSGI Middlewares
00824| ---------------------------
00825| 
00826| If you want to add a WSGI middleware to your application you can wrap the
00827| internal WSGI application.  For example if you want to use one of the
00828| middlewares from the Werkzeug package to work around bugs in lighttpd, you
00829| can do it like this::
00830| 
00831|     from werkzeug.contrib.fixers import LighttpdCGIRootFix
00832|     app.wsgi_app = LighttpdCGIRootFix(app.wsgi_app)
00833| 
00834| Using Flask Extensions
00835| ----------------------
00836| 
00837| Extensions are packages that help you accomplish common tasks. For
00838| example, Flask-SQLAlchemy provides SQLAlchemy support that makes it simple
00839| and easy to use with Flask.
00840| 
00841| For more on Flask extensions, have a look at :ref:`extensions`.
00842| 
00843| Deploying to a Web Server
00844| -------------------------
00845| 
00846| Ready to deploy your new Flask app? Go to :ref:`deployment`.
00847|

00770|     def update_template_context(self, context):
00771|         """Update the template context with some commonly used variables.
00772|         This injects request, session, config and g into the template
00773|         context as well as everything template context processors want
00774|         to inject.  Note that the as of Flask 0.6, the original values
00775|         in the context will not be overridden if a context processor
00776|         decides to return a value with the same key.
00777| 
00778|         :param context: the context as a dictionary that is updated in place
00779|                         to add extra variables.
00780|         """
00781|         funcs = self.template_context_processors[None]
00782|         reqctx = _request_ctx_stack.top
00783|         if reqctx is not None:
00784|             bp = reqctx.request.blueprint
00785|             if bp is not None and bp in self.template_context_processors:
00786|                 funcs = chain(funcs, self.template_context_processors[bp])
00787|         orig_ctx = context.copy()
00788|         for func in funcs:
00789|             context.update(func())
00790|         # make sure the original values win.  This makes it possible to
00791|         # easier add new variables in context processors without breaking
00792|         # existing views.
00793|         context.update(orig_ctx)

00801|         """
00802|         rv = {'app': self, 'g': g}

00926|             app.testing = True

00931|         you want to access the context locals for testing::
00932|

def test_teardown_request_handler(app, client):
    called = []

    @app.teardown_request
    def teardown_request(exc):
        called.append(True)
        return "Ignored"

    @app.route('/')
    def root():
        return "Response"

    rv = client.get('/')
    assert rv.status_code == 200
    assert b'Response' in rv.data
    assert len(called) == 1

def test_session_transactions(app, client):
    @app.route('/')
    def index():

        assert rv.data == b'[42]'
        with client.session_transaction() as sess:

## Issue Title
Serial port access problem in DEBUG mode.

## Issue Body
### Expected Behavior

Sending commands through the serial port.

```python
app = Flask(__name__)
serialPort = serial.Serial(port = "COM5", baudrate=1000000,
                           bytesize=8, timeout=2, stopbits=serial.STOPBITS_ONE)

lamp = {
   1 : {'name' : 'n1', 'state' : True},
   2 : {'name' : 'n2', 'state' : True} 
}

@app.route("/")
def hello():
   templateData = {
      'lamp': lamp
      }

   
   return render_template('main.html', **templateData)


@app.route("/setPin/<action>")
def action(action):

   if action == "on":

      serialPort.write(b"n2c1111\r\n")
      lamp[1]["state"] = True

   if action == "off":
      serialPort.write(b"n2c0000\r\n")
      lamp[1]["state"] = False


   templateData = {
      'lamp': lamp
   }

   return render_template('main.html', **templateData)

if __name__ == "__main__":
   app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=5000, debug=True)
```


### Actual Behavior

I can not access the serial port with  FLASK_ENV = development and FLASK_DEBUG = 1. Everything works fine with DEBUG mode disabled.

00539|         data = None

00551|         rv.last_modified = last_modified
00552|     elif mtime is not None:
00553|         rv.last_modified = mtime
00554|

00557|         cache_timeout = current_app.get_send_file_max_age(filename)
00558|     if cache_timeout is not None:

00564|

00587| def safe_join(directory, *pathnames):
00588|     """Safely join `directory` and zero or more untrusted `pathnames`
00589|     components.
00590| 
00591|     Example usage::
00592| 
00593|         @app.route('/wiki/<path:filename>')
00594|         def wiki_page(filename):
00595|             filename = safe_join(app.config['WIKI_FOLDER'], filename)
00596|             with open(filename, 'rb') as fd:
00597|                 content = fd.read()  # Read and process the file content...
00598| 
00599|     :param directory: the trusted base directory.
00600|     :param pathnames: the untrusted pathnames relative to that directory.
00601|     :raises: :class:`~werkzeug.exceptions.NotFound` if one or more passed
00602|             paths fall out of its boundaries.
00603|     """
00604|     for filename in pathnames:
00605|         if filename != '':
00606|             filename = posixpath.normpath(filename)
00607|         for sep in _os_alt_seps:
00608|             if sep in filename:
00609|                 raise NotFound()
00610|         if os.path.isabs(filename) or \
00611|            filename == '..' or \
00612|            filename.startswith('../'):
00613|             raise NotFound()
00614|         directory = os.path.join(directory, filename)
00615|     return directory
00616| 
00617| 
00618| def send_from_directory(directory, filename, **options):
00619|     """Send a file from a given directory with :func:`send_file`.  This
00620|     is a secure way to quickly expose static files from an upload folder
00621|     or something similar.
00622| 
00623|     Example usage::
00624| 
00625|         @app.route('/uploads/<path:filename>')
00626|         def download_file(filename):
00627|             return send_from_directory(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'],
00628|                                        filename, as_attachment=True)
00629| 
00630|     .. admonition:: Sending files and Performance
00631| 
00632|        It is strongly recommended to activate either ``X-Sendfile`` support in
00633|        your webserver or (if no authentication happens) to tell the webserver
00634|        to serve files for the given path on its own without calling into the
00635|        web application for improved performance.
00636| 
00637|     .. versionadded:: 0.5
00638| 
00639|     :param directory: the directory where all the files are stored.
00640|     :param filename: the filename relative to that directory to
00641|                      download.
00642|     :param options: optional keyword arguments that are directly
00643|                     forwarded to :func:`send_file`.
00644|     """
00645|     filename = safe_join(directory, filename)
00646|     if not os.path.isabs(filename):
00647|         filename = os.path.join(current_app.root_path, filename)
00648|     try:
00649|         if not os.path.isfile(filename):
00650|             raise NotFound()
00651|     except (TypeError, ValueError):
00652|         raise BadRequest()
00653|     options.setdefault('conditional', True)
00654|     return send_file(filename, **options)
00655|

00657| def get_root_path(import_name):
00658|     """Returns the path to a package or cwd if that cannot be found.  This
00659|     returns the path of a package or the folder that contains a module.
00660| 
00661|     Not to be confused with the package path returned by :func:`find_package`.
00662|     """
00663|     # Module already imported and has a file attribute.  Use that first.
00664|     mod = sys.modules.get(import_name)
00665|     if mod is not None and hasattr(mod, '__file__'):
00666|         return os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(mod.__file__))
00667| 
00668|     # Next attempt: check the loader.
00669|     loader = pkgutil.get_loader(import_name)
00670| 
00671|     # Loader does not exist or we're referring to an unloaded main module
00672|     # or a main module without path (interactive sessions), go with the
00673|     # current working directory.
00674|     if loader is None or import_name == '__main__':
00675|         return os.getcwd()
00676| 
00677|     # For .egg, zipimporter does not have get_filename until Python 2.7.
00678|     # Some other loaders might exhibit the same behavior.
00679|     if hasattr(loader, 'get_filename'):
00680|         filepath = loader.get_filename(import_name)
00681|     else:
00682|         # Fall back to imports.
00683|         __import__(import_name)
00684|         mod = sys.modules[import_name]
00685|         filepath = getattr(mod, '__file__', None)
00686| 
00687|         # If we don't have a filepath it might be because we are a
00688|         # namespace package.  In this case we pick the root path from the
00689|         # first module that is contained in our package.
00690|         if filepath is None:
00691|             raise RuntimeError('No root path can be found for the provided '
00692|                                'module "%s".  This can happen because the '
00693|                                'module came from an import hook that does '
00694|                                'not provide file name information or because '
00695|                                'it\'s a namespace package.  In this case '
00696|                                'the root path needs to be explicitly '
00697|                                'provided.' % import_name)
00698| 
00699|     # filepath is import_name.py for a module, or __init__.py for a package.
00700|     return os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(filepath))
