00849|     def test_client(self, use_cookies=True, **kwargs):
00850|         """Creates a test client for this application.  For information
00851|         about unit testing head over to :ref:`testing`.
00852| 
00853|         Note that if you are testing for assertions or exceptions in your
00854|         application code, you must set ``app.testing = True`` in order for the
00855|         exceptions to propagate to the test client.  Otherwise, the exception
00856|         will be handled by the application (not visible to the test client) and
00857|         the only indication of an AssertionError or other exception will be a
00858|         500 status code response to the test client.  See the :attr:`testing`
00859|         attribute.  For example::
00860| 
00861|             app.testing = True
00862|             client = app.test_client()
00863| 
00864|         The test client can be used in a ``with`` block to defer the closing down
00865|         of the context until the end of the ``with`` block.  This is useful if
00866|         you want to access the context locals for testing::
00867| 
00868|             with app.test_client() as c:
00869|                 rv = c.get('/?vodka=42')
00870|                 assert request.args['vodka'] == '42'
00871| 
00872|         Additionally, you may pass optional keyword arguments that will then
00873|         be passed to the application's :attr:`test_client_class` constructor.
00874|         For example::
00875| 
00876|             from flask.testing import FlaskClient
00877| 
00878|             class CustomClient(FlaskClient):
00879|                 def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
00880|                     self._authentication = kwargs.pop("authentication")
00881|                     super(CustomClient,self).__init__( *args, **kwargs)
00882| 
00883|             app.test_client_class = CustomClient
00884|             client = app.test_client(authentication='Basic ....')
00885| 
00886|         See :class:`~flask.testing.FlaskClient` for more information.
00887| 
00888|         .. versionchanged:: 0.4
00889|            added support for ``with`` block usage for the client.
00890| 
00891|         .. versionadded:: 0.7
00892|            The `use_cookies` parameter was added as well as the ability
00893|            to override the client to be used by setting the
00894|            :attr:`test_client_class` attribute.
00895| 
00896|         .. versionchanged:: 0.11
00897|            Added `**kwargs` to support passing additional keyword arguments to
00898|            the constructor of :attr:`test_client_class`.
00899|         """
00900|         cls = self.test_client_class
00901|         if cls is None:
00902|             from flask.testing import FlaskClient as cls
00903|         return cls(self, self.response_class, use_cookies=use_cookies, **kwargs)

00348| .. module:: flask.json

00350| Flask uses ``simplejson`` for the JSON implementation.  Since simplejson
00351| is provided by both the standard library as well as extension, Flask will
00352| try simplejson first and then fall back to the stdlib json module.  On top
00353| of that it will delegate access to the current application's JSON encoders
00354| and decoders for easier customization.
00355|

00368| library.  The following extensions are by default applied to the stdlib's
00369| JSON module:

00002| ===========================
00003| 
00004| Flask itself is changing like any software is changing over time.  Most of
00005| the changes are the nice kind, the kind where you don't have to change
00006| anything in your code to profit from a new release.
00007| 
00008| However every once in a while there are changes that do require some
00009| changes in your code or there are changes that make it possible for you to
00010| improve your own code quality by taking advantage of new features in
00011| Flask.
00012| 
00013| This section of the documentation enumerates all the changes in Flask from
00014| release to release and how you can change your code to have a painless
00015| updating experience.
00016| 
00017| Use the :command:`pip` command to upgrade your existing Flask installation by
00018| providing the ``--upgrade`` parameter::
00019| 
00020|     $ pip install --upgrade Flask
00021| 
00022| .. _upgrading-to-012:
00023| 
00024| Version 0.12
00025| ------------
00026| 
00027| Changes to send_file
00028| ````````````````````
00029| 
00030| The ``filename`` is no longer automatically inferred from file-like objects.
00031| This means that the following code will no longer automatically have
00032| ``X-Sendfile`` support, etag generation or MIME-type guessing::
00033| 
00034|     response = send_file(open('/path/to/file.txt'))
00035| 
00036| Any of the following is functionally equivalent::
00037| 
00038|     fname = '/path/to/file.txt'
00039| 
00040|     # Just pass the filepath directly
00041|     response = send_file(fname)
00042| 
00043|     # Set the MIME-type and ETag explicitly
00044|     response = send_file(open(fname), mimetype='text/plain')
00045|     response.set_etag(...)
00046| 
00047|     # Set `attachment_filename` for MIME-type guessing
00048|     # ETag still needs to be manually set
00049|     response = send_file(open(fname), attachment_filename=fname)
00050|     response.set_etag(...)
00051| 
00052| The reason for this is that some file-like objects have a invalid or even
00053| misleading ``name`` attribute. Silently swallowing errors in such cases was not
00054| a satisfying solution.
00055| 
00056| Additionally the default of falling back to ``application/octet-stream`` has
00057| been restricted. If Flask can't guess one or the user didn't provide one, the
00058| function fails if no filename information was provided.
00059| 
00060| .. _upgrading-to-011:
00061| 
00062| Version 0.11
00063| ------------
00064| 
00065| 0.11 is an odd release in the Flask release cycle because it was supposed
00066| to be the 1.0 release.  However because there was such a long lead time up
00067| to the release we decided to push out a 0.11 release first with some
00068| changes removed to make the transition easier.  If you have been tracking
00069| the master branch which was 1.0 you might see some unexpected changes.
00070| 
00071| In case you did track the master branch you will notice that :command:`flask --app`
00072| is removed now.  You need to use the environment variable to specify an
00073| application.
00074| 
00075| Debugging
00076| `````````
00077| 
00078| Flask 0.11 removed the ``debug_log_format`` attribute from Flask
00079| applications.  Instead the new ``LOGGER_HANDLER_POLICY`` configuration can
00080| be used to disable the default log handlers and custom log handlers can be
00081| set up.
00082| 
00083| Error handling
00084| ``````````````
00085| 
00086| The behavior of error handlers was changed.
00087| The precedence of handlers used to be based on the decoration/call order of
00088| :meth:`~flask.Flask.errorhandler` and
00089| :meth:`~flask.Flask.register_error_handler`, respectively.
00090| Now the inheritance hierarchy takes precedence and handlers for more
00091| specific exception classes are executed instead of more general ones.

Flask itself is changing like any software is changing over time.  Most of
the changes are the nice kind, the kind where you don't have to change
anything in your code to profit from a new release.

However every once in a while there are changes that do require some
changes in your code or there are changes that make it possible for you to
improve your own code quality by taking advantage of new features in
Flask.

This section of the documentation enumerates all the changes in Flask from
release to release and how you can change your code to have a painless
updating experience.

Use the :command:`pip` command to upgrade your existing Flask installation by
providing the ``--upgrade`` parameter::

    $ pip install --upgrade Flask

00103|                                   handler.  The default is ``'always'``

00105|                                   handler is always active.  ``'debug'``
00106|                                   will only activate logging in debug
00107|                                   mode, ``'production'`` will only log in

00110| ``SERVER_NAME``                   the name and port number of the server.
00111|                                   Required for subdomain support (e.g.:
00112|                                   ``'myapp.dev:5000'``)  Note that
00113|                                   localhost does not support subdomains so
00114|                                   setting this to “localhost” does not

00138|                                   hook on :class:`~flask.Flask` or

00028| class Request(RequestBase):
00029|     """The request object used by default in Flask.  Remembers the

00034|     :attr:`~flask.Flask.request_class` to your subclass.

00037|     provides all of the attributes Werkzeug defines plus a few Flask
00038|     specific ones.

00042|     #: useful to inspect which methods are allowed for the URL from
00043|     #: a before/after handler (``request.url_rule.methods``) etc.
00044|     #:
00045|     #: .. versionadded:: 0.6

00047|

00049|     #: happened when matching, this will be ``None``.
00050|     view_args = None
00051| 
00052|     #: If matching the URL failed, this is the exception that will be
00053|     #: raised / was raised as part of the request handling.  This is
00054|     #: usually a :exc:`~werkzeug.exceptions.NotFound` exception or
00055|     #: something similar.
00056|     routing_exception = None
00057| 
00058|     # Switched by the request context until 1.0 to opt in deprecated
00059|     # module functionality.
00060|     _is_old_module = False

00849|     def test_client(self, use_cookies=True, **kwargs):
00850|         """Creates a test client for this application.  For information
00851|         about unit testing head over to :ref:`testing`.
00852| 
00853|         Note that if you are testing for assertions or exceptions in your
00854|         application code, you must set ``app.testing = True`` in order for the
00855|         exceptions to propagate to the test client.  Otherwise, the exception
00856|         will be handled by the application (not visible to the test client) and
00857|         the only indication of an AssertionError or other exception will be a
00858|         500 status code response to the test client.  See the :attr:`testing`
00859|         attribute.  For example::
00860| 
00861|             app.testing = True
00862|             client = app.test_client()
00863| 
00864|         The test client can be used in a ``with`` block to defer the closing down
00865|         of the context until the end of the ``with`` block.  This is useful if
00866|         you want to access the context locals for testing::
00867| 
00868|             with app.test_client() as c:
00869|                 rv = c.get('/?vodka=42')
00870|                 assert request.args['vodka'] == '42'
00871| 
00872|         Additionally, you may pass optional keyword arguments that will then
00873|         be passed to the application's :attr:`test_client_class` constructor.
00874|         For example::
00875| 
00876|             from flask.testing import FlaskClient
00877| 
00878|             class CustomClient(FlaskClient):
00879|                 def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
00880|                     self._authentication = kwargs.pop("authentication")
00881|                     super(CustomClient,self).__init__( *args, **kwargs)
00882| 
00883|             app.test_client_class = CustomClient
00884|             client = app.test_client(authentication='Basic ....')
00885| 
00886|         See :class:`~flask.testing.FlaskClient` for more information.
00887| 
00888|         .. versionchanged:: 0.4
00889|            added support for ``with`` block usage for the client.
00890| 
00891|         .. versionadded:: 0.7
00892|            The `use_cookies` parameter was added as well as the ability
00893|            to override the client to be used by setting the
00894|            :attr:`test_client_class` attribute.
00895| 
00896|         .. versionchanged:: 0.11
00897|            Added `**kwargs` to support passing additional keyword arguments to
00898|            the constructor of :attr:`test_client_class`.
00899|         """
00900|         cls = self.test_client_class
00901|         if cls is None:
00902|             from flask.testing import FlaskClient as cls
00903|         return cls(self, self.response_class, use_cookies=use_cookies, **kwargs)

00866|     def get_send_file_max_age(self, filename):
00867|         """Provides default cache_timeout for the :func:`send_file` functions.
00868| 
00869|         By default, this function returns ``SEND_FILE_MAX_AGE_DEFAULT`` from
00870|         the configuration of :data:`~flask.current_app`.
00871| 
00872|         Static file functions such as :func:`send_from_directory` use this
00873|         function, and :func:`send_file` calls this function on
00874|         :data:`~flask.current_app` when the given cache_timeout is ``None``. If a
00875|         cache_timeout is given in :func:`send_file`, that timeout is used;
00876|         otherwise, this method is called.
00877| 
00878|         This allows subclasses to change the behavior when sending files based
00879|         on the filename.  For example, to set the cache timeout for .js files
00880|         to 60 seconds::
00881| 
00882|             class MyFlask(flask.Flask):
00883|                 def get_send_file_max_age(self, name):
00884|                     if name.lower().endswith('.js'):
00885|                         return 60
00886|                     return flask.Flask.get_send_file_max_age(self, name)
00887| 
00888|         .. versionadded:: 0.9
00889|         """
00890|         return total_seconds(current_app.send_file_max_age_default)
00891| 
00892|     def send_static_file(self, filename):
00893|         """Function used internally to send static files from the static
00894|         folder to the browser.
00895| 
00896|         .. versionadded:: 0.5
00897|         """
00898|         if not self.has_static_folder:
00899|             raise RuntimeError('No static folder for this object')
00900|         # Ensure get_send_file_max_age is called in all cases.
00901|         # Here, we ensure get_send_file_max_age is called for Blueprints.
00902|         cache_timeout = self.get_send_file_max_age(filename)
00903|         return send_from_directory(self.static_folder, filename,
00904|                                    cache_timeout=cache_timeout)

00906|     def open_resource(self, resource, mode='rb'):
00907|         """Opens a resource from the application's resource folder.  To see
00908|         how this works, consider the following folder structure::
00909| 
00910|             /myapplication.py
00911|             /schema.sql
00912|             /static
00913|                 /style.css
00914|             /templates
00915|                 /layout.html
00916|                 /index.html
00917| 
00918|         If you want to open the :file:`schema.sql` file you would do the
00919|         following::
00920| 
00921|             with app.open_resource('schema.sql') as f:
00922|                 contents = f.read()
00923|                 do_something_with(contents)
00924| 
00925|         :param resource: the name of the resource.  To access resources within
00926|                          subfolders use forward slashes as separator.
00927|         :param mode: resource file opening mode, default is 'rb'.
00928|         """
00929|         if mode not in ('r', 'rb'):
00930|             raise ValueError('Resources can only be opened for reading')
00931|         return open(os.path.join(self.root_path, resource), mode)

00934| def total_seconds(td):
00935|     """Returns the total seconds from a timedelta object.
00936| 
00937|     :param timedelta td: the timedelta to be converted in seconds
00938| 
00939|     :returns: number of seconds
00940|     :rtype: int
00941|     """
00942|     return td.days * 60 * 60 * 24 + td.seconds

00069| class Flask(_PackageBoundObject):
00070|     """The flask object implements a WSGI application and acts as the central
00071|     object.  It is passed the name of the module or package of the
00072|     application.  Once it is created it will act as a central registry for
00073|     the view functions, the URL rules, template configuration and much more.
00074| 
00075|     The name of the package is used to resolve resources from inside the
00076|     package or the folder the module is contained in depending on if the
00077|     package parameter resolves to an actual python package (a folder with
00078|     an :file:`__init__.py` file inside) or a standard module (just a ``.py`` file).
00079| 
00080|     For more information about resource loading, see :func:`open_resource`.
00081| 
00082|     Usually you create a :class:`Flask` instance in your main module or
00083|     in the :file:`__init__.py` file of your package like this::
00084| 
00085|         from flask import Flask
00086|         app = Flask(__name__)
00087| 
00088|     .. admonition:: About the First Parameter
00089| 
00090|         The idea of the first parameter is to give Flask an idea of what
00091|         belongs to your application.  This name is used to find resources
00092|         on the filesystem, can be used by extensions to improve debugging
00093|         information and a lot more.
00094| 
00095|         So it's important what you provide there.  If you are using a single
00096|         module, `__name__` is always the correct value.  If you however are
00097|         using a package, it's usually recommended to hardcode the name of
00098|         your package there.
00099| 
00100|         For example if your application is defined in :file:`yourapplication/app.py`
00101|         you should create it with one of the two versions below::
00102| 
00103|             app = Flask('yourapplication')
00104|             app = Flask(__name__.split('.')[0])
00105| 
00106|         Why is that?  The application will work even with `__name__`, thanks
00107|         to how resources are looked up.  However it will make debugging more
00108|         painful.  Certain extensions can make assumptions based on the
00109|         import name of your application.  For example the Flask-SQLAlchemy
00110|         extension will look for the code in your application that triggered
00111|         an SQL query in debug mode.  If the import name is not properly set
00112|         up, that debugging information is lost.  (For example it would only
00113|         pick up SQL queries in `yourapplication.app` and not
00114|         `yourapplication.views.frontend`)

00697| @with_appcontext
00698| def routes_command(sort, all_methods):
00699|     """Show all registered routes with endpoints and methods."""
00700| 
00701|     rules = list(current_app.url_map.iter_rules())
00702|     ignored_methods = set(() if all_methods else ('HEAD', 'OPTIONS'))
00703| 
00704|     if sort in ('endpoint', 'rule'):
00705|         rules = sorted(rules, key=attrgetter(sort))
00706|     elif sort == 'methods':
00707|         rules = sorted(rules, key=lambda rule: sorted(rule.methods))
00708| 
00709|     rule_methods = [
00710|         ', '.join(sorted(rule.methods - ignored_methods)) for rule in rules
00711|     ]
00712| 
00713|     headers = ('Endpoint', 'Methods', 'Rule')
00714|     widths = (
00715|         max(len(rule.endpoint) for rule in rules),
00716|         max(len(methods) for methods in rule_methods),
00717|         max(len(rule.rule) for rule in rules),
00718|     )
00719|     widths = [max(len(h), w) for h, w in zip(headers, widths)]
00720|     row = '{{0:<{0}}}  {{1:<{1}}}  {{2:<{2}}}'.format(*widths)
00721| 
00722|     click.echo(row.format(*headers).strip())
00723|     click.echo(row.format(*('-' * width for width in widths)))
00724| 
00725|     for rule, methods in zip(rules, rule_methods):
00726|         click.echo(row.format(rule.endpoint, methods, rule.rule).rstrip())

    for name in ('.env', '.flaskenv'):
        path = dotenv.find_dotenv(name, usecwd=True)

        if not path:
            continue

        if new_dir is None:
            new_dir = os.path.dirname(path)

        dotenv.load_dotenv(path)

    if new_dir and os.getcwd() != new_dir:
        os.chdir(new_dir)

    return new_dir is not None  # at least one file was located and loaded

00002| 
00003| .. _cli:
00004| 
00005| Command Line Interface
00006| ======================
00007| 
00008| Installing Flask installs the ``flask`` script, a `Click`_ command line
00009| interface, in your virtualenv. Executed from the terminal, this script gives
00010| access to built-in, extension, and application-defined commands. The ``--help``
00011| option will give more information about any commands and options.
00012| 
00013| .. _Click: http://click.pocoo.org/
00014| 
00015| 
00016| Application Discovery
00017| ---------------------
00018| 
00019| The ``flask`` command is installed by Flask, not your application; it must be
00020| told where to find your application in order to use it. The ``FLASK_APP``
00021| environment variable is used to specify how to load the application.
00022| 
00023| Unix Bash (Linux, Mac, etc.)::
00024| 
00025|     $ export FLASK_APP=hello
00026|     $ flask run
00027| 
00028| Windows CMD::
00029| 
00030|     > set FLASK_APP=hello
00031|     > flask run
00032| 
00033| Windows PowerShell::
00034| 
00035|     > $env:FLASK_APP = "hello"
00036|     > flask run
00037| 
00038| While ``FLASK_APP`` supports a variety of options for specifying your
00039| application, most use cases should be simple. Here are the typical values:
00040| 
00041| (nothing)
00042|     The file :file:`wsgi.py` is imported, automatically detecting an app
00043|     (``app``). This provides an easy way to create an app from a factory with
00044|     extra arguments.
00045| 
00046| ``FLASK_APP=hello``
00047|     The name is imported, automatically detecting an app (``app``) or factory
00048|     (``create_app``).
00049| 
00050| ----
00051| 
00052| ``FLASK_APP`` has three parts: an optional path that sets the current working
00053| directory, a Python file or dotted import path, and an optional variable
00054| name of the instance or factory. If the name is a factory, it can optionally
00055| be followed by arguments in parentheses. The following values demonstrate these
00056| parts:
00057| 
00058| ``FLASK_APP=src/hello``
00059|     Sets the current working directory to ``src`` then imports ``hello``.
00060| 
00061| ``FLASK_APP=hello.web``
00062|     Imports the path ``hello.web``.
00063| 
00064| ``FLASK_APP=hello:app2``
00065|     Uses the ``app2`` Flask instance in ``hello``.
00066| 
00067| ``FLASK_APP="hello:create_app('dev')"``
00068|     The ``create_app`` factory in ``hello`` is called with the string ``'dev'``
00069|     as the argument.
00070| 
00071| If ``FLASK_APP`` is not set, the command will look for a file called
00072| :file:`wsgi.py` or :file:`app.py` and try to detect an application instance or
00073| factory.
00074| 
00075| Within the given import, the command looks for an application instance named
00076| ``app`` or ``application``, then any application instance. If no instance is
00077| found, the command looks for a factory function named ``create_app`` or
00078| ``make_app`` that returns an instance.
00079| 
00080| When calling an application factory, if the factory takes an argument named
00081| ``info``, then the :class:`~cli.ScriptInfo` instance is passed as a keyword
00082| argument. If parentheses follow the factory name, their contents are parsed
00083| as Python literals and passes as arguments to the function. This means that
00084| strings must still be in quotes.
00085| 
00086| 
00087| Run the Development Server
00088| --------------------------
00089| 
00090| The :func:`run <cli.run_command>` command will start the development server. It
00091| replaces the :meth:`Flask.run` method in most cases. ::
00092| 
00093|     $ flask run
00094|      * Serving Flask app "hello"
00095|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/ (Press CTRL+C to quit)
00096| 
00097| .. warning:: Do not use this command to run your application in production.
00098|     Only use the development server during development. The development server
00099|     is provided for convenience, but is not designed to be particularly secure,
00100|     stable, or efficient. See :ref:`deployment` for how to run in production.
00101| 
00102| 
00103| Open a Shell
00104| ------------
00105| 
00106| To explore the data in your application, you can start an interactive Python
00107| shell with the :func:`shell <cli.shell_command>` command. An application
00108| context will be active, and the app instance will be imported. ::
00109| 
00110|     $ flask shell
00111|     Python 3.6.2 (default, Jul 20 2017, 03:52:27)
00112|     [GCC 7.1.1 20170630] on linux
00113|     App: example
00114|     Instance: /home/user/Projects/hello/instance
00115|     >>>
00116| 
00117| Use :meth:`~Flask.shell_context_processor` to add other automatic imports.
00118| 
00119| 
00120| Environments
00121| ------------
00122| 
00123| .. versionadded:: 1.0
00124| 
00125| The environment in which the Flask app runs is set by the
00126| :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` environment variable. If not set it defaults to
00127| ``production``. The other recognized environment is ``development``.
00128| Flask and extensions may choose to enable behaviors based on the
00129| environment.
00130| 
00131| If the env is set to ``development``, the ``flask`` command will enable
00132| debug mode and ``flask run`` will enable the interactive debugger and
00133| reloader.
00134| 
00135| ::
00136| 
00137|     $ FLASK_ENV=development flask run
00138|      * Serving Flask app "hello"
00139|      * Environment: development
00140|      * Debug mode: on
00141|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/ (Press CTRL+C to quit)
00142|      * Restarting with inotify reloader
00143|      * Debugger is active!
00144|      * Debugger PIN: 223-456-919
00145| 
00146| 
00147| Debug Mode
00148| ----------
00149| 
00150| Debug mode will be enabled when :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` is ``development``,
00151| as described above. If you want to control debug mode separately, use
00152| :envvar:`FLASK_DEBUG`. The value ``1`` enables it, ``0`` disables it.
00153| 
00154| 
00155| .. _dotenv:
00156| 
00157| Environment Variables From dotenv
00158| ---------------------------------
00159| 
00160| Rather than setting ``FLASK_APP`` each time you open a new terminal, you can
00161| use Flask's dotenv support to set environment variables automatically.
00162| 
00163| If `python-dotenv`_ is installed, running the ``flask`` command will set
00164| environment variables defined in the files :file:`.env` and :file:`.flaskenv`.
00165| This can be used to avoid having to set ``FLASK_APP`` manually every time you
00166| open a new terminal, and to set configuration using environment variables
00167| similar to how some deployment services work.
00168| 
00169| Variables set on the command line are used over those set in :file:`.env`,
00170| which are used over those set in :file:`.flaskenv`. :file:`.flaskenv` should be
00171| used for public variables, such as ``FLASK_APP``, while :file:`.env` should not
00172| be committed to your repository so that it can set private variables.
00173| 
00174| Directories are scanned upwards from the directory you call ``flask``
00175| from to locate the files. The current working directory will be set to the
00176| location of the file, with the assumption that that is the top level project
00177| directory.
00178| 
00179| The files are only loaded by the ``flask`` command or calling
00180| :meth:`~Flask.run`. If you would like to load these files when running in
00181| production, you should call :func:`~cli.load_dotenv` manually.
00182| 
00183| .. _python-dotenv: https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv#readme
00184| 
00185| 
00186| Environment Variables From virtualenv
00187| -------------------------------------
00188| 
00189| If you do not want to install dotenv support, you can still set environment
00190| variables by adding them to the end of the virtualenv's :file:`activate`
00191| script. Activating the virtualenv will set the variables.
00192| 
00193| Unix Bash, :file:`venv/bin/activate`::
00194| 
00195|     export FLASK_APP=hello
00196| 
00197| Windows CMD, :file:`venv\\Scripts\\activate.bat`::
00198| 
00199|     set FLASK_APP=hello
00200| 
00201| It is preferred to use dotenv support over this, since :file:`.flaskenv` can be
00202| committed to the repository so that it works automatically wherever the project
00203| is checked out.
00204| 
00205| 
00206| Custom Commands
00207| ---------------
00208| 
00209| The ``flask`` command is implemented using `Click`_. See that project's
00210| documentation for full information about writing commands.
00211| 
00212| This example adds the command ``create_user`` that takes the argument
00213| ``name``. ::
00214| 
00215|     import click
00216|     from flask import Flask
00217| 
00218|     app = Flask(__name__)
00219| 
00220|     @app.cli.command()
00221|     @click.argument('name')

.. _cli:

Command Line Interface
======================

Installing Flask installs the ``flask`` script, a `Click`_ command line
interface, in your virtualenv. Executed from the terminal, this script gives
access to built-in, extension, and application-defined commands. The ``--help``
option will give more information about any commands and options.

.. _Click: http://click.pocoo.org/


Application Discovery
---------------------

The ``flask`` command is installed by Flask, not your application; it must be
told where to find your application in order to use it. The ``FLASK_APP``
environment variable is used to specify how to load the application.","truncated":true},"time":{"start":1770024306339,"end":1770024306395}}}}

00002| 
00003| Development Server
00004| ==================
00005| 
00006| .. currentmodule:: flask
00007| 
00008| Starting with Flask 0.11 there are multiple built-in ways to run a
00009| development server.  The best one is the :command:`flask` command line utility
00010| but you can also continue using the :meth:`Flask.run` method.
00011| 
00012| Command Line
00013| ------------
00014| 
00015| The :command:`flask` command line script (:ref:`cli`) is strongly
00016| recommended for development because it provides a superior reload
00017| experience due to how it loads the application.  The basic usage is like
00018| this::
00019| 
00020|     $ export FLASK_APP=my_application
00021|     $ export FLASK_ENV=development
00022|     $ flask run
00023| 
00024| This enables the development environment, including the interactive
00025| debugger and reloader, and then starts the server on
00026| *http://localhost:5000/*.
00027| 
00028| The individual features of the server can be controlled by passing more
00029| arguments to the ``run`` option. For instance the reloader can be
00030| disabled::
00031| 
00032|     $ flask run --no-reload
00033| 
00034| .. note::
00035| 
00036|     Prior to Flask 1.0 the :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` environment variable was
00037|     not supported and you needed to enable debug mode by exporting
00038|     ``FLASK_DEBUG=1``. This can still be used to control debug mode, but
00039|     you should prefer setting the development environment as shown
00040|     above.
00041| 
00042| In Code
00043| -------
00044| 
00045| The alternative way to start the application is through the
00046| :meth:`Flask.run` method.  This will immediately launch a local server
00047| exactly the same way the :command:`flask` script does.
00048| 
00049| Example::
00050| 
00051|     if __name__ == '__main__':
00052|         app.run()
00053| 
00054| This works well for the common case but it does not work well for
00055| development which is why from Flask 0.11 onwards the :command:`flask`
00056| method is recommended.  The reason for this is that due to how the reload
00057| mechanism works there are some bizarre side-effects (like executing
00058| certain code twice, sometimes crashing without message or dying when a
00059| syntax or import error happens).
00060| 
00061| It is however still a perfectly valid method for invoking a non automatic
00062| reloading application.
00063|

Development Server
==================

.. currentmodule:: flask

Starting with Flask 0.11 there are multiple built-in ways to run a
development server.  The best one is the :command:`flask` command line utility
but you can also continue using the :meth:`Flask.run` method.

Command Line
------------

The :command:`flask` command line script (:ref:`cli`) is strongly
recommended for development because it provides a superior reload
experience due to how it loads the application.  The basic usage is like
this::

    $ export FLASK_APP=my_application
    $ export FLASK_ENV=development","truncated":false},"time":{"start":1770024365659,"end":1770024365704}}}}

00002| 
00003| Configuration Handling
00004| ======================
00005| 
00006| Applications need some kind of configuration.  There are different settings
00007| you might want to change depending on the application environment like
00008| toggling the debug mode, setting the secret key, and other such
00009| environment-specific things.
00010| 
00011| The way Flask is designed usually requires the configuration to be
00012| available when the application starts up.  You can hardcode the
00013| configuration in the code, which for many small applications is not
00014| actually that bad, but there are better ways.
00015| 
00016| Independent of how you load your config, there is a config object
00017| available which holds the loaded configuration values:
00018| The :attr:`~flask.Flask.config` attribute of the :class:`~flask.Flask`
00019| object.  This is the place where Flask itself puts certain configuration
00020| values and also where extensions can put their configuration values.  But
00021| this is also where you can have your own configuration.
00022| 
00023| 
00024| Configuration Basics
00025| --------------------
00026| 
00027| The :attr:`~flask.Flask.config` is actually a subclass of a dictionary and
00028| can be modified just like any dictionary::
00029| 
00030|     app = Flask(__name__)
00031|     app.config['TESTING'] = True
00032| 
00033| Certain configuration values are also forwarded to the
00034| :attr:`~flask.Flask` object so you can read and write them from there::
00035| 
00036|     app.testing = True
00037| 
00038| To update multiple keys at once you can use the :meth:`dict.update`
00039| method::
00040| 
00041|     app.config.update(
00042|         TESTING=True,
00043|         SECRET_KEY=b'_5#y2L"F4Q8z\n\xec]/'
00044|     )
00045| 
00046| 
00047| Environment and Debug Features
00048| ------------------------------
00049| 
00050| The :data:`ENV` and :data:`DEBUG` config values are special because they
00051| may behave inconsistently if changed after the app has begun setting up.
00052| In order to set the environment and debug mode reliably, Flask uses
00053| environment variables.
00054| 
00055| The environment is used to indicate to Flask, extensions, and other
00056| programs, like Sentry, what context Flask is running in. It is
00057| controlled with the :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` environment variable and
00058| defaults to ``production``.
00059| 
00060| Setting :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` to ``development`` will enable debug mode.
00061| ``flask run`` will use the interactive debugger and reloader by default
00062| in debug mode. To control this separately from the environment, use the
00063| :envvar:`FLASK_DEBUG` flag.
00064| 
00065| .. versionchanged:: 1.0
00066|     Added :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` to control the environment separately
00067|     from debug mode. The development environment enables debug mode.
00068| 
00069| To switch Flask to the development environment and enable debug mode,
00070| set :envvar:`FLASK_ENV`::
00071| 
00072|     $ export FLASK_ENV=development
00073|     $ flask run
00074| 
00075| (On Windows, use ``set`` instead of ``export``.)
00076| 
00077| Using the environment variables as described above is recommended. While
00078| it is possible to set :data:`ENV` and :data:`DEBUG` in your config or
00079| code, this is strongly discouraged. They can't be read early by the
00080| ``flask`` command, and some systems or extensions may have already
00081| configured themselves based on a previous value.
00082| 
00083| 
00084| Builtin Configuration Values
00085| ----------------------------
00086| 
00087| The following configuration values are used internally by Flask:
00088| 
00089| .. py:data:: ENV
00090| 
00091|     What environment the app is running in. Flask and extensions may
00092|     enable behaviors based on the environment, such as enabling debug
00093|     mode. The :attr:`~flask.Flask.env` attribute maps to this config
00094|     key. This is set by the :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` environment variable and
00095|     may not behave as expected if set in code.
00096| 
00097|     **Do not enable development when deploying in production.**
00098| 
00099|     Default: ``'production'``
00100| 
00101|     .. versionadded:: 1.0
00102| 
00103| .. py:data:: DEBUG
00104| 
00105|     Whether debug mode is enabled. When using ``flask run`` to start the
00106|     development server, an interactive debugger will be shown for
00107|     unhandled exceptions, and the server will be reloaded when code
00108|     changes. The :attr:`~flask.Flask.debug` attribute maps to this
00109|     config key. This is enabled when :data:`ENV` is ``'development'``
00110|     and is overridden by the ``FLASK_DEBUG`` environment variable. It
00111|     may not behave as expected if set in code.
00112| 
00113|     **Do not enable debug mode when deploying in production.**
00114| 
00115|     Default: ``True`` if :data:`ENV` is ``'production'``, or ``False``
00116|     otherwise.
00117| 
00118| .. py:data:: TESTING
00119| 
00120|     Enable testing mode. Exceptions are propagated rather than handled by the
00121|     the app's error handlers. Extensions may also change their behavior to
00122|     facilitate easier testing. You should enable this in your own tests.
00123| 
00124|     Default: ``False``
00125| 
00126| .. py:data:: PROPAGATE_EXCEPTIONS
00127| 
00128|     Exceptions are re-raised rather than being handled by the app's error
00129|     handlers. If not set, this is implicitly true if ``TESTING`` or ``DEBUG``
00130|     is enabled.
00131| 
00132|     Default: ``None``
00133| 
00134| .. py:data:: PRESERVE_CONTEXT_ON_EXCEPTION
00135| 
00136|     Don't pop the request context when an exception occurs. If not set, this
00137|     is true if ``DEBUG`` is true. This allows debuggers to introspect the
00138|     request data on errors, and should normally not need to be set directly.
00139| 
00140|     Default: ``None``
00141|

Configuration Handling
======================

Applications need some kind of configuration.  There are different settings
you might want to change depending on the application environment like
toggling the debug mode, setting the secret key, and other such
environment-specific things.

The way Flask is designed usually requires the configuration to be
available when the application starts up.  You can hardcode the
configuration in the code, which for many small applications is not
actually that bad, but there are better ways.

Independent of how you load your config, there is a config object
available which holds the loaded configuration values:
The :attr:`~flask.Flask.config` attribute of the :class:`~flask.Flask`
object.  This is the place where Flask itself puts certain configuration
values and also where extensions can put their configuration values.  But
this is also where you can have your own configuration.","truncated":true},"time":{"start":1770024365687,"end":1770024365705}}}}

00002| 
00003| Quickstart
00004| ==========
00005| 
00006| Eager to get started?  This page gives a good introduction to Flask.  It
00007| assumes you already have Flask installed.  If you do not, head over to the
00008| :ref:`installation` section.
00009| 
00010| 
00011| A Minimal Application
00012| ---------------------
00013| 
00014| A minimal Flask application looks something like this::
00015| 
00016|     from flask import Flask
00017|     app = Flask(__name__)
00018| 
00019|     @app.route('/')
00020|     def hello_world():
00021|         return 'Hello, World!'
00022| 
00023| So what did that code do?
00024| 
00025| 1. First we imported the :class:`~flask.Flask` class.  An instance of this
00026|    class will be our WSGI application.
00027| 2. Next we create an instance of this class. The first argument is the name of
00028|    the application's module or package.  If you are using a single module (as
00029|    in this example), you should use ``__name__`` because depending on if it's
00030|    started as application or imported as module the name will be different
00031|    (``'__main__'`` versus the actual import name). This is needed so that
00032|    Flask knows where to look for templates, static files, and so on. For more
00033|    information have a look at the :class:`~flask.Flask` documentation.
00034| 3. We then use the :meth:`~flask.Flask.route` decorator to tell Flask what URL
00035|    should trigger our function.
00036| 4. The function is given a name which is also used to generate URLs for that
00037|    particular function, and returns the message we want to display in the
00038|    user's browser.
00039| 
00040| Just save it as :file:`hello.py` or something similar. Make sure to not call
00041| your application :file:`flask.py` because this would conflict with Flask
00042| itself.
00043| 
00044| To run the application you can either use the :command:`flask` command or
00045| python's ``-m`` switch with Flask.  Before you can do that you need
00046| to tell your terminal the application to work with by exporting the
00047| ``FLASK_APP`` environment variable::
00048| 
00049|     $ export FLASK_APP=hello.py
00050|     $ flask run
00051|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/
00052| 
00053| If you are on Windows, the environment variable syntax depends on command line
00054| interpreter. On Command Prompt::
00055| 
00056|     C:\path\to\app>set FLASK_APP=hello.py
00057| 
00058| And on PowerShell::
00059| 
00060|     PS C:\path\to\app> $env:FLASK_APP = "hello.py"
00061| 
00062| Alternatively you can use :command:`python -m flask`::
00063| 
00064|     $ export FLASK_APP=hello.py
00065|     $ python -m flask run
00066|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/
00067| 
00068| This launches a very simple builtin server, which is good enough for testing
00069| but probably not what you want to use in production. For deployment options see
00070| :ref:`deployment`.
00071| 
00072| Now head over to `http://127.0.0.1:5000/ <http://127.0.0.1:5000/>`_, and you
00073| should see your hello world greeting.
00074| 
00075| .. _public-server:
00076| 
00077| .. admonition:: Externally Visible Server
00078| 
00079|    If you run the server you will notice that the server is only accessible
00080|    from your own computer, not from any other in the network.  This is the
00081|    default because in debugging mode a user of the application can execute
00082|    arbitrary Python code on your computer.
00083| 
00084|    If you have the debugger disabled or trust the users on your network,
00085|    you can make the server publicly available simply by adding
00086|    ``--host=0.0.0.0`` to the command line::
00087| 
00088|        flask run --host=0.0.0.0
00089| 
00090|    This tells your operating system to listen on all public IPs.
00091| 
00092| 
00093| What to do if the Server does not Start
00094| ---------------------------------------
00095| 
00096| In case the :command:`python -m flask` fails or :command:`flask` does not exist,
00097| there are multiple reasons this might be the case.  First of all you need
00098| to look at the error message.
00099| 
00100| Old Version of Flask
00101| ````````````````````
00102| 
00103| Versions of Flask older than 0.11 use to have different ways to start the
00104| application.  In short, the :command:`flask` command did not exist, and
00105| neither did :command:`python -m flask`.  In that case you have two options:
00106| either upgrade to newer Flask versions or have a look at the :ref:`server`
00107| docs to see the alternative method for running a server.
00108| 
00109| Invalid Import Name
00110| ```````````````````
00111| 
00112| The ``FLASK_APP`` environment variable is the name of the module to import at
00113| :command:`flask run`. In case that module is incorrectly named you will get an
00114| import error upon start (or if debug is enabled when you navigate to the
00115| application). It will tell you what it tried to import and why it failed.
00116| 
00117| The most common reason is a typo or because you did not actually create an
00118| ``app`` object.
00119| 
00120| .. _debug-mode:
00121| 
00122| Debug Mode
00123| ----------
00124| 
00125| (Want to just log errors and stack traces? See :ref:`application-errors`)
00126| 
00127| The :command:`flask` script is nice to start a local development server, but
00128| you would have to restart it manually after each change to your code.
00129| That is not very nice and Flask can do better.  If you enable debug
00130| support the server will reload itself on code changes, and it will also
00131| provide you with a helpful debugger if things go wrong.
00132| 
00133| To enable all development features (including debug mode) you can export
00134| the ``FLASK_ENV`` environment variable and set it to ``development``
00135| before running the server::
00136| 
00137|     $ export FLASK_ENV=development
00138|     $ flask run
00139| 
00140| (On Windows you need to use ``set`` instead of ``export``.)
00141| 
00142| This does the following things:
00143| 
00144| 1.  it activates the debugger
00145| 2.  it activates the automatic reloader
00146| 3.  it enables the debug mode on the Flask application.
00147| 
00148| You can also control debug mode separately from the environment by
00149| exporting ``FLASK_DEBUG=1``.
00150| 
00151| There are more parameters that are explained in the :ref:`server` docs.
00152| 
00153| .. admonition:: Attention
00154| 
00155|    Even though the interactive debugger does not work in forking environments
00156|    (which makes it nearly impossible to use on production servers), it still
00157|    allows the execution of arbitrary code. This makes it a major security risk
00158|    and therefore it **must never be used on production machines**.
00159| 
00160| Screenshot of the debugger in action:
00161| 
00162| .. image:: _static/debugger.png
00163|    :align: center
00164|    :class: screenshot
00165|    :alt: screenshot of debugger in action
00166| 
00167| More information on using the debugger can be found in the `Werkzeug
00168| documentation`_.
00169| 
00170| .. _Werkzeug documentation: http://werkzeug.pocoo.org/docs/debug/#using-the-debugger
00171|

Quickstart
==========

Eager to get started?  This page gives a good introduction to Flask.  It
assumes you already have Flask installed.  If you do not, head over to the

A Minimal Application
---------------------

    from flask import Flask
    app = Flask(__name__)

    def hello_world():

00162| def make_response(*args):
00163|     """Sometimes it is necessary to set additional headers in a view.  Because
00164|     views do not have to return response objects but can return a value that
00165|     is converted into a response object by Flask itself, it becomes tricky to
00166|     add headers to it.  This function can be called instead of using a return
00167|     and you will get a response object which you can use to attach headers.
00168| 
00169|     If view looked like this and you want to add a new header::
00170| 
00171|         def index():
00172|             return render_template('index.html', foo=42)
00173| 
00174|     You can now do something like this::
00175| 
00176|         def index():
00177|             response = make_response(render_template('index.html', foo=42))
00178|             response.headers['X-Parachutes'] = 'parachutes are cool'
00179|             return response

00182|     view function.  This for example creates a response with a 404 error

00211| def url_for(endpoint, **values):

00213| 
00214|     Variable arguments that are unknown to the target endpoint are appended
00215|     to the generated URL as query arguments.  If the value of a query argument
00216|     is ``None``, the whole pair is skipped.  In case blueprints are active
00217|     you can shortcut references to the same blueprint by prefixing the
00218|     local endpoint with a dot (``.``).

00220|     This will reference the index function local to the current blueprint::

00224|     See :ref:`url-building`.
00225| 
00226|     Configuration values ``APPLICATION_ROOT`` and ``SERVER_NAME`` are only used when
00227|     generating URLs outside of a request context.
00228| 
00229|     To integrate applications, :class:`Flask` has a hook to intercept URL build
00230|     errors through :attr:`Flask.url_build_error_handlers`.  The `url_for`
00231|     function results in a :exc:`~werkzeug.routing.BuildError` when the current
00232|     app does not have a URL for the given endpoint and values.  When it does, the
00233|     :data:`~flask.current_app` calls its :attr:`~Flask.url_build_error_handlers` if
00234|     it is not ``None``, which can return a string to use as the result of
00235|     `url_for` (instead of `url_for`'s default to raise the
00236|     :exc:`~werkzeug.routing.BuildError` exception) or re-raise the exception.

00240|             "Looks up an external URL when `url_for` cannot build a URL."
00241|             # This is an example of hooking the build_error_handler.
00242|             # Here, lookup_url is some utility function you've built
00243|             # which looks up the endpoint in some external URL registry.
00244|             url = lookup_url(endpoint, **values)
00245|             if url is None:
00246|                 # External lookup did not have a URL.
00247|                 # Re-raise the BuildError, in context of original traceback.
00248|                 exc_type, exc_value, tb = sys.exc_info()
00249|                 if exc_value is error:
00250|                     raise exc_type, exc_value, tb
00251|                 else:
00252|                     raise error
00253|             # url_for will use this result, instead of raising BuildError.
00254|             return url
00255| 
00256|         app.url_build_error_handlers.append(external_url_handler)

00258|     Here, `error` is the instance of :exc:`~werkzeug.routing.BuildError`, and
00259|     `endpoint` and `values` are the arguments passed into `url_for`.  Note
00260|     that this is for building URLs outside the current application, and not for
00261|     handling 404 NotFound errors.
00262| 
00263|     .. versionadded:: 0.10
00264|        The `_scheme` parameter was added.

00266|     .. versionadded:: 0.9
00267|        The `_anchor` and `_method` parameters were added.

00269|     .. versionadded:: 0.9

00271|        :exc:`~werkzeug.routing.BuildError`.
00272| 
00273|     :param endpoint: the endpoint of the URL (name of the function)
00274|     :param values: the variable arguments of the URL rule

00276|       address can be changed via ``SERVER_NAME`` configuration variable which
00277|       falls back to the `Host` header, then to the IP and port of the request.
00278|     :param _scheme: a string specifying the desired URL scheme. The `_external`
00279|       parameter must be set to ``True`` or a :exc:`ValueError` is raised. The default
00280|       behavior uses the same scheme as the current request, or
00281|       :data:`PREFERRED_URL_SCHEME` if no request context is available.
00282|       This also can be set to an empty string to build protocol-relative
00283|       URLs.

00285|     :param _method: if provided this explicitly specifies an HTTP method.

00287|     appctx = _app_ctx_stack.top
00288|     reqctx = _request_ctx_stack.top

00290|     if appctx is None:

00292|             "Attempted to generate a URL without the application context being"
00293|             " pushed. This has to be executed when application context is"
00294|             " available."
00295|         )

00298|     # features that support "relative" URLs.

00300|         url_adapter = reqctx.url_adapter

00303|         if endpoint[:1] == ".":

00305|                 endpoint = f"{blueprint_name}{endpoint}"
00306|             else:
00307|                 endpoint = endpoint[1:]

00312|     # the URLs external by default.

00316|         if url_adapter is None:

01871|     def finalize_request(self, rv, from_error_handler=False):
01872|         """Given the return value from a view function this finalizes
01873|         the request by converting it into a response and invoking the
01874|         postprocessing functions.  This is invoked for both normal
01875|         request dispatching as well as error handlers.
01876| 
01877|         Because this means that it might be called as a result of a
01878|         failure a special safe mode is available which can be enabled
01879|         with the `from_error_handler` flag.  If enabled, failures in
01880|         response processing will be logged and otherwise ignored.
01881| 
01882|         :internal:
01883|         """
01884|         response = self.make_response(rv)
01885|         try:
01886|             response = self.process_response(response)
01887|             request_finished.send(self, response=response)
01888|         except Exception:
01889|             if not from_error_handler:
01890|                 raise
01891|             self.logger.exception(
01892|                 "Request finalizing failed with an error while handling an error"
01893|             )
01894|         return response

02052|     def create_url_adapter(self, request):
02053|         """Creates a URL adapter for the given request. The URL adapter
02054|         is created at a point where the request context is not yet set
02055|         up so the request is passed explicitly.

02061|            URL adapter is created for the application context.

02064|             :data:`SERVER_NAME` no longer implicitly enables subdomain
02065|             matching. Use :attr:`subdomain_matching` instead.
02066|         """
02067|         if request is not None:
02068|             # If subdomain matching is disabled (the default), use the
02069|             # default subdomain in all cases. This should be the default
02070|             # in Werkzeug but it currently does not have that feature.
02071|             if not self.subdomain_matching:

02077|                 request.environ,

02079|                 subdomain=subdomain,

02082|         # to work.
02083|         if self.config["SERVER_NAME"] is not None:

02267|     def test_request_context(self, *args, **kwargs):
02268|         """Create a :class:`~flask.ctx.RequestContext` for a WSGI
02269|         environment created from the given values. This is mostly useful
02270|         during testing, where you may want to run a function that uses
02271|         request data without dispatching a full request.
02272| 
02273|         See :doc:`/reqcontext`.
02274| 
02275|         Use a ``with`` block to push the context, which will make
02276|         :data:`request` point at the request for the created
02277|         environment. ::
02278| 
02279|             with test_request_context(...):
02280|                 generate_report()
02281| 
02282|         When using the shell, it may be easier to push and pop the
02283|         context manually to avoid indentation. ::
02284| 
02285|             ctx = app.test_request_context(...)
02286|             ctx.push()
02287|             ...
02288|             ctx.pop()
02289| 
02290|         Takes the same arguments as Werkzeug's
02291|         :class:`~werkzeug.test.EnvironBuilder`, with some defaults from
02292|         the application. See the linked Werkzeug docs for most of the
02293|         available arguments. Flask-specific behavior is listed here.
02294| 
02295|         :param path: URL path being requested.
02296|         :param base_url: Base URL where the app is being served, which
02297|             ``path`` is relative to. If not given, built from
02298|             :data:`PREFERRED_URL_SCHEME`, ``subdomain``,
02299|             :data:`SERVER_NAME`, and :data:`APPLICATION_ROOT`.
02300|         :param subdomain: Subdomain name to append to
02301|             :data:`SERVER_NAME`.
02302|         :param url_scheme: Scheme to use instead of
02303|             :data:`PREFERRED_URL_SCHEME`.
02304|         :param data: The request body, either as a string or a dict of
02305|             form keys and values.
02306|         :param json: If given, this is serialized as JSON and passed as
02307|             ``data``. Also defaults ``content_type`` to
02308|             ``application/json``.
02309|         :param args: other positional arguments passed to
02310|             :class:`~werkzeug.test.EnvironBuilder`.
02311|         :param kwargs: other keyword arguments passed to
02312|             :class:`~werkzeug.test.EnvironBuilder`.
02313|         """
02314|         from .testing import EnvironBuilder
02315| 
02316|         builder = EnvironBuilder(self, *args, **kwargs)
02317| 
02318|         try:
02319|             return self.request_context(builder.get_environ())
02320|         finally:

02323|     def wsgi_app(self, environ, start_response):
02324|         """The actual WSGI application. This is not implemented in
02325|         :meth:`__call__` so that middlewares can be applied without
02326|         losing a reference to the app object. Instead of doing this::
02327| 
02328|             app = MyMiddleware(app)
02329| 
02330|         It's a better idea to do this instead::
02331| 
02332|             app.wsgi_app = MyMiddleware(app.wsgi_app)
02333| 
02334|         Then you still have the original application object around and
02335|         can continue to call methods on it.
02336| 
02337|         .. versionchanged:: 0.7
02338|             Teardown events for the request and app contexts are called
02339|             even if an unhandled error occurs. Other events may not be
02340|             called depending on when an error occurs during dispatch.
02341|             See :ref:`callbacks-and-errors`.
02342| 
02343|         :param environ: A WSGI environment.
02344|         :param start_response: A callable accepting a status code,
02345|             a list of headers, and an optional exception context to
02346|             start the response.
02347|         """
02348|         ctx = self.request_context(environ)
02349|         error = None
02350|         try:
02351|             try:
02352|                 ctx.push()
02353|                 response = self.full_dispatch_request()
02354|             except Exception as e:
02355|                 error = e
02356|                 response = self.handle_exception(e)
02357|             except:  # noqa: B001
02358|                 error = sys.exc_info()[1]
02359|                 raise
02360|             return response(environ, start_response)
02361|         finally:
02362|             if self.should_ignore_error(error):
02363|                 error = None
02364|             ctx.auto_pop(error)
02365| 
02366|     def __call__(self, environ, start_response):
02367|         """The WSGI server calls the Flask application object as the
02368|         WSGI application. This calls :meth:`wsgi_app` which can be
02369|         wrapped to applying middleware."""
02370|         return self.wsgi_app(environ, start_response)

00242| def htmlsafe_dumps(obj, **kwargs):
00243|     """Serialize an object to a string of JSON, replacing HTML-unsafe
00244|     characters with Unicode escapes. Otherwise behaves the same as
00245|     :func:`dumps`.
00246| 
00247|     This is available in templates as the ``|tojson`` filter, which will
00248|     also mark the result with ``|safe``.
00249| 
00250|     The returned string is safe to render in HTML documents and
00251|     ``<script>`` tags. The exception is in HTML attributes that are
00252|     double quoted; either use single quotes or the ``|forceescape``
00253|     filter.
00254| 
00255|     .. versionchanged:: 0.10
00256|         Single quotes are escaped, making this safe to use in HTML,
00257|         ``<script>`` tags, and single-quoted attributes without further
00258|         escaping.
00259|     """
00260|     return dumps(obj, **kwargs).translate(_htmlsafe_map)

00271| def jsonify(*args, **kwargs):
00272|     """Serialize data to JSON and wrap it in a :class:`~flask.Response`
00273|     with the :mimetype:`application/json` mimetype.
00274| 
00275|     Uses :func:`dumps` to serialize the data, but ``args`` and
00276|     ``kwargs`` are treated as data rather than arguments to
00277|     :func:`json.dumps`.
00278| 
00279|     1.  Single argument: Treated as a single value.
00280|     2.  Multiple arguments: Treated as a list of values.
00281|         ``jsonify(1, 2, 3)`` is the same as ``jsonify([1, 2, 3])``.
00282|     3.  Keyword arguments: Treated as a dict of values.
00283|         ``jsonify(data=data, errors=errors)`` is the same as
00284|         ``jsonify({"data": data, "errors": errors})``.
00285|     4.  Passing both arguments and keyword arguments is not allowed as
00286|         it's not clear what should happen.
00287| 
00288|     .. code-block:: python
00289| 
00290|         from flask import jsonify
00291| 
00292|         @app.route("/users/me")
00293|         def get_current_user():
00294|             return jsonify(
00295|                 username=g.user.username,
00296|                 email=g.user.email,
00297|                 id=g.user.id,
00298|             )
00299| 
00300|     Will return a JSON response like this:
00301| 
00302|     .. code-block:: javascript
00303| 
00304|         {
00305|           "username": "admin",
00306|           "email": "admin@localhost",
00307|           "id": 42
00308|         }
00309| 
00310|     The default output omits indents and spaces after separators. In
00311|     debug mode or if :data:`JSONIFY_PRETTYPRINT_REGULAR` is ``True``,
00312|     the output will be formatted to be easier to read.
00313| 
00314|     .. versionchanged:: 0.11
00315|         Added support for serializing top-level arrays. This introduces
00316|         a security risk in ancient browsers. See :ref:`security-json`.
00317| 
00318|     .. versionadded:: 0.2
00319|     """
00320|     indent = None
00321|     separators = (",", ":")
00322| 
00323|     if current_app.config["JSONIFY_PRETTYPRINT_REGULAR"] or current_app.debug:
00324|         indent = 2
00325|         separators = (", ", ": ")
00326| 
00327|     if args and kwargs:
00328|         raise TypeError("jsonify() behavior undefined when passed both args and kwargs")
00329|     elif len(args) == 1:  # single args are passed directly to dumps()
00330|         data = args[0]
00331|     else:
00332|         data = args or kwargs
00333| 
00334|     return current_app.response_class(
00335|         f"{dumps(data, indent=indent, separators=separators)}\n",
00336|         mimetype=current_app.config["JSONIFY_MIMETYPE"],
00337|     )
00338|

00341|     return Markup(htmlsafe_dumps(obj, **kwargs))

00423|     def create_url_adapter(self, request: Request | None) -> MapAdapter | None:
00424|         """Creates a URL adapter for the given request. The URL adapter
00425|         is created at a point where the request context is not yet set
00426|         up so the request is passed explicitly.
00427| 
00428|         .. versionadded:: 0.6
00429|

00431|            This can now also be called without a request object when the
00432|            URL adapter is created for the application context.
00433| 
00434|         .. versionchanged:: 1.0
00435|             :data:`SERVER_NAME` no longer implicitly enables subdomain
00436|             matching. Use :attr:`subdomain_matching` instead.
00437|         """
00438|         if request is not None:
00439|             # If subdomain matching is disabled (the default), use the
00440|             # default subdomain in all cases. This should be the default
00441|             # in Werkzeug but it currently does not have that feature.
00442|             if not self.subdomain_matching:
00443|                 subdomain = self.url_map.default_subdomain or None

00445|                 subdomain = None
00446| 
00447|             return self.url_map.bind_to_environ(
00448|                 request.environ,
00449|                 server_name=self.config["SERVER_NAME"],
00450|                 subdomain=subdomain,
00451|             )

00453|         # to work.
00454|         if self.config["SERVER_NAME"] is not None:
00455|             return self.url_map.bind(
00456|                 self.config["SERVER_NAME"],
00457|                 script_name=self.config["APPLICATION_ROOT"],
00458|                 url_scheme=self.config["PREFERRED_URL_SCHEME"],
00459|             )

00464|         """Intercept routing exceptions and possibly do something else.
00465| 
00466|         In debug mode, intercept a routing redirect and replace it with
00467|         an error if the body will be discarded.

00469|         With modern Werkzeug this shouldn't occur, since it now uses a
00470|         308 status which tells the browser to resend the method and
00471|         body.

00476|         :meta private:
00477|         :internal:

00480|             not self.debug
00481|             or not isinstance(request.routing_exception, RequestRedirect)
00482|             or request.routing_exception.code in {307, 308}

00484|         ):

00491|     def update_template_context(self, context: dict[str, t.Any]) -> None:
00492|         """Update the template context with some commonly used variables.
00493|         This injects request, session, config and g into the template
00494|         context as well as everything template context processors want
00495|         to inject.  Note that the as of Flask 0.6, the original values
00496|         in the context will not be overridden if a context processor
00497|         decides to return a value with the same key.
00498| 
00499|         :param context: the context as a dictionary that is updated in place
00500|                         to add extra variables.
00501|         """
00502|         names: t.Iterable[str | None] = (None,)
00503| 
00504|         # A template may be rendered outside a request context.
00505|         if request:
00506|             names = chain(names, reversed(request.blueprints))
00507| 
00508|         # The values passed to render_template take precedence. Keep a
00509|         # copy to re-apply after all context functions.
00510|         orig_ctx = context.copy()
00511| 
00512|         for name in names:
00513|             if name in self.template_context_processors:
00514|                 for func in self.template_context_processors[name]:
00515|                     context.update(self.ensure_sync(func)())
00516| 
00517|         context.update(orig_ctx)

00519|     def make_shell_context(self) -> dict[str, t.Any]:
00520|         """Returns the shell context for an interactive shell for this
00521|         application.  This runs all the registered shell context
00522|         processors.
00523| 
00524|         .. versionadded:: 0.11
00525|         """
00526|         rv = {"app": self, "g": g}
00527|         for processor in self.shell_context_processors:
00528|             rv.update(processor())
00529|         return rv

00059| class App(Scaffold):
00060|     """The flask object implements a WSGI application and acts as the central
00061|     object.  It is passed the name of the module or package of the
00062|     application.  Once it is created it will act as a central registry for
00063|     the view functions, the URL rules, template configuration and much more.
00064| 
00065|     The name of the package is used to resolve resources from inside the
00066|     package or the folder the module is contained in depending on if the
00067|     package parameter resolves to an actual python package (a folder with
00068|     an :file:`__init__.py` file inside) or a standard module (just a ``.py`` file).
00069| 
00070|     For more information about resource loading, see :func:`open_resource`.
00071| 
00072|     Usually you create a :class:`Flask` instance in your main module or
00073|     in the :file:`__init__.py` file of your package like this::
00074| 
00075|         from flask import Flask
00076|         app = Flask(__name__)
00077| 
00078|     .. admonition:: About the First Parameter
00079| 
00080|         The idea of the first parameter is to give Flask an idea of what
00081|         belongs to your application.  This name is used to find resources
00082|         on the filesystem, can be used by extensions to improve debugging
00083|         information and a lot more.
00084| 
00085|         So it's important what you provide there.  If you are using a single
00086|         module, `__name__` is always the correct value.  If you however are
00087|         using a package, it's usually recommended to hardcode the name of
00088|         your package there.
00089| 
00090|         For example if your application is defined in :file:`yourapplication/app.py`
00091|         you should create it with one of the two versions below::
00092|

00279|     def get_send_file_max_age(self, filename: str | None) -> int | None:
00280|         """Used by :func:`send_file` to determine the ``max_age`` cache
00281|         value for a given file path if it wasn't passed.
00282| 
00283|         By default, this returns :data:`SEND_FILE_MAX_AGE_DEFAULT` from
00284|         the configuration of :data:`~flask.current_app`. This defaults
00285|         to ``None``, which tells the browser to use conditional requests
00286|         instead of a timed cache, which is usually preferable.
00287| 
00288|         Note this is a duplicate of the same method in the Flask
00289|         class.
00290| 
00291|         .. versionchanged:: 2.0
00292|             The default configuration is ``None`` instead of 12 hours.
00293| 
00294|         .. versionadded:: 0.9
00295|         """
00296|         value = current_app.config["SEND_FILE_MAX_AGE_DEFAULT"]
00297| 
00298|         if value is None:
00299|             return None
00300| 
00301|         if isinstance(value, timedelta):
00302|             return int(value.total_seconds())
00303| 
00304|         return value  # type: ignore[no-any-return]

00307|         """The view function used to serve files from
00308|         :attr:`static_folder`. A route is automatically registered for
00309|         this view at :attr:`static_url_path` if :attr:`static_folder` is

00312|         Note this is a duplicate of the same method in the Flask
00313|         class.

00316| 
00317|         """
00318|         if not self.has_static_folder:
00319|             raise RuntimeError("'static_folder' must be set to serve static_files.")
00320| 
00321|         # send_file only knows to call get_send_file_max_age on the app,
00322|         # call it here so it works for blueprints too.
00323|         max_age = self.get_send_file_max_age(filename)
00324|         return send_from_directory(
00325|             t.cast(str, self.static_folder), filename, max_age=max_age

00238| class AppContext:
00239|     """The app context contains application-specific information. An app
00240|     context is created and pushed at the beginning of each request if
00241|     one is not already active. An app context is also pushed when
00242|     running CLI commands.
00243|     """
00244| 
00245|     def __init__(self, app: Flask) -> None:
00246|         self.app = app
00247|         self.url_adapter = app.create_url_adapter(None)
00248|         self.g: _AppCtxGlobals = app.app_ctx_globals_class()
00249|         self._cv_tokens: list[contextvars.Token[AppContext]] = []
00250| 
00251|     def push(self) -> None:
00252|         """Binds the app context to the current context."""
00253|         self._cv_tokens.append(_cv_app.set(self))
00254|         appcontext_pushed.send(self.app, _async_wrapper=self.app.ensure_sync)
00255| 
00256|     def pop(self, exc: BaseException | None = _sentinel) -> None:  # type: ignore
00257|         """Pops the app context."""
00258|         try:
00259|             if len(self._cv_tokens) == 1:
00260|                 if exc is _sentinel:
00261|                     exc = sys.exc_info()[1]
00262|                 self.app.do_teardown_appcontext(exc)
00263|         finally:
00264|             ctx = _cv_app.get()
00265|             _cv_app.reset(self._cv_tokens.pop())
00266| 
00267|         if ctx is not self:
00268|             raise AssertionError(
00269|                 f"Popped wrong app context. ({ctx!r} instead of {self!r})"
00270|             )
00271| 
00272|         appcontext_popped.send(self.app, _async_wrapper=self.app.ensure_sync)
00273| 
00274|     def __enter__(self) -> AppContext:
00275|         self.push()
00276|         return self
00277|

00280|         exc_type: type | None,
00281|         exc_value: BaseException | None,
00282|         tb: TracebackType | None,
00283|     ) -> None:
00284|         self.pop(exc_value)

00287| class RequestContext:
00288|     """The request context contains per-request information. The Flask
00289|     app creates and pushes it at the beginning of the request, then pops
00290|     it at the end of the request. It will create the URL adapter and
00291|     request object for the WSGI environment provided.
00292| 
00293|     Do not attempt to use this class directly, instead use
00294|     :meth:`~flask.Flask.test_request_context` and
00295|     :meth:`~flask.Flask.request_context` to create this object.
00296| 
00297|     When the request context is popped, it will evaluate all the
00298|     functions registered on the application for teardown execution
00299|     (:meth:`~flask.Flask.teardown_request`).
00300| 
00301|     The request context is automatically popped at the end of the
00302|     request. When using the interactive debugger, the context will be
00303|     restored so ``request`` is still accessible. Similarly, the test
00304|     client can preserve the context after the request ends. However,
00305|     teardown functions may already have closed some resources such as
00306|     database connections.
00307|     """
00308| 
00309|     def __init__(
00310|         self,
00311|         app: Flask,
00312|         environ: WSGIEnvironment,
00313|         request: Request | None = None,
00314|         session: SessionMixin | None = None,
00315|     ) -> None:
00316|         self.app = app
00317|         if request is None:
00318|             request = app.request_class(environ)
00319|             request.json_module = app.json
00320|         self.request: Request = request
00321|         self.url_adapter = None
00322|         try:
00323|             self.url_adapter = app.create_url_adapter(self.request)
00324|         except HTTPException as e:
00325|             self.request.routing_exception = e
00326|         self.flashes: list[tuple[str, str]] | None = None
00327|         self.session: SessionMixin | None = session
00328|         # Functions that should be executed after the request on the response
00329|         # object.  These will be called before the regular "after_request"
00330|         # functions.
00331|         self._after_request_functions: list[ft.AfterRequestCallable[t.Any]] = []
00332| 
00333|         self._cv_tokens: list[
00334|             tuple[contextvars.Token[RequestContext], AppContext | None]
00335|         ] = []
00336| 
00337|     def copy(self) -> RequestContext:
00338|         """Creates a copy of this request context with the same request object.
00339|         This can be used to move a request context to a different greenlet.
00340|         Because the actual request object is the same this cannot be used to
00341|         move a request context to a different thread unless access to the
00342|         request object is locked.
00343| 
00344|         .. versionadded:: 0.10
00345| 
00346|         .. versionchanged:: 1.1
00347|            The current session object is used instead of reloading the original
00348|            data. This prevents `flask.session` pointing to an out-of-date object.
00349|         """
00350|         return self.__class__(
00351|             self.app,
00352|             environ=self.request.environ,
00353|             request=self.request,
00354|             session=self.session,
00355|         )
00356| 
00357|     def match_request(self) -> None:
00358|         """Can be overridden by a subclass to hook into the matching
00359|         of the request.
00360|         """
00361|         try:
00362|             result = self.url_adapter.match(return_rule=True)  # type: ignore
00363|             self.request.url_rule, self.request.view_args = result  # type: ignore
00364|         except HTTPException as e:
00365|             self.request.routing_exception = e

00378|         self._cv_tokens.append((_cv_request.set(self), app_ctx))
