00454| def send_file(filename_or_fp, mimetype=None, as_attachment=False,
00455|               attachment_filename=None, add_etags=True,
00456|               cache_timeout=None, conditional=False, last_modified=None):
00457|     """Sends the contents of a file to the client.  This will use the
00458|     most efficient method available and configured.  By default it will
00459|     try to use the WSGI server's file_wrapper support.  Alternatively
00460|     you can set the application's :attr:`~Flask.use_x_sendfile` attribute
00461|     to ``True`` to directly emit an ``X-Sendfile`` header.  This however
00462|     requires support of the underlying webserver for ``X-Sendfile``.
00463| 
00464|     By default it will try to guess the mimetype for you, but you can
00465|     also explicitly provide one.  For extra security you probably want
00466|     to send certain files as attachment (HTML for instance).  The mimetype
00467|     guessing requires a `filename` or an `attachment_filename` to be
00468|     provided.
00469| 
00470|     ETags will also be attached automatically if a `filename` is provided. You
00471|     can turn this off by setting `add_etags=False`.
00472| 
00473|     If `conditional=True` and `filename` is provided, this method will try to
00474|     upgrade the response stream to support range requests.  This will allow
00475|     the request to be answered with partial content response.
00476| 
00477|     Please never pass filenames to this function from user sources;
00478|     you should use :func:`send_from_directory` instead.
00479| 
00480|     .. versionadded:: 0.2
00481| 
00482|     .. versionadded:: 0.5
00483|        The `add_etags`, `cache_timeout` and `conditional` parameters were
00484|        added.  The default behavior is now to attach etags.
00485| 
00486|     .. versionchanged:: 0.7
00487|        mimetype guessing and etag support for file objects was
00488|        deprecated because it was unreliable.  Pass a filename if you are
00489|        able to, otherwise attach an etag yourself.  This functionality
00490|        will be removed in Flask 1.0
00491| 
00492|     .. versionchanged:: 0.9
00493|        cache_timeout pulls its default from application config, when None.
00494| 
00495|     .. versionchanged:: 0.12
00496|        The filename is no longer automatically inferred from file objects. If
00497|        you want to use automatic mimetype and etag support, pass a filepath via
00498|        `filename_or_fp` or `attachment_filename`.
00499|

00504|     .. versionchanged:: 1.0

00509|     .. versionchanged:: 1.0.3

00002| ===========================
00003| 
00004| Flask itself is changing like any software is changing over time.  Most of
00005| the changes are the nice kind, the kind where you don't have to change
00006| anything in your code to profit from a new release.
00007| 
00008| However every once in a while there are changes that do require some
00009| changes in your code or there are changes that make it possible for you to
00010| improve your own code quality by taking advantage of new features in
00011| Flask.
00012| 
00013| This section of the documentation enumerates all the changes in Flask from
00014| release to release and how you can change your code to have a painless
00015| updating experience.
00016| 
00017| Use the :command:`pip` command to upgrade your existing Flask installation by
00018| providing the ``--upgrade`` parameter::
00019| 
00020|     $ pip install --upgrade Flask
00021| 
00022| .. _upgrading-to-012:
00023| 
00024| Version 0.12
00025| ------------
00026| 
00027| Changes to send_file
00028| ````````````````````
00029| 
00030| The ``filename`` is no longer automatically inferred from file-like objects.
00031| This means that the following code will no longer automatically have
00032| ``X-Sendfile`` support, etag generation or MIME-type guessing::
00033| 
00034|     response = send_file(open('/path/to/file.txt'))
00035| 
00036| Any of the following is functionally equivalent::
00037| 
00038|     fname = '/path/to/file.txt'
00039| 
00040|     # Just pass the filepath directly
00041|     response = send_file(fname)
00042| 
00043|     # Set the MIME-type and ETag explicitly
00044|     response = send_file(open(fname), mimetype='text/plain')
00045|     response.set_etag(...)
00046| 
00047|     # Set `attachment_filename` for MIME-type guessing
00048|     # ETag still needs to be manually set
00049|     response = send_file(open(fname), attachment_filename=fname)
00050|     response.set_etag(...)
00051| 
00052| The reason for this is that some file-like objects have an invalid or even
00053| misleading ``name`` attribute. Silently swallowing errors in such cases was not
00054| a satisfying solution.
00055| 
00056| Additionally the default of falling back to ``application/octet-stream`` has
00057| been restricted. If Flask can't guess one or the user didn't provide one, the
00058| function fails if no filename information was provided.
00059| 
00060| .. _upgrading-to-011:
00061| 
00062| Version 0.11
00063| ------------
00064| 
00065| 0.11 is an odd release in the Flask release cycle because it was supposed
00066| to be the 1.0 release.  However because there was such a long lead time up
00067| to the release we decided to push out a 0.11 release first with some
00068| changes removed to make the transition easier.  If you have been tracking
00069| the master branch which was 1.0 you might see some unexpected changes.
00070| 
00071| In case you did track the master branch you will notice that :command:`flask --app`
00072| is removed now.  You need to use the environment variable to specify an
00073| application.
00074| 
00075| Debugging
00076| `````````
00077| 
00078| Flask 0.11 removed the ``debug_log_format`` attribute from Flask
00079| applications.  Instead the new ``LOGGER_HANDLER_POLICY`` configuration can
00080| be used to disable the default log handlers and custom log handlers can be
00081| set up.
00082| 
00083| Error handling
00084| ``````````````
00085| 
00086| The behavior of error handlers was changed.
00087| The precedence of handlers used to be based on the decoration/call order of
00088| :meth:`~flask.Flask.errorhandler` and
00089| :meth:`~flask.Flask.register_error_handler`, respectively.
00090| Now the inheritance hierarchy takes precedence and handlers for more
00091| specific exception classes are executed instead of more general ones.
00092| See :ref:`error-handlers` for specifics.
00093| 
00094| Trying to register a handler on an instance now raises :exc:`ValueError`.
00095| 
00096| .. note::
00097| 
00098|     There used to be a logic error allowing you to register handlers
00099|     only for exception *instances*. This was unintended and plain wrong,
00100|     and therefore was replaced with the intended behavior of registering
00101|     handlers only using exception classes and HTTP error codes.
00102| 
00103| Templating
00104| ``````````
00105| 
00106| The :func:`~flask.templating.render_template_string` function has changed to
00107| autoescape template variables by default. This better matches the behavior
00108| of :func:`~flask.templating.render_template`.
00109| 
00110| Extension imports
00111| `````````````````
00112| 
00113| Extension imports of the form ``flask.ext.foo`` are deprecated, you should use
00114| ``flask_foo``.
00115| 
00116| The old form still works, but Flask will issue a
00117| ``flask.exthook.ExtDeprecationWarning`` for each extension you import the old
00118| way. We also provide a migration utility called `flask-ext-migrate
00119| <https://github.com/pallets/flask-ext-migrate>`_ that is supposed to
00120| automatically rewrite your imports for this.
00121|

Flask itself is changing like any software is changing over time.  Most of
the changes are the nice kind, the kind where you don't have to change
anything in your code to profit from a new release.

However every once in a while there are changes that do require some
changes in your code or there are changes that make it possible for you to
improve your own code quality by taking advantage of new features in
Flask.

This section of the documentation enumerates all the changes in Flask from
release to release and how you can change your code to have a painless
updating experience.

Use the :command:`pip` command to upgrade your existing Flask installation by
providing the ``--upgrade`` parameter::

    $ pip install --upgrade Flask

00363| def get_template_attribute(template_name, attribute):
00364|     """Loads a macro (or variable) a template exports.  This can be used to
00365|     invoke a macro from within Python code.  If you for example have a
00366|     template named :file:`_cider.html` with the following contents:
00367| 
00368|     .. sourcecode:: html+jinja
00369| 
00370|        {% macro hello(name) %}Hello {{ name }}!{% endmacro %}
00371| 
00372|     You can access this from Python code like this::
00373| 
00374|         hello = get_template_attribute('_cider.html', 'hello')
00375|         return hello('World')
00376| 
00377|     .. versionadded:: 0.2
00378| 
00379|     :param template_name: the name of the template
00380|     :param attribute: the name of the variable of macro to access
00381|     """
00382|     return getattr(current_app.jinja_env.get_template(template_name).module,
00383|                    attribute)

00386| def flash(message, category='message'):
00387|     """Flashes a message to the next request.  In order to remove the
00388|     flashed message from the session and to display it to the user,
00389|     the template has to call :func:`get_flashed_messages`.
00390| 
00391|     .. versionchanged:: 0.3
00392|        `category` parameter added.
00393| 
00394|     :param message: the message to be flashed.
00395|     :param category: the category for the message.  The following values
00396|                      are recommended: ``'message'`` for any kind of message,
00397|                      ``'error'`` for errors, ``'info'`` for information
00398|                      messages and ``'warning'`` for warnings.  However any
00399|                      kind of string can be used as category.
00400|     """
00401|     # Original implementation:
00402|     #
00403|     #     session.setdefault('_flashes', []).append((category, message))
00404|     #
00405|     # This assumed that changes made to mutable structures in the session are
00406|     # always in sync with the session object, which is not true for session
00407|     # implementations that use external storage for keeping their keys/values.
00408|     flashes = session.get('_flashes', [])
00409|     flashes.append((category, message))
00410|     session['_flashes'] = flashes
00411|     message_flashed.send(current_app._get_current_object(),
00412|                          message=message, category=category)
00413| 
00414| 
00415| def get_flashed_messages(with_categories=False, category_filter=[]):
00416|     """Pulls all flashed messages from the session and returns them.
00417|     Further calls in the same request to the function will return
00418|     the same messages.  By default just the messages are returned,
00419|     but when `with_categories` is set to ``True``, the return value will
00420|     be a list of tuples in the form ``(category, message)`` instead.
00421| 
00422|     Filter the flashed messages to one or more categories by providing those
00423|     categories in `category_filter`.  This allows rendering categories in
00424|     separate html blocks.  The `with_categories` and `category_filter`
00425|     arguments are distinct:
00426| 
00427|     * `with_categories` controls whether categories are returned with message
00428|       text (``True`` gives a tuple, where ``False`` gives just the message text).
00429|     * `category_filter` filters the messages down to only those matching the
00430|       provided categories.
00431| 
00432|     See :ref:`message-flashing-pattern` for examples.

00436|

00018| class BlueprintSetupState(object):
00019|     """Temporary holder object for registering a blueprint with the
00020|     application.  An instance of this class is created by the
00021|     :meth:`~flask.Blueprint.make_setup_state` method and later passed
00022|     to all register callback functions.
00023|     """
00024| 
00025|     def __init__(self, blueprint, app, options, first_registration):
00026|         #: a reference to the current application
00027|         self.app = app
00028| 
00029|         #: a reference to the blueprint that created this setup state.
00030|         self.blueprint = blueprint
00031| 
00032|         #: a dictionary with all options that were passed to the
00033|         #: :meth:`~flask.Flask.register_blueprint` method.
00034|         self.options = options
00035| 
00036|         #: as blueprints can be registered multiple times with the
00037|         #: application and not everything wants to be registered
00038|         #: multiple times on it, this attribute can be used to figure
00039|         #: out if the blueprint was registered in the past already.
00040|         self.first_registration = first_registration
00041| 
00042|         subdomain = self.options.get('subdomain')
00043|         if subdomain is None:
00044|             subdomain = self.blueprint.subdomain
00045| 
00046|         #: The subdomain that the blueprint should be active for, ``None``
00047|         #: otherwise.
00048|         self.subdomain = subdomain
00049| 
00050|         url_prefix = self.options.get('url_prefix')
00051|         if url_prefix is None:
00052|             url_prefix = self.blueprint.url_prefix
00053| 
00054|         #: The prefix that should be used for all URLs defined on the
00055|         #: blueprint.
00056|         self.url_prefix = url_prefix
00057| 
00058|         #: A dictionary with URL defaults that is added to each and every
00059|         #: URL that was defined with the blueprint.
00060|         self.url_defaults = dict(self.blueprint.url_values_defaults)
00061|         self.url_defaults.update(self.options.get('url_defaults', ()))
00062| 
00063|     def add_url_rule(self, rule, endpoint=None, view_func=None, **options):
00064|         """A helper method to register a rule (and optionally a view function)
00065|         to the application.  The endpoint is automatically prefixed with the
00066|         blueprint's name.
00067|         """
00068|         if self.url_prefix:
00069|             rule = self.url_prefix + rule
00070|         options.setdefault('subdomain', self.subdomain)
00071|         if endpoint is None:
00072|             endpoint = _endpoint_from_view_func(view_func)
00073|         defaults = self.url_defaults
00074|         if 'defaults' in options:
00075|             defaults = dict(defaults, **options.pop('defaults'))
00076|         self.app.add_url_rule(rule, '%s.%s' % (self.blueprint.name, endpoint),
00077|                               view_func, defaults=defaults, **options)

00080| class Blueprint(_PackageBoundObject):
00081|     """Represents a blueprint.  A blueprint is an object that records
00082|     functions that will be called with the
00083|     :class:`~flask.blueprints.BlueprintSetupState` later to register functions
00084|     or other things on the main application.  See :ref:`blueprints` for more
00085|     information.
00086| 
00087|     .. versionadded:: 0.7
00088|     """
00089| 
00090|     warn_on_modifications = False
00091|     _got_registered_once = False
00092| 
00093|     #: Blueprint local JSON decoder class to use.
00094|     #: Set to ``None`` to use the app's :class:`~flask.app.Flask.json_encoder`.
00095|     json_encoder = None
00096|     #: Blueprint local JSON decoder class to use.
00097|     #: Set to ``None`` to use the app's :class:`~flask.app.Flask.json_decoder`.
00098|     json_decoder = None
00099| 
00100|     # TODO remove the next three attrs when Sphinx :inherited-members: works
00101|     # https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/741
00102| 
00103|     #: The name of the package or module that this app belongs to. Do not
00104|     #: change this once it is set by the constructor.
00105|     import_name = None
00106| 
00107|     #: Location of the template files to be added to the template lookup.
00108|     #: ``None`` if templates should not be added.
00109|     template_folder = None
00110| 
00111|     #: Absolute path to the package on the filesystem. Used to look up
00112|     #: resources contained in the package.
00113|     root_path = None
00114| 
00115|     def __init__(self, name, import_name, static_folder=None,
00116|                  static_url_path=None, template_folder=None,
00117|                  url_prefix=None, subdomain=None, url_defaults=None,
00118|                  root_path=None):
00119|         _PackageBoundObject.__init__(self, import_name, template_folder,
00120|                                      root_path=root_path)
00121|         self.name = name
00122|         self.url_prefix = url_prefix
00123|         self.subdomain = subdomain
00124|         self.static_folder = static_folder
00125|         self.static_url_path = static_url_path
00126|         self.deferred_functions = []
00127|         if url_defaults is None:
00128|             url_defaults = {}
00129|         self.url_values_defaults = url_defaults

00131|     def record(self, func):
00132|         """Registers a function that is called when the blueprint is
00133|         registered on the application.  This function is called with the
00134|         state as argument as returned by the :meth:`make_setup_state`
00135|         method.
00136|         """
00137|         if self._got_registered_once and self.warn_on_modifications:
00138|             from warnings import warn
00139|             warn(Warning('The blueprint was already registered once '
00140|                          'but is getting modified now.  These changes '
00141|                          'will not show up.'))
00142|         self.deferred_functions.append(func)
00143| 
00144|     def record_once(self, func):
00145|         """Works like :meth:`record` but wraps the function in another
00146|         function that will ensure the function is only called once.  If the
00147|         blueprint is registered a second time on the application, the
00148|         function passed is not called.
00149|         """
00150|         def wrapper(state):
00151|             if state.first_registration:
00152|                 func(state)
00153|         return self.record(update_wrapper(wrapper, func))
00154| 
00155|     def make_setup_state(self, app, options, first_registration=False):
00156|         """Creates an instance of :meth:`~flask.blueprints.BlueprintSetupState`
00157|         object that is later passed to the register callback functions.
00158|         Subclasses can override this to return a subclass of the setup state.
00159|         """
00160|         return BlueprintSetupState(self, app, options, first_registration)
00161| 
00162|     def register(self, app, options, first_registration=False):
00163|         """Called by :meth:`Flask.register_blueprint` to register all views
00164|         and callbacks registered on the blueprint with the application. Creates
00165|         a :class:`.BlueprintSetupState` and calls each :meth:`record` callback
00166|         with it.
00167| 
00168|         :param app: The application this blueprint is being registered with.
00169|         :param options: Keyword arguments forwarded from
00170|             :meth:`~Flask.register_blueprint`.
00171|         :param first_registration: Whether this is the first time this
00172|             blueprint has been registered on the application.
00173|         """
00174|         self._got_registered_once = True
00175|         state = self.make_setup_state(app, options, first_registration)
00176| 
00177|         if self.has_static_folder:
00178|             state.add_url_rule(
00179|                 self.static_url_path + '/<path:filename>',
00180|                 view_func=self.send_static_file, endpoint='static'
00181|             )
00182| 
00183|         for deferred in self.deferred_functions:
00184|             deferred(state)

00186|     def route(self, rule, **options):
00187|         """Like :meth:`Flask.route` but for a blueprint.  The endpoint for the
00188|         :func:`url_for` function is prefixed with the name of the blueprint.
00189|         """
00190|         def decorator(f):
00191|             endpoint = options.pop("endpoint", f.__name__)
00192|             self.add_url_rule(rule, endpoint, f, **options)
00193|             return f
00194|         return decorator

00196|     def add_url_rule(self, rule, endpoint=None, view_func=None, **options):
00197|         """Like :meth:`Flask.add_url_rule` but for a blueprint.  The endpoint for
00198|         the :func:`url_for` function is prefixed with the name of the blueprint.
00199|         """
00200|         if endpoint:
00201|             assert '.' not in endpoint, "Blueprint endpoints should not contain dots"
00202|         if view_func:
00203|             assert '.' not in view_func.__name__, "Blueprint view function name should not contain dots"
00204|         self.record(lambda s:
00205|             s.add_url_rule(rule, endpoint, view_func, **options))

00207|     def endpoint(self, endpoint):
00208|         """Like :meth:`Flask.endpoint` but for a blueprint.  This does not
00209|         prefix the endpoint with the blueprint name, this has to be done
00210|         explicitly by the user of this method.  If the endpoint is prefixed
00211|         with a `.` it will be registered to the current blueprint, otherwise
00212|         it's an application independent endpoint.
00213|         """
00214|         def decorator(f):
00215|             def register_endpoint(state):
00216|                 state.app.view_functions[endpoint] = f
00217|             self.record_once(register_endpoint)
00218|             return f
00219|         return decorator

00260|         """Register a custom template test, available application wide.  Like

00288|         """Register a custom template global, available application wide.  Like

00421|         only.  Please be aware that routing does not happen local to a
00422|         blueprint so an error handler for 404 usually is not handled by

01077|     @setupmethod
01078|     def register_blueprint(self, blueprint, **options):
01079|         """Register a :class:`~flask.Blueprint` on the application. Keyword
01080|         arguments passed to this method will override the defaults set on the
01081|         blueprint.
01082| 
01083|         Calls the blueprint's :meth:`~flask.Blueprint.register` method after
01084|         recording the blueprint in the application's :attr:`blueprints`.
01085| 
01086|         :param blueprint: The blueprint to register.
01087|         :param url_prefix: Blueprint routes will be prefixed with this.
01088|         :param subdomain: Blueprint routes will match on this subdomain.
01089|         :param url_defaults: Blueprint routes will use these default values for
01090|             view arguments.
01091|         :param options: Additional keyword arguments are passed to
01092|             :class:`~flask.blueprints.BlueprintSetupState`. They can be
01093|             accessed in :meth:`~flask.Blueprint.record` callbacks.
01094| 
01095|         .. versionadded:: 0.7
01096|         """
01097|         first_registration = False
01098| 
01099|         if blueprint.name in self.blueprints:
01100|             assert self.blueprints[blueprint.name] is blueprint, (
01101|                 'A name collision occurred between blueprints %r and %r. Both'
01102|                 ' share the same name "%s". Blueprints that are created on the'
01103|                 ' fly need unique names.' % (
01104|                     blueprint, self.blueprints[blueprint.name], blueprint.name
01105|                 )
01106|             )
01107|         else:
01108|             self.blueprints[blueprint.name] = blueprint
01109|             self._blueprint_order.append(blueprint)
01110|             first_registration = True
01111| 
01112|         blueprint.register(self, options, first_registration)
01113| 
01114|     def iter_blueprints(self):
01115|         """Iterates over all blueprints by the order they were registered.
01116| 
01117|         .. versionadded:: 0.11
01118|         """
01119|         return iter(self._blueprint_order)

01121|     @setupmethod
01122|     def add_url_rule(self, rule, endpoint=None, view_func=None,
01123|                      provide_automatic_options=None, **options):
01124|         """Connects a URL rule.  Works exactly like the :meth:`route`
01125|         decorator.  If a view_func is provided it will be registered with the
01126|         endpoint.
01127| 
01128|         Basically this example::
01129| 
01130|             @app.route('/')
01131|             def index():
01132|                 pass
01133| 
01134|         Is equivalent to the following::
01135| 
01136|             def index():
01137|                 pass
01138|             app.add_url_rule('/', 'index', index)
01139| 
01140|         If the view_func is not provided you will need to connect the endpoint
01141|         to a view function like so::
01142| 
01143|             app.view_functions['index'] = index
01144| 
01145|         Internally :meth:`route` invokes :meth:`add_url_rule` so if you want
01146|         to customize the behavior via subclassing you only need to change
01147|         this method.
01148| 
01149|         For more information refer to :ref:`url-route-registrations`.
01150| 
01151|         .. versionchanged:: 0.2
01152|            `view_func` parameter added.
01153| 
01154|         .. versionchanged:: 0.6
01155|            ``OPTIONS`` is added automatically as method.
01156| 
01157|         :param rule: the URL rule as string
01158|         :param endpoint: the endpoint for the registered URL rule.  Flask
01159|                          itself assumes the name of the view function as
01160|                          endpoint
01161|         :param view_func: the function to call when serving a request to the
01162|                           provided endpoint
01163|         :param provide_automatic_options: controls whether the ``OPTIONS``
01164|             method should be added automatically. This can also be controlled
01165|             by setting the ``view_func.provide_automatic_options = False``
01166|             before adding the rule.
01167|         :param options: the options to be forwarded to the underlying
01168|                         :class:`~werkzeug.routing.Rule` object.  A change
01169|                         to Werkzeug is handling of method options.  methods
01170|                         is a list of methods this rule should be limited
01171|                         to (``GET``, ``POST`` etc.).  By default a rule
01172|                         just listens for ``GET`` (and implicitly ``HEAD``).
01173|                         Starting with Flask 0.6, ``OPTIONS`` is implicitly
01174|                         added and handled by the standard request handling.
01175|         """
01176|         if endpoint is None:
01177|             endpoint = _endpoint_from_view_func(view_func)
01178|         options['endpoint'] = endpoint
01179|         methods = options.pop('methods', None)
01180| 
01181|         # if the methods are not given and the view_func object knows its
01182|         # methods we can use that instead.  If neither exists, we go with
01183|         # a tuple of only ``GET`` as default.
01184|         if methods is None:
01185|             methods = getattr(view_func, 'methods', None) or ('GET',)
01186|         if isinstance(methods, string_types):
01187|             raise TypeError('Allowed methods have to be iterables of strings, '
01188|                             'for example: @app.route(..., methods=["POST"])')
01189|         methods = set(item.upper() for item in methods)
01190| 
01191|         # Methods that should always be added
01192|         required_methods = set(getattr(view_func, 'required_methods', ()))
01193| 
01194|         # starting with Flask 0.8 the view_func object can disable and
01195|         # force-enable the automatic options handling.
01196|         if provide_automatic_options is None:
01197|             provide_automatic_options = getattr(view_func,
01198|                 'provide_automatic_options', None)
01199| 
01200|         if provide_automatic_options is None:
01201|             if 'OPTIONS' not in methods:
01202|                 provide_automatic_options = True
01203|                 required_methods.add('OPTIONS')
01204|             else:
01205|                 provide_automatic_options = False
01206| 
01207|         # Add the required methods now.
01208|         methods |= required_methods
01209| 
01210|         rule = self.url_rule_class(rule, methods=methods, **options)
01211|         rule.provide_automatic_options = provide_automatic_options
01212| 
01213|         self.url_map.add(rule)
01214|         if view_func is not None:
01215|             old_func = self.view_functions.get(endpoint)
01216|             if old_func is not None and old_func != view_func:
01217|                 raise AssertionError('View function mapping is overwriting an '
01218|                                      'existing endpoint function: %s' % endpoint)
01219|             self.view_functions[endpoint] = view_func
01220| 
01221|     def route(self, rule, **options):
01222|         """A decorator that is used to register a view function for a
01223|         given URL rule.  This does the same thing as :meth:`add_url_rule`
01224|         but is intended for decorator usage::
01225| 
01226|             @app.route('/')
01227|             def index():
01228|                 return 'Hello World'
01229| 
01230|         For more information refer to :ref:`url-route-registrations`.
01231| 
01232|         :param rule: the URL rule as string
01233|         :param endpoint: the endpoint for the registered URL rule.  Flask
01234|                          itself assumes the name of the view function as
01235|                          endpoint
01236|         :param options: the options to be forwarded to the underlying
01237|                         :class:`~werkzeug.routing.Rule` object.  A change
01238|                         to Werkzeug is handling of method options.  methods
01239|                         is a list of methods this rule should be limited
01240|                         to (``GET``, ``POST`` etc.).  By default a rule
01241|                         just listens for ``GET`` (and implicitly ``HEAD``).
01242|                         Starting with Flask 0.6, ``OPTIONS`` is implicitly
01243|                         added and handled by the standard request handling.
01244|         """
01245|         def decorator(f):
01246|             endpoint = options.pop('endpoint', None)
01247|             self.add_url_rule(rule, endpoint, f, **options)
01248|             return f
01249|         return decorator

def test_blueprint_url_definitions(app, client):
    bp = flask.Blueprint('test', __name__)

    @bp.route('/foo', defaults={'baz': 42})
    def foo(bar, baz):
        return '%s/%d' % (bar, baz)

    @bp.route('/bar')
    def bar(bar):
        return text_type(bar)

    app.register_blueprint(bp, url_prefix='/1', url_defaults={'bar': 23})
    app.register_blueprint(bp, url_prefix='/2', url_defaults={'bar': 19})

00009| class BlueprintSetupState:
00010|     """Temporary holder object for registering a blueprint with the
00011|     application.  An instance of this class is created by the
00012|     :meth:`~flask.Blueprint.make_setup_state` method and later passed
00013|     to all register callback functions.
00014|     """
00015| 
00016|     def __init__(self, blueprint, app, options, first_registration):
00017|         #: a reference to the current application
00018|         self.app = app
00019| 
00020|         #: a reference to the blueprint that created this setup state.
00021|         self.blueprint = blueprint
00022| 
00023|         #: a dictionary with all options that were passed to the
00024|         #: :meth:`~flask.Flask.register_blueprint` method.
00025|         self.options = options
00026| 
00027|         #: as blueprints can be registered multiple times with the
00028|         #: application and not everything wants to be registered
00029|         #: multiple times on it, this attribute can be used to figure
00030|         #: out if the blueprint was registered in the past already.
00031|         self.first_registration = first_registration
00032| 
00033|         subdomain = self.options.get("subdomain")
00034|         if subdomain is None:
00035|             subdomain = self.blueprint.subdomain
00036| 
00037|         #: The subdomain that the blueprint should be active for, ``None``
00038|         #: otherwise.
00039|         self.subdomain = subdomain
00040| 
00041|         url_prefix = self.options.get("url_prefix")
00042|         if url_prefix is None:
00043|             url_prefix = self.blueprint.url_prefix
00044|         #: The prefix that should be used for all URLs defined on the
00045|         #: blueprint.
00046|         self.url_prefix = url_prefix
00047| 
00048|         #: A dictionary with URL defaults that is added to each and every
00049|         #: URL that was defined with the blueprint.
00050|         self.url_defaults = dict(self.blueprint.url_values_defaults)
00051|         self.url_defaults.update(self.options.get("url_defaults", ()))
00052| 
00053|     def add_url_rule(self, rule, endpoint=None, view_func=None, **options):
00054|         """A helper method to register a rule (and optionally a view function)
00055|         to the application.  The endpoint is automatically prefixed with the
00056|         blueprint's name.
00057|         """
00058|         if self.url_prefix is not None:
00059|             if rule:
00060|                 rule = "/".join((self.url_prefix.rstrip("/"), rule.lstrip("/")))
00061|             else:
00062|                 rule = self.url_prefix
00063|         options.setdefault("subdomain", self.subdomain)
00064|         if endpoint is None:
00065|             endpoint = _endpoint_from_view_func(view_func)
00066|         defaults = self.url_defaults
00067|         if "defaults" in options:
00068|             defaults = dict(defaults, **options.pop("defaults"))
00069|         self.app.add_url_rule(
00070|             rule,
00071|             f"{self.blueprint.name}.{endpoint}",
00072|             view_func,
00073|             defaults=defaults,
00074|             **options,
00075|         )

00078| class Blueprint(Scaffold):
00079|     """Represents a blueprint, a collection of routes and other
00080|     app-related functions that can be registered on a real application
00081|     later.
00082| 
00083|     A blueprint is an object that allows defining application functions
00084|     without requiring an application object ahead of time. It uses the
00085|     same decorators as :class:`~flask.Flask`, but defers the need for an
00086|     application by recording them for later registration.
00087| 
00088|     Decorating a function with a blueprint creates a deferred function
00089|     that is called with :class:`~flask.blueprints.BlueprintSetupState`
00090|     when the blueprint is registered on an application.
00091| 
00092|     See :doc:`/blueprints` for more information.
00093| 
00094|     :param name: The name of the blueprint. Will be prepended to each
00095|         endpoint name.
00096|     :param import_name: The name of the blueprint package, usually
00097|         ``__name__``. This helps locate the ``root_path`` for the
00098|         blueprint.
00099|     :param static_folder: A folder with static files that should be
00100|         served by the blueprint's static route. The path is relative to
00101|         the blueprint's root path. Blueprint static files are disabled
00102|         by default.
00103|     :param static_url_path: The url to serve static files from.
00104|         Defaults to ``static_folder``. If the blueprint does not have
00105|         a ``url_prefix``, the app's static route will take precedence,
00106|         and the blueprint's static files won't be accessible.
00107|     :param template_folder: A folder with templates that should be added
00108|         to the app's template search path. The path is relative to the
00109|         blueprint's root path. Blueprint templates are disabled by
00110|         default. Blueprint templates have a lower precedence than those
00111|         in the app's templates folder.
00112|     :param url_prefix: A path to prepend to all of the blueprint's URLs,
00113|         to make them distinct from the rest of the app's routes.
00114|     :param subdomain: A subdomain that blueprint routes will match on by
00115|         default.
00116|     :param url_defaults: A dict of default values that blueprint routes
00117|         will receive by default.
00118|     :param root_path: By default, the blueprint will automatically set
00119|         this based on ``import_name``. In certain situations this
00120|         automatic detection can fail, so the path can be specified
00121|         manually instead.
00122| 
00123|     .. versionchanged:: 1.1.0
00124|         Blueprints have a ``cli`` group to register nested CLI commands.
00125|         The ``cli_group`` parameter controls the name of the group under
00126|         the ``flask`` command.

00139|     json_decoder = None

00175|     def record(self, func):
00176|         """Registers a function that is called when the blueprint is
00177|         registered on the application.  This function is called with the
00178|         state as argument as returned by the :meth:`make_setup_state`
00179|         method.

00181|         if self._got_registered_once and self.warn_on_modifications:
00182|             from warnings import warn

00186|                     "The blueprint was already registered once but is"

00193|     def record_once(self, func):

00241|                     key = self.name if key is None else f"{self.name}.{key}"
00242| 
00243|                     if ensure_sync:

00245| 
00246|                     parent_dict[key].extend(values)

00250|                 value = defaultdict(

00252|                     {
00253|                         code: {
00254|                             exc_class: app.ensure_sync(func)
00255|                             for exc_class, func in code_values.items()
00256|                         }
00257|                         for code, code_values in value.items()
00258|                     },
00259|                 )
00260|                 app.error_handler_spec[key] = value
00261| 
00262|             for endpoint, func in self.view_functions.items():
00263|                 app.view_functions[endpoint] = app.ensure_sync(func)
00264| 
00265|             extend(
00266|                 self.before_request_funcs, app.before_request_funcs, ensure_sync=True
00267|             )
00268|             extend(self.after_request_funcs, app.after_request_funcs, ensure_sync=True)
00269|             extend(
00270|                 self.teardown_request_funcs,
00271|                 app.teardown_request_funcs,
00272|                 ensure_sync=True,

00284|         cli_resolved_group = options.get("cli_group", self.cli_group)

00286|         if cli_resolved_group is None:
00287|             app.cli.commands.update(self.cli.commands)
00288|         elif cli_resolved_group is _sentinel:
00289|             self.cli.name = self.name

00292|             self.cli.name = cli_resolved_group

00295|     def add_url_rule(self, rule, endpoint=None, view_func=None, **options):
00296|         """Like :meth:`Flask.add_url_rule` but for a blueprint.  The endpoint for
00297|         the :func:`url_for` function is prefixed with the name of the blueprint.

00972|         """Register a :class:`~flask.Blueprint` on the application. Keyword
00973|         arguments passed to this method will override the defaults set on the
00974|         blueprint.
00975| 
00976|         Calls the blueprint's :meth:`~flask.Blueprint.register` method after
00977|         recording the blueprint in the application's :attr:`blueprints`.
00978| 
00979|         :param blueprint: The blueprint to register.
00980|         :param url_prefix: Blueprint routes will be prefixed with this.
00981|         :param subdomain: Blueprint routes will match on this subdomain.
00982|         :param url_defaults: Blueprint routes will use these default values for
00983|             view arguments.
00984|         :param options: Additional keyword arguments are passed to
00985|             :class:`~flask.blueprints.BlueprintSetupState`. They can be
00986|             accessed in :meth:`~flask.Blueprint.record` callbacks.
00987| 
00988|         .. versionadded:: 0.7
00989|         """
00990|         first_registration = False
00991| 
00992|         if blueprint.name in self.blueprints:
00993|             assert self.blueprints[blueprint.name] is blueprint, (
00994|                 "A name collision occurred between blueprints"
00995|                 f" {blueprint!r} and {self.blueprints[blueprint.name]!r}."
00996|                 f" Both share the same name {blueprint.name!r}."
00997|                 f" Blueprints that are created on the fly need unique"
00998|                 f" names."
00999|             )
01000|         else:
01001|             self.blueprints[blueprint.name] = blueprint
01002|             first_registration = True
01003| 
01004|         blueprint.register(self, options, first_registration)

01024|         options["endpoint"] = endpoint

01026|

01028|         # methods we can use that instead.  If neither exists, we go with
01029|         # a tuple of only ``GET`` as default.
01030|         if methods is None:
01031|             methods = getattr(view_func, "methods", None) or ("GET",)
01032|         if isinstance(methods, str):
01033|             raise TypeError(

01036|             )
01037|         methods = {item.upper() for item in methods}
01038| 
01039|         # Methods that should always be added
01040|         required_methods = set(getattr(view_func, "required_methods", ()))
01041| 
01042|         # starting with Flask 0.8 the view_func object can disable and
01043|         # force-enable the automatic options handling.
01044|         if provide_automatic_options is None:
01045|             provide_automatic_options = getattr(
01046|                 view_func, "provide_automatic_options", None
01047|             )
01048| 
01049|         if provide_automatic_options is None:
01050|             if "OPTIONS" not in methods:
01051|                 provide_automatic_options = True
01052|                 required_methods.add("OPTIONS")
01053|             else:
01054|                 provide_automatic_options = False
01055| 
01056|         # Add the required methods now.

from jinja2 import TemplateNotFound

    backend = flask.Blueprint("backend", __name__)
    sideend = flask.Blueprint("sideend", __name__)

00002| ====================================
00003| 
00004| .. currentmodule:: flask
00005| 
00006| .. versionadded:: 0.7
00007| 
00008| Flask uses a concept of *blueprints* for making application components and
00009| supporting common patterns within an application or across applications.
00010| Blueprints can greatly simplify how large applications work and provide a
00011| central means for Flask extensions to register operations on applications.
00012| A :class:`Blueprint` object works similarly to a :class:`Flask`
00013| application object, but it is not actually an application.  Rather it is a
00014| *blueprint* of how to construct or extend an application.
00015| 
00016| Why Blueprints?
00017| ---------------
00018| 
00019| Blueprints in Flask are intended for these cases:
00020| 
00021| * Factor an application into a set of blueprints.  This is ideal for
00022|   larger applications; a project could instantiate an application object,
00023|   initialize several extensions, and register a collection of blueprints.
00024| * Register a blueprint on an application at a URL prefix and/or subdomain.
00025|   Parameters in the URL prefix/subdomain become common view arguments
00026|   (with defaults) across all view functions in the blueprint.
00027| * Register a blueprint multiple times on an application with different URL
00028|   rules.
00029| * Provide template filters, static files, templates, and other utilities
00030|   through blueprints.  A blueprint does not have to implement applications
00031|   or view functions.
00032| * Register a blueprint on an application for any of these cases when
00033|   initializing a Flask extension.
00034| 
00035| A blueprint in Flask is not a pluggable app because it is not actually an
00036| application -- it's a set of operations which can be registered on an
00037| application, even multiple times.  Why not have multiple application
00038| objects?  You can do that (see :doc:`/patterns/appdispatch`), but your
00039| applications will have separate configs and will be managed at the WSGI
00040| layer.
00041| 
00042| Blueprints instead provide separation at the Flask level, share
00043| application config, and can change an application object as necessary with
00044| being registered. The downside is that you cannot unregister a blueprint
00045| once an application was created without having to destroy the whole
00046| application object.
00047| 
00048| The Concept of Blueprints
00049| -------------------------
00050| 
00051| The basic concept of blueprints is that they record operations to execute
00052| when registered on an application.  Flask associates view functions with
00053| blueprints when dispatching requests and generating URLs from one endpoint
00054| to another.
00055| 
00056| My First Blueprint
00057| ------------------
00058| 
00059| This is what a very basic blueprint looks like.  In this case we want to
00060| implement a blueprint that does simple rendering of static templates::
00061| 
00062|     from flask import Blueprint, render_template, abort
00063|     from jinja2 import TemplateNotFound
00064| 
00065|     simple_page = Blueprint('simple_page', __name__,
00066|                             template_folder='templates')
00067| 
00068|     @simple_page.route('/', defaults={'page': 'index'})
00069|     @simple_page.route('/<page>')
00070|     def show(page):
00071|         try:
00072|             return render_template(f'pages/{page}.html')
00073|         except TemplateNotFound:
00074|             abort(404)
00075| 
00076| When you bind a function with the help of the ``@simple_page.route``
00077| decorator, the blueprint will record the intention of registering the
00078| function ``show`` on the application when it's later registered.
00079| Additionally it will prefix the endpoint of the function with the
00080| name of the blueprint which was given to the :class:`Blueprint`
00081| constructor (in this case also ``simple_page``). The blueprint's name
00082| does not modify the URL, only the endpoint.
00083| 
00084| Registering Blueprints
00085| ----------------------
00086| 
00087| So how do you register that blueprint?  Like this::
00088| 
00089|     from flask import Flask
00090|     from yourapplication.simple_page import simple_page
00091| 
00092|     app = Flask(__name__)
00093|     app.register_blueprint(simple_page)
00094| 
00095| If you check the rules registered on the application, you will find
00096| these::
00097| 
00098|     >>> app.url_map
00099|     Map([<Rule '/static/<filename>' (HEAD, OPTIONS, GET) -> static>,
00100|      <Rule '/<page>' (HEAD, OPTIONS, GET) -> simple_page.show>,
00101|      <Rule '/' (HEAD, OPTIONS, GET) -> simple_page.show>])
00102| 
00103| The first one is obviously from the application itself for the static
00104| files.  The other two are for the `show` function of the ``simple_page``
00105| blueprint.  As you can see, they are also prefixed with the name of the
00106| blueprint and separated by a dot (``.``).
00107| 
00108| Blueprints however can also be mounted at different locations::
00109| 
00110|     app.register_blueprint(simple_page, url_prefix='/pages')
00111| 
00112| And sure enough, these are the generated rules::
00113| 
00114|     >>> app.url_map
00115|     Map([<Rule '/static/<filename>' (HEAD, OPTIONS, GET) -> static>,
00116|      <Rule '/pages/<page>' (HEAD, OPTIONS, GET) -> simple_page.show>,
00117|      <Rule '/pages/' (HEAD, OPTIONS, GET) -> simple_page.show>])
00118| 
00119| On top of that you can register blueprints multiple times though not every
00120| blueprint might respond properly to that.  In fact it depends on how the
00121| blueprint is implemented if it can be mounted more than once.
00122| 
00123| Blueprint Resources
00124| -------------------
00125| 
00126| Blueprints can provide resources as well.  Sometimes you might want to
00127| introduce a blueprint only for the resources it provides.
00128| 
00129| Blueprint Resource Folder
00130| `````````````````````````
00131| 
00132| Like for regular applications, blueprints are considered to be contained
00133| in a folder.  While multiple blueprints can originate from the same folder,
00134| it does not have to be the case and it's usually not recommended.
00135| 
00136| The folder is inferred from the second argument to :class:`Blueprint` which
00137| is usually `__name__`.  This argument specifies what logical Python
00138| module or package corresponds to the blueprint.  If it points to an actual
00139| Python package that package (which is a folder on the filesystem) is the
00140| resource folder.  If it's a module, the package the module is contained in
00141| will be the resource folder.  You can access the
00142| :attr:`Blueprint.root_path` property to see what the resource folder is::
00143| 
00144|     >>> simple_page.root_path
00145|     '/Users/username/TestProject/yourapplication'
00146| 
00147| To quickly open sources from this folder you can use the
00148| :meth:`~Blueprint.open_resource` function::
00149| 
00150|     with simple_page.open_resource('static/style.css') as f:
00151|         code = f.read()
00152| 
00153| Static Files
00154| ````````````
00155| 
00156| A blueprint can expose a folder with static files by providing the path
00157| to the folder on the filesystem with the ``static_folder`` argument.
00158| It is either an absolute path or relative to the blueprint's location::
00159| 
00160|     admin = Blueprint('admin', __name__, static_folder='static')
00161| 
00162| By default the rightmost part of the path is where it is exposed on the
00163| web. This can be changed with the ``static_url_path`` argument. Because the
00164| folder is called ``static`` here it will be available at the
00165| ``url_prefix`` of the blueprint + ``/static``. If the blueprint
00166| has the prefix ``/admin``, the static URL will be ``/admin/static``.
00167| 
00168| The endpoint is named ``blueprint_name.static``. You can generate URLs
00169| to it with :func:`url_for` like you would with the static folder of the
00170| application::
00171| 
00172|     url_for('admin.static', filename='style.css')
00173| 
00174| However, if the blueprint does not have a ``url_prefix``, it is not
00175| possible to access the blueprint's static folder. This is because the
00176| URL would be ``/static`` in this case, and the application's ``/static``
00177| route takes precedence. Unlike template folders, blueprint static
00178| folders are not searched if the file does not exist in the application
00179| static folder.
00180| 
00181| Templates
00182| `````````
00183| 
00184| If you want the blueprint to expose templates you can do that by providing
00185| the `template_folder` parameter to the :class:`Blueprint` constructor::
00186| 
00187|     admin = Blueprint('admin', __name__, template_folder='templates')
00188| 
00189| For static files, the path can be absolute or relative to the blueprint
00190| resource folder.
00191| 
00192| The template folder is added to the search path of templates but with a lower
00193| priority than the actual application's template folder. That way you can
00194| easily override templates that a blueprint provides in the actual application.
00195| This also means that if you don't want a blueprint template to be accidentally
00196| overridden, make sure that no other blueprint or actual application template
00197| has the same relative path. When multiple blueprints provide the same relative
00198| template path the first blueprint registered takes precedence over the others.
00199| 
00200| 
00201| So if you have a blueprint in the folder ``yourapplication/admin`` and you
00202| want to render the template ``'admin/index.html'`` and you have provided
00203| ``templates`` as a `template_folder` you will have to create a file like
00204| this: :file:`yourapplication/admin/templates/admin/index.html`. The reason
00205| for the extra ``admin`` folder is to avoid getting our template overridden
00206| by a template named ``index.html`` in the actual application template
00207| folder.
00208| 
00209| To further reiterate this: if you have a blueprint named ``admin`` and you
00210| want to render a template called :file:`index.html` which is specific to this
00211| blueprint, the best idea is to lay out your templates like this::
00212| 
00213|     yourpackage/
00214|         blueprints/
00215|             admin/
00216|                 templates/
00217|                     admin/
00218|                         index.html
00219|                 __init__.py
00220| 
00221| And then when you want to render the template, use :file:`admin/index.html` as

.. currentmodule:: flask

.. versionadded:: 0.7

Flask uses a concept of *blueprints* for making application components and
supporting common patterns within an application or across applications.
Blueprints can greatly simplify how large applications work and provide a
central means for Flask extensions to register operations on applications.
A :class:`Blueprint` object works similarly to a :class:`Flask`
application object, but it is not actually an application.  Rather it is a
*blueprint* of how to construct or extend an application.

Why Blueprints?
---------------

Blueprints in Flask are intended for these cases:

00002| ===
00003| 
00004| .. module:: flask
00005| 
00006| This part of the documentation covers all the interfaces of Flask.  For
00007| parts where Flask depends on external libraries, we document the most
00008| important right here and provide links to the canonical documentation.
00009| 
00010| 
00011| Application Object
00012| ------------------
00013| 
00014| .. autoclass:: Flask
00015|    :members:
00016|    :inherited-members:
00017| 
00018| 
00019| Blueprint Objects
00020| -----------------
00021| 
00022| .. autoclass:: Blueprint
00023|    :members:
00024|    :inherited-members:
00025| 
00026| Incoming Request Data
00027| ---------------------
00028| 
00029| .. autoclass:: Request
00030|     :members:
00031|     :inherited-members:
00032|     :exclude-members: json_module
00033| 
00034| .. attribute:: request
00035| 
00036|    To access incoming request data, you can use the global `request`
00037|    object.  Flask parses incoming request data for you and gives you
00038|    access to it through that global object.  Internally Flask makes
00039|    sure that you always get the correct data for the active thread if you
00040|    are in a multithreaded environment.
00041| 
00042|    This is a proxy.  See :ref:`notes-on-proxies` for more information.
00043| 
00044|    The request object is an instance of a :class:`~flask.Request`.
00045| 
00046| 
00047| Response Objects
00048| ----------------
00049| 
00050| .. autoclass:: flask.Response
00051|     :members:
00052|     :inherited-members:
00053|     :exclude-members: json_module
00054| 
00055| Sessions
00056| --------
00057| 
00058| If you have set :attr:`Flask.secret_key` (or configured it from
00059| :data:`SECRET_KEY`) you can use sessions in Flask applications. A session makes
00060| it possible to remember information from one request to another. The way Flask
00061| does this is by using a signed cookie. The user can look at the session
00062| contents, but can't modify it unless they know the secret key, so make sure to
00063| set that to something complex and unguessable.
00064| 
00065| To access the current session you can use the :class:`session` object:
00066| 
00067| .. class:: session
00068| 
00069|    The session object works pretty much like an ordinary dict, with the
00070|    difference that it keeps track of modifications.
00071| 
00072|    This is a proxy.  See :ref:`notes-on-proxies` for more information.
00073| 
00074|    The following attributes are interesting:
00075| 
00076|    .. attribute:: new
00077| 
00078|       ``True`` if the session is new, ``False`` otherwise.
00079| 
00080|    .. attribute:: modified
00081| 
00082|       ``True`` if the session object detected a modification.  Be advised
00083|       that modifications on mutable structures are not picked up
00084|       automatically, in that situation you have to explicitly set the
00085|       attribute to ``True`` yourself.  Here an example::
00086| 
00087|           # this change is not picked up because a mutable object (here
00088|           # a list) is changed.
00089|           session['objects'].append(42)
00090|           # so mark it as modified yourself
00091|           session.modified = True
00092| 
00093|    .. attribute:: permanent
00094| 
00095|       If set to ``True`` the session lives for
00096|       :attr:`~flask.Flask.permanent_session_lifetime` seconds.  The
00097|       default is 31 days.  If set to ``False`` (which is the default) the
00098|       session will be deleted when the user closes the browser.
00099| 
00100| 
00101| Session Interface
00102| -----------------
00103| 
00104| .. versionadded:: 0.8
00105| 
00106| The session interface provides a simple way to replace the session
00107| implementation that Flask is using.
00108| 
00109| .. currentmodule:: flask.sessions
00110| 
00111| .. autoclass:: SessionInterface
00112|    :members:
00113| 
00114| .. autoclass:: SecureCookieSessionInterface
00115|    :members:
00116| 
00117| .. autoclass:: SecureCookieSession
00118|    :members:
00119| 
00120| .. autoclass:: NullSession
00121|    :members:
00122| 
00123| .. autoclass:: SessionMixin
00124|    :members:
00125| 
00126| .. admonition:: Notice
00127| 
00128|    The ``PERMANENT_SESSION_LIFETIME`` config key can also be an integer
00129|    starting with Flask 0.8.  Either catch this down yourself or use
00130|    the :attr:`~flask.Flask.permanent_session_lifetime` attribute on the
00131|    app which converts the result to an integer automatically.
00132|

00152| Application Globals
00153| -------------------
00154| 
00155| .. currentmodule:: flask
00156| 
00157| To share data that is valid for one request only from one function to
00158| another, a global variable is not good enough because it would break in
00159| threaded environments.  Flask provides you with a special object that
00160| ensures it is only valid for the active request and that will return
00161| different values for each request.  In a nutshell: it does the right
00162| thing, like it does for :class:`request` and :class:`session`.
00163| 
00164| .. data:: g
00165| 
00166|     A namespace object that can store data during an
00167|     :doc:`application context </appcontext>`. This is an instance of
00168|     :attr:`Flask.app_ctx_globals_class`, which defaults to
00169|     :class:`ctx._AppCtxGlobals`.
00170| 
00171|     This is a good place to store resources during a request. During
00172|     testing, you can use the :ref:`faking-resources` pattern to
00173|     pre-configure such resources.
00174| 
00175|     This is a proxy. See :ref:`notes-on-proxies` for more information.
00176| 
00177|     .. versionchanged:: 0.10
00178|         Bound to the application context instead of the request context.
00179| 
00180| .. autoclass:: flask.ctx._AppCtxGlobals
00181|     :members:
00182|

00185| ----------------------------

00187| .. data:: current_app
00188| 
00189|     A proxy to the application handling the current request. This is
00190|     useful to access the application without needing to import it, or if
00191|     it can't be imported, such as when using the application factory
00192|     pattern or in blueprints and extensions.
00193| 
00194|     This is only available when an

import pytest
import werkzeug.serving
from jinja2 import TemplateNotFound

import flask


def test_context_processing(app, client):
    @app.context_processor
    def context_processor():
        return {"injected_value": 42}

    @app.route("/")
    def index():
        return flask.render_template("context_template.html", value=23)

    rv = client.get("/")
    assert rv.data == b"<p>23|42"

00002| 
00003| Version 2.0.2
00004| -------------
00005| 
00006| Unreleased
00007| 
00008| -   Fix type annotation for ``teardown_request``. :issue:`4093`
00009| -   Fix type annotation for ``before_request`` and ``before_app_request``
00010|     decorators. :issue:`4104`
00011| -   Fixed the issue where typing requires template global
00012|     decorators to accept functions with no arguments. :issue:`4098`
00013| 
00014| 
00015| Version 2.0.1
00016| -------------
00017| 
00018| Released 2021-05-21
00019| 
00020| -   Re-add the ``filename`` parameter in ``send_from_directory``. The
00021|     ``filename`` parameter has been renamed to ``path``, the old name
00022|     is deprecated. :pr:`4019`
00023| -   Mark top-level names as exported so type checking understands
00024|     imports in user projects. :issue:`4024`
00025| -   Fix type annotation for ``g`` and inform mypy that it is a namespace
00026|     object that has arbitrary attributes. :issue:`4020`
00027| -   Fix some types that weren't available in Python 3.6.0. :issue:`4040`
00028| -   Improve typing for ``send_file``, ``send_from_directory``, and
00029|     ``get_send_file_max_age``. :issue:`4044`, :pr:`4026`
00030| -   Show an error when a blueprint name contains a dot. The ``.`` has
00031|     special meaning, it is used to separate (nested) blueprint names and
00032|     the endpoint name. :issue:`4041`
00033| -   Combine URL prefixes when nesting blueprints that were created with
00034|     a ``url_prefix`` value. :issue:`4037`
00035| -   Roll back a change to the order that URL matching was done. The
00036|     URL is again matched after the session is loaded, so the session is
00037|     available in custom URL converters. :issue:`4053`
00038| -   Re-add deprecated ``Config.from_json``, which was accidentally
00039|     removed early. :issue:`4078`
00040| -   Improve typing for some functions using ``Callable`` in their type
00041|     signatures, focusing on decorator factories. :issue:`4060`
00042| -   Nested blueprints are registered with their dotted name. This allows
00043|     different blueprints with the same name to be nested at different
00044|     locations. :issue:`4069`
00045| -   ``register_blueprint`` takes a ``name`` option to change the
00046|     (pre-dotted) name the blueprint is registered with. This allows the
00047|     same blueprint to be registered multiple times with unique names for
00048|     ``url_for``. Registering the same blueprint with the same name
00049|     multiple times is deprecated. :issue:`1091`
00050| -   Improve typing for ``stream_with_context``. :issue:`4052`
00051| 
00052| 
00053| Version 2.0.0
00054| -------------
00055| 
00056| Released 2021-05-11
00057| 
00058| -   Drop support for Python 2 and 3.5.
00059| -   Bump minimum versions of other Pallets projects: Werkzeug >= 2,
00060|     Jinja2 >= 3, MarkupSafe >= 2, ItsDangerous >= 2, Click >= 8. Be sure
00061|     to check the change logs for each project. For better compatibility
00062|     with other applications (e.g. Celery) that still require Click 7,
00063|     there is no hard dependency on Click 8 yet, but using Click 7 will
00064|     trigger a DeprecationWarning and Flask 2.1 will depend on Click 8.
00065| -   JSON support no longer uses simplejson. To use another JSON module,
00066|     override ``app.json_encoder`` and ``json_decoder``. :issue:`3555`
00067| -   The ``encoding`` option to JSON functions is deprecated. :pr:`3562`
00068| -   Passing ``script_info`` to app factory functions is deprecated. This
00069|     was not portable outside the ``flask`` command. Use
00070|     ``click.get_current_context().obj`` if it's needed. :issue:`3552`
00071| -   The CLI shows better error messages when the app failed to load
00072|     when looking up commands. :issue:`2741`
00073| -   Add :meth:`sessions.SessionInterface.get_cookie_name` to allow
00074|     setting the session cookie name dynamically. :pr:`3369`
00075| -   Add :meth:`Config.from_file` to load config using arbitrary file
00076|     loaders, such as ``toml.load`` or ``json.load``.
00077|     :meth:`Config.from_json` is deprecated in favor of this. :pr:`3398`
00078| -   The ``flask run`` command will only defer errors on reload. Errors
00079|     present during the initial call will cause the server to exit with
00080|     the traceback immediately. :issue:`3431`
00081| -   :func:`send_file` raises a :exc:`ValueError` when passed an
00082|     :mod:`io` object in text mode. Previously, it would respond with
00083|     200 OK and an empty file. :issue:`3358`
00084| -   When using ad-hoc certificates, check for the cryptography library
00085|     instead of PyOpenSSL. :pr:`3492`
00086| -   When specifying a factory function with ``FLASK_APP``, keyword
00087|     argument can be passed. :issue:`3553`
00088| -   When loading a ``.env`` or ``.flaskenv`` file, the current working
00089|     directory is no longer changed to the location of the file.
00090|     :pr:`3560`
00091| -   When returning a ``(response, headers)`` tuple from a view, the
00092|     headers replace rather than extend existing headers on the response.
00093|     For example, this allows setting the ``Content-Type`` for
00094|     ``jsonify()``. Use ``response.headers.extend()`` if extending is
00095|     desired. :issue:`3628`
00096| -   The ``Scaffold`` class provides a common API for the ``Flask`` and
00097|     ``Blueprint`` classes. ``Blueprint`` information is stored in
00098|     attributes just like ``Flask``, rather than opaque lambda functions.
00099|     This is intended to improve consistency and maintainability.
00100|     :issue:`3215`
00101| -   Include ``samesite`` and ``secure`` options when removing the
00102|     session cookie. :pr:`3726`
00103| -   Support passing a ``pathlib.Path`` to ``static_folder``. :pr:`3579`
00104| -   ``send_file`` and ``send_from_directory`` are wrappers around the
00105|     implementations in ``werkzeug.utils``. :pr:`3828`
00106| -   Some ``send_file`` parameters have been renamed, the old names are
00107|     deprecated. ``attachment_filename`` is renamed to ``download_name``.
00108|     ``cache_timeout`` is renamed to ``max_age``. ``add_etags`` is
00109|     renamed to ``etag``. :pr:`3828, 3883`
00110| -   ``send_file`` passes ``download_name`` even if
00111|     ``as_attachment=False`` by using ``Content-Disposition: inline``.
00112|     :pr:`3828`
00113| -   ``send_file`` sets ``conditional=True`` and ``max_age=None`` by
00114|     default. ``Cache-Control`` is set to ``no-cache`` if ``max_age`` is
00115|     not set, otherwise ``public``. This tells browsers to validate
00116|     conditional requests instead of using a timed cache. :pr:`3828`
00117| -   ``helpers.safe_join`` is deprecated. Use
00118|     ``werkzeug.utils.safe_join`` instead. :pr:`3828`
00119| -   The request context does route matching before opening the session.
00120|     This could allow a session interface to change behavior based on
00121|     ``request.endpoint``. :issue:`3776`

00024| class _AppCtxGlobals:
00025|     """A plain object. Used as a namespace for storing data during an
00026|     application context.

00028|     Creating an app context automatically creates this object, which is
00029|     made available as the :data:`g` proxy.
00030| 
00031|     .. describe:: 'key' in g
00032| 
00033|         Check whether an attribute is present.
00034| 
00035|         .. versionadded:: 0.10
00036| 
00037|     .. describe:: iter(g)
00038| 
00039|         Return an iterator over the attribute names.
00040| 
00041|         .. versionadded:: 0.10
00042|     """
00043| 
00044|     # Define attr methods to let mypy know this is a namespace object
00045|     # that has arbitrary attributes.
00046| 
00047|     def __getattr__(self, name: str) -> t.Any:
00048|         try:
00049|             return self.__dict__[name]
00050|         except KeyError:
00051|             raise AttributeError(name) from None
00052| 
00053|     def __setattr__(self, name: str, value: t.Any) -> None:
00054|         self.__dict__[name] = value
00055| 
00056|     def __delattr__(self, name: str) -> None:
00057|         try:
00058|             del self.__dict__[name]
00059|         except KeyError:
00060|             raise AttributeError(name) from None
00061| 
00062|     def get(self, name: str, default: t.Optional[t.Any] = None) -> t.Any:
00063|         """Get an attribute by name, or a default value. Like
00064|         :meth:`dict.get`.
00065| 
00066|         :param name: Name of attribute to get.
00067|         :param default: Value to return if the attribute is not present.
00068| 
00069|         .. versionadded:: 0.10
00070|         """
00071|         return self.__dict__.get(name, default)
00072| 
00073|     def pop(self, name: str, default: t.Any = _sentinel) -> t.Any:
00074|         """Get and remove an attribute by name. Like :meth:`dict.pop`.
00075| 
00076|         :param name: Name of attribute to pop.
00077|         :param default: Value to return if the attribute is not present,
00078|             instead of raising a ``KeyError``.
00079| 
00080|         .. versionadded:: 0.11
00081|         """
00082|         if default is _sentinel:
00083|             return self.__dict__.pop(name)
00084|         else:
00085|             return self.__dict__.pop(name, default)
00086| 
00087|     def setdefault(self, name: str, default: t.Any = None) -> t.Any:

00096|         """

00002| =========
00003| 
00004| Flask leverages Jinja2 as its template engine.  You are obviously free to use
00005| a different template engine, but you still have to install Jinja2 to run
00006| Flask itself.  This requirement is necessary to enable rich extensions.
00007| An extension can depend on Jinja2 being present.
00008| 
00009| This section only gives a very quick introduction into how Jinja2
00010| is integrated into Flask.  If you want information on the template
00011| engine's syntax itself, head over to the official `Jinja2 Template
00012| Documentation <https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/templates/>`_ for
00013| more information.
00014| 
00015| Jinja Setup
00016| -----------
00017| 
00018| Unless customized, Jinja2 is configured by Flask as follows:
00019| 
00020| -   autoescaping is enabled for all templates ending in ``.html``,
00021|     ``.htm``, ``.xml`` as well as ``.xhtml`` when using
00022|     :func:`~flask.templating.render_template`.
00023| -   autoescaping is enabled for all strings when using
00024|     :func:`~flask.templating.render_template_string`.
00025| -   a template has the ability to opt in/out autoescaping with the
00026|     ``{% autoescape %}`` tag.
00027| -   Flask inserts a couple of global functions and helpers into the
00028|     Jinja2 context, additionally to the values that are present by
00029|     default.
00030| 
00031| Standard Context
00032| ----------------
00033| 
00034| The following global variables are available within Jinja2 templates
00035| by default:
00036| 
00037| .. data:: config
00038|    :noindex:
00039| 
00040|    The current configuration object (:data:`flask.config`)
00041| 
00042|    .. versionadded:: 0.6
00043| 
00044|    .. versionchanged:: 0.10
00045|       This is now always available, even in imported templates.
00046| 
00047| .. data:: request
00048|    :noindex:
00049| 
00050|    The current request object (:class:`flask.request`).  This variable is
00051|    unavailable if the template was rendered without an active request
00052|    context.
00053| 
00054| .. data:: session
00055|    :noindex:
00056| 
00057|    The current session object (:class:`flask.session`).  This variable
00058|    is unavailable if the template was rendered without an active request
00059|    context.
00060| 
00061| .. data:: g
00062|    :noindex:
00063| 
00064|    The request-bound object for global variables (:data:`flask.g`).  This
00065|    variable is unavailable if the template was rendered without an active
00066|    request context.
00067| 
00068| .. function:: url_for
00069|    :noindex:
00070| 
00071|    The :func:`flask.url_for` function.
00072| 
00073| .. function:: get_flashed_messages
00074|    :noindex:
00075| 
00076|    The :func:`flask.get_flashed_messages` function.
00077| 
00078| .. admonition:: The Jinja Context Behavior
00079| 
00080|    These variables are added to the context of variables, they are not
00081|    global variables.  The difference is that by default these will not
00082|    show up in the context of imported templates.  This is partially caused
00083|    by performance considerations, partially to keep things explicit.
00084| 
00085|    What does this mean for you?  If you have a macro you want to import,
00086|    that needs to access the request object you have two possibilities:
00087| 
00088|    1.   you explicitly pass the request to the macro as parameter, or
00089|         the attribute of the request object you are interested in.
00090|    2.   you import the macro "with context".
00091| 
00092|    Importing with context looks like this:
00093| 
00094|    .. sourcecode:: jinja
00095| 
00096|       {% from '_helpers.html' import my_macro with context %}
00097| 
00098| 
00099| Controlling Autoescaping
00100| ------------------------
00101| 
00102| Autoescaping is the concept of automatically escaping special characters
00103| for you.  Special characters in the sense of HTML (or XML, and thus XHTML)
00104| are ``&``, ``>``, ``<``, ``"`` as well as ``'``.  Because these characters
00105| carry specific meanings in documents on their own you have to replace them
00106| by so called "entities" if you want to use them for text.  Not doing so
00107| would not only cause user frustration by the inability to use these
00108| characters in text, but can also lead to security problems.  (see
00109| :ref:`security-xss`)
00110| 
00111| Sometimes however you will need to disable autoescaping in templates.
00112| This can be the case if you want to explicitly inject HTML into pages, for
00113| example if they come from a system that generates secure HTML like a
00114| markdown to HTML converter.
00115| 
00116| There are three ways to accomplish that:
00117| 
00118| -   In the Python code, wrap the HTML string in a :class:`~flask.Markup`
00119|     object before passing it to the template.  This is in general the
00120|     recommended way.
00121| -   Inside the template, use the ``|safe`` filter to explicitly mark a
00122|     string as safe HTML (``{{ myvariable|safe }}``)
00123| -   Temporarily disable the autoescape system altogether.
00124| 
00125| To disable the autoescape system in templates, you can use the ``{%
00126| autoescape %}`` block:
00127| 
00128| .. sourcecode:: html+jinja
00129| 
00130|     {% autoescape false %}
00131|         <p>autoescaping is disabled here
00132|         <p>{{ will_not_be_escaped }}
00133|     {% endautoescape %}
00134| 
00135| Whenever you do this, please be very cautious about the variables you are
00136| using in this block.
00137| 
00138| .. _registering-filters:
00139| 
00140| Registering Filters
00141| -------------------
00142| 
00143| If you want to register your own filters in Jinja2 you have two ways to do
00144| that.  You can either put them by hand into the
00145| :attr:`~flask.Flask.jinja_env` of the application or use the
00146| :meth:`~flask.Flask.template_filter` decorator.
00147| 
00148| The two following examples work the same and both reverse an object::
00149| 
00150|     @app.template_filter('reverse')
00151|     def reverse_filter(s):
00152|         return s[::-1]
00153| 
00154|     def reverse_filter(s):
00155|         return s[::-1]
00156|     app.jinja_env.filters['reverse'] = reverse_filter
00157| 
00158| In case of the decorator the argument is optional if you want to use the
00159| function name as name of the filter.  Once registered, you can use the filter
00160| in your templates in the same way as Jinja2's builtin filters, for example if
00161| you have a Python list in context called `mylist`::
00162| 
00163|     {% for x in mylist | reverse %}
00164|     {% endfor %}
00165| 
00166| 
00167| Context Processors
00168| ------------------
00169| 
00170| To inject new variables automatically into the context of a template,
00171| context processors exist in Flask.  Context processors run before the
00172| template is rendered and have the ability to inject new values into the
00173| template context.  A context processor is a function that returns a
00174| dictionary.  The keys and values of this dictionary are then merged with
00175| the template context, for all templates in the app::
00176| 
00177|     @app.context_processor
00178|     def inject_user():
00179|         return dict(user=g.user)
00180| 
00181| The context processor above makes a variable called `user` available in
00182| the template with the value of `g.user`.  This example is not very
00183| interesting because `g` is available in templates anyways, but it gives an
00184| idea how this works.
00185| 
00186| Variables are not limited to values; a context processor can also make
00187| functions available to templates (since Python allows passing around
00188| functions)::
00189| 
00190|     @app.context_processor
00191|     def utility_processor():
00192|         def format_price(amount, currency="€"):
00193|             return f"{amount:.2f}{currency}"
00194|         return dict(format_price=format_price)
00195| 
00196| The context processor above makes the `format_price` function available to all
00197| templates::
00198| 
00199|     {{ format_price(0.33) }}
00200| 
00201| You could also build `format_price` as a template filter (see
00202| :ref:`registering-filters`), but this demonstrates how to pass functions in a
00203| context processor.
00204|

Flask leverages Jinja2 as its template engine.  You are obviously free to use
a different template engine, but you still have to install Jinja2 to run
Flask itself.  This requirement is necessary to enable rich extensions.
An extension can depend on Jinja2 being present.

This section only gives a very quick introduction into how Jinja2
is integrated into Flask.  If you want information on the template
engine's syntax itself, head over to the official `Jinja2 Template
Documentation <https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/templates/>`_ for
more information.

Jinja Setup
-----------

Unless customized, Jinja2 is configured by Flask as follows:

-   autoescaping is enabled for all templates ending in ``.html``,
