00002| ===
00003| 
00004| .. module:: flask
00005| 
00006| This part of the documentation covers all the interfaces of Flask.  For
00007| parts where Flask depends on external libraries, we document the most
00008| important right here and provide links to the canonical documentation.
00009| 
00010| 
00011| Application Object
00012| ------------------
00013| 
00014| .. autoclass:: Flask
00015|    :members:
00016|    :inherited-members:
00017| 
00018| 
00019| Blueprint Objects
00020| -----------------
00021| 
00022| .. autoclass:: Blueprint
00023|    :members:
00024|    :inherited-members:
00025| 
00026| Incoming Request Data
00027| ---------------------
00028| 
00029| .. autoclass:: Request
00030|     :members:
00031|     :inherited-members:
00032|     :exclude-members: json_module
00033| 
00034| .. attribute:: request
00035| 
00036|    To access incoming request data, you can use the global `request`
00037|    object.  Flask parses incoming request data for you and gives you
00038|    access to it through that global object.  Internally Flask makes
00039|    sure that you always get the correct data for the active thread if you
00040|    are in a multithreaded environment.
00041| 
00042|    This is a proxy.  See :ref:`notes-on-proxies` for more information.
00043| 
00044|    The request object is an instance of a :class:`~flask.Request`.
00045| 
00046| 
00047| Response Objects
00048| ----------------
00049| 
00050| .. autoclass:: flask.Response
00051|     :members:
00052|     :inherited-members:
00053|     :exclude-members: json_module
00054| 
00055| Sessions
00056| --------
00057| 
00058| If you have set :attr:`Flask.secret_key` (or configured it from
00059| :data:`SECRET_KEY`) you can use sessions in Flask applications. A session makes
00060| it possible to remember information from one request to another. The way Flask
00061| does this is by using a signed cookie. The user can look at the session
00062| contents, but can't modify it unless they know the secret key, so make sure to
00063| set that to something complex and unguessable.
00064| 
00065| To access the current session you can use the :class:`session` object:
00066| 
00067| .. class:: session
00068| 
00069|    The session object works pretty much like an ordinary dict, with the
00070|    difference that it keeps track of modifications.
00071| 
00072|    This is a proxy.  See :ref:`notes-on-proxies` for more information.
00073| 
00074|    The following attributes are interesting:
00075| 
00076|    .. attribute:: new
00077| 
00078|       ``True`` if the session is new, ``False`` otherwise.
00079| 
00080|    .. attribute:: modified
00081| 
00082|       ``True`` if the session object detected a modification.  Be advised
00083|       that modifications on mutable structures are not picked up
00084|       automatically, in that situation you have to explicitly set the
00085|       attribute to ``True`` yourself.  Here an example::
00086| 
00087|           # this change is not picked up because a mutable object (here
00088|           # a list) is changed.
00089|           session['objects'].append(42)
00090|           # so mark it as modified yourself
00091|           session.modified = True
00092| 
00093|    .. attribute:: permanent
00094| 
00095|       If set to ``True`` the session lives for
00096|       :attr:`~flask.Flask.permanent_session_lifetime` seconds.  The
00097|       default is 31 days.  If set to ``False`` (which is the default) the
00098|       session will be deleted when the user closes the browser.
00099| 
00100| 
00101| Session Interface
00102| -----------------
00103| 
00104| .. versionadded:: 0.8
00105| 
00106| The session interface provides a simple way to replace the session
00107| implementation that Flask is using.
00108| 
00109| .. currentmodule:: flask.sessions
00110| 
00111| .. autoclass:: SessionInterface
00112|    :members:
00113| 
00114| .. autoclass:: SecureCookieSessionInterface
00115|    :members:
00116| 
00117| .. autoclass:: SecureCookieSession
00118|    :members:
00119| 
00120| .. autoclass:: NullSession
00121|    :members:
00122| 
00123| .. autoclass:: SessionMixin
00124|    :members:
00125| 
00126| .. admonition:: Notice
00127| 
00128|    The ``PERMANENT_SESSION_LIFETIME`` config key can also be an integer
00129|    starting with Flask 0.8.  Either catch this down yourself or use
00130|    the :attr:`~flask.Flask.permanent_session_lifetime` attribute on the
00131|    app which converts the result to an integer automatically.
00132|

00135| -----------
00136| 
00137| .. currentmodule:: flask.testing
00138|

00140|    :members:

00144| ---------------
00145|

00152| Application Globals
00153| -------------------
00154| 
00155| .. currentmodule:: flask
00156| 
00157| To share data that is valid for one request only from one function to
00158| another, a global variable is not good enough because it would break in
00159| threaded environments.  Flask provides you with a special object that
00160| ensures it is only valid for the active request and that will return
00161| different values for each request.  In a nutshell: it does the right
00162| thing, like it does for :class:`request` and :class:`session`.
00163| 
00164| .. data:: g
00165| 
00166|     A namespace object that can store data during an
00167|     :doc:`application context </appcontext>`. This is an instance of
00168|     :attr:`Flask.app_ctx_globals_class`, which defaults to
00169|     :class:`ctx._AppCtxGlobals`.
00170| 
00171|     This is a good place to store resources during a request. During
00172|     testing, you can use the :ref:`faking-resources` pattern to
00173|     pre-configure such resources.
00174| 
00175|     This is a proxy. See :ref:`notes-on-proxies` for more information.
00176| 
00177|     .. versionchanged:: 0.10
00178|         Bound to the application context instead of the request context.
00179| 
00180| .. autoclass:: flask.ctx._AppCtxGlobals
00181|     :members:
00182| 
00183| 
00184| Useful Functions and Classes
00185| ----------------------------
00186| 
00187| .. data:: current_app
00188| 
00189|     A proxy to the application handling the current request. This is
00190|     useful to access the application without needing to import it, or if
00191|     it can't be imported, such as when using the application factory
00192|     pattern or in blueprints and extensions.
00193| 
00194|     This is only available when an
00195|     :doc:`application context </appcontext>` is pushed. This happens
00196|     automatically during requests and CLI commands. It can be controlled
00197|     manually with :meth:`~flask.Flask.app_context`.
00198| 
00199|     This is a proxy. See :ref:`notes-on-proxies` for more information.

00560| def _path_is_ancestor(path, other):
00561|     """Take ``other`` and remove the length of ``path`` from it. Then join it
00562|     to ``path``. If it is the original value, ``path`` is an ancestor of
00563|     ``other``."""
00564|     return os.path.join(path, other[len(path):].lstrip(os.sep)) == other
00565|

00567| def load_dotenv(path=None):
00568|     """Load "dotenv" files in order of precedence to set environment variables.
00569| 
00570|     If an env var is already set it is not overwritten, so earlier files in the
00571|     list are preferred over later files.
00572| 
00573|     Changes the current working directory to the location of the first file
00574|     found, with the assumption that it is in the top level project directory
00575|     and will be where the Python path should import local packages from.
00576| 
00577|     This is a no-op if `python-dotenv`_ is not installed.
00578| 
00579|     .. _python-dotenv: https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv#readme
00580| 
00581|     :param path: Load the file at this location instead of searching.
00582|     :return: ``True`` if a file was loaded.
00583| 
00584|     .. versionadded:: 1.0
00585|     """
00586|     if dotenv is None:
00587|         if path or os.path.exists('.env') or os.path.exists('.flaskenv'):
00588|             click.secho(
00589|                 ' * Tip: There are .env files present.'
00590|                 ' Do "pip install python-dotenv" to use them.',
00591|                 fg='yellow')
00592|         return
00593| 
00594|     if path is not None:
00595|         return dotenv.load_dotenv(path)
00596| 
00597|     new_dir = None
00598| 
00599|     for name in ('.env', '.flaskenv'):
00600|         path = dotenv.find_dotenv(name, usecwd=True)
00601| 
00602|         if not path:
00603|             continue
00604| 
00605|         if new_dir is None:
00606|             new_dir = os.path.dirname(path)
00607| 
00608|         dotenv.load_dotenv(path)
00609| 
00610|     if new_dir and os.getcwd() != new_dir:
00611|         os.chdir(new_dir)
00612| 
00613|     return new_dir is not None  # at least one file was located and loaded

00155| .. _dotenv:
00156| 
00157| Environment Variables From dotenv
00158| ---------------------------------
00159| 
00160| Rather than setting ``FLASK_APP`` each time you open a new terminal, you can
00161| use Flask's dotenv support to set environment variables automatically.
00162| 
00163| If `python-dotenv`_ is installed, running the ``flask`` command will set
00164| environment variables defined in the files :file:`.env` and :file:`.flaskenv`.
00165| This can be used to avoid having to set ``FLASK_APP`` manually every time you
00166| open a new terminal, and to set configuration using environment variables
00167| similar to how some deployment services work.
00168| 
00169| Variables set on the command line are used over those set in :file:`.env`,
00170| which are used over those set in :file:`.flaskenv`. :file:`.flaskenv` should be
00171| used for public variables, such as ``FLASK_APP``, while :file:`.env` should not
00172| be committed to your repository so that it can set private variables.
00173| 
00174| Directories are scanned upwards from the directory you call ``flask``
00175| from to locate the files. The current working directory will be set to the
00176| location of the file, with the assumption that that is the top level project
00177| directory.
00178| 
00179| The files are only loaded by the ``flask`` command or calling
00180| :meth:`~Flask.run`. If you would like to load these files when running in
00181| production, you should call :func:`~cli.load_dotenv` manually.
00182| 
00183| .. _python-dotenv: https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv#readme
00184| 
00185| 
00186| Setting Command Options
00187| ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
00188| 
00189| Click is configured to load default values for command options from
00190| environment variables. The variables use the pattern
00191| ``FLASK_COMMAND_OPTION``. For example, to set the port for the run
00192| command, instead of ``flask run --port 8000``:
00193| 
00194| .. code-block:: none
00195| 
00196|     export FLASK_RUN_PORT=8000
00197|     flask run
00198|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:8000/
00199| 
00200| These can be added to the ``.flaskenv`` file just like ``FLASK_APP`` to
00201| control default command options.
00202| 
00203| 
00204| Disable dotenv
00205| ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
00206| 
00207| The ``flask`` command will show a message if it detects dotenv files but
00208| python-dotenv is not installed.
00209| 
00210| .. code-block:: none
00211| 
00212|     flask run
00213|      * Tip: There are .env files present. Do "pip install python-dotenv" to use them.
00214| 
00215| You can tell Flask not to load dotenv files even when python-dotenv is
00216| installed by setting the ``FLASK_SKIP_DOTENV`` environment variable.
00217| This can be useful if you want to load them manually, or if you're using
00218| a project runner that loads them already. Keep in mind that the
00219| environment variables must be set before the app loads or it won't
00220| configure as expected.
00221| 
00222| .. code-block:: none
00223| 
00224|     export FLASK_SKIP_DOTENV=1
00225|     flask run
00226| 
00227| 
00228| Environment Variables From virtualenv
00229| -------------------------------------
00230| 
00231| If you do not want to install dotenv support, you can still set environment
00232| variables by adding them to the end of the virtualenv's :file:`activate`
00233| script. Activating the virtualenv will set the variables.
00234| 
00235| Unix Bash, :file:`venv/bin/activate`::
00236| 
00237|     export FLASK_APP=hello
00238| 
00239| Windows CMD, :file:`venv\\Scripts\\activate.bat`::
00240| 
00241|     set FLASK_APP=hello
00242| 
00243| It is preferred to use dotenv support over this, since :file:`.flaskenv` can be
00244| committed to the repository so that it works automatically wherever the project
00245| is checked out.
00246| 
00247| 
00248| Custom Commands
00249| ---------------
00250| 
00251| The ``flask`` command is implemented using `Click`_. See that project's
00252| documentation for full information about writing commands.
00253| 
00254| This example adds the command ``create_user`` that takes the argument
00255| ``name``. ::
00256| 
00257|     import click
00258|     from flask import Flask
00259| 
00260|     app = Flask(__name__)
00261| 
00262|     @app.cli.command()
00263|     @click.argument('name')
00264|     def create_user(name):
00265|         ...
00266| 
00267| ::
00268| 
00269|     flask create_user admin
00270|

.. _dotenv:

Environment Variables From dotenv
---------------------------------

Rather than setting ``FLASK_APP`` each time you open a new terminal, you can
use Flask's dotenv support to set environment variables automatically.

If `python-dotenv`_ is installed, running the ``flask`` command will set
environment variables defined in the files :file:`.env` and :file:`.flaskenv`.
This can be used to avoid having to set ``FLASK_APP`` manually every time you
open a new terminal, and to set configuration using environment variables
similar to how some deployment services work.

Variables set on the command line are used over those set in :file:`.env`,
which are used over those set in :file:`.flaskenv`. :file:`.flaskenv` should be","truncated":true},"time":{"start":1770022556091,"end":1770022556157}}}}

00147| -   Removed error handler caching because it caused unexpected results

00151| -   Fix incorrect JSON encoding of aware, non-UTC datetimes. (`#2374`_)
00152| -   Template auto reloading will honor debug mode even even if
00153|     :attr:`~Flask.jinja_env` was already accessed. (`#2373`_)
00154| -   The following old deprecated code was removed. (`#2385`_)
00155| 
00156|     -   ``flask.ext`` - import extensions directly by their name instead
00157|         of through the ``flask.ext`` namespace. For example,
00158|         ``import flask.ext.sqlalchemy`` becomes
00159|         ``import flask_sqlalchemy``.
00160|     -   ``Flask.init_jinja_globals`` - extend
00161|         :meth:`Flask.create_jinja_environment` instead.
00162|     -   ``Flask.error_handlers`` - tracked by
00163|         :attr:`Flask.error_handler_spec`, use :meth:`Flask.errorhandler`
00164|         to register handlers.
00165|     -   ``Flask.request_globals_class`` - use
00166|         :attr:`Flask.app_ctx_globals_class` instead.
00167|     -   ``Flask.static_path`` - use :attr:`Flask.static_url_path`
00168|         instead.
00169|     -   ``Request.module`` - use :attr:`Request.blueprint` instead.
00170| 
00171| -   The :attr:`Request.json` property is no longer deprecated.
00172|     (`#1421`_)
00173| -   Support passing a :class:`~werkzeug.test.EnvironBuilder` or
00174|     ``dict`` to :meth:`test_client.open <werkzeug.test.Client.open>`.
00175|     (`#2412`_)
00176| -   The ``flask`` command and :meth:`Flask.run` will load environment
00177|     variables from ``.env`` and ``.flaskenv`` files if python-dotenv is
00178|     installed. (`#2416`_)
00179| -   When passing a full URL to the test client, the scheme in the URL is
00180|     used instead of :data:`PREFERRED_URL_SCHEME`. (`#2430`_)
00181| -   :attr:`Flask.logger` has been simplified. ``LOGGER_NAME`` and
00182|     ``LOGGER_HANDLER_POLICY`` config was removed. The logger is always
00183|     named ``flask.app``. The level is only set on first access, it
00184|     doesn't check :attr:`Flask.debug` each time. Only one format is
00185|     used, not different ones depending on :attr:`Flask.debug`. No
00186|     handlers are removed, and a handler is only added if no handlers are
00187|     already configured. (`#2436`_)
00188| -   Blueprint view function names may not contain dots. (`#2450`_)
00189| -   Fix a ``ValueError`` caused by invalid ``Range`` requests in some
00190|     cases. (`#2526`_)
00191| -   The development server uses threads by default. (`#2529`_)
00192| -   Loading config files with ``silent=True`` will ignore
00193|     :data:`~errno.ENOTDIR` errors. (`#2581`_)
00194| -   Pass ``--cert`` and ``--key`` options to ``flask run`` to run the
00195|     development server over HTTPS. (`#2606`_)
00196| -   Added :data:`SESSION_COOKIE_SAMESITE` to control the ``SameSite``
00197|     attribute on the session cookie. (`#2607`_)
00198| -   Added :meth:`~flask.Flask.test_cli_runner` to create a Click runner
00199|     that can invoke Flask CLI commands for testing. (`#2636`_)
00200| -   Subdomain matching is disabled by default and setting
00201|     :data:`SERVER_NAME` does not implicitly enable it. It can be enabled
00202|     by passing ``subdomain_matching=True`` to the ``Flask`` constructor.
00203|     (`#2635`_)
00204| -   A single trailing slash is stripped from the blueprint
00205|     ``url_prefix`` when it is registered with the app. (`#2629`_)
00206| -   :meth:`Request.get_json` doesn't cache the

00208| -   :func:`Request.get_json` no longer accepts arbitrary encodings.
00209|     Incoming JSON should be encoded using UTF-8 per :rfc:`8259`, but

00215|     windows. (`#2709`_)
00216| -   Rewrote the tutorial docs and example project to take a more
00217|     structured approach to help new users avoid common pitfalls.
00218|     (`#2676`_)

## Issue Title
Handle app factory in FLASK_APP

## Issue Body
`FLASK_APP=myproject.app:create_app('dev')`
[
Gunicorn does this with `eval`](https://github.com/benoitc/gunicorn/blob/fbd151e9841e2c87a18512d71475bcff863a5171/gunicorn/util.py#L364), which I'm not super happy with. Instead, we could use `literal_eval` to allow a simple list of arguments. The line should never be so complicated that `eval` would be necessary anyway.

~~~python
# might need to fix this regex
m = re.search(r'(\w+)(\(.*\))', app_obj)

if m:
    app = getattr(mod, m.group(1))(*literal_eval(m.group(2)))
~~~']' timed out after 900 seconds

00029|     return wrapped_view
00030| 
00031| 
00032| @bp.before_app_request
00033| def load_logged_in_user():
00034|     """If a user id is stored in the session, load the user object from
00035|     the database into ``g.user``."""
00036|     user_id = session.get("user_id")
00037| 
00038|     if user_id is None:
00039|         g.user = None
00040|     else:
00041|         g.user = (
00042|             get_db().execute("SELECT * FROM user WHERE id = ?", (user_id,)).fetchone()
00043|         )
00044| 
00045| 
00046| @bp.route("/register", methods=("GET", "POST"))
00047| def register():
00048|     """Register a new user.
00049| 
00050|     Validates that the username is not already taken. Hashes the
00051|     password for security.
00052|     """
00053|     if request.method == "POST":
00054|         username = request.form["username"]
00055|         password = request.form["password"]
00056|         db = get_db()
00057|         error = None
00058| 
00059|         if not username:
00060|             error = "Username is required."
00061|         elif not password:
00062|             error = "Password is required."
00063|         elif (
00064|             db.execute("SELECT id FROM user WHERE username = ?", (username,)).fetchone()
00065|             is not None
00066|         ):
00067|             error = f"User {username} is already registered."
00068| 
00069|         if error is None:
00070|             # the name is available, store it in the database and go to
00071|             # the login page
00072|             db.execute(

00074|                 (username, generate_password_hash(password)),
00075|             )
00076|             db.commit()

00078| 
00079|         flash(error)
00080| 
00081|     return render_template("auth/register.html")
00082| 
00083| 
00084| @bp.route("/login", methods=("GET", "POST"))
00085| def login():
00086|     """Log in a registered user by adding the user id to the session."""
00087|     if request.method == "POST":
00088|         username = request.form["username"]
00089|         password = request.form["password"]
00090|         db = get_db()
00091|         error = None
00092|         user = db.execute(
00093|             "SELECT * FROM user WHERE username = ?", (username,)
00094|         ).fetchone()
00095| 
00096|         if user is None:
00097|             error = "Incorrect username."
00098|         elif not check_password_hash(user["password"], password):
00099|             error = "Incorrect password."
00100| 
00101|         if error is None:
00102|             # store the user id in a new session and return to the index
00103|             session.clear()
00104|             session["user_id"] = user["id"]
00105|             return redirect(url_for("index"))
00106| 
00107|         flash(error)
00108| 
00109|     return render_template("auth/login.html")
00110| 
00111|

00113| def logout():
00114|     """Clear the current session, including the stored user id."""
00115|     session.clear()
00116|     return redirect(url_for("index"))

00001| .. currentmodule:: flask
00002| 
00003| Blueprints and Views
00004| ====================
00005| 
00006| A view function is the code you write to respond to requests to your
00007| application. Flask uses patterns to match the incoming request URL to
00008| the view that should handle it. The view returns data that Flask turns
00009| into an outgoing response. Flask can also go the other direction and
00010| generate a URL to a view based on its name and arguments.
00011| 
00012| 
00013| Create a Blueprint
00014| ------------------
00015| 
00016| A :class:`Blueprint` is a way to organize a group of related views and
00017| other code. Rather than registering views and other code directly with
00018| an application, they are registered with a blueprint. Then the blueprint
00019| is registered with the application when it is available in the factory
00020| function.
00021| 
00022| Flaskr will have two blueprints, one for authentication functions and
00023| one for the blog posts functions. The code for each blueprint will go
00024| in a separate module. Since the blog needs to know about authentication,
00025| you'll write the authentication one first.
00026| 
00027| .. code-block:: python
00028|     :caption: ``flaskr/auth.py``
00029| 
00030|     import functools
00031| 
00032|     from flask import (
00033|         Blueprint, flash, g, redirect, render_template, request, session, url_for
00034|     )
00035|     from werkzeug.security import check_password_hash, generate_password_hash
00036| 
00037|     from flaskr.db import get_db
00038| 
00039|     bp = Blueprint('auth', __name__, url_prefix='/auth')
00040| 
00041| This creates a :class:`Blueprint` named ``'auth'``. Like the application
00042| object, the blueprint needs to know where it's defined, so ``__name__``
00043| is passed as the second argument. The ``url_prefix`` will be prepended
00044| to all the URLs associated with the blueprint.
00045| 
00046| Import and register the blueprint from the factory using
00047| :meth:`app.register_blueprint() <Flask.register_blueprint>`. Place the
00048| new code at the end of the factory function before returning the app.
00049| 
00050| .. code-block:: python
00051|     :caption: ``flaskr/__init__.py``
00052| 
00053|     def create_app():
00054|         app = ...
00055|         # existing code omitted
00056| 
00057|         from . import auth
00058|         app.register_blueprint(auth.bp)
00059| 
00060|         return app
00061| 
00062| The authentication blueprint will have views to register new users and
00063| to log in and log out.
00064| 
00065| 
00066| The First View: Register
00067| ------------------------
00068| 
00069| When the user visits the ``/auth/register`` URL, the ``register`` view
00070| will return `HTML`_ with a form for them to fill out. When they submit
00071| the form, it will validate their input and either show the form again
00072| with an error message or create the new user and go to the login page.
00073| 
00074| .. _HTML: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/HTML
00075| 
00076| For now you will just write the view code. On the next page, you'll
00077| write templates to generate the HTML form.
00078| 
00079| .. code-block:: python
00080|     :caption: ``flaskr/auth.py``
00081| 
00082|     @bp.route('/register', methods=('GET', 'POST'))
00083|     def register():
00084|         if request.method == 'POST':
00085|             username = request.form['username']
00086|             password = request.form['password']
00087|             db = get_db()
00088|             error = None
00089| 
00090|             if not username:
00091|                 error = 'Username is required.'
00092|             elif not password:
00093|                 error = 'Password is required.'
00094|             elif db.execute(
00095|                 'SELECT id FROM user WHERE username = ?', (username,)
00096|             ).fetchone() is not None:
00097|                 error = f"User {username} is already registered."
00098| 
00099|             if error is None:
00100|                 db.execute(
00101|                     'INSERT INTO user (username, password) VALUES (?, ?)',
00102|                     (username, generate_password_hash(password))
00103|                 )
00104|                 db.commit()
00105|                 return redirect(url_for('auth.login'))
00106| 
00107|             flash(error)
00108| 
00109|         return render_template('auth/register.html')
00110| 
00111| Here's what the ``register`` view function is doing:
00112| 
00113| #.  :meth:`@bp.route <Blueprint.route>` associates the URL ``/register``
00114|     with the ``register`` view function. When Flask receives a request
00115|     to ``/auth/register``, it will call the ``register`` view and use
00116|     the return value as the response.
00117| 
00118| #.  If the user submitted the form,
00119|     :attr:`request.method <Request.method>` will be ``'POST'``. In this
00120|     case, start validating the input.
00121| 
00122| #.  :attr:`request.form <Request.form>` is a special type of
00123|     :class:`dict` mapping submitted form keys and values. The user will
00124|     input their ``username`` and ``password``.
00125| 
00126| #.  Validate that ``username`` and ``password`` are not empty.
00127| 
00128| #.  Validate that ``username`` is not already registered by querying the
00129|     database and checking if a result is returned.
00130|     :meth:`db.execute <sqlite3.Connection.execute>` takes a SQL query
00131|     with ``?`` placeholders for any user input, and a tuple of values
00132|     to replace the placeholders with. The database library will take
00133|     care of escaping the values so you are not vulnerable to a
00134|     *SQL injection attack*.
00135| 
00136|     :meth:`~sqlite3.Cursor.fetchone` returns one row from the query.
00137|     If the query returned no results, it returns ``None``. Later,
00138|     :meth:`~sqlite3.Cursor.fetchall` is used, which returns a list of
00139|     all results.
00140| 
00141| #.  If validation succeeds, insert the new user data into the database.
00142|     For security, passwords should never be stored in the database
00143|     directly. Instead,
00144|     :func:`~werkzeug.security.generate_password_hash` is used to
00145|     securely hash the password, and that hash is stored. Since this
00146|     query modifies data, :meth:`db.commit() <sqlite3.Connection.commit>`
00147|     needs to be called afterwards to save the changes.
00148| 
00149| #.  After storing the user, they are redirected to the login page.
00150|     :func:`url_for` generates the URL for the login view based on its
00151|     name. This is preferable to writing the URL directly as it allows
00152|     you to change the URL later without changing all code that links to
00153|     it. :func:`redirect` generates a redirect response to the generated
00154|     URL.
00155| 
00156| #.  If validation fails, the error is shown to the user. :func:`flash`
00157|     stores messages that can be retrieved when rendering the template.
00158| 
00159| #.  When the user initially navigates to ``auth/register``, or
00160|     there was a validation error, an HTML page with the registration
00161|     form should be shown. :func:`render_template` will render a template
00162|     containing the HTML, which you'll write in the next step of the
00163|     tutorial.
00164| 
00165| 
00166| Login
00167| -----
00168| 
00169| This view follows the same pattern as the ``register`` view above.
00170| 
00171| .. code-block:: python
00172|     :caption: ``flaskr/auth.py``
00173| 
00174|     @bp.route('/login', methods=('GET', 'POST'))
00175|     def login():
00176|         if request.method == 'POST':
00177|             username = request.form['username']
00178|             password = request.form['password']
00179|             db = get_db()
00180|             error = None
00181|             user = db.execute(
00182|                 'SELECT * FROM user WHERE username = ?', (username,)
00183|             ).fetchone()
00184| 
00185|             if user is None:
00186|                 error = 'Incorrect username.'
00187|             elif not check_password_hash(user['password'], password):
00188|                 error = 'Incorrect password.'
00189| 
00190|             if error is None:
00191|                 session.clear()
00192|                 session['user_id'] = user['id']
00193|                 return redirect(url_for('index'))
00194| 
00195|             flash(error)
00196| 
00197|         return render_template('auth/login.html')
00198| 
00199| There are a few differences from the ``register`` view:
00200| 
00201| #.  The user is queried first and stored in a variable for later use.
00202| 
00203| #.  :func:`~werkzeug.security.check_password_hash` hashes the submitted
00204|     password in the same way as the stored hash and securely compares
00205|     them. If they match, the password is valid.
00206| 
00207| #.  :data:`session` is a :class:`dict` that stores data across requests.
00208|     When validation succeeds, the user's ``id`` is stored in a new
00209|     session. The data is stored in a *cookie* that is sent to the
00210|     browser, and the browser then sends it back with subsequent requests.
00211|     Flask securely *signs* the data so that it can't be tampered with.
00212| 
00213| Now that the user's ``id`` is stored in the :data:`session`, it will be
00214| available on subsequent requests. At the beginning of each request, if
00215| a user is logged in their information should be loaded and made
00216| available to other views.
00217| 
00218| .. code-block:: python
00219|     :caption: ``flaskr/auth.py``
00220| 
00221|     @bp.before_app_request
00222|     def load_logged_in_user():
00223|         user_id = session.get('user_id')
00224| 
00225|         if user_id is None:
00226|             g.user = None
00227|         else:
00228|             g.user = get_db().execute(
00229|                 'SELECT * FROM user WHERE id = ?', (user_id,)
00230|             ).fetchone()
00231| 
00232| :meth:`bp.before_app_request() <Blueprint.before_app_request>` registers
00233| a function that runs before the view function, no matter what URL is
00234| requested. ``load_logged_in_user`` checks if a user id is stored in the
00235| :data:`session` and gets that user's data from the database, storing it
00236| on :data:`g.user <g>`, which lasts for the length of the request. If
00237| there is no user id, or if the id doesn't exist, ``g.user`` will be
00238| ``None``.
00239| 
00240| 
00241| Logout
00242| ------
00243| 
00244| To log out, you need to remove the user id from the :data:`session`.
00245| Then ``load_logged_in_user`` won't load a user on subsequent requests.
00246| 
00247| .. code-block:: python
00248|     :caption: ``flaskr/auth.py``
00249| 
00250|     @bp.route('/logout')
00251|     def logout():
00252|         session.clear()
00253|         return redirect(url_for('index'))
00254| 
00255| 
00256| Require Authentication in Other Views
00257| -------------------------------------
00258| 
00259| Creating, editing, and deleting blog posts will require a user to be
00260| logged in. A *decorator* can be used to check this for each view it's
00261| applied to.
00262| 
00263| .. code-block:: python
00264|     :caption: ``flaskr/auth.py``
00265| 
00266|     def login_required(view):
00267|         @functools.wraps(view)
00268|         def wrapped_view(**kwargs):
00269|             if g.user is None:
00270|                 return redirect(url_for('auth.login'))
00271| 
00272|             return view(**kwargs)
00273| 
00274|         return wrapped_view
00275| 
00276| This decorator returns a new view function that wraps the original view
00277| it's applied to. The new function checks if a user is loaded and
00278| redirects to the login page otherwise. If a user is loaded the original
00279| view is called and continues normally. You'll use this decorator when
00280| writing the blog views.
00281| 
00282| Endpoints and URLs
00283| ------------------
00284| 
00285| The :func:`url_for` function generates the URL to a view based on a name
00286| and arguments. The name associated with a view is also called the
00287| *endpoint*, and by default it's the same as the name of the view
00288| function.
00289| 
00290| For example, the ``hello()`` view that was added to the app
00291| factory earlier in the tutorial has the name ``'hello'`` and can be
00292| linked to with ``url_for('hello')``. If it took an argument, which
00293| you'll see later, it would be linked to using
00294| ``url_for('hello', who='World')``.
00295| 
00296| When using a blueprint, the name of the blueprint is prepended to the
00297| name of the function, so the endpoint for the ``login`` function you
00298| wrote above is ``'auth.login'`` because you added it to the ``'auth'``
00299| blueprint.
00300| 
00301| Continue to :doc:`templates`.
00302| 

(End of file - total 302 lines)

Blueprints and Views
====================

A view function is the code you write to respond to requests to your
application. Flask uses patterns to match the incoming request URL to
the view that should handle it. The view returns data that Flask turns
into an outgoing response. Flask can also go the other direction and
generate a URL to a view based on its name and arguments.


Create a Blueprint
------------------

A :class:`Blueprint` is a way to organize a group of related views and
other code. Rather than registering views and other code directly with
an application, they are registered with a blueprint. Then the blueprint
is registered with the application when it is available in the factory
function.","truncated":false},"time":{"start":1770023443820,"end":1770023443848}}}}

00003| Test Coverage
00004| =============
00005| 
00006| Writing unit tests for your application lets you check that the code
00007| you wrote works the way you expect. Flask provides a test client that
00008| simulates requests to the application and returns the response data.
00009| 
00010| You should test as much of your code as possible. Code in functions only
00011| runs when the function is called, and code in branches, such as ``if``
00012| blocks, only runs when the condition is met. You want to make sure that
00013| each function is tested with data that covers each branch.
00014| 
00015| The closer you get to 100% coverage, the more comfortable you can be
00016| that making a change won't unexpectedly change other behavior. However,
00017| 100% coverage doesn't guarantee that your application doesn't have bugs.
00018| In particular, it doesn't test how the user interacts with the
00019| application in the browser. Despite this, test coverage is an important
00020| tool to use during development.
00021| 
00022| .. note::
00023|     This is being introduced late in the tutorial, but in your future
00024|     projects you should test as you develop.
00025| 
00026| You'll use `pytest`_ and `coverage`_ to test and measure your code.
00027| Install them both:
00028| 
00029| .. code-block:: none
00030| 
00031|     $ pip install pytest coverage
00032| 
00033| .. _pytest: https://pytest.readthedocs.io/
00034| .. _coverage: https://coverage.readthedocs.io/
00035| 
00036| 
00037| Setup and Fixtures
00038| ------------------
00039| 
00040| The test code is located in the ``tests`` directory. This directory is
00041| *next to* the ``flaskr`` package, not inside it. The
00042| ``tests/conftest.py`` file contains setup functions called *fixtures*
00043| that each test will use. Tests are in Python modules that start with
00044| ``test_``, and each test function in those modules also starts with
00045| ``test_``.
00046| 
00047| Each test will create a new temporary database file and populate some
00048| data that will be used in the tests. Write a SQL file to insert that
00049| data.
00050| 
00051| .. code-block:: sql
00052|     :caption: ``tests/data.sql``
00053| 
00054|     INSERT INTO user (username, password)
00055|     VALUES
00056|       ('test', 'pbkdf2:sha256:50000$TCI4GzcX$0de171a4f4dac32e3364c7ddc7c14f3e2fa61f2d17574483f7ffbb431b4acb2f'),
00057|       ('other', 'pbkdf2:sha256:50000$kJPKsz6N$d2d4784f1b030a9761f5ccaeeaca413f27f2ecb76d6168407af962ddce849f79');
00058| 
00059|     INSERT INTO post (title, body, author_id, created)
00060|     VALUES
00061|       ('test title', 'test' || x'0a' || 'body', 1, '2018-01-01 00:00:00');
00062| 
00063| The ``app`` fixture will call the factory and pass ``test_config`` to
00064| configure the application and database for testing instead of using your
00065| local development configuration.
00066| 
00067| .. code-block:: python
00068|     :caption: ``tests/conftest.py``
00069| 
00070|     import os
00071|     import tempfile
00072| 
00073|     import pytest
00074|     from flaskr import create_app
00075|     from flaskr.db import get_db, init_db
00076| 
00077|     with open(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), 'data.sql'), 'rb') as f:
00078|         _data_sql = f.read().decode('utf8')
00079| 
00080| 
00081|     @pytest.fixture
00082|     def app():
00083|         db_fd, db_path = tempfile.mkstemp()
00084| 
00085|         app = create_app({
00086|             'TESTING': True,
00087|             'DATABASE': db_path,
00088|         })
00089| 
00090|         with app.app_context():
00091|             init_db()
00092|             get_db().executescript(_data_sql)
00093| 
00094|         yield app
00095| 
00096|         os.close(db_fd)
00097|         os.unlink(db_path)
00098| 
00099| 
00100|     @pytest.fixture
00101|     def client(app):
00102|         return app.test_client()
00103| 
00104| 
00105|     @pytest.fixture
00106|     def runner(app):
00107|         return app.test_cli_runner()
00108| 
00109| :func:`tempfile.mkstemp` creates and opens a temporary file, returning
00110| the file descriptor and the path to it. The ``DATABASE`` path is
00111| overridden so it points to this temporary path instead of the instance
00112| folder. After setting the path, the database tables are created and the
00113| test data is inserted. After the test is over, the temporary file is
00114| closed and removed.
00115| 
00116| :data:`TESTING` tells Flask that the app is in test mode. Flask changes
00117| some internal behavior so it's easier to test, and other extensions can
00118| also use the flag to make testing them easier.
00119| 
00120| The ``client`` fixture calls
00121| :meth:`app.test_client() <Flask.test_client>` with the application
00122| object created by the ``app`` fixture. Tests will use the client to make
00123| requests to the application without running the server.
00124| 
00125| The ``runner`` fixture is similar to ``client``.
00126| :meth:`app.test_cli_runner() <Flask.test_cli_runner>` creates a runner
00127| that can call the Click commands registered with the application.
00128| 
00129| Pytest uses fixtures by matching their function names with the names
00130| of arguments in the test functions. For example, the ``test_hello``
00131| function you'll write next takes a ``client`` argument. Pytest matches
00132| that with the ``client`` fixture function, calls it, and passes the
00133| returned value to the test function.
00134| 
00135| 
00136| Factory
00137| -------
00138| 
00139| There's not much to test about the factory itself. Most of the code will
00140| be executed for each test already, so if something fails the other tests
00141| will notice.
00142| 
00143| The only behavior that can change is passing test config. If config is
00144| not passed, there should be some default configuration, otherwise the
00145| configuration should be overridden.
00146| 
00147| .. code-block:: python
00148|     :caption: ``tests/test_factory.py``
00149| 
00150|     from flaskr import create_app
00151| 
00152| 
00153|     def test_config():
00154|         assert not create_app().testing
00155|         assert create_app({'TESTING': True}).testing
00156| 
00157| 
00158|     def test_hello(client):
00159|         response = client.get('/hello')
00160|         assert response.data == b'Hello, World!'
00161| 
00162| You added the ``hello`` route as an example when writing the factory at
00163| the beginning of the tutorial. It returns "Hello, World!", so the test
00164| checks that the response data matches.
00165| 
00166| 
00167| Database
00168| --------
00169| 
00170| Within an application context, ``get_db`` should return the same
00171| connection each time it's called. After the context, the connection
00172| should be closed.
00173| 
00174| .. code-block:: python
00175|     :caption: ``tests/test_db.py``
00176| 
00177|     import sqlite3
00178| 
00179|     import pytest
00180|     from flaskr.db import get_db
00181| 
00182| 
00183|     def test_get_close_db(app):
00184|         with app.app_context():
00185|             db = get_db()
00186|             assert db is get_db()
00187| 
00188|         with pytest.raises(sqlite3.ProgrammingError) as e:
00189|             db.execute('SELECT 1')
00190| 
00191|         assert 'closed' in str(e.value)
00192| 
00193| The ``init-db`` command should call the ``init_db`` function and output
00194| a message.
00195| 
00196| .. code-block:: python
00197|     :caption: ``tests/test_db.py``
00198| 
00199|     def test_init_db_command(runner, monkeypatch):
00200|         class Recorder(object):
00201|             called = False
00202| 
00203|         def fake_init_db():
00204|             Recorder.called = True
00205| 
00206|         monkeypatch.setattr('flaskr.db.init_db', fake_init_db)
00207|         result = runner.invoke(args=['init-db'])
00208|         assert 'Initialized' in result.output
00209|         assert Recorder.called
00210| 
00211| This test uses Pytest's ``monkeypatch`` fixture to replace the
00212| ``init_db`` function with one that records that it's been called. The
00213| ``runner`` fixture you wrote above is used to call the ``init-db``
00214| command by name.
00215| 
00216| 
00217| Authentication
00218| --------------
00219| 
00220| For most of the views, a user needs to be logged in. The easiest way to
00221| do this in tests is to make a ``POST`` request to the ``login`` view
00222| with the client. Rather than writing that out every time, you can write
00223| a class with methods to do that, and use a fixture to pass it the client
00224| for each test.
00225| 
00226| .. code-block:: python
00227|     :caption: ``tests/conftest.py``
00228| 
00229|     class AuthActions(object):
00230|         def __init__(self, client):
00231|             self._client = client
00232| 
00233|         def login(self, username='test', password='test'):
00234|             return self._client.post(
00235|                 '/auth/login',
00236|                 data={'username': username, 'password': password}
00237|             )
00238| 
00239|         def logout(self):
00240|             return self._client.get('/auth/logout')
00241| 
00242| 
00243|     @pytest.fixture
00244|     def auth(client):
00245|         return AuthActions(client)
00246| 
00247| With the ``auth`` fixture, you can call ``auth.login()`` in a test to
00248| log in as the ``test`` user, which was inserted as part of the test
00249| data in the ``app`` fixture.
00250| 
00251| The ``register`` view should render successfully on ``GET``. On ``POST``
00252| with valid form data, it should redirect to the login URL and the user's
00253| data should be in the database. Invalid data should display error
00254| messages.
00255| 
00256| .. code-block:: python
00257|     :caption: ``tests/test_auth.py``
00258| 
00259|     import pytest
00260|     from flask import g, session
00261|     from flaskr.db import get_db
00262| 
00263| 
00264|     def test_register(client, app):
00265|         assert client.get('/auth/register').status_code == 200
00266|         response = client.post(
00267|             '/auth/register', data={'username': 'a', 'password': 'a'}
00268|         )
00269|         assert 'http://localhost/auth/login' == response.headers['Location']
00270| 
00271|         with app.app_context():
00272|             assert get_db().execute(
00273|                 "SELECT * FROM user WHERE username = 'a'",
00274|             ).fetchone() is not None
00275| 
00276| 
00277|     @pytest.mark.parametrize(('username', 'password', 'message'), (
00278|         ('', '', b'Username is required.'),
00279|         ('a', '', b'Password is required.'),
00280|         ('test', 'test', b'already registered'),
00281|     ))
00282|     def test_register_validate_input(client, username, password, message):
00283|         response = client.post(
00284|             '/auth/register',
00285|             data={'username': username, 'password': password}
00286|         )
00287|         assert message in response.data
00288| 
00289| :meth:`client.get() <werkzeug.test.Client.get>` makes a ``GET`` request
00290| and returns the :class:`Response` object returned by Flask. Similarly,
00291| :meth:`client.post() <werkzeug.test.Client.post>` makes a ``POST``
00292| request, converting the ``data`` dict into form data.
00293| 
00294| To test that the page renders successfully, a simple request is made and
00295| checked for a ``200 OK`` :attr:`~Response.status_code`. If
00296| rendering failed, Flask would return a ``500 Internal Server Error``
00297| code.
00298| 
00299| :attr:`~Response.headers` will have a ``Location`` header with the login
00300| URL when the register view redirects to the login view.
00301| 
00302| :attr:`~Response.data` contains the body of the response as bytes. If
00303| you expect a certain value to render on the page, check that it's in
00304| ``data``. Bytes must be compared to bytes. If you want to compare text,
00305| use :meth:`get_data(as_text=True) <werkzeug.wrappers.Response.get_data>`
00306| instead.
00307| 
00308| ``pytest.mark.parametrize`` tells Pytest to run the same test function
00309| with different arguments. You use it here to test different invalid
00310| input and error messages without writing the same code three times.
00311| 
00312| The tests for the ``login`` view are very similar to those for
00313| ``register``. Rather than testing the data in the database,
00314| :data:`session` should have ``user_id`` set after logging in.
00315| 
00316| .. code-block:: python
00317|     :caption: ``tests/test_auth.py``
00318| 
00319|     def test_login(client, auth):
00320|         assert client.get('/auth/login').status_code == 200
00321|         response = auth.login()
00322|         assert response.headers['Location'] == 'http://localhost/'
00323| 
00324|         with client:
00325|             client.get('/')
00326|             assert session['user_id'] == 1
00327|             assert g.user['username'] == 'test'
00328| 
00329| 
00330|     @pytest.mark.parametrize(('username', 'password', 'message'), (
00331|         ('a', 'test', b'Incorrect username.'),
00332|         ('test', 'a', b'Incorrect password.'),
00333|     ))
00334|     def test_login_validate_input(auth, username, password, message):
00335|         response = auth.login(username, password)
00336|         assert message in response.data
00337| 
00338| Using ``client`` in a ``with`` block allows accessing context variables
00339| such as :data:`session` after the response is returned. Normally,
00340| accessing ``session`` outside of a request would raise an error.
00341| 
00342| Testing ``logout`` is the opposite of ``login``. :data:`session` should
00343| not contain ``user_id`` after logging out.
00344| 
00345| .. code-block:: python
00346|     :caption: ``tests/test_auth.py``
00347| 
00348|     def test_logout(client, auth):
00349|         auth.login()
00350| 
00351|         with client:
00352|             auth.logout()
00353|             assert 'user_id' not in session
00354| 
00355| 
00356| Blog
00357| ----
00358| 
00359| All the blog views use the ``auth`` fixture you wrote earlier. Call
00360| ``auth.login()`` and subsequent requests from the client will be logged
00361| in as the ``test`` user.
00362| 
00363| The ``index`` view should display information about the post that was
00364| added with the test data. When logged in as the author, there should be
00365| a link to edit the post.
00366| 
00367| You can also test some more authentication behavior while testing the
00368| ``index`` view. When not logged in, each page shows links to log in or
00369| register. When logged in, there's a link to log out.
00370| 
00371| .. code-block:: python
00372|     :caption: ``tests/test_blog.py``
00373| 
00374|     import pytest
00375|     from flaskr.db import get_db
00376| 
00377| 
00378|     def test_index(client, auth):
00379|         response = client.get('/')
00380|         assert b"Log In" in response.data
00381|         assert b"Register" in response.data
00382| 
00383|         auth.login()
00384|         response = client.get('/')
00385|         assert b'Log Out' in response.data
00386|         assert b'test title' in response.data
00387|         assert b'by test on 2018-01-01' in response.data
00388|         assert b'test\nbody' in response.data
00389|         assert b'href="/1/update"' in response.data
00390| 
00391| A user must be logged in to access the ``create``, ``update``, and
00392| ``delete`` views. The logged in user must be the author of the post to
00393| access ``update`` and ``delete``, otherwise a ``403 Forbidden`` status
00394| is returned. If a ``post`` with the given ``id`` doesn't exist,
00395| ``update`` and ``delete`` should return ``404 Not Found``.
00396| 
00397| .. code-block:: python
00398|     :caption: ``tests/test_blog.py``
00399| 
00400|     @pytest.mark.parametrize('path', (
00401|         '/create',
00402|         '/1/update',
00403|         '/1/delete',
00404|     ))
00405|     def test_login_required(client, path):
00406|         response = client.post(path)
00407|         assert response.headers['Location'] == 'http://localhost/auth/login'
00408| 
00409| 
00410|     def test_author_required(app, client, auth):
00411|         # change the post author to another user
00412|         with app.app_context():
00413|             db = get_db()
00414|             db.execute('UPDATE post SET author_id = 2 WHERE id = 1')
00415|             db.commit()
00416| 
00417|         auth.login()
00418|         # current user can't modify other user's post
00419|         assert client.post('/1/update').status_code == 403
00420|         assert client.post('/1/delete').status_code == 403
00421|         # current user doesn't see edit link
00422|         assert b'href="/1/update"' not in client.get('/').data
00423| 
00424| 
00425|     @pytest.mark.parametrize('path', (
00426|         '/2/update',
00427|         '/2/delete',
00428|     ))
00429|     def test_exists_required(client, auth, path):
00430|         auth.login()
00431|         assert client.post(path).status_code == 404
00432| 
00433| The ``create`` and ``update`` views should render and return a
00434| ``200 OK`` status for a ``GET`` request. When valid data is sent in a
00435| ``POST`` request, ``create`` should insert the new post data into the
00436| database, and ``update`` should modify the existing data. Both pages
00437| should show an error message on invalid data.
00438| 
00439| .. code-block:: python
00440|     :caption: ``tests/test_blog.py``
00441| 
00442|     def test_create(client, auth, app):
00443|         auth.login()
00444|         assert client.get('/create').status_code == 200
00445|         client.post('/create', data={'title': 'created', 'body': ''})
00446| 
00447|         with app.app_context():
00448|             db = get_db()
00449|             count = db.execute('SELECT COUNT(id) FROM post').fetchone()[0]
00450|             assert count == 2
00451| 
00452| 
00453|     def test_update(client, auth, app):
00454|         auth.login()
00455|         assert client.get('/1/update').status_code == 200
00456|         client.post('/1/update', data={'title': 'updated', 'body': ''})
00457| 
00458|         with app.app_context():
00459|             db = get_db()
00460|             post = db.execute('SELECT * FROM post WHERE id = 1').fetchone()
00461|             assert post['title'] == 'updated'
00462| 
00463| 
00464|     @pytest.mark.parametrize('path', (
00465|         '/create',
00466|         '/1/update',
00467|     ))
00468|     def test_create_update_validate(client, auth, path):
00469|         auth.login()
00470|         response = client.post(path, data={'title': '', 'body': ''})
00471|         assert b'Title is required.' in response.data
00472| 
00473| The ``delete`` view should redirect to the index URL and the post should
00474| no longer exist in the database.
00475| 
00476| .. code-block:: python
00477|     :caption: ``tests/test_blog.py``
00478| 
00479|     def test_delete(client, auth, app):
00480|         auth.login()
00481|         response = client.post('/1/delete')
00482|         assert response.headers['Location'] == 'http://localhost/'
00483| 
00484|         with app.app_context():
00485|             db = get_db()
00486|             post = db.execute('SELECT * FROM post WHERE id = 1').fetchone()
00487|             assert post is None
00488| 
00489| 
00490| Running the Tests
00491| -----------------
00492| 
00493| Some extra configuration, which is not required but makes running
00494| tests with coverage less verbose, can be added to the project's
00495| ``setup.cfg`` file.
00496| 
00497| .. code-block:: none
00498|     :caption: ``setup.cfg``
00499| 
00500|     [tool:pytest]
00501|     testpaths = tests
00502| 
00503|     [coverage:run]
00504|     branch = True
00505|     source =
00506|         flaskr
00507| 
00508| To run the tests, use the ``pytest`` command. It will find and run all
00509| the test functions you've written.
00510| 
00511| .. code-block:: none
00512| 
00513|     $ pytest
00514| 
00515|     ========================= test session starts ==========================
00516|     platform linux -- Python 3.6.4, pytest-3.5.0, py-1.5.3, pluggy-0.6.0
00517|     rootdir: /home/user/Projects/flask-tutorial, inifile: setup.cfg
00518|     collected 23 items
00519| 
00520|     tests/test_auth.py ........                                      [ 34%]
00521|     tests/test_blog.py ............                                  [ 86%]
00522|     tests/test_db.py ..                                              [ 95%]
00523|     tests/test_factory.py ..                                         [100%]
00524| 
00525|     ====================== 24 passed in 0.64 seconds =======================
00526| 
00527| If any tests fail, pytest will show the error that was raised. You can
00528| run ``pytest -v`` to get a list of each test function rather than dots.
00529| 
00530| To measure the code coverage of your tests, use the ``coverage`` command
00531| to run pytest instead of running it directly.
00532| 
00533| .. code-block:: none
00534| 
00535|     $ coverage run -m pytest
00536| 
00537| You can either view a simple coverage report in the terminal:
00538| 
00539| .. code-block:: none
00540| 
00541|     $ coverage report
00542| 
00543|     Name                 Stmts   Miss Branch BrPart  Cover
00544|     ------------------------------------------------------

00552| An HTML report allows you to see which lines were covered in each file:

Test Coverage
=============

Writing unit tests for your application lets you check that the code
you wrote works the way you expect. Flask provides a test client that
simulates requests to the application and returns the response data.

You should test as much of your code as possible. Code in functions only
runs when the function is called, and code in branches, such as ``if``
blocks, only runs when the condition is met. You want to make sure that
each function is tested with data that covers each branch.

The closer you get to 100% coverage, the more comfortable you can be
that making a change won't unexpectedly change other behavior. However,
100% coverage doesn't guarantee that your application doesn't have bugs.
In particular, it doesn't test how the user interacts with the
application in the browser. Despite this, test coverage is an important
tool to use during development.","truncated":false},"time":{"start":1770023443834,"end":1770023443849}}}}

00001| .. currentmodule:: flask
00002| 
00003| Define and Access the Database
00004| ==============================
00005| 
00006| The application will use a `SQLite`_ database to store users and posts.
00007| Python comes with built-in support for SQLite in the :mod:`sqlite3`
00008| module.
00009| 
00010| SQLite is convenient because it doesn't require setting up a separate
00011| database server and is built-in to Python. However, if concurrent
00012| requests try to write to the database at the same time, they will slow
00013| down as each write happens sequentially. Small applications won't notice
00014| this. Once you become big, you may want to switch to a different
00015| database.
00016| 
00017| The tutorial doesn't go into detail about SQL. If you are not familiar
00018| with it, the SQLite docs describe the `language`_.
00019| 
00020| .. _SQLite: https://sqlite.org/about.html
00021| .. _language: https://sqlite.org/lang.html
00022| 
00023| 
00024| Connect to the Database
00025| -----------------------
00026| 
00027| The first thing to do when working with a SQLite database (and most
00028| other Python database libraries) is to create a connection to it. Any
00029| queries and operations are performed using the connection, which is
00030| closed after the work is finished.
00031| 
00032| In web applications this connection is typically tied to the request. It
00033| is created at some point when handling a request, and closed before the
00034| response is sent.
00035| 
00036| .. code-block:: python
00037|     :caption: ``flaskr/db.py``
00038| 
00039|     import sqlite3
00040| 
00041|     import click
00042|     from flask import current_app, g
00043|     from flask.cli import with_appcontext
00044| 
00045| 
00046|     def get_db():
00047|         if 'db' not in g:
00048|             g.db = sqlite3.connect(
00049|                 current_app.config['DATABASE'],
00050|                 detect_types=sqlite3.PARSE_DECLTYPES
00051|             )
00052|             g.db.row_factory = sqlite3.Row
00053| 
00054|         return g.db
00055| 
00056| 
00057|     def close_db(e=None):
00058|         db = g.pop('db', None)
00059| 
00060|         if db is not None:
00061|             db.close()
00062| 
00063| :data:`g` is a special object that is unique for each request. It is
00064| used to store data that might be accessed by multiple functions during
00065| the request. The connection is stored and reused instead of creating a
00066| new connection if ``get_db`` is called a second time in the same
00067| request.
00068| 
00069| :data:`current_app` is another special object that points to the Flask
00070| application handling the request. Since you used an application factory,
00071| there is no application object when writing the rest of your code.
00072| ``get_db`` will be called when the application has been created and is
00073| handling a request, so :data:`current_app` can be used.
00074| 
00075| :func:`sqlite3.connect` establishes a connection to the file pointed at
00076| by the ``DATABASE`` configuration key. This file doesn't have to exist
00077| yet, and won't until you initialize the database later.
00078| 
00079| :class:`sqlite3.Row` tells the connection to return rows that behave
00080| like dicts. This allows accessing the columns by name.
00081| 
00082| ``close_db`` checks if a connection was created by checking if ``g.db``
00083| was set. If the connection exists, it is closed. Further down you will
00084| tell your application about the ``close_db`` function in the application
00085| factory so that it is called after each request.
00086| 
00087| 
00088| Create the Tables
00089| -----------------
00090| 
00091| In SQLite, data is stored in *tables* and *columns*. These need to be
00092| created before you can store and retrieve data. Flaskr will store users
00093| in the ``user`` table, and posts in the ``post`` table. Create a file
00094| with the SQL commands needed to create empty tables:
00095| 
00096| .. code-block:: sql
00097|     :caption: ``flaskr/schema.sql``
00098| 
00099|     DROP TABLE IF EXISTS user;
00100|     DROP TABLE IF EXISTS post;
00101| 
00102|     CREATE TABLE user (
00103|       id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
00104|       username TEXT UNIQUE NOT NULL,
00105|       password TEXT NOT NULL
00106|     );
00107| 
00108|     CREATE TABLE post (
00109|       id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
00110|       author_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
00111|       created TIMESTAMP NOT NULL DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
00112|       title TEXT NOT NULL,
00113|       body TEXT NOT NULL,
00114|       FOREIGN KEY (author_id) REFERENCES user (id)
00115|     );
00116| 
00117| Add the Python functions that will run these SQL commands to the
00118| ``db.py`` file:
00119| 
00120| .. code-block:: python
00121|     :caption: ``flaskr/db.py``
00122| 
00123|     def init_db():
00124|         db = get_db()
00125| 
00126|         with current_app.open_resource('schema.sql') as f:
00127|             db.executescript(f.read().decode('utf8'))
00128| 
00129| 
00130|     @click.command('init-db')
00131|     @with_appcontext
00132|     def init_db_command():
00133|         """Clear the existing data and create new tables."""
00134|         init_db()
00135|         click.echo('Initialized the database.')
00136| 
00137| :meth:`open_resource() <Flask.open_resource>` opens a file relative to
00138| the ``flaskr`` package, which is useful since you won't necessarily know
00139| where that location is when deploying the application later. ``get_db``
00140| returns a database connection, which is used to execute the commands
00141| read from the file.
00142| 
00143| :func:`click.command` defines a command line command called ``init-db``
00144| that calls the ``init_db`` function and shows a success message to the
00145| user. You can read :doc:`/cli` to learn more about writing commands.
00146| 
00147| 
00148| Register with the Application
00149| -----------------------------
00150| 
00151| The ``close_db`` and ``init_db_command`` functions need to be registered
00152| with the application instance; otherwise, they won't be used by the
00153| application. However, since you're using a factory function, that
00154| instance isn't available when writing the functions. Instead, write a
00155| function that takes an application and does the registration.
00156| 
00157| .. code-block:: python
00158|     :caption: ``flaskr/db.py``
00159| 
00160|     def init_app(app):
00161|         app.teardown_appcontext(close_db)
00162|         app.cli.add_command(init_db_command)
00163| 
00164| :meth:`app.teardown_appcontext() <Flask.teardown_appcontext>` tells
00165| Flask to call that function when cleaning up after returning the
00166| response.
00167| 
00168| :meth:`app.cli.add_command() <click.Group.add_command>` adds a new
00169| command that can be called with the ``flask`` command.
00170| 
00171| Import and call this function from the factory. Place the new code at
00172| the end of the factory function before returning the app.
00173| 
00174| .. code-block:: python
00175|     :caption: ``flaskr/__init__.py``
00176| 
00177|     def create_app():
00178|         app = ...
00179|         # existing code omitted
00180| 
00181|         from . import db
00182|         db.init_app(app)
00183| 
00184|         return app
00185| 
00186| 
00187| Initialize the Database File
00188| ----------------------------
00189| 
00190| Now that ``init-db`` has been registered with the app, it can be called
00191| using the ``flask`` command, similar to the ``run`` command from the
00192| previous page.
00193| 
00194| .. note::
00195| 
00196|     If you're still running the server from the previous page, you can
00197|     either stop the server, or run this command in a new terminal. If
00198|     you use a new terminal, remember to change to your project directory
00199|     and activate the env as described in :doc:`/installation`. You'll
00200|     also need to set ``FLASK_APP`` and ``FLASK_ENV`` as shown on the
00201|     previous page.
00202| 
00203| Run the ``init-db`` command:
00204| 
00205| .. code-block:: none
00206| 
00207|     $ flask init-db
00208|     Initialized the database.
00209| 
00210| There will now be a ``flaskr.sqlite`` file in the ``instance`` folder in
00211| your project.
00212| 
00213| Continue to :doc:`views`.
00214| 

(End of file - total 214 lines)
</file>","title":"docs/tutorial/database.rst","metadata":{"preview":".. currentmodule:: flask

Define and Access the Database
==============================

The application will use a `SQLite`_ database to store users and posts.
Python comes with built-in support for SQLite in the :mod:`sqlite3`
module.

SQLite is convenient because it doesn't require setting up a separate
database server and is built-in to Python. However, if concurrent
requests try to write to the database at the same time, they will slow
down as each write happens sequentially. Small applications won't notice
this. Once you become big, you may want to switch to a different
database.

The tutorial doesn't go into detail about SQL. If you are not familiar
with it, the SQLite docs describe the `language`_.

.. _SQLite: https://sqlite.org/about.html","truncated":false},"time":{"start":1770023504513,"end":1770023504519}}}}

00028| class SessionMixin(object):
00029|     """Expands a basic dictionary with an accessors that are expected
00030|     by Flask extensions and users for the session.
00031|     """
00032| 
00033|     def _get_permanent(self):
00034|         return self.get('_permanent', False)
00035| 
00036|     def _set_permanent(self, value):
00037|         self['_permanent'] = bool(value)
00038| 
00039|     #: this reflects the ``'_permanent'`` key in the dict.
00040|     permanent = property(_get_permanent, _set_permanent)
00041|     del _get_permanent, _set_permanent
00042| 
00043|     #: some session backends can tell you if a session is new, but that is
00044|     #: not necessarily guaranteed.  Use with caution.  The default mixin
00045|     #: implementation just hardcodes `False` in.
00046|     new = False
00047| 
00048|     #: for some backends this will always be `True`, but some backends will
00049|     #: default this to false and detect changes in the dictionary for as
00050|     #: long as changes do not happen on mutable structures in the session.
00051|     #: The default mixin implementation just hardcodes `True` in.
00052|     modified = True
00053| 
00054| 
00055| class TaggedJSONSerializer(object):
00056|     """A customized JSON serializer that supports a few extra types that
00057|     we take for granted when serializing (tuples, markup objects, datetime).
00058|     """
00059| 
00060|     def dumps(self, value):
00061|         def _tag(value):
00062|             if isinstance(value, tuple):
00063|                 return {' t': [_tag(x) for x in value]}
00064|             elif isinstance(value, uuid.UUID):
00065|                 return {' u': value.hex}
00066|             elif isinstance(value, bytes):
00067|                 return {' b': b64encode(value).decode('ascii')}
00068|             elif callable(getattr(value, '__html__', None)):
00069|                 return {' m': text_type(value.__html__())}
00070|             elif isinstance(value, list):
00071|                 return [_tag(x) for x in value]
00072|             elif isinstance(value, datetime):
00073|                 return {' d': http_date(value)}
00074|             elif isinstance(value, dict):
00075|                 return dict((k, _tag(v)) for k, v in iteritems(value))
00076|             elif isinstance(value, str):
00077|                 try:
00078|                     return text_type(value)
00079|                 except UnicodeError:
00080|                     raise UnexpectedUnicodeError(u'A byte string with '
00081|                         u'non-ASCII data was passed to the session system '
00082|                         u'which can only store unicode strings.  Consider '
00083|                         u'base64 encoding your string (String was %r)' % value)
00084|             return value
00085|         return json.dumps(_tag(value), separators=(',', ':'))
00086| 
00087|     def loads(self, value):
00088|         def object_hook(obj):
00089|             if len(obj) != 1:
00090|                 return obj
00091|             the_key, the_value = next(iteritems(obj))
00092|             if the_key == ' t':
00093|                 return tuple(the_value)
00094|             elif the_key == ' u':
00095|                 return uuid.UUID(the_value)
00096|             elif the_key == ' b':
00097|                 return b64decode(the_value)
00098|             elif the_key == ' m':
00099|                 return Markup(the_value)
00100|             elif the_key == ' d':
00101|                 return parse_date(the_value)
00102|             return obj
00103|         return json.loads(value, object_hook=object_hook)
00104|

00109| class SecureCookieSession(CallbackDict, SessionMixin):
00110|     """Baseclass for sessions based on signed cookies."""
00111| 
00112|     def __init__(self, initial=None):
00113|         def on_update(self):
00114|             self.modified = True
00115|         CallbackDict.__init__(self, initial, on_update)
00116|         self.modified = False
00117| 
00118| 
00119| class NullSession(SecureCookieSession):
00120|     """Class used to generate nicer error messages if sessions are not
00121|     available.  Will still allow read-only access to the empty session
00122|     but fail on setting.
00123|     """
00124| 
00125|     def _fail(self, *args, **kwargs):
00126|         raise RuntimeError('the session is unavailable because no secret '
00127|                            'key was set.  Set the secret_key on the '
00128|                            'application to something unique and secret.')
00129|     __setitem__ = __delitem__ = clear = pop = popitem = \
00130|         update = setdefault = _fail
00131|     del _fail
00132| 
00133| 
00134| class SessionInterface(object):
00135|     """The basic interface you have to implement in order to replace the
00136|     default session interface which uses werkzeug's securecookie
00137|     implementation.  The only methods you have to implement are
00138|     :meth:`open_session` and :meth:`save_session`, the others have
00139|     useful defaults which you don't need to change.
00140| 
00141|     The session object returned by the :meth:`open_session` method has to
00142|     provide a dictionary like interface plus the properties and methods
00143|     from the :class:`SessionMixin`.  We recommend just subclassing a dict
00144|     and adding that mixin::
00145| 
00146|         class Session(dict, SessionMixin):
00147|             pass
00148| 
00149|     If :meth:`open_session` returns `None` Flask will call into
00150|     :meth:`make_null_session` to create a session that acts as replacement
00151|     if the session support cannot work because some requirement is not
00152|     fulfilled.  The default :class:`NullSession` class that is created
00153|     will complain that the secret key was not set.
00154| 
00155|     To replace the session interface on an application all you have to do
00156|     is to assign :attr:`flask.Flask.session_interface`::
00157| 
00158|         app = Flask(__name__)
00159|         app.session_interface = MySessionInterface()
00160| 
00161|     .. versionadded:: 0.8
00162|     """
00163| 
00164|     #: :meth:`make_null_session` will look here for the class that should
00165|     #: be created when a null session is requested.  Likewise the
00166|     #: :meth:`is_null_session` method will perform a typecheck against
00167|     #: this type.
00168|     null_session_class = NullSession
00169| 
00170|     #: A flag that indicates if the session interface is pickle based.
00171|     #: This can be used by flask extensions to make a decision in regards
00172|     #: to how to deal with the session object.
00173|     #:
00174|     #: .. versionadded:: 0.10
00175|     pickle_based = False
00176| 
00177|     def make_null_session(self, app):
00178|         """Creates a null session which acts as a replacement object if the
00179|         real session support could not be loaded due to a configuration
00180|         error.  This mainly aids the user experience because the job of the
00181|         null session is to still support lookup without complaining but
00182|         modifications are answered with a helpful error message of what
00183|         failed.
00184| 
00185|         This creates an instance of :attr:`null_session_class` by default.
00186|         """
00187|         return self.null_session_class()
00188| 
00189|     def is_null_session(self, obj):
00190|         """Checks if a given object is a null session.  Null sessions are
00191|         not asked to be saved.
00192| 
00193|         This checks if the object is an instance of :attr:`null_session_class`
00194|         by default.
00195|         """
00196|         return isinstance(obj, self.null_session_class)
00197| 
00198|     def get_cookie_domain(self, app):
00199|         """Helpful helper method that returns the cookie domain that should
00200|         be used for the session cookie if session cookies are used.
00201|         """
00202|         if app.config['SESSION_COOKIE_DOMAIN'] is not None:
00203|             return app.config['SESSION_COOKIE_DOMAIN']
00204|         if app.config['SERVER_NAME'] is not None:
00205|             # chop of the port which is usually not supported by browsers
00206|             rv = '.' + app.config['SERVER_NAME'].rsplit(':', 1)[0]
00207| 
00208|             # Google chrome does not like cookies set to .localhost, so
00209|             # we just go with no domain then.  Flask documents anyways that
00210|             # cross domain cookies need a fully qualified domain name
00211|             if rv == '.localhost':
00212|                 rv = None
00213| 
00214|             # If we infer the cookie domain from the server name we need
00215|             # to check if we are in a subpath.  In that case we can't
00216|             # set a cross domain cookie.
00217|             if rv is not None:
00218|                 path = self.get_cookie_path(app)
00219|                 if path != '/':
00220|                     rv = rv.lstrip('.')
00221| 
00222|             return rv
00223| 
00224|     def get_cookie_path(self, app):
00225|         """Returns the path for which the cookie should be valid.  The
00226|         default implementation uses the value from the SESSION_COOKIE_PATH``
00227|         config var if it's set, and falls back to ``APPLICATION_ROOT`` or
00228|         uses ``/`` if it's `None`.
00229|         """
00230|         return app.config['SESSION_COOKIE_PATH'] or \
00231|                app.config['APPLICATION_ROOT'] or '/'
00232| 
00233|     def get_cookie_httponly(self, app):
00234|         """Returns True if the session cookie should be httponly.  This
00235|         currently just returns the value of the ``SESSION_COOKIE_HTTPONLY``
00236|         config var.
00237|         """
00238|         return app.config['SESSION_COOKIE_HTTPONLY']
00239| 
00240|     def get_cookie_secure(self, app):
00241|         """Returns True if the cookie should be secure.  This currently
00242|         just returns the value of the ``SESSION_COOKIE_SECURE`` setting.
00243|         """

00246|     def get_expiration_time(self, app, session):
00247|         """A helper method that returns an expiration date for the session
00248|         or `None` if the session is linked to the browser session.  The
00249|         default implementation returns now + the permanent session
00250|         lifetime configured on the application.
00251|         """
00252|         if session.permanent:
00253|             return datetime.utcnow() + app.permanent_session_lifetime
00254| 
00255|     def should_set_cookie(self, app, session):
00256|         """Indicates weather a cookie should be set now or not.  This is
00257|         used by session backends to figure out if they should emit a
00258|         set-cookie header or not.  The default behavior is controlled by
00259|         the ``SESSION_REFRESH_EACH_REQUEST`` config variable.  If
00260|         it's set to `False` then a cookie is only set if the session is
00261|         modified, if set to `True` it's always set if the session is
00262|         permanent.
00263| 
00264|         This check is usually skipped if sessions get deleted.
00265| 
00266|         .. versionadded:: 1.0
00267|         """
00268|         if session.modified:
00269|             return True
00270|         save_each = app.config['SESSION_REFRESH_EACH_REQUEST']
00271|         return save_each and session.permanent
00272| 
00273|     def open_session(self, app, request):
00274|         """This method has to be implemented and must either return `None`
00275|         in case the loading failed because of a configuration error or an
00276|         instance of a session object which implements a dictionary like
00277|         interface + the methods and attributes on :class:`SessionMixin`.
00278|         """
00279|         raise NotImplementedError()
00280| 
00281|     def save_session(self, app, session, response):
00282|         """This is called for actual sessions returned by :meth:`open_session`
00283|         at the end of the request.  This is still called during a request
00284|         context so if you absolutely need access to the request you can do
00285|         that.
00286|         """
00287|         raise NotImplementedError()
