00001| Templates
00002| =========
00003| 
00004| Flask leverages Jinja2 as template engine.  You are obviously free to use
00005| a different template engine, but you still have to install Jinja2 to run
00006| Flask itself.  This requirement is necessary to enable rich extensions.
00007| An extension can depend on Jinja2 being present.
00008| 
00009| This section only gives a very quick introduction into how Jinja2
00010| is integrated into Flask.  If you want information on the template
00011| engine's syntax itself, head over to the official `Jinja2 Template
00012| Documentation <http://jinja.pocoo.org/docs/templates>`_ for
00013| more information.
00014| 
00015| Jinja Setup
00016| -----------
00017| 
00018| Unless customized, Jinja2 is configured by Flask as follows:
00019| 
00020| -   autoescaping is enabled for all templates ending in ``.html``,
00021|     ``.htm``, ``.xml`` as well as ``.xhtml`` when using
00022|     :func:`~flask.templating.render_template`.
00023| -   autoescaping is enabled for all strings when using
00024|     :func:`~flask.templating.render_template_string`.
00025| -   a template has the ability to opt in/out autoescaping with the
00026|     ``{% autoescape %}`` tag.
00027| -   Flask inserts a couple of global functions and helpers into the
00028|     Jinja2 context, additionally to the values that are present by
00029|     default.
00030| 
00031| Standard Context
00032| ----------------
00033| 
00034| The following global variables are available within Jinja2 templates
00035| by default:
00036| 
00037| .. data:: config
00038|    :noindex:
00039| 
00040|    The current configuration object (:data:`flask.config`)
00041| 
00042|    .. versionadded:: 0.6
00043| 
00044|    .. versionchanged:: 0.10
00045|       This is now always available, even in imported templates.
00046| 
00047| .. data:: request
00048|    :noindex:
00049| 
00050|    The current request object (:class:`flask.request`).  This variable is
00051|    unavailable if the template was rendered without an active request
00052|    context.
00053| 
00054| .. data:: session
00055|    :noindex:
00056| 
00057|    The current session object (:class:`flask.session`).  This variable
00058|    is unavailable if the template was rendered without an active request
00059|    context.
00060| 
00061| .. data:: g
00062|    :noindex:
00063| 
00064|    The request-bound object for global variables (:data:`flask.g`).  This
00065|    variable is unavailable if the template was rendered without an active
00066|    request context.
00067| 
00068| .. function:: url_for
00069|    :noindex:
00070| 
00071|    The :func:`flask.url_for` function.
00072| 
00073| .. function:: get_flashed_messages
00074|    :noindex:
00075| 
00076|    The :func:`flask.get_flashed_messages` function.
00077| 
00078| .. admonition:: The Jinja Context Behavior
00079| 
00080|    These variables are added to the context of variables, they are not
00081|    global variables.  The difference is that by default these will not
00082|    show up in the context of imported templates.  This is partially caused
00083|    by performance considerations, partially to keep things explicit.
00084| 
00085|    What does this mean for you?  If you have a macro you want to import,
00086|    that needs to access the request object you have two possibilities:
00087| 
00088|    1.   you explicitly pass the request to the macro as parameter, or
00089|         the attribute of the request object you are interested in.
00090|    2.   you import the macro "with context".
00091| 
00092|    Importing with context looks like this:
00093| 
00094|    .. sourcecode:: jinja
00095| 
00096|       {% from '_helpers.html' import my_macro with context %}
00097| 
00098| Standard Filters
00099| ----------------
00100| 
00101| These filters are available in Jinja2 additionally to the filters provided
00102| by Jinja2 itself:
00103| 
00104| .. function:: tojson
00105|    :noindex:
00106| 
00107|    This function converts the given object into JSON representation.  This
00108|    is for example very helpful if you try to generate JavaScript on the
00109|    fly.
00110| 
00111|    Note that inside ``script`` tags no escaping must take place, so make
00112|    sure to disable escaping with ``|safe`` before Flask 0.10 if you intend
00113|    to use it inside ``script`` tags:
00114| 
00115|    .. sourcecode:: html+jinja
00116| 
00117|        <script type=text/javascript>
00118|            doSomethingWith({{ user.username|tojson|safe }});
00119|        </script>
00120| 
00121| Controlling Autoescaping
00122| ------------------------
00123| 
00124| Autoescaping is the concept of automatically escaping special characters
00125| for you.  Special characters in the sense of HTML (or XML, and thus XHTML)
00126| are ``&``, ``>``, ``<``, ``"`` as well as ``'``.  Because these characters
00127| carry specific meanings in documents on their own you have to replace them
00128| by so called "entities" if you want to use them for text.  Not doing so
00129| would not only cause user frustration by the inability to use these
00130| characters in text, but can also lead to security problems.  (see
00131| :ref:`xss`)
00132| 
00133| Sometimes however you will need to disable autoescaping in templates.
00134| This can be the case if you want to explicitly inject HTML into pages, for
00135| example if they come from a system that generates secure HTML like a
00136| markdown to HTML converter.
00137| 
00138| There are three ways to accomplish that:
00139| 
00140| -   In the Python code, wrap the HTML string in a :class:`~flask.Markup`
00141|     object before passing it to the template.  This is in general the
00142|     recommended way.
00143| -   Inside the template, use the ``|safe`` filter to explicitly mark a
00144|     string as safe HTML (``{{ myvariable|safe }}``)
00145| -   Temporarily disable the autoescape system altogether.
00146| 
00147| To disable the autoescape system in templates, you can use the ``{%
00148| autoescape %}`` block:
00149| 
00150| .. sourcecode:: html+jinja
00151| 
00152|     {% autoescape false %}
00153|         <p>autoescaping is disabled here
00154|         <p>{{ will_not_be_escaped }}
00155|     {% endautoescape %}
00156| 
00157| Whenever you do this, please be very cautious about the variables you are
00158| using in this block.
00159| 
00160| .. _registering-filters:
00161| 
00162| Registering Filters
00163| -------------------
00164| 
00165| If you want to register your own filters in Jinja2 you have two ways to do
00166| that.  You can either put them by hand into the
00167| :attr:`~flask.Flask.jinja_env` of the application or use the
00168| :meth:`~flask.Flask.template_filter` decorator.
00169| 
00170| The two following examples work the same and both reverse an object::
00171| 
00172|     @app.template_filter('reverse')
00173|     def reverse_filter(s):
00174|         return s[::-1]
00175| 
00176|     def reverse_filter(s):
00177|         return s[::-1]
00178|     app.jinja_env.filters['reverse'] = reverse_filter
00179| 
00180| In case of the decorator the argument is optional if you want to use the
00181| function name as name of the filter.  Once registered, you can use the filter
00182| in your templates in the same way as Jinja2's builtin filters, for example if
00183| you have a Python list in context called `mylist`::
00184| 
00185|     {% for x in mylist | reverse %}
00186|     {% endfor %}
00187| 
00188| 
00189| Context Processors
00190| ------------------
00191| 
00192| To inject new variables automatically into the context of a template,
00193| context processors exist in Flask.  Context processors run before the
00194| template is rendered and have the ability to inject new values into the
00195| template context.  A context processor is a function that returns a
00196| dictionary.  The keys and values of this dictionary are then merged with
00197| the template context, for all templates in the app::
00198| 
00199|     @app.context_processor
00200|     def inject_user():
00201|         return dict(user=g.user)
00202| 
00203| The context processor above makes a variable called `user` available in
00204| the template with the value of `g.user`.  This example is not very
00205| interesting because `g` is available in templates anyways, but it gives an
00206| idea how this works.
00207| 
00208| Variables are not limited to values; a context processor can also make
00209| functions available to templates (since Python allows passing around
00210| functions)::
00211| 
00212|     @app.context_processor
00213|     def utility_processor():
00214|         def format_price(amount, currency=u'€'):
00215|             return u'{0:.2f}{1}'.format(amount, currency)
00216|         return dict(format_price=format_price)
00217| 
00218| The context processor above makes the `format_price` function available to all
00219| templates::
00220| 
00221|     {{ format_price(0.33) }}
00222| 
00223| You could also build `format_price` as a template filter (see
00224| :ref:`registering-filters`), but this demonstrates how to pass functions in a
00225| context processor.
00226|

more information.

Jinja Setup
-----------

Unless customized, Jinja2 is configured by Flask as follows:

00201| .. admonition:: More on ``SERVER_NAME``
00202| 
00203|    The ``SERVER_NAME`` key is used for the subdomain support.  Because
00204|    Flask cannot guess the subdomain part without the knowledge of the
00205|    actual server name, this is required if you want to work with
00206|    subdomains.  This is also used for the session cookie.
00207| 
00208|    Please keep in mind that not only Flask has the problem of not knowing
00209|    what subdomains are, your web browser does as well.  Most modern web
00210|    browsers will not allow cross-subdomain cookies to be set on a
00211|    server name without dots in it.  So if your server name is
00212|    ``'localhost'`` you will not be able to set a cookie for
00213|    ``'localhost'`` and every subdomain of it.  Please choose a different
00214|    server name in that case, like ``'myapplication.local'`` and add
00215|    this name + the subdomains you want to use into your host config
00216|    or setup a local `bind`_.
00217| 
00218| .. _bind: https://www.isc.org/downloads/bind/
00219| 
00220| .. versionadded:: 0.4

00248| Configuring from Files
00249| ----------------------
00250| 
00251| Configuration becomes more useful if you can store it in a separate file,
00252| ideally located outside the actual application package. This makes
00253| packaging and distributing your application possible via various package
00254| handling tools (:ref:`distribute-deployment`) and finally modifying the
00255| configuration file afterwards.
00256| 
00257| So a common pattern is this::
00258| 
00259|     app = Flask(__name__)
00260|     app.config.from_object('yourapplication.default_settings')
00261|     app.config.from_envvar('YOURAPPLICATION_SETTINGS')
00262| 
00263| This first loads the configuration from the
00264| `yourapplication.default_settings` module and then overrides the values
00265| with the contents of the file the :envvar:``YOURAPPLICATION_SETTINGS``
00266| environment variable points to.  This environment variable can be set on
00267| Linux or OS X with the export command in the shell before starting the
00268| server::
00269| 
00270|     $ export YOURAPPLICATION_SETTINGS=/path/to/settings.cfg
00271|     $ python run-app.py
00272|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/
00273|      * Restarting with reloader...
00274| 
00275| On Windows systems use the `set` builtin instead::
00276| 
00277|     >set YOURAPPLICATION_SETTINGS=\path\to\settings.cfg
00278| 
00279| The configuration files themselves are actual Python files.  Only values
00280| in uppercase are actually stored in the config object later on.  So make

00344| Version 0.6
00345| -----------
00346| 
00347| Flask 0.6 comes with a backwards incompatible change which affects the
00348| order of after-request handlers.  Previously they were called in the order
00349| of the registration, now they are called in reverse order.  This change
00350| was made so that Flask behaves more like people expected it to work and
00351| how other systems handle request pre- and post-processing.  If you
00352| depend on the order of execution of post-request functions, be sure to
00353| change the order.
00354| 
00355| Another change that breaks backwards compatibility is that context
00356| processors will no longer override values passed directly to the template
00357| rendering function.  If for example `request` is as variable passed
00358| directly to the template, the default context processor will not override
00359| it with the current request object.  This makes it easier to extend
00360| context processors later to inject additional variables without breaking

00161| By default the rightmost part of the path is where it is exposed on the
00162| web.  Because the folder is called :file:`static` here it will be available at
00163| the location of the blueprint + ``/static``.  Say the blueprint is
00164| registered for ``/admin`` the static folder will be at ``/admin/static``.
00165| 
00166| The endpoint is named `blueprint_name.static` so you can generate URLs to
00167| it like you would do to the static folder of the application::
00168| 
00169|     url_for('admin.static', filename='style.css')
00170| 
00171| Templates
00172| `````````
00173| 
00174| If you want the blueprint to expose templates you can do that by providing
00175| the `template_folder` parameter to the :class:`Blueprint` constructor::
00176| 
00177|     admin = Blueprint('admin', __name__, template_folder='templates')
00178| 
00179| As for static files, the path can be absolute or relative to the blueprint
00180| resource folder.  The template folder is added to the searchpath of
00181| templates but with a lower priority than the actual application's template
00182| folder.  That way you can easily override templates that a blueprint
00183| provides in the actual application.
00184| 
00185| So if you have a blueprint in the folder ``yourapplication/admin`` and you
00186| want to render the template ``'admin/index.html'`` and you have provided
00187| ``templates`` as a `template_folder` you will have to create a file like
00188| this: :file:`yourapplication/admin/templates/admin/index.html`.
00189| 
00190| To further reiterate this: if you have a blueprint named ``admin`` and you
00191| want to render a template called :file:`index.html` which is specific to this
00192| blueprint, the best idea is to lay out your templates like this::
00193| 
00194|     yourpackage/
00195|         blueprints/
00196|             admin/
00197|                 templates/
00198|                     admin/
00199|                         index.html
00200|                 __init__.py
00201| 
00202| And then when you want to render the template, use :file:`admin/index.html` as
00203| the name to look up the template by.  If you encounter problems loading
00204| the correct templates enable the ``EXPLAIN_TEMPLATE_LOADING`` config
00205| variable which will instruct Flask to print out the steps it goes through
00206| to locate templates on every ``render_template`` call.
00207| 
00208| Building URLs
00209| -------------
00210| 
00211| If you want to link from one page to another you can use the
00212| :func:`url_for` function just like you normally would do just that you
00213| prefix the URL endpoint with the name of the blueprint and a dot (``.``)::
00214| 
00215|     url_for('admin.index')
00216| 
00217| Additionally if you are in a view function of a blueprint or a rendered
00218| template and you want to link to another endpoint of the same blueprint,
00219| you can use relative redirects by prefixing the endpoint with a dot only::
00220| 
00221|     url_for('.index')
00222| 
00223| This will link to ``admin.index`` for instance in case the current request
00224| was dispatched to any other admin blueprint endpoint.
00225| 
00226| Error Handlers
00227| --------------
00228| 
00229| Blueprints support the errorhandler decorator just like the :class:`Flask`
00230| application object, so it is easy to make Blueprint-specific custom error

00002| 
00003| Quickstart
00004| ==========
00005| 
00006| Eager to get started?  This page gives a good introduction to Flask.  It
00007| assumes you already have Flask installed.  If you do not, head over to the
00008| :ref:`installation` section.
00009| 
00010| 
00011| A Minimal Application
00012| ---------------------
00013| 
00014| A minimal Flask application looks something like this::
00015| 
00016|     from flask import Flask
00017|     app = Flask(__name__)
00018| 
00019|     @app.route('/')
00020|     def hello_world():
00021|         return 'Hello, World!'
00022| 
00023| So what did that code do?
00024| 
00025| 1. First we imported the :class:`~flask.Flask` class.  An instance of this
00026|    class will be our WSGI application.
00027| 2. Next we create an instance of this class. The first argument is the name of
00028|    the application's module or package.  If you are using a single module (as
00029|    in this example), you should use `__name__` because depending on if it's
00030|    started as application or imported as module the name will be different
00031|    (``'__main__'`` versus the actual import name). This is needed so that
00032|    Flask knows where to look for templates, static files, and so on. For more
00033|    information have a look at the :class:`~flask.Flask` documentation.
00034| 3. We then use the :meth:`~flask.Flask.route` decorator to tell Flask what URL
00035|    should trigger our function.
00036| 4. The function is given a name which is also used to generate URLs for that
00037|    particular function, and returns the message we want to display in the
00038|    user's browser.
00039| 
00040| Just save it as :file:`hello.py` or something similar. Make sure to not call
00041| your application :file:`flask.py` because this would conflict with Flask
00042| itself.
00043| 
00044| To run the application you can either use the :command:`flask` command or
00045| python's :option:`-m` switch with Flask.  Before you can do that you need
00046| to tell your terminal the application to work with by exporting the
00047| `FLASK_APP` environment variable::
00048| 
00049|     $ export FLASK_APP=hello.py
00050|     $ flask run
00051|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/
00052| 
00053| If you are on Windows you need to use `set` instead of `export`.
00054| 
00055| Alternatively you can use `python -m flask`::
00056| 
00057|     $ export FLASK_APP=hello.py
00058|     $ python -m flask run
00059|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/
00060| 
00061| This launches a very simple builtin server, which is good enough for testing
00062| but probably not what you want to use in production. For deployment options see
00063| :ref:`deployment`.
00064| 
00065| Now head over to `http://127.0.0.1:5000/ <http://127.0.0.1:5000/>`_, and you
00066| should see your hello world greeting.
00067| 
00068| .. _public-server:
00069| 
00070| .. admonition:: Externally Visible Server
00071| 
00072|    If you run the server you will notice that the server is only accessible
00073|    from your own computer, not from any other in the network.  This is the
00074|    default because in debugging mode a user of the application can execute
00075|    arbitrary Python code on your computer.
00076| 
00077|    If you have the debugger disabled or trust the users on your network,
00078|    you can make the server publicly available simply by adding
00079|    ``--host=0.0.0.0`` to the command line::
00080| 
00081|        flask run --host=0.0.0.0
00082| 
00083|    This tells your operating system to listen on all public IPs.
00084| 
00085| 
00086| What to do if the Server does not Start
00087| ---------------------------------------
00088| 
00089| In case the ``python -m flask`` fails or :command:`flask` does not exist,
00090| there are multiple reasons this might be the case.  First of all you need
00091| to look at the error message.
00092| 
00093| Old Version of Flask
00094| ````````````````````
00095| 
00096| Versions of Flask older than 0.11 use to have different ways to start the
00097| application.  In short, the :command:`flask` command did not exist, and
00098| neither did ``python -m flask``.  In that case you have two options:
00099| either upgrade to newer Flask versions or have a look at the :ref:`server`
00100| docs to see the alternative method for running a server.
00101| 
00102| Invalid Import Name
00103| ```````````````````
00104| 
00105| The :option:`-a` argument to :command:`flask` is the name of the module to
00106| import.  In case that module is incorrectly named you will get an import
00107| error upon start (or if debug is enabled when you navigate to the
00108| application).  It will tell you what it tried to import and why it failed.
00109| 
00110| The most common reason is a typo or because you did not actually create an
00111| ``app`` object.
00112| 
00113| .. _debug-mode:
00114| 
00115| Debug Mode
00116| ----------
00117| 
00118| (Want to just log errors and stack traces? See :ref:`application-errors`)
00119| 
00120| The :command:`flask` script is nice to start a local development server, but
00121| you would have to restart it manually after each change to your code.
00122| That is not very nice and Flask can do better.  If you enable debug
00123| support the server will reload itself on code changes, and it will also
00124| provide you with a helpful debugger if things go wrong.
00125| 
00126| To enable debug mode you can export the `FLASK_DEBUG` environment variable
00127| before running the server::
00128| 
00129|     $ export FLASK_DEBUG=1
00130|     $ flask run
00131| 
00132| (On Windows you need to use `set` instead of `export`).
00133| 
00134| This does the following things:
00135| 
00136| 1.  it activates the debugger
00137| 2.  it activates the automatic reloader
00138| 3.  it enables the debug mode on the Flask application.
00139| 
00140| There are more parameters that are explained in the :ref:`server` docs.
00141| 
00142| .. admonition:: Attention
00143| 
00144|    Even though the interactive debugger does not work in forking environments
00145|    (which makes it nearly impossible to use on production servers), it still
00146|    allows the execution of arbitrary code. This makes it a major security risk
00147|    and therefore it **must never be used on production machines**.
00148| 
00149| Screenshot of the debugger in action:
00150| 
00151| .. image:: _static/debugger.png
00152|    :align: center
00153|    :class: screenshot
00154|    :alt: screenshot of debugger in action
00155| 
00156| Have another debugger in mind? See :ref:`working-with-debuggers`.
00157| 
00158| 
00159| Routing
00160| -------
00161| 
00162| Modern web applications have beautiful URLs.  This helps people remember
00163| the URLs, which is especially handy for applications that are used from
00164| mobile devices with slower network connections.  If the user can directly
00165| go to the desired page without having to hit the index page it is more
00166| likely they will like the page and come back next time.
00167| 
00168| As you have seen above, the :meth:`~flask.Flask.route` decorator is used to
00169| bind a function to a URL.  Here are some basic examples::
00170| 
00171|     @app.route('/')
00172|     def index():
00173|         return 'Index Page'
00174| 
00175|     @app.route('/hello')
00176|     def hello():
00177|         return 'Hello, World'
00178| 
00179| But there is more to it!  You can make certain parts of the URL dynamic and
00180| attach multiple rules to a function.
00181| 
00182| Variable Rules
00183| ``````````````
00184| 
00185| To add variable parts to a URL you can mark these special sections as
00186| ``<variable_name>``.  Such a part is then passed as a keyword argument to your
00187| function.  Optionally a converter can be used by specifying a rule with
00188| ``<converter:variable_name>``.  Here are some nice examples::
00189| 
00190|     @app.route('/user/<username>')
00191|     def show_user_profile(username):
00192|         # show the user profile for that user
00193|         return 'User %s' % username
00194| 
00195|     @app.route('/post/<int:post_id>')
00196|     def show_post(post_id):
00197|         # show the post with the given id, the id is an integer
00198|         return 'Post %d' % post_id
00199| 
00200| The following converters exist:
00201| 
00202| =========== ===============================================
00203| `string`    accepts any text without a slash (the default)
00204| `int`       accepts integers
00205| `float`     like `int` but for floating point values
00206| `path`      like the default but also accepts slashes
00207| `any`       matches one of the items provided
00208| `uuid`      accepts UUID strings
00209| =========== ===============================================
00210| 
00211| .. admonition:: Unique URLs / Redirection Behavior
00212| 
00213|    Flask's URL rules are based on Werkzeug's routing module.  The idea
00214|    behind that module is to ensure beautiful and unique URLs based on
00215|    precedents laid down by Apache and earlier HTTP servers.
00216| 
00217|    Take these two rules::
00218| 
00219|         @app.route('/projects/')
00220|         def projects():
00221|             return 'The project page'

00003|     flask.config
00004|     ~~~~~~~~~~~~
00005| 
00006|     Implements the configuration related objects.
00007| 
00008|     :copyright: (c) 2015 by Armin Ronacher.

00012| import os
00013| import types
00014| import errno

00016| from werkzeug.utils import import_string
00017| from ._compat import string_types, iteritems
00018| from . import json
00019| 
00020| 
00021| class ConfigAttribute(object):
00022|     """Makes an attribute forward to the config"""
00023| 
00024|     def __init__(self, name, get_converter=None):
00025|         self.__name__ = name
00026|         self.get_converter = get_converter
00027| 
00028|     def __get__(self, obj, type=None):
00029|         if obj is None:
00030|             return self
00031|         rv = obj.config[self.__name__]
00032|         if self.get_converter is not None:
00033|             rv = self.get_converter(rv)
00034|         return rv
00035| 
00036|     def __set__(self, obj, value):
00037|         obj.config[self.__name__] = value
00038| 
00039| 
00040| class Config(dict):
00041|     """Works exactly like a dict but provides ways to fill it from files
00042|     or special dictionaries.  There are two common patterns to populate the
00043|     config.
00044| 
00045|     Either you can fill the config from a config file::
00046| 
00047|         app.config.from_pyfile('yourconfig.cfg')
00048| 
00049|     Or alternatively you can define the configuration options in the
00050|     module that calls :meth:`from_object` or provide an import path to
00051|     a module that should be loaded.  It is also possible to tell it to
00052|     use the same module and with that provide the configuration values
00053|     just before the call::
00054| 
00055|         DEBUG = True
00056|         SECRET_KEY = 'development key'
00057|         app.config.from_object(__name__)
00058| 
00059|     In both cases (loading from any Python file or loading from modules),
00060|     only uppercase keys are added to the config.  This makes it possible to use
00061|     lowercase values in the config file for temporary values that are not added
00062|     to the config or to define the config keys in the same file that implements
00063|     the application.
00064| 
00065|     Probably the most interesting way to load configurations is from an
00066|     environment variable pointing to a file::
00067| 
00068|         app.config.from_envvar('YOURAPPLICATION_SETTINGS')
00069| 
00070|     In this case before launching the application you have to set this
00071|     environment variable to the file you want to use.  On Linux and OS X
00072|     use the export statement::
00073| 
00074|         export YOURAPPLICATION_SETTINGS='/path/to/config/file'
00075| 
00076|     On windows use `set` instead.
00077| 
00078|     :param root_path: path to which files are read relative from.  When the
00079|                       config object is created by the application, this is
00080|                       the application's :attr:`~flask.Flask.root_path`.
00081|     :param defaults: an optional dictionary of default values
00082|     """
00083| 
00084|     def __init__(self, root_path, defaults=None):
00085|         dict.__init__(self, defaults or {})
00086|         self.root_path = root_path
00087| 
00088|     def from_envvar(self, variable_name, silent=False):
00089|         """Loads a configuration from an environment variable pointing to
00090|         a configuration file.  This is basically just a shortcut with nicer
00091|         error messages for this line of code::
00092| 
00093|             app.config.from_pyfile(os.environ['YOURAPPLICATION_SETTINGS'])
00094| 
00095|         :param variable_name: name of the environment variable
00096|         :param silent: set to ``True`` if you want silent failure for missing
00097|                        files.
00098|         :return: bool. ``True`` if able to load config, ``False`` otherwise.
00099|         """
00100|         rv = os.environ.get(variable_name)
00101|         if not rv:
00102|             if silent:
00103|                 return False
00104|             raise RuntimeError('The environment variable %r is not set '
00105|                                'and as such configuration could not be '
00106|                                'loaded.  Set this variable and make it '
00107|                                'point to a configuration file' %
00108|                                variable_name)
00109|         return self.from_pyfile(rv, silent=silent)
00110| 
00111|     def from_pyfile(self, filename, silent=False):
00112|         """Updates the values in the config from a Python file.  This function
00113|         behaves as if the file was imported as module with the
00114|         :meth:`from_object` function.
00115| 
00116|         :param filename: the filename of the config.  This can either be an
00117|                          absolute filename or a filename relative to the
00118|                          root path.
00119|         :param silent: set to ``True`` if you want silent failure for missing
00120|                        files.
00121| 
00122|         .. versionadded:: 0.7
00123|            `silent` parameter.
00124|         """
00125|         filename = os.path.join(self.root_path, filename)
00126|         d = types.ModuleType('config')
00127|         d.__file__ = filename
00128|         try:
00129|             with open(filename) as config_file:
00130|                 exec(compile(config_file.read(), filename, 'exec'), d.__dict__)
00131|         except IOError as e:
00132|             if silent and e.errno in (errno.ENOENT, errno.EISDIR):
00133|                 return False
00134|             e.strerror = 'Unable to load configuration file (%s)' % e.strerror
00135|             raise
00136|         self.from_object(d)
00137|         return True
00138| 
00139|     def from_object(self, obj):
00140|         """Updates the values from the given object.  An object can be of one
00141|         of the following two types:
00142| 
00143|         -   a string: in this case the object with that name will be imported
00144|         -   an actual object reference: that object is used directly
00145| 
00146|         Objects are usually either modules or classes. :meth:`from_object`
00147|         loads only the uppercase attributes of the module/class. A ``dict``
00148|         object will not work with :meth:`from_object` because the keys of a
00149|         ``dict`` are not attributes of the ``dict`` class.
00150| 
00151|         Example of module-based configuration::
00152| 
00153|             app.config.from_object('yourapplication.default_config')
00154|             from yourapplication import default_config
00155|             app.config.from_object(default_config)
00156| 
00157|         You should not use this function to load the actual configuration but
00158|         rather configuration defaults.  The actual config should be loaded
00159|         with :meth:`from_pyfile` and ideally from a location not within the
00160|         package because the package might be installed system wide.
00161| 
00162|         See :ref:`config-dev-prod` for an example of class-based configuration
00163|         using :meth:`from_object`.
00164| 
00165|         :param obj: an import name or object
00166|         """
00167|         if isinstance(obj, string_types):
00168|             obj = import_string(obj)
00169|         for key in dir(obj):
00170|             if key.isupper():
00171|                 self[key] = getattr(obj, key)
00172| 
00173|     def from_json(self, filename, silent=False):
00174|         """Updates the values in the config from a JSON file. This function
00175|         behaves as if the JSON object was a dictionary and passed to the
00176|         :meth:`from_mapping` function.
00177| 
00178|         :param filename: the filename of the JSON file.  This can either be an
00179|                          absolute filename or a filename relative to the
00180|                          root path.
00181|         :param silent: set to ``True`` if you want silent failure for missing
00182|                        files.
00183| 
00184|         .. versionadded:: 0.11
00185|         """
00186|         filename = os.path.join(self.root_path, filename)
00187| 
00188|         try:
00189|             with open(filename) as json_file:
00190|                 obj = json.loads(json_file.read())
00191|         except IOError as e:
00192|             if silent and e.errno in (errno.ENOENT, errno.EISDIR):
00193|                 return False
00194|             e.strerror = 'Unable to load configuration file (%s)' % e.strerror
00195|             raise
00196|         return self.from_mapping(obj)
00197| 
00198|     def from_mapping(self, *mapping, **kwargs):
00199|         """Updates the config like :meth:`update` ignoring items with non-upper
00200|         keys.
00201| 
00202|         .. versionadded:: 0.11
00203|         """
00204|         mappings = []
00205|         if len(mapping) == 1:
00206|             if hasattr(mapping[0], 'items'):
00207|                 mappings.append(mapping[0].items())
00208|             else:
00209|                 mappings.append(mapping[0])
00210|         elif len(mapping) > 1:
00211|             raise TypeError(
00212|                 'expected at most 1 positional argument, got %d' % len(mapping)
00213|             )
00214|         mappings.append(kwargs.items())
00215|         for mapping in mappings:
00216|             for (key, value) in mapping:
00217|                 if key.isupper():
00218|                     self[key] = value
00219|         return True
00220| 
00221|     def get_namespace(self, namespace, lowercase=True, trim_namespace=True):
00222|         """Returns a dictionary containing a subset of configuration options
00223|         that match the specified namespace/prefix. Example usage::
00224| 
00225|             app.config['IMAGE_STORE_TYPE'] = 'fs'
00226|             app.config['IMAGE_STORE_PATH'] = '/var/app/images'
00227|             app.config['IMAGE_STORE_BASE_URL'] = 'http://img.website.com'
00228|             image_store_config = app.config.get_namespace('IMAGE_STORE_')
00229| 
00230|         The resulting dictionary `image_store_config` would look like::
00231| 
00232|             {
00233|                 'type': 'fs',
00234|                 'path': '/var/app/images',
00235|                 'base_url': 'http://img.website.com'
00236|             }
00237| 
00238|         This is often useful when configuration options map directly to
00239|         keyword arguments in functions or class constructors.
00240| 
00241|         :param namespace: a configuration namespace
00242|         :param lowercase: a flag indicating if the keys of the resulting
00243|                           dictionary should be lowercase
00244|         :param trim_namespace: a flag indicating if the keys of the resulting
00245|                           dictionary should not include the namespace
00246| 
00247|         .. versionadded:: 0.11
00248|         """
00249|         rv = {}
00250|         for k, v in iteritems(self):
00251|             if not k.startswith(namespace):
00252|                 continue
00253|             if trim_namespace:
00254|                 key = k[len(namespace):]
00255|             else:
00256|                 key = k
00257|             if lowercase:
00258|                 key = key.lower()
00259|             rv[key] = v
00260|         return rv
00261| 
00262|     def __repr__(self):
00263|         return '<%s %s>' % (self.__class__.__name__, dict.__repr__(self))
00264|

00001| .. _config:
00002| 
00003| Configuration Handling
00004| ======================
00005| 
00006| .. versionadded:: 0.3
00007| 
00008| Applications need some kind of configuration.  There are different settings
00009| you might want to change depending on the application environment like
00010| toggling the debug mode, setting the secret key, and other such
00011| environment-specific things.
00012| 
00013| The way Flask is designed usually requires the configuration to be
00014| available when the application starts up.  You can hardcode the
00015| configuration in the code, which for many small applications is not
00016| actually that bad, but there are better ways.
00017| 
00018| Independent of how you load your config, there is a config object
00019| available which holds the loaded configuration values:
00020| The :attr:`~flask.Flask.config` attribute of the :class:`~flask.Flask`
00021| object.  This is the place where Flask itself puts certain configuration
00022| values and also where extensions can put their configuration values.  But
00023| this is also where you can have your own configuration.
00024| 
00025| Configuration Basics
00026| --------------------
00027| 
00028| The :attr:`~flask.Flask.config` is actually a subclass of a dictionary and
00029| can be modified just like any dictionary::
00030| 
00031|     app = Flask(__name__)
00032|     app.config['DEBUG'] = True
00033| 
00034| Certain configuration values are also forwarded to the
00035| :attr:`~flask.Flask` object so you can read and write them from there::
00036| 
00037|     app.debug = True
00038| 
00039| To update multiple keys at once you can use the :meth:`dict.update`
00040| method::
00041| 
00042|     app.config.update(
00043|         DEBUG=True,
00044|         SECRET_KEY='...'
00045|     )
00046| 
00047| Builtin Configuration Values
00048| ----------------------------
00049| 
00050| The following configuration values are used internally by Flask:
00051| 
00052| .. tabularcolumns:: |p{6.5cm}|p{8.5cm}|
00053| 
00054| ================================= =========================================
00055| ``DEBUG``                         enable/disable debug mode
00056| ``TESTING``                       enable/disable testing mode
00057| ``PROPAGATE_EXCEPTIONS``          explicitly enable or disable the
00058|                                   propagation of exceptions.  If not set or
00059|                                   explicitly set to ``None`` this is
00060|                                   implicitly true if either ``TESTING`` or
00061|                                   ``DEBUG`` is true.
00062| ``PRESERVE_CONTEXT_ON_EXCEPTION`` By default if the application is in
00063|                                   debug mode the request context is not
00064|                                   popped on exceptions to enable debuggers
00065|                                   to introspect the data.  This can be
00066|                                   disabled by this key.  You can also use
00067|                                   this setting to force-enable it for non
00068|                                   debug execution which might be useful to
00069|                                   debug production applications (but also
00070|                                   very risky).
00071| ``SECRET_KEY``                    the secret key
00072| ``SESSION_COOKIE_NAME``           the name of the session cookie
00073| ``SESSION_COOKIE_DOMAIN``         the domain for the session cookie.  If
00074|                                   this is not set, the cookie will be
00075|                                   valid for all subdomains of
00076|                                   ``SERVER_NAME``.
00077| ``SESSION_COOKIE_PATH``           the path for the session cookie.  If
00078|                                   this is not set the cookie will be valid
00079|                                   for all of ``APPLICATION_ROOT`` or if
00080|                                   that is not set for ``'/'``.
00081| ``SESSION_COOKIE_HTTPONLY``       controls if the cookie should be set
00082|                                   with the httponly flag.  Defaults to
00083|                                   ``True``.
00084| ``SESSION_COOKIE_SECURE``         controls if the cookie should be set
00085|                                   with the secure flag.  Defaults to
00086|                                   ``False``.
00087| ``PERMANENT_SESSION_LIFETIME``    the lifetime of a permanent session as
00088|                                   :class:`datetime.timedelta` object.
00089|                                   Starting with Flask 0.8 this can also be
00090|                                   an integer representing seconds.
00091| ``SESSION_REFRESH_EACH_REQUEST``  this flag controls how permanent
00092|                                   sessions are refreshed.  If set to ``True``
00093|                                   (which is the default) then the cookie
00094|                                   is refreshed each request which
00095|                                   automatically bumps the lifetime.  If
00096|                                   set to ``False`` a `set-cookie` header is
00097|                                   only sent if the session is modified.
00098|                                   Non permanent sessions are not affected
00099|                                   by this.
00100| ``USE_X_SENDFILE``                enable/disable x-sendfile
00101| ``LOGGER_NAME``                   the name of the logger
00102| ``LOGGER_HANDLER_POLICY``         the policy of the default logging
00103|                                   handler.  The default is ``'always'``
00104|                                   which means that the default logging
00105|                                   handler is always active.  ``'debug'``
00106|                                   will only activate logging in debug
00107|                                   mode, ``'production'`` will only log in
00108|                                   production and ``'never'`` disables it
00109|                                   entirely.
00110| ``SERVER_NAME``                   the name and port number of the server.
00111|                                   Required for subdomain support (e.g.:
00112|                                   ``'myapp.dev:5000'``)  Note that
00113|                                   localhost does not support subdomains so
00114|                                   setting this to “localhost” does not
00115|                                   help.  Setting a ``SERVER_NAME`` also
00116|                                   by default enables URL generation
00117|                                   without a request context but with an
00118|                                   application context.
00119| ``APPLICATION_ROOT``              If the application does not occupy
00120|                                   a whole domain or subdomain this can
00121|                                   be set to the path where the application
00122|                                   is configured to live.  This is for
00123|                                   session cookie as path value.  If
00124|                                   domains are used, this should be
00125|                                   ``None``.
00126| ``MAX_CONTENT_LENGTH``            If set to a value in bytes, Flask will
00127|                                   reject incoming requests with a
00128|                                   content length greater than this by
00129|                                   returning a 413 status code.
00130| ``SEND_FILE_MAX_AGE_DEFAULT``     Default cache control max age to use with
00131|                                   :meth:`~flask.Flask.send_static_file` (the
00132|                                   default static file handler) and
00133|                                   :func:`~flask.send_file`, as
00134|                                   :class:`datetime.timedelta` or as seconds.
00135|                                   Override this value on a per-file
00136|                                   basis using the
00137|                                   :meth:`~flask.Flask.get_send_file_max_age`
00138|                                   hook on :class:`~flask.Flask` or
00139|                                   :class:`~flask.Blueprint`,
00140|                                   respectively. Defaults to 43200 (12 hours).
00141| ``TRAP_HTTP_EXCEPTIONS``          If this is set to ``True`` Flask will
00142|                                   not execute the error handlers of HTTP
00143|                                   exceptions but instead treat the
00144|                                   exception like any other and bubble it
00145|                                   through the exception stack.  This is
00146|                                   helpful for hairy debugging situations
00147|                                   where you have to find out where an HTTP
00148|                                   exception is coming from.
00149| ``TRAP_BAD_REQUEST_ERRORS``       Werkzeug's internal data structures that
00150|                                   deal with request specific data will
00151|                                   raise special key errors that are also
00152|                                   bad request exceptions.  Likewise many
00153|                                   operations can implicitly fail with a
00154|                                   BadRequest exception for consistency.
00155|                                   Since it's nice for debugging to know
00156|                                   why exactly it failed this flag can be
00157|                                   used to debug those situations.  If this
00158|                                   config is set to ``True`` you will get
00159|                                   a regular traceback instead.
00160| ``PREFERRED_URL_SCHEME``          The URL scheme that should be used for
00161|                                   URL generation if no URL scheme is
00162|                                   available.  This defaults to ``http``.
00163| ``JSON_AS_ASCII``                 By default Flask serialize object to
00164|                                   ascii-encoded JSON.  If this is set to
00165|                                   ``False`` Flask will not encode to ASCII
00166|                                   and output strings as-is and return
00167|                                   unicode strings.  ``jsonify`` will
00168|                                   automatically encode it in ``utf-8``
00169|                                   then for transport for instance.
00170| ``JSON_SORT_KEYS``                By default Flask will serialize JSON
00171|                                   objects in a way that the keys are
00172|                                   ordered.  This is done in order to
00173|                                   ensure that independent of the hash seed
00174|                                   of the dictionary the return value will
00175|                                   be consistent to not trash external HTTP
00176|                                   caches.  You can override the default
00177|                                   behavior by changing this variable.
00178|                                   This is not recommended but might give
00179|                                   you a performance improvement on the
00180|                                   cost of cacheability.
00181| ``JSONIFY_PRETTYPRINT_REGULAR``   If this is set to ``True`` (the default)
00182|                                   jsonify responses will be pretty printed
00183|                                   if they are not requested by an
00184|                                   XMLHttpRequest object (controlled by
00185|                                   the ``X-Requested-With`` header)
00186| ``JSONIFY_MIMETYPE``              MIME type used for jsonify responses.
00187| ``TEMPLATES_AUTO_RELOAD``         Whether to check for modifications of
00188|                                   the template source and reload it
00189|                                   automatically. By default the value is
00190|                                   ``None`` which means that Flask checks
00191|                                   original file only in debug mode.
00192| ``EXPLAIN_TEMPLATE_LOADING``      If this is enabled then every attempt to
00193|                                   load a template will write an info
00194|                                   message to the logger explaining the
00195|                                   attempts to locate the template.  This
00196|                                   can be useful to figure out why
00197|                                   templates cannot be found or wrong
00198|                                   templates appear to be loaded.
00199| ================================= =========================================
00200| 
00201| .. admonition:: More on ``SERVER_NAME``
00202| 
00203|    The ``SERVER_NAME`` key is used for the subdomain support.  Because
00204|    Flask cannot guess the subdomain part without the knowledge of the
00205|    actual server name, this is required if you want to work with
00206|    subdomains.  This is also used for the session cookie.
00207| 
00208|    Please keep in mind that not only Flask has the problem of not knowing
00209|    what subdomains are, your web browser does as well.  Most modern web
00210|    browsers will not allow cross-subdomain cookies to be set on a
00211|    server name without dots in it.  So if your server name is
00212|    ``'localhost'`` you will not be able to set a cookie for
00213|    ``'localhost'`` and every subdomain of it.  Please choose a different
00214|    server name in that case, like ``'myapplication.local'`` and add
00215|    this name + the subdomains you want to use into your host config
00216|    or setup a local `bind`_.
00217| 
00218| .. _bind: https://www.isc.org/downloads/bind/
00219| 
00220| .. versionadded:: 0.4

00001| .. _api:
00002| 
00003| API
00004| ===
00005| 
00006| .. module:: flask
00007| 
00008| This part of the documentation covers all the interfaces of Flask.  For
00009| parts where Flask depends on external libraries, we document the most
00010| important right here and provide links to the canonical documentation.
00011| 
00012| 
00013| Application Object
00014| ------------------
00015| 
00016| .. autoclass:: Flask
00017|    :members:
00018|    :inherited-members:
00019| 
00020| 
00021| Blueprint Objects
00022| -----------------
00023| 
00024| .. autoclass:: Blueprint
00025|    :members:
00026|    :inherited-members:
00027| 
00028| Incoming Request Data
00029| ---------------------
00030| 
00031| .. autoclass:: Request
00032|    :members:
00033| 
00034|    .. attribute:: form
00035| 
00036|       A :class:`~werkzeug.datastructures.MultiDict` with the parsed form data from ``POST``
00037|       or ``PUT`` requests.  Please keep in mind that file uploads will not
00038|       end up here,  but instead in the :attr:`files` attribute.
00039| 
00040|    .. attribute:: args
00041| 
00042|       A :class:`~werkzeug.datastructures.MultiDict` with the parsed contents of the query
00043|       string.  (The part in the URL after the question mark).
00044| 
00045|    .. attribute:: values
00046| 
00047|       A :class:`~werkzeug.datastructures.CombinedMultiDict` with the contents of both
00048|       :attr:`form` and :attr:`args`.
00049| 
00050|    .. attribute:: cookies
00051| 
00052|       A :class:`dict` with the contents of all cookies transmitted with
00053|       the request.
00054| 
00055|    .. attribute:: stream
00056| 
00057|       If the incoming form data was not encoded with a known mimetype
00058|       the data is stored unmodified in this stream for consumption.  Most
00059|       of the time it is a better idea to use :attr:`data` which will give
00060|       you that data as a string.  The stream only returns the data once.
00061| 
00062|    .. attribute:: headers
00063| 
00064|       The incoming request headers as a dictionary like object.
00065| 
00066|    .. attribute:: data
00067| 
00068|       Contains the incoming request data as string in case it came with
00069|       a mimetype Flask does not handle.
00070| 
00071|    .. attribute:: files
00072| 
00073|       A :class:`~werkzeug.datastructures.MultiDict` with files uploaded as part of a
00074|       ``POST`` or ``PUT`` request.  Each file is stored as
00075|       :class:`~werkzeug.datastructures.FileStorage` object.  It basically behaves like a
00076|       standard file object you know from Python, with the difference that
00077|       it also has a :meth:`~werkzeug.datastructures.FileStorage.save` function that can
00078|       store the file on the filesystem.
00079| 
00080|    .. attribute:: environ
00081| 
00082|       The underlying WSGI environment.
00083| 
00084|    .. attribute:: method
00085| 
00086|       The current request method (``POST``, ``GET`` etc.)
00087| 
00088|    .. attribute:: path
00089|    .. attribute:: full_path
00090|    .. attribute:: script_root
00091|    .. attribute:: url
00092|    .. attribute:: base_url
00093|    .. attribute:: url_root
00094| 
00095|       Provides different ways to look at the current `IRI
00096|       <http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3987>`_.  Imagine your application is
00097|       listening on the following application root::
00098| 
00099|           http://www.example.com/myapplication
00100| 
00101|       And a user requests the following URI::
00102| 
00103|           http://www.example.com/myapplication/%CF%80/page.html?x=y
00104| 
00105|       In this case the values of the above mentioned attributes would be
00106|       the following:
00107| 
00108|       ============= ======================================================
00109|       `path`        ``u'/π/page.html'``
00110|       `full_path`   ``u'/π/page.html?x=y'``
00111|       `script_root` ``u'/myapplication'``
00112|       `base_url`    ``u'http://www.example.com/myapplication/π/page.html'``
00113|       `url`         ``u'http://www.example.com/myapplication/π/page.html?x=y'``
00114|       `url_root`    ``u'http://www.example.com/myapplication/'``
00115|       ============= ======================================================
00116| 
00117|    .. attribute:: is_xhr
00118| 
00119|       ``True`` if the request was triggered via a JavaScript
00120|       `XMLHttpRequest`. This only works with libraries that support the
00121|       ``X-Requested-With`` header and set it to `XMLHttpRequest`.
00122|       Libraries that do that are prototype, jQuery and Mochikit and
00123|       probably some more.
00124| 
00125| .. class:: request
00126| 
00127|    To access incoming request data, you can use the global `request`
00128|    object.  Flask parses incoming request data for you and gives you
00129|    access to it through that global object.  Internally Flask makes
00130|    sure that you always get the correct data for the active thread if you
00131|    are in a multithreaded environment.
00132| 
00133|    This is a proxy.  See :ref:`notes-on-proxies` for more information.
00134| 
00135|    The request object is an instance of a :class:`~werkzeug.wrappers.Request`
00136|    subclass and provides all of the attributes Werkzeug defines.  This
00137|    just shows a quick overview of the most important ones.
00138| 
00139| 
00140| Response Objects
00141| ----------------
00142| 
00143| .. autoclass:: flask.Response
00144|    :members: set_cookie, data, mimetype
00145| 
00146|    .. attribute:: headers
00147| 
00148|       A :class:`~werkzeug.datastructures.Headers` object representing the response headers.
00149| 
00150|    .. attribute:: status
00151| 
00152|       A string with a response status.
00153| 
00154|    .. attribute:: status_code
00155| 
00156|       The response status as integer.
00157| 
00158| 
00159| Sessions
00160| --------
00161| 
00162| If you have the :attr:`Flask.secret_key` set you can use sessions in Flask
00163| applications.  A session basically makes it possible to remember
00164| information from one request to another.  The way Flask does this is by
00165| using a signed cookie.  So the user can look at the session contents, but
00166| not modify it unless they know the secret key, so make sure to set that
00167| to something complex and unguessable.
00168| 
00169| To access the current session you can use the :class:`session` object:
00170| 
00171| .. class:: session
00172| 
00173|    The session object works pretty much like an ordinary dict, with the
00174|    difference that it keeps track on modifications.
00175| 
00176|    This is a proxy.  See :ref:`notes-on-proxies` for more information.
00177| 
00178|    The following attributes are interesting:
00179| 
00180|    .. attribute:: new
00181| 
00182|       ``True`` if the session is new, ``False`` otherwise.
00183| 
00184|    .. attribute:: modified
00185| 
00186|       ``True`` if the session object detected a modification.  Be advised
00187|       that modifications on mutable structures are not picked up
00188|       automatically, in that situation you have to explicitly set the
00189|       attribute to ``True`` yourself.  Here an example::
00190| 
00191|           # this change is not picked up because a mutable object (here
00192|           # a list) is changed.
00193|           session['objects'].append(42)
00194|           # so mark it as modified yourself
00195|           session.modified = True
00196| 
00197|    .. attribute:: permanent
00198| 
00199|       If set to ``True`` the session lives for
00200|       :attr:`~flask.Flask.permanent_session_lifetime` seconds.  The
00201|       default is 31 days.  If set to ``False`` (which is the default) the
00202|       session will be deleted when the user closes the browser.
00203| 
00204| 
00205| Session Interface
00206| -----------------
00207| 
00208| .. versionadded:: 0.8
00209| 
00210| The session interface provides a simple way to replace the session
00211| implementation that Flask is using.
00212| 
00213| .. currentmodule:: flask.sessions
00214| 
00215| .. autoclass:: SessionInterface
00216|    :members:
00217| 
00218| .. autoclass:: SecureCookieSessionInterface
00219|    :members:
00220|

00001| Unicode in Flask
00002| ================
00003| 
00004| Flask, like Jinja2 and Werkzeug, is totally Unicode based when it comes to
00005| text.  Not only these libraries, also the majority of web related Python
00006| libraries that deal with text.  If you don't know Unicode so far, you
00007| should probably read `The Absolute Minimum Every Software Developer
00008| Absolutely, Positively Must Know About Unicode and Character Sets
00009| <http://www.joelonsoftware.com/articles/Unicode.html>`_.  This part of the
00010| documentation just tries to cover the very basics so that you have a
00011| pleasant experience with Unicode related things.
00012| 
00013| Automatic Conversion
00014| --------------------
00015| 
00016| Flask has a few assumptions about your application (which you can change
00017| of course) that give you basic and painless Unicode support:
00018| 
00019| -   the encoding for text on your website is UTF-8
00020| -   internally you will always use Unicode exclusively for text except
00021|     for literal strings with only ASCII character points.
00022| -   encoding and decoding happens whenever you are talking over a protocol
00023|     that requires bytes to be transmitted.
00024| 
00025| So what does this mean to you?
00026| 
00027| HTTP is based on bytes.  Not only the protocol, also the system used to
00028| address documents on servers (so called URIs or URLs).  However HTML which
00029| is usually transmitted on top of HTTP supports a large variety of
00030| character sets and which ones are used, are transmitted in an HTTP header.
00031| To not make this too complex Flask just assumes that if you are sending
00032| Unicode out you want it to be UTF-8 encoded.  Flask will do the encoding
00033| and setting of the appropriate headers for you.
00034| 
00035| The same is true if you are talking to databases with the help of
00036| SQLAlchemy or a similar ORM system.  Some databases have a protocol that
00037| already transmits Unicode and if they do not, SQLAlchemy or your other ORM
00038| should take care of that.
00039| 
00040| The Golden Rule
00041| ---------------
00042| 
00043| So the rule of thumb: if you are not dealing with binary data, work with
00044| Unicode.  What does working with Unicode in Python 2.x mean?
00045| 
00046| -   as long as you are using ASCII charpoints only (basically numbers,
00047|     some special characters of latin letters without umlauts or anything
00048|     fancy) you can use regular string literals (``'Hello World'``).
00049| -   if you need anything else than ASCII in a string you have to mark
00050|     this string as Unicode string by prefixing it with a lowercase `u`.
00051|     (like ``u'Hänsel und Gretel'``)
00052| -   if you are using non-Unicode characters in your Python files you have
00053|     to tell Python which encoding your file uses.  Again, I recommend
00054|     UTF-8 for this purpose.  To tell the interpreter your encoding you can
00055|     put the ``# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-`` into the first or second line of
00056|     your Python source file.
00057| -   Jinja is configured to decode the template files from UTF-8.  So make
00058|     sure to tell your editor to save the file as UTF-8 there as well.
00059| 
00060| Encoding and Decoding Yourself
00061| ------------------------------
00062| 
00063| If you are talking with a filesystem or something that is not really based
00064| on Unicode you will have to ensure that you decode properly when working
00065| with Unicode interface.  So for example if you want to load a file on the
00066| filesystem and embed it into a Jinja2 template you will have to decode it
00067| from the encoding of that file.  Here the old problem that text files do
00068| not specify their encoding comes into play.  So do yourself a favour and
00069| limit yourself to UTF-8 for text files as well.
00070| 
00071| Anyways.  To load such a file with Unicode you can use the built-in
00072| :meth:`str.decode` method::
00073| 
00074|     def read_file(filename, charset='utf-8'):
00075|         with open(filename, 'r') as f:
00076|             return f.read().decode(charset)
00077| 
00078| To go from Unicode into a specific charset such as UTF-8 you can use the
00079| :meth:`unicode.encode` method::
00080| 
00081|     def write_file(filename, contents, charset='utf-8'):
00082|         with open(filename, 'w') as f:
00083|             f.write(contents.encode(charset))
00084| 
00085| Configuring Editors
00086| -------------------
00087| 
00088| Most editors save as UTF-8 by default nowadays but in case your editor is
00089| not configured to do this you have to change it.  Here some common ways to
00090| set your editor to store as UTF-8:
00091| 
00092| -   Vim: put ``set enc=utf-8`` to your ``.vimrc`` file.
00093| 
00094| -   Emacs: either use an encoding cookie or put this into your ``.emacs``
00095|     file::
00096| 
00097|         (prefer-coding-system 'utf-8)
00098|         (setq default-buffer-file-coding-system 'utf-8)
00099| 
00100| -   Notepad++:
00101| 
00102|     1. Go to *Settings -> Preferences ...*
00103|     2. Select the "New Document/Default Directory" tab
00104|     3. Select "UTF-8 without BOM" as encoding
00105| 
00106|     It is also recommended to use the Unix newline format, you can select
00107|     it in the same panel but this is not a requirement.
00108| 

(End of file - total 108 lines)
</file>","title":"docs/unicode.rst","metadata":{"preview":"Unicode in Flask
================

Flask, like Jinja2 and Werkzeug, is totally Unicode based when it comes to
text.  Not only these libraries, also the majority of web related Python
libraries that deal with text.  If you don't know Unicode so far, you
should probably read `The Absolute Minimum Every Software Developer
Absolutely, Positively Must Know About Unicode and Character Sets
<http://www.joelonsoftware.com/articles/Unicode.html>`_.  This part of the
documentation just tries to cover the very basics so that you have a
pleasant experience with Unicode related things.

Automatic Conversion
--------------------

Flask has a few assumptions about your application (which you can change
of course) that give you basic and painless Unicode support:

-   the encoding for text on your website is UTF-8
-   internally you will always use Unicode exclusively for text except","truncated":false},"time":{"start":1770024850068,"end":1770024850089}}}}

00001| .. _python3-support:
00002| 
00003| Python 3 Support
00004| ================
00005| 
00006| Flask, its dependencies, and most Flask extensions support Python 3.
00007| You should start using Python 3 for your next project,
00008| but there are a few things to be aware of.
00009| 
00010| You need to use Python 3.3 or higher.  3.2 and older are *not* supported.
00011| 
00012| You should use the latest versions of all Flask-related packages.
00013| Flask 0.10 and Werkzeug 0.9 were the first versions to introduce Python 3 support.
00014| 
00015| Python 3 changed how unicode and bytes are handled, which complicates how low
00016| level code handles HTTP data.  This mainly affects WSGI middleware interacting
00017| with the WSGI ``environ`` data.  Werkzeug wraps that information in high-level
00018| helpers, so encoding issues should not affect you.
00019| 
00020| The majority of the upgrade work is in the lower-level libraries like
00021| Flask and Werkzeug, not the high-level application code.
00022| For example, all of the examples in the Flask repository work on both Python 2 and 3
00023| and did not require a single line of code changed.
00024|

Python 3 Support
================

Flask, its dependencies, and most Flask extensions support Python 3.
You should start using Python 3 for your next project,
but there are a few things to be aware of.

You need to use Python 3.3 or higher.  3.2 and older are *not* supported.

You should use the latest versions of all Flask-related packages.
Flask 0.10 and Werkzeug 0.9 were the first versions to introduce Python 3 support.

Python 3 changed how unicode and bytes are handled, which complicates how low
level code handles HTTP data.  This mainly affects WSGI middleware interacting
with the WSGI ``environ`` data.  Werkzeug wraps that information in high-level
helpers, so encoding issues should not affect you.

00001| .. _quickstart:
00002| 
00003| Quickstart
00004| ==========
00005| 
00006| Eager to get started?  This page gives a good introduction to Flask.  It
00007| assumes you already have Flask installed.  If you do not, head over to the
00008| :ref:`installation` section.
00009| 
00010| 
00011| A Minimal Application
00012| ---------------------
00013| 
00014| A minimal Flask application looks something like this::
00015| 
00016|     from flask import Flask
00017|     app = Flask(__name__)
00018| 
00019|     @app.route('/')
00020|     def hello_world():
00021|         return 'Hello, World!'
00022| 
00023| So what did that code do?
00024| 
00025| 1. First we imported the :class:`~flask.Flask` class.  An instance of this
00026|    class will be our WSGI application.
00027| 2. Next we create an instance of this class. The first argument is the name of
00028|    the application's module or package.  If you are using a single module (as
00029|    in this example), you should use ``__name__`` because depending on if it's
00030|    started as application or imported as module the name will be different
00031|    (``'__main__'`` versus the actual import name). This is needed so that
00032|    Flask knows where to look for templates, static files, and so on. For more
00033|    information have a look at the :class:`~flask.Flask` documentation.
00034| 3. We then use the :meth:`~flask.Flask.route` decorator to tell Flask what URL
00035|    should trigger our function.
00036| 4. The function is given a name which is also used to generate URLs for that
00037|    particular function, and returns the message we want to display in the
00038|    user's browser.
00039| 
00040| Just save it as :file:`hello.py` or something similar. Make sure to not call
00041| your application :file:`flask.py` because this would conflict with Flask
00042| itself.
00043| 
00044| To run the application you can either use the :command:`flask` command or
00045| python's ``-m`` switch with Flask.  Before you can do that you need
00046| to tell your terminal the application to work with by exporting the
00047| ``FLASK_APP`` environment variable::
00048| 
00049|     $ export FLASK_APP=hello.py
00050|     $ flask run
00051|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/
00052| 
00053| If you are on Windows you need to use ``set`` instead of ``export``.
00054| 
00055| Alternatively you can use :command:`python -m flask`::
00056| 
00057|     $ export FLASK_APP=hello.py
00058|     $ python -m flask run
00059|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/
00060| 
00061| This launches a very simple builtin server, which is good enough for testing
00062| but probably not what you want to use in production. For deployment options see
00063| :ref:`deployment`.
00064| 
00065| Now head over to `http://127.0.0.1:5000/ <http://127.0.0.1:5000/>`_, and you
00066| should see your hello world greeting.
00067| 
00068| .. _public-server:
00069| 
00070| .. admonition:: Externally Visible Server
00071| 
00072|    If you run the server you will notice that the server is only accessible
00073|    from your own computer, not from any other in the network.  This is the
00074|    default because in debugging mode a user of the application can execute
00075|    arbitrary Python code on your computer.
00076| 
00077|    If you have the debugger disabled or trust the users on your network,
00078|    you can make the server publicly available simply by adding
00079|    ``--host=0.0.0.0`` to the command line::
00080| 
00081|        flask run --host=0.0.0.0
00082| 
00083|    This tells your operating system to listen on all public IPs.
00084| 
00085| 
00086| What to do if the Server does not Start
00087| ---------------------------------------
00088| 
00089| In case the :command:`python -m flask` fails or :command:`flask` does not exist,
00090| there are multiple reasons this might be the case.  First of all you need
00091| to look at the error message.
00092| 
00093| Old Version of Flask
00094| ````````````````````
00095| 
00096| Versions of Flask older than 0.11 use to have different ways to start the
00097| application.  In short, the :command:`flask` command did not exist, and
00098| neither did :command:`python -m flask`.  In that case you have two options:
00099| either upgrade to newer Flask versions or have a look at the :ref:`server`
00100| docs to see the alternative method for running a server.
00101| 
00102| Invalid Import Name
00103| ```````````````````
00104| 
00105| The ``FLASK_APP`` environment variable is the name of the module to import at 
00106| :command:`flask run`. In case that module is incorrectly named you will get an 
00107| import error upon start (or if debug is enabled when you navigate to the 
00108| application). It will tell you what it tried to import and why it failed.
00109| 
00110| The most common reason is a typo or because you did not actually create an
00111| ``app`` object.
00112| 
00113| .. _debug-mode:
00114| 
00115| Debug Mode
00116| ----------
00117| 
00118| (Want to just log errors and stack traces? See :ref:`application-errors`)
00119| 
00120| The :command:`flask` script is nice to start a local development server, but
00121| you would have to restart it manually after each change to your code.
00122| That is not very nice and Flask can do better.  If you enable debug
00123| support the server will reload itself on code changes, and it will also
00124| provide you with a helpful debugger if things go wrong.
00125| 
00126| To enable debug mode you can export the ``FLASK_DEBUG`` environment variable
00127| before running the server::
00128| 
00129|     $ export FLASK_DEBUG=1
00130|     $ flask run
00131| 
00132| (On Windows you need to use ``set`` instead of ``export``).
00133| 
00134| This does the following things:
00135| 
00136| 1.  it activates the debugger
00137| 2.  it activates the automatic reloader
00138| 3.  it enables the debug mode on the Flask application.
00139| 
00140| There are more parameters that are explained in the :ref:`server` docs.
00141| 
00142| .. admonition:: Attention
00143| 
00144|    Even though the interactive debugger does not work in forking environments
00145|    (which makes it nearly impossible to use on production servers), it still
00146|    allows the execution of arbitrary code. This makes it a major security risk
00147|    and therefore it **must never be used on production machines**.
00148| 
00149| Screenshot of the debugger in action:
00150| 
00151| .. image:: _static/debugger.png
00152|    :align: center
00153|    :class: screenshot
00154|    :alt: screenshot of debugger in action
00155| 
00156| Have another debugger in mind? See :ref:`working-with-debuggers`.
00157| 
00158| 
00159| Routing
00160| -------
00161| 
00162| Modern web applications have beautiful URLs.  This helps people remember
00163| the URLs, which is especially handy for applications that are used from
00164| mobile devices with slower network connections.  If the user can directly
00165| go to the desired page without having to hit the index page it is more
00166| likely they will like the page and come back next time.
00167| 
00168| As you have seen above, the :meth:`~flask.Flask.route` decorator is used to
00169| bind a function to a URL.  Here are some basic examples::
00170| 
00171|     @app.route('/')
00172|     def index():
00173|         return 'Index Page'
00174| 
00175|     @app.route('/hello')
00176|     def hello():
00177|         return 'Hello, World'
00178| 
00179| But there is more to it!  You can make certain parts of the URL dynamic and
00180| attach multiple rules to a function.
00181| 
00182| Variable Rules
00183| ``````````````
00184| 
00185| To add variable parts to a URL you can mark these special sections as
00186| ``<variable_name>``.  Such a part is then passed as a keyword argument to your
00187| function.  Optionally a converter can be used by specifying a rule with
00188| ``<converter:variable_name>``.  Here are some nice examples::
00189| 
00190|     @app.route('/user/<username>')
00191|     def show_user_profile(username):
00192|         # show the user profile for that user
00193|         return 'User %s' % username
00194| 
00195|     @app.route('/post/<int:post_id>')
00196|     def show_post(post_id):
00197|         # show the post with the given id, the id is an integer
00198|         return 'Post %d' % post_id
00199| 
00200| The following converters exist:
00201| 
00202| =========== ===============================================
00203| `string`    accepts any text without a slash (the default)
00204| `int`       accepts integers
00205| `float`     like ``int`` but for floating point values
00206| `path`      like the default but also accepts slashes
00207| `any`       matches one of the items provided
00208| `uuid`      accepts UUID strings
00209| =========== ===============================================
00210| 
00211| .. admonition:: Unique URLs / Redirection Behavior
00212| 
00213|    Flask's URL rules are based on Werkzeug's routing module.  The idea
00214|    behind that module is to ensure beautiful and unique URLs based on
00215|    precedents laid down by Apache and earlier HTTP servers.
00216| 
00217|    Take these two rules::
00218| 
00219|         @app.route('/projects/')
00220|         def projects():
00221|             return 'The project page'
00222| 
00223|         @app.route('/about')
00224|         def about():
00225|             return 'The about page'
00226| 
00227|    Though they look rather similar, they differ in their use of the trailing
00228|    slash in the URL *definition*.  In the first case, the canonical URL for the
00229|    ``projects`` endpoint has a trailing slash.  In that sense, it is similar to
00230|    a folder on a filesystem.  Accessing it without a trailing slash will cause
00231|    Flask to redirect to the canonical URL with the trailing slash.
00232| 
00233|    In the second case, however, the URL is defined without a trailing slash,
00234|    rather like the pathname of a file on UNIX-like systems. Accessing the URL
00235|    with a trailing slash will produce a 404 "Not Found" error.
00236| 
00237|    This behavior allows relative URLs to continue working even if the trailing
00238|    slash is omitted, consistent with how Apache and other servers work.  Also,
00239|    the URLs will stay unique, which helps search engines avoid indexing the
00240|    same page twice.
00241| 
00242| 
00243| .. _url-building:
00244| 
00245| URL Building
00246| ````````````
00247| 
00248| If it can match URLs, can Flask also generate them?  Of course it can.  To
00249| build a URL to a specific function you can use the :func:`~flask.url_for`
00250| function.  It accepts the name of the function as first argument and a number
00251| of keyword arguments, each corresponding to the variable part of the URL rule.
00252| Unknown variable parts are appended to the URL as query parameters.  Here are
00253| some examples::
00254| 
00255|     >>> from flask import Flask, url_for
00256|     >>> app = Flask(__name__)
00257|     >>> @app.route('/')
00258|     ... def index(): pass
00259|     ...
00260|     >>> @app.route('/login')
