00100| class Flask(Scaffold):
00101|     """The flask object implements a WSGI application and acts as the central
00102|     object.  It is passed the name of the module or package of the
00103|     application.  Once it is created it will act as a central registry for
00104|     the view functions, the URL rules, template configuration and much more.
00105| 
00106|     The name of the package is used to resolve resources from inside the
00107|     package or the folder the module is contained in depending on if the
00108|     package parameter resolves to an actual python package (a folder with
00109|     an :file:`__init__.py` file inside) or a standard module (just a ``.py`` file).
00110| 
00111|     For more information about resource loading, see :func:`open_resource`.
00112| 
00113|     Usually you create a :class:`Flask` instance in your main module or
00114|     in the :file:`__init__.py` file of your package like this::
00115| 
00116|         from flask import Flask
00117|         app = Flask(__name__)
00118| 
00119|     .. admonition:: About the First Parameter
00120| 
00121|         The idea of the first parameter is to give Flask an idea of what
00122|         belongs to your application.  This name is used to find resources
00123|         on the filesystem, can be used by extensions to improve debugging
00124|         information and a lot more.
00125| 
00126|         So it's important what you provide there.  If you are using a single
00127|         module, `__name__` is always the correct value.  If you however are
00128|         using a package, it's usually recommended to hardcode the name of
00129|         your package there.
00130| 
00131|         For example if your application is defined in :file:`yourapplication/app.py`
00132|         you should create it with one of the two versions below::
00133| 
00134|             app = Flask('yourapplication')
00135|             app = Flask(__name__.split('.')[0])
00136| 
00137|         Why is that?  The application will work even with `__name__`, thanks
00138|         to how resources are looked up.  However it will make debugging more
00139|         painful.  Certain extensions can make assumptions based on the
00140|         import name of your application.  For example the Flask-SQLAlchemy
00141|         extension will look for the code in your application that triggered
00142|         an SQL query in debug mode.  If the import name is not properly set
00143|         up, that debugging information is lost.  (For example it would only
00144|         pick up SQL queries in `yourapplication.app` and not
00145|         `yourapplication.views.frontend`)
00146| 
00147|     .. versionadded:: 0.7
00148|        The `static_url_path`, `static_folder`, and `template_folder`
00149|        parameters were added.
00150| 
00151|     .. versionadded:: 0.8
00152|        The `instance_path` and `instance_relative_config` parameters were
00153|        added.
00154| 
00155|     .. versionadded:: 0.11
00156|        The `root_path` parameter was added.
00157| 
00158|     .. versionadded:: 1.0
00159|        The ``host_matching`` and ``static_host`` parameters were added.
00160| 
00161|     .. versionadded:: 1.0
00162|        The ``subdomain_matching`` parameter was added. Subdomain
00163|        matching needs to be enabled manually now. Setting
00164|        :data:`SERVER_NAME` does not implicitly enable it.
00165| 
00166|     :param import_name: the name of the application package
00167|     :param static_url_path: can be used to specify a different path for the
00168|                             static files on the web.  Defaults to the name
00169|                             of the `static_folder` folder.
00170|     :param static_folder: The folder with static files that is served at
00171|         ``static_url_path``. Relative to the application ``root_path``
00172|         or an absolute path. Defaults to ``'static'``.
00173|     :param static_host: the host to use when adding the static route.
00174|         Defaults to None. Required when using ``host_matching=True``
00175|         with a ``static_folder`` configured.
00176|     :param host_matching: set ``url_map.host_matching`` attribute.
00177|         Defaults to False.
00178|     :param subdomain_matching: consider the subdomain relative to
00179|         :data:`SERVER_NAME` when matching routes. Defaults to False.
00180|     :param template_folder: the folder that contains the templates that should
00181|                             be used by the application.  Defaults to
00182|                             ``'templates'`` folder in the root path of the
00183|                             application.
00184|     :param instance_path: An alternative instance path for the application.
00185|                           By default the folder ``'instance'`` next to the
00186|                           package or module is assumed to be the instance
00187|                           path.
00188|     :param instance_relative_config: if set to ``True`` relative filenames
00189|                                      for loading the config are assumed to
00190|                                      be relative to the instance path instead
00191|                                      of the application root.
00192|     :param root_path: The path to the root of the application files.
00193|         This should only be set manually when it can't be detected
00194|         automatically, such as for namespace packages.
00195|     """
00196| 
00197|     #: The class that is used for request objects.  See :class:`~flask.Request`
00198|     #: for more information.
00199|     request_class = Request
00200| 
00201|     #: The class that is used for response objects.  See
00202|     #: :class:`~flask.Response` for more information.
00203|     response_class = Response
00204| 
00205|     #: The class that is used for the Jinja environment.

00208|     jinja_environment = Environment

00210|     #: The class that is used for the :data:`~flask.g` instance.
00211|     #:
00212|     #: Example use cases for a custom class:
00213|     #:
00214|     #: 1. Store arbitrary attributes on flask.g.
00215|     #: 2. Add a property for lazy per-request database connectors.
00216|     #: 3. Return None instead of AttributeError on unexpected attributes.
00217|     #: 4. Raise exception if an unexpected attr is set, a "controlled" flask.g.
00218|     #:
00219|     #: In Flask 0.9 this property was called `request_globals_class` but it
00220|     #: was changed in 0.10 to :attr:`app_ctx_globals_class` because the
00221|     #: flask.g object is now application context scoped.
00222|     #:
00223|     #: .. versionadded:: 0.10
00224|     app_ctx_globals_class = _AppCtxGlobals
00225| 
00226|     #: The class that is used for the ``config`` attribute of this app.
00227|     #: Defaults to :class:`~flask.Config`.
00228|     #:
00229|     #: Example use cases for a custom class:
00230|     #:
00231|     #: 1. Default values for certain config options.
00232|     #: 2. Access to config values through attributes in addition to keys.
00233|     #:
00234|     #: .. versionadded:: 0.11
00235|     config_class = Config
00236|

00238|     #: Flask extensions (and in the future probably also Flask itself).
00239|     #: For example this might activate test helpers that have an
00240|     #: additional runtime cost which should not be enabled by default.
00241|     #:

00243|     #: default it's implicitly enabled.

00245|     #: This attribute can also be configured from the config with the

00247|     testing = ConfigAttribute("TESTING")
00248| 
00249|     #: If a secret key is set, cryptographic components can use this to
00250|     #: sign cookies and other things. Set this to a complex random value

00252|     #:
00253|     #: This attribute can also be configured from the config with the
00254|     #: :data:`SECRET_KEY` configuration key. Defaults to ``None``.
00255|     secret_key = ConfigAttribute("SECRET_KEY")
00256| 
00257|     #: The secure cookie uses this for the name of the session cookie.
00258|     #:
00259|     #: This attribute can also be configured from the config with the
00260|     #: ``SESSION_COOKIE_NAME`` configuration key.  Defaults to ``'session'``
00261|     session_cookie_name = ConfigAttribute("SESSION_COOKIE_NAME")
00262| 
00263|     #: A :class:`~datetime.timedelta` which is used to set the expiration
00264|     #: date of a permanent session.  The default is 31 days which makes a
00265|     #: permanent session survive for roughly one month.
00266|     #:
00267|     #: This attribute can also be configured from the config with the
00268|     #: ``PERMANENT_SESSION_LIFETIME`` configuration key.  Defaults to
00269|     #: ``timedelta(days=31)``
00270|     permanent_session_lifetime = ConfigAttribute(
00271|         "PERMANENT_SESSION_LIFETIME", get_converter=_make_timedelta
00272|     )

00276|     #: ``None``, which tells the browser to use conditional requests

00385|     def __init__(
00386|         self,

00399|             import_name=import_name,
00400|             static_folder=static_folder,
00401|             static_url_path=static_url_path,
00402|             template_folder=template_folder,
00403|             root_path=root_path,

00409|             raise ValueError(
00410|                 "If an instance path is provided it must be absolute."
00411|                 " A relative path was given instead."
00412|             )

00415|         #:
00416|         #: .. versionadded:: 0.8
00417|         self.instance_path = instance_path

00420|         #: exactly like a regular dictionary but supports additional methods
00421|         #: to load a config from files.

00424|         #: A list of functions that are called when :meth:`url_for` raises a
00425|         #: :exc:`~werkzeug.routing.BuildError`.  Each function registered here
00426|         #: is called with `error`, `endpoint` and `values`.  If a function

00428|         #: tried.

00432|             t.Callable[[Exception, str, dict], str]

00434| 
00435|         #: A list of functions that will be called at the beginning of the
00436|         #: first request to this instance. To register a function, use the
00437|         #: :meth:`before_first_request` decorator.
00438|         #:

00441| 
00442|         #: A list of functions that are called when the application context
00443|         #: is destroyed.  Since the application context is also torn down
00444|         #: if the request ends this is the place to store code that disconnects
00445|         #: from databases.
00446|         #:
00447|         #: .. versionadded:: 0.9

00449| 
00450|         #: A list of shell context processor functions that should be run
00451|         #: when a shell context is created.

00453|         #: .. versionadded:: 0.11
00454|         self.shell_context_processors: t.List[t.Callable[[], t.Dict[str, t.Any]]] = []
00455| 
00456|         #: Maps registered blueprint names to blueprint objects. The
00457|         #: dict retains the order the blueprints were registered in.
00458|         #: Blueprints can be registered multiple times, this dict does
00459|         #: not track how often they were attached.
00460|         #:

00463| 
00464|         #: a place where extensions can store application specific state.  For
00465|         #: example this is where an extension could store database engines and
00466|         #: similar things.
00467|         #:
00468|         #: The key must match the name of the extension module. For example in
00469|         #: case of a "Flask-Foo" extension in `flask_foo`, the key would be
00470|         #: ``'foo'``.

00475|         #: The :class:`~werkzeug.routing.Map` for this instance.  You can use
00476|         #: this to change the routing converters after the class was created
00477|         #: but before any routes are connected.  Example::
00478|         #:
00479|         #:    from werkzeug.routing import BaseConverter
00480|         #:
00481|         #:    class ListConverter(BaseConverter):
00482|         #:        def to_python(self, value):
00483|         #:            return value.split(',')
00484|         #:        def to_url(self, values):
00485|         #:            return ','.join(super(ListConverter, self).to_url(value)
00486|         #:                            for value in values)

00488|         #:    app = Flask(__name__)

00492|         self.url_map.host_matching = host_matching
00493|         self.subdomain_matching = subdomain_matching

00500|         # Add a static route using the provided static_url_path, static_host,
00501|         # and static_folder if there is a configured static_folder.
00502|         # Note we do this without checking if static_folder exists.
00503|         # For one, it might be created while the server is running (e.g. during
00504|         # development). Also, Google App Engine stores static files somewhere
00505|         if self.has_static_folder:
00506|             assert (
00507|                 bool(static_host) == host_matching
00508|             ), "Invalid static_host/host_matching combination"
00509|             # Use a weakref to avoid creating a reference cycle between the app
00510|             # and the view function (see #3761).
00511|             self_ref = weakref.ref(self)
00512|             self.add_url_rule(
00513|                 f"{self.static_url_path}/<path:filename>",
00514|                 endpoint="static",
00515|                 host=static_host,
00516|                 view_func=lambda **kw: self_ref().send_static_file(**kw),  # type: ignore # noqa: B950
00517|             )
00518| 
00519|         # Set the name of the Click group in case someone wants to add
00520|         # the app's commands to another CLI tool.
00521|         self.cli.name = self.name

00523|     def _is_setup_finished(self) -> bool:
00524|         return self.debug and self._got_first_request

00526|     @locked_cached_property
00527|     def name(self) -> str:  # type: ignore
00528|         """The name of the application.  This is usually the import name
00529|         with the difference that it's guessed from the run file if the
00530|         import name is main.  This name is used as a display name when
00531|         Flask needs the name of the application.  It can be set and overridden
00532|         to change the value.
00533| 
00534|         .. versionadded:: 0.8
00535|         """
00536|         if self.import_name == "__main__":
00537|             fn = getattr(sys.modules["__main__"], "__file__", None)
00538|             if fn is None:
00539|                 return "__main__"
00540|             return os.path.splitext(os.path.basename(fn))[0]
00541|         return self.import_name
00542|

00546|         value in case it's set, otherwise a sensible default is returned.

00548|         .. versionadded:: 0.7
00549|         """
00550|         rv = self.config["PROPAGATE_EXCEPTIONS"]
00551|         if rv is not None:
00552|             return rv
00553|         return self.testing or self.debug

00562|         """
00563|         rv = self.config["PRESERVE_CONTEXT_ON_EXCEPTION"]

00566|         return self.debug

00569|     def logger(self) -> logging.Logger:

00571|         the same name as :attr:`name`.

00573|         In debug mode, the logger's :attr:`~logging.Logger.level` will
00574|         be set to :data:`~logging.DEBUG`.

00576|         If there are no handlers configured, a default handler will be

00585|             ``"flask.app"``. The level is only set during configuration,

00591|         .. versionadded:: 0.3

00593|         return create_logger(self)

00614|     def make_config(self, instance_relative: bool = False) -> Config:
00615|         """Used to create the config attribute by the Flask constructor.
00616|         The `instance_relative` parameter is passed in from the constructor
00617|         of Flask (there named `instance_relative_config`) and indicates if
00618|         the config should be relative to the instance path or the root path
00619|         of the application.
00620| 
00621|         .. versionadded:: 0.8
00622|         """
00623|         root_path = self.root_path
00624|         if instance_relative:
00625|             root_path = self.instance_path
00626|         defaults = dict(self.default_config)
00627|         defaults["ENV"] = get_env()
00628|         defaults["DEBUG"] = get_debug_flag()
00629|         return self.config_class(root_path, defaults)
00630| 
00631|     def auto_find_instance_path(self) -> str:
00632|         """Tries to locate the instance path if it was not provided to the
00633|         constructor of the application class.  It will basically calculate
00634|         the path to a folder named ``instance`` next to your main file or
00635|         the package.
00636| 
00637|         .. versionadded:: 0.8
00638|         """
00639|         prefix, package_path = find_package(self.import_name)
00640|         if prefix is None:
00641|             return os.path.join(package_path, "instance")
00642|         return os.path.join(prefix, "var", f"{self.name}-instance")
00643| 
00644|     def open_instance_resource(self, resource: str, mode: str = "rb") -> t.IO[t.AnyStr]:
00645|         """Opens a resource from the application's instance folder
00646|         (:attr:`instance_path`).  Otherwise works like
00647|         :meth:`open_resource`.  Instance resources can also be opened for
00648|         writing.
00649| 
00650|         :param resource: the name of the resource.  To access resources within
00651|                          subfolders use forward slashes as separator.
00652|         :param mode: resource file opening mode, default is 'rb'.
00653|         """
00654|         return open(os.path.join(self.instance_path, resource), mode)

00656|     @property
00657|     def templates_auto_reload(self) -> bool:
00658|         """Reload templates when they are changed. Used by
00659|         :meth:`create_jinja_environment`.
00660| 
00661|         This attribute can be configured with :data:`TEMPLATES_AUTO_RELOAD`. If
00662|         not set, it will be enabled in debug mode.
00663| 
00664|         .. versionadded:: 1.0
00665|             This property was added but the underlying config and behavior
00666|             already existed.
00667|         """
00668|         rv = self.config["TEMPLATES_AUTO_RELOAD"]
00669|         return rv if rv is not None else self.debug
00670| 
00671|     @templates_auto_reload.setter
00672|     def templates_auto_reload(self, value: bool) -> None:
00673|         self.config["TEMPLATES_AUTO_RELOAD"] = value
00674| 
00675|     def create_jinja_environment(self) -> Environment:
00676|         """Create the Jinja environment based on :attr:`jinja_options`
00677|         and the various Jinja-related methods of the app. Changing
00678|         :attr:`jinja_options` after this will have no effect. Also adds
00679|         Flask-related globals and filters to the environment.
00680| 
00681|         .. versionchanged:: 0.11
00682|            ``Environment.auto_reload`` set in accordance with
00683|            ``TEMPLATES_AUTO_RELOAD`` configuration option.
00684| 
00685|         .. versionadded:: 0.5
00686|         """
00687|         options = dict(self.jinja_options)
00688| 
00689|         if "autoescape" not in options:
00690|             options["autoescape"] = self.select_jinja_autoescape
00691| 
00692|         if "auto_reload" not in options:
00693|             options["auto_reload"] = self.templates_auto_reload
00694| 
00695|         rv = self.jinja_environment(self, **options)
00696|         rv.globals.update(
00697|             url_for=url_for,
00698|             get_flashed_messages=get_flashed_messages,
00699|             config=self.config,
00700|             # request, session and g are normally added with the
00701|             # context processor for efficiency reasons but for imported
00702|             # templates we also want the proxies in there.
00703|             request=request,
00704|             session=session,
00705|             g=g,
00706|         )
00707|         rv.policies["json.dumps_function"] = json.dumps
00708|         return rv
00709| 
00710|     def create_global_jinja_loader(self) -> DispatchingJinjaLoader:
00711|         """Creates the loader for the Jinja2 environment.  Can be used to
00712|         override just the loader and keeping the rest unchanged.  It's
00713|         discouraged to override this function.  Instead one should override
00714|         the :meth:`jinja_loader` function instead.
00715| 
00716|         The global loader dispatches between the loaders of the application
00717|         and the individual blueprints.
00718| 
00719|         .. versionadded:: 0.7
00720|         """
00721|         return DispatchingJinjaLoader(self)
00722| 
00723|     def select_jinja_autoescape(self, filename: str) -> bool:
00724|         """Returns ``True`` if autoescaping should be active for the given
00725|         template name. If no template name is given, returns `True`.
00726| 
00727|         .. versionadded:: 0.5
00728|         """
00729|         if filename is None:
00730|             return True
00731|         return filename.endswith((".html", ".htm", ".xml", ".xhtml"))
00732| 
00733|     def update_template_context(self, context: dict) -> None:
00734|         """Update the template context with some commonly used variables.
00735|         This injects request, session, config and g into the template
00736|         context as well as everything template context processors want
00737|         to inject.  Note that the as of Flask 0.6, the original values
00738|         in the context will not be overridden if a context processor
00739|         decides to return a value with the same key.
00740| 
00741|         :param context: the context as a dictionary that is updated in place
00742|                         to add extra variables.
00743|         """
00744|         funcs: t.Iterable[
00745|             TemplateContextProcessorCallable
00746|         ] = self.template_context_processors[None]
00747|         reqctx = _request_ctx_stack.top
00748|         if reqctx is not None:
00749|             for bp in self._request_blueprints():
00750|                 if bp in self.template_context_processors:
00751|                     funcs = chain(funcs, self.template_context_processors[bp])
00752|         orig_ctx = context.copy()
00753|         for func in funcs:
00754|             context.update(func())
00755|         # make sure the original values win.  This makes it possible to
00756|         # easier add new variables in context processors without breaking
00757|         # existing views.
00758|         context.update(orig_ctx)
00759| 
00760|     def make_shell_context(self) -> dict:
00761|         """Returns the shell context for an interactive shell for this
00762|         application.  This runs all the registered shell context
00763|         processors.
00764| 
00765|         .. versionadded:: 0.11
00766|         """
00767|         rv = {"app": self, "g": g}
00768|         for processor in self.shell_context_processors:
00769|             rv.update(processor())
00770|         return rv
00771| 
00772|     #: What environment the app is running in. Flask and extensions may
00773|     #: enable behaviors based on the environment, such as enabling debug
00774|     #: mode. This maps to the :data:`ENV` config key. This is set by the
00775|     #: :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` environment variable and may not behave as
00776|     #: expected if set in code.
00777|     #:
00778|     #: **Do not enable development when deploying in production.**
00779|     #:
00780|     #: Default: ``'production'``
00781|     env = ConfigAttribute("ENV")

00783|     @property
00784|     def debug(self) -> bool:
00785|         """Whether debug mode is enabled. When using ``flask run`` to start
00786|         the development server, an interactive debugger will be shown for
00787|         unhandled exceptions, and the server will be reloaded when code
00788|         changes. This maps to the :data:`DEBUG` config key. This is
00789|         enabled when :attr:`env` is ``'development'`` and is overridden
00790|         by the ``FLASK_DEBUG`` environment variable. It may not behave as
00791|         expected if set in code.
00792| 
00793|         **Do not enable debug mode when deploying in production.**
00794| 
00795|         Default: ``True`` if :attr:`env` is ``'development'``, or
00796|         ``False`` otherwise.
00797|         """
00798|         return self.config["DEBUG"]
00799| 
00800|     @debug.setter

00802|         self.config["DEBUG"] = value
00803|         self.jinja_env.auto_reload = self.templates_auto_reload

00805|     def run(
00806|         self,
00807|         host: t.Optional[str] = None,
00808|         port: t.Optional[int] = None,
00809|         debug: t.Optional[bool] = None,
00810|         load_dotenv: bool = True,
00811|         **options: t.Any,
00812|     ) -> None:
00813|         """Runs the application on a local development server.
00814| 
00815|         Do not use ``run()`` in a production setting. It is not intended to
00816|         meet security and performance requirements for a production server.
00817|         Instead, see :doc:`/deploying/index` for WSGI server recommendations.
00818| 
00819|         If the :attr:`debug` flag is set the server will automatically reload
00820|         for code changes and show a debugger in case an exception happened.
00821| 
00822|         If you want to run the application in debug mode, but disable the
00823|         code execution on the interactive debugger, you can pass
00824|         ``use_evalex=False`` as parameter.  This will keep the debugger's
00825|         traceback screen active, but disable code execution.
00826| 
00827|         It is not recommended to use this function for development with
00828|         automatic reloading as this is badly supported.  Instead you should
00829|         be using the :command:`flask` command line script's ``run`` support.
00830| 
00831|         .. admonition:: Keep in Mind
00832| 
00833|            Flask will suppress any server error with a generic error page
00834|            unless it is in debug mode.  As such to enable just the
00835|            interactive debugger without the code reloading, you have to
00836|            invoke :meth:`run` with ``debug=True`` and ``use_reloader=False``.
00837|            Setting ``use_debugger`` to ``True`` without being in debug mode
00838|            won't catch any exceptions because there won't be any to
00839|            catch.
00840| 
00841|         :param host: the hostname to listen on. Set this to ``'0.0.0.0'`` to
00842|             have the server available externally as well. Defaults to
00843|             ``'127.0.0.1'`` or the host in the ``SERVER_NAME`` config variable
00844|             if present.
00845|         :param port: the port of the webserver. Defaults to ``5000`` or the
00846|             port defined in the ``SERVER_NAME`` config variable if present.
00847|         :param debug: if given, enable or disable debug mode. See
00848|             :attr:`debug`.
00849|         :param load_dotenv: Load the nearest :file:`.env` and :file:`.flaskenv`
00850|             files to set environment variables. Will also change the working
00851|             directory to the directory containing the first file found.
00852|         :param options: the options to be forwarded to the underlying Werkzeug
00853|             server. See :func:`werkzeug.serving.run_simple` for more
00854|             information.
00855| 
00856|         .. versionchanged:: 1.0
00857|             If installed, python-dotenv will be used to load environment
00858|             variables from :file:`.env` and :file:`.flaskenv` files.
00859| 
00860|             If set, the :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` and :envvar:`FLASK_DEBUG`
00861|             environment variables will override :attr:`env` and
00862|             :attr:`debug`.
00863| 
00864|             Threaded mode is enabled by default.
00865| 
00866|         .. versionchanged:: 0.10
00867|             The default port is now picked from the ``SERVER_NAME``
00868|             variable.
00869|         """
00870|         # Change this into a no-op if the server is invoked from the
00871|         # command line. Have a look at cli.py for more information.
00872|         if os.environ.get("FLASK_RUN_FROM_CLI") == "true":
00873|             from .debughelpers import explain_ignored_app_run
00874| 
00875|             explain_ignored_app_run()
00876|             return
00877| 
00878|         if get_load_dotenv(load_dotenv):
00879|             cli.load_dotenv()
00880| 
00881|             # if set, let env vars override previous values
00882|             if "FLASK_ENV" in os.environ:
00883|                 self.env = get_env()
00884|                 self.debug = get_debug_flag()
00885|             elif "FLASK_DEBUG" in os.environ:
00886|                 self.debug = get_debug_flag()

00928|         """Creates a test client for this application.  For information

00933|         exceptions to propagate to the test client.  Otherwise, the exception
00934|         will be handled by the application (not visible to the test client) and
00935|         the only indication of an AssertionError or other exception will be a

00937|         attribute.  For example::

00942|         The test client can be used in a ``with`` block to defer the closing down
00943|         of the context until the end of the ``with`` block.  This is useful if
00944|         you want to access the context locals for testing::

00951|         be passed to the application's :attr:`test_client_class` constructor.

00957|                 def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
00958|                     self._authentication = kwargs.pop("authentication")

00961|             app.test_client_class = CustomClient
00962|             client = app.test_client(authentication='Basic ....')

00974|         .. versionchanged:: 0.11

00976|            the constructor of :attr:`test_client_class`.
00977|         """

00980|             from .testing import FlaskClient as cls  # type: ignore
00981|         return cls(  # type: ignore

00013| @LocalProxy
00014| def wsgi_errors_stream() -> t.TextIO:
00015|     """Find the most appropriate error stream for the application. If a request
00016|     is active, log to ``wsgi.errors``, otherwise use ``sys.stderr``.
00017| 
00018|     If you configure your own :class:`logging.StreamHandler`, you may want to
00019|     use this for the stream. If you are using file or dict configuration and
00020|     can't import this directly, you can refer to it as
00021|     ``ext://flask.logging.wsgi_errors_stream``.
00022|     """
00023|     return request.environ["wsgi.errors"] if request else sys.stderr
00024| 
00025| 
00026| def has_level_handler(logger: logging.Logger) -> bool:
00027|     """Check if there is a handler in the logging chain that will handle the
00028|     given logger's :meth:`effective level <~logging.Logger.getEffectiveLevel>`.
00029|     """
00030|     level = logger.getEffectiveLevel()
00031|     current = logger
00032| 
00033|     while current:
00034|         if any(handler.level <= level for handler in current.handlers):
00035|             return True
00036| 
00037|         if not current.propagate:
00038|             break
00039| 
00040|         current = current.parent  # type: ignore
00041| 
00042|     return False
00043| 
00044| 
00045| #: Log messages to :func:`~flask.logging.wsgi_errors_stream` with the format
00046| #: ``[%(asctime)s] %(levelname)s in %(module)s: %(message)s``.
00047| default_handler = logging.StreamHandler(wsgi_errors_stream)  # type: ignore
00048| default_handler.setFormatter(
00049|     logging.Formatter("[%(asctime)s] %(levelname)s in %(module)s: %(message)s")
00050| )
00051| 
00052| 
00053| def create_logger(app: "Flask") -> logging.Logger:
00054|     """Get the Flask app's logger and configure it if needed.
00055| 
00056|     The logger name will be the same as
00057|     :attr:`app.import_name <flask.Flask.name>`.
00058| 
00059|     When :attr:`~flask.Flask.debug` is enabled, set the logger level to
00060|     :data:`logging.DEBUG` if it is not set.
00061| 
00062|     If there is no handler for the logger's effective level, add a
00063|     :class:`~logging.StreamHandler` for
00064|     :func:`~flask.logging.wsgi_errors_stream` with a basic format.
00065|     """
00066|     logger = logging.getLogger(app.name)
00067| 
00068|     if app.debug and not logger.level:
00069|         logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
00070| 
00071|     if not has_level_handler(logger):
00072|         logger.addHandler(default_handler)
00073| 
00074|     return logger

00001| .. currentmodule:: flask
00002| 
00003| Version 2.1.0
00004| -------------
00005| 
00006| Unreleased
00007| 
00008| -   Update Click dependency to >= 8.0.
00009| 
00010| 
00011| Version 2.0.1
00012| -------------
00013| 
00014| Unreleased
00015| 
00016| 
00017| Version 2.0.0
00018| -------------
00019| 
00020| Released 2021-05-11
00021| 
00022| -   Drop support for Python 2 and 3.5.
00023| -   Bump minimum versions of other Pallets projects: Werkzeug >= 2,
00024|     Jinja2 >= 3, MarkupSafe >= 2, ItsDangerous >= 2, Click >= 8. Be sure
00025|     to check the change logs for each project. For better compatibility
00026|     with other applications (e.g. Celery) that still require Click 7,
00027|     there is no hard dependency on Click 8 yet, but using Click 7 will
00028|     trigger a DeprecationWarning and Flask 2.1 will depend on Click 8.
00029| -   JSON support no longer uses simplejson. To use another JSON module,
00030|     override ``app.json_encoder`` and ``json_decoder``. :issue:`3555`
00031| -   The ``encoding`` option to JSON functions is deprecated. :pr:`3562`
00032| -   Passing ``script_info`` to app factory functions is deprecated. This
00033|     was not portable outside the ``flask`` command. Use
00034|     ``click.get_current_context().obj`` if it's needed. :issue:`3552`
00035| -   The CLI shows better error messages when the app failed to load
00036|     when looking up commands. :issue:`2741`
00037| -   Add :meth:`sessions.SessionInterface.get_cookie_name` to allow
00038|     setting the session cookie name dynamically. :pr:`3369`
00039| -   Add :meth:`Config.from_file` to load config using arbitrary file
00040|     loaders, such as ``toml.load`` or ``json.load``.
00041|     :meth:`Config.from_json` is deprecated in favor of this. :pr:`3398`
00042| -   The ``flask run`` command will only defer errors on reload. Errors
00043|     present during the initial call will cause the server to exit with
00044|     the traceback immediately. :issue:`3431`
00045| -   :func:`send_file` raises a :exc:`ValueError` when passed an
00046|     :mod:`io` object in text mode. Previously, it would respond with
00047|     200 OK and an empty file. :issue:`3358`
00048| -   When using ad-hoc certificates, check for the cryptography library
00049|     instead of PyOpenSSL. :pr:`3492`
00050| -   When specifying a factory function with ``FLASK_APP``, keyword
00051|     argument can be passed. :issue:`3553`
00052| -   When loading a ``.env`` or ``.flaskenv`` file, the current working
00053|     directory is no longer changed to the location of the file.
00054|     :pr:`3560`
00055| -   When returning a ``(response, headers)`` tuple from a view, the
00056|     headers replace rather than extend existing headers on the response.
00057|     For example, this allows setting the ``Content-Type`` for
00058|     ``jsonify()``. Use ``response.headers.extend()`` if extending is
00059|     desired. :issue:`3628`
00060| -   The ``Scaffold`` class provides a common API for the ``Flask`` and
00061|     ``Blueprint`` classes. ``Blueprint`` information is stored in
00062|     attributes just like ``Flask``, rather than opaque lambda functions.
00063|     This is intended to improve consistency and maintainability.
00064|     :issue:`3215`
00065| -   Include ``samesite`` and ``secure`` options when removing the
00066|     session cookie. :pr:`3726`
00067| -   Support passing a ``pathlib.Path`` to ``static_folder``. :pr:`3579`
00068| -   ``send_file`` and ``send_from_directory`` are wrappers around the
00069|     implementations in ``werkzeug.utils``. :pr:`3828`
00070| -   Some ``send_file`` parameters have been renamed, the old names are
00071|     deprecated. ``attachment_filename`` is renamed to ``download_name``.
00072|     ``cache_timeout`` is renamed to ``max_age``. ``add_etags`` is
00073|     renamed to ``etag``. :pr:`3828, 3883`
00074| -   ``send_file`` passes ``download_name`` even if
00075|     ``as_attachment=False`` by using ``Content-Disposition: inline``.
00076|     :pr:`3828`
00077| -   ``send_file`` sets ``conditional=True`` and ``max_age=None`` by
00078|     default. ``Cache-Control`` is set to ``no-cache`` if ``max_age`` is
00079|     not set, otherwise ``public``. This tells browsers to validate
00080|     conditional requests instead of using a timed cache. :pr:`3828`
00081| -   ``helpers.safe_join`` is deprecated. Use
00082|     ``werkzeug.utils.safe_join`` instead. :pr:`3828`
00083| -   The request context does route matching before opening the session.
00084|     This could allow a session interface to change behavior based on
00085|     ``request.endpoint``. :issue:`3776`
00086| -   Use Jinja's implementation of the ``|tojson`` filter. :issue:`3881`
00087| -   Add route decorators for common HTTP methods. For example,
00088|     ``@app.post("/login")`` is a shortcut for
00089|     ``@app.route("/login", methods=["POST"])``. :pr:`3907`
00090| -   Support async views, error handlers, before and after request, and
00091|     teardown functions. :pr:`3412`
00092| -   Support nesting blueprints. :issue:`593, 1548`, :pr:`3923`
00093| -   Set the default encoding to "UTF-8" when loading ``.env`` and
00094|     ``.flaskenv`` files to allow to use non-ASCII characters. :issue:`3931`
00095| -   ``flask shell`` sets up tab and history completion like the default
00096|     ``python`` shell if ``readline`` is installed. :issue:`3941`
00097| -   ``helpers.total_seconds()`` is deprecated. Use
00098|     ``timedelta.total_seconds()`` instead. :pr:`3962`
00099| -   Add type hinting. :pr:`3973`.
00100| 
00101| 
00102| Version 1.1.2
00103| -------------
00104| 
00105| Released 2020-04-03
00106| 
00107| -   Work around an issue when running the ``flask`` command with an
00108|     external debugger on Windows. :issue:`3297`
00109| -   The static route will not catch all URLs if the ``Flask``
00110|     ``static_folder`` argument ends with a slash. :issue:`3452`
00111| 
00112| 
00113| Version 1.1.1
00114| -------------
00115| 
00116| Released 2019-07-08
00117| 
00118| -   The ``flask.json_available`` flag was added back for compatibility
00119|     with some extensions. It will raise a deprecation warning when used,
00120|     and will be removed in version 2.0.0. :issue:`3288`

00895|     for import. If the package is not installed, it's assumed that the
00896|     package was imported from the current working directory.

00578|     spec = importlib.util.find_spec(import_name)
00579|     loader = spec.loader if spec is not None else None
00580| 
00581|     # Loader does not exist or we're referring to an unloaded main
00582|     # module or a main module without path (interactive sessions), go
00583|     # with the current working directory.
00584|     if loader is None or import_name == "__main__":
00585|         return os.getcwd()
00586| 
00587|     if hasattr(loader, "get_filename"):
00588|         filepath = loader.get_filename(import_name)
00589|     else:
00590|         # Fall back to imports.
00591|         __import__(import_name)
00592|         mod = sys.modules[import_name]
00593|         filepath = getattr(mod, "__file__", None)
00594| 
00595|         # If we don't have a file path it might be because it is a
00596|         # namespace package. In this case pick the root path from the
00597|         # first module that is contained in the package.
00598|         if filepath is None:
00599|             raise RuntimeError(
00600|                 "No root path can be found for the provided module"
00601|                 f" {import_name!r}. This can happen because the module"
00602|                 " came from an import hook that does not provide file"
00603|                 " name information or because it's a namespace package."
00604|                 " In this case the root path needs to be explicitly"
00605|                 " provided."
00606|             )
00607| 
00608|     # filepath is import_name.py for a module, or __init__.py for a package.
00609|     return os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(filepath))

00213|     Avoiding ``__import__`` helps create Flask instances where there are errors
00214|     at import time.  Those runtime errors will be apparent to the user soon
00215|     enough, but tools which build Flask instances meta-programmatically benefit
00216|     from a Flask which does not ``__import__``.  Instead of importing to
00217|     retrieve file paths or metadata on a module or package, use the pkgutil and
00218|     imp modules in the Python standard library.
00219|     """
00220| 
00221|     def test_name_with_import_error(self, modules_tmp_path):
00222|         (modules_tmp_path / "importerror.py").write_text("raise NotImplementedError()")
00223|         try:
00224|             flask.Flask("importerror")
00225|         except NotImplementedError:
00226|             AssertionError("Flask(import_name) is importing import_name.")
00227|

def test_redirect_no_app():
    response = flask.redirect("https://localhost", 307)
    assert response.location == "https://localhost"
    assert response.status_code == 307


def test_redirect_with_app(app):
    def redirect(location, code=302):
        raise ValueError

    app.redirect = redirect

    with app.app_context(), pytest.raises(ValueError):
        flask.redirect("other")

import pytest

import flask


def test_explicit_instance_paths(modules_tmp_path):
    with pytest.raises(ValueError, match=".*must be absolute"):
        flask.Flask(__name__, instance_path="instance")

    app = flask.Flask(__name__, instance_path=os.fspath(modules_tmp_path))
    assert app.instance_path == os.fspath(modules_tmp_path)


def test_uninstalled_module_paths(modules_tmp_path, purge_module):
    (modules_tmp_path / "config_module_app.py").write_text(
        "import os\n"
        "import flask\n"
        "here = os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(__file__))\n"

00082| 
00083| Deferred Errors on Reload
00084| ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
00085| 
00086| When using the ``flask run`` command with the reloader, the server will
00087| continue to run even if you introduce syntax errors or other
00088| initialization errors into the code. Accessing the site will show the
00089| interactive debugger for the error, rather than crashing the server.
00090| 
00091| If a syntax error is already present when calling ``flask run``, it will
00092| fail immediately and show the traceback rather than waiting until the
00093| site is accessed. This is intended to make errors more visible initially
00094| while still allowing the server to handle errors on reload.
00095| 
00096| 
00097| In Code
00098| -------
00099| 
00100| The development server can also be started from Python with the :meth:`Flask.run`
00101| method. This method takes arguments similar to the CLI options to control the server.
00102| The main difference from the CLI command is that the server will crash if there are
00103| errors when reloading. ``debug=True`` can be passed to enable debug mode.
00104| 
00105| Place the call in a main block, otherwise it will interfere when trying to import and
00106| run the application with a production server later.
00107| 
00108| .. code-block:: python
00109| 
00110|     if __name__ == "__main__":
00111|         app.run(debug=True)
00112| 
00113| .. code-block:: text
00114| 
00115|     $ python hello.py
00116|

Deferred Errors on Reload
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

When using the ``flask run`` command with the reloader, the server will
continue to run even if you introduce syntax errors or other
initialization errors into the code. Accessing the site will show the
interactive debugger for the error, rather than crashing the server.

If a syntax error is already present when calling ``flask run``, it will
fail immediately and show the traceback rather than waiting until the
site is accessed. This is intended to make errors more visible initially
while still allowing the server to handle errors on reload.


In Code
-------

The development server can also be started from Python with the :meth:`Flask.run`","truncated":false},"time":{"start":1770025839604,"end":1770025839606}}}}

00002| ============================
00003| 
00004| 
00005| In Production
00006| -------------
00007| 
00008| **Do not run the development server, or enable the built-in debugger, in
00009| a production environment.** The debugger allows executing arbitrary
00010| Python code from the browser. It's protected by a pin, but that should
00011| not be relied on for security.
00012| 
00013| Use an error logging tool, such as Sentry, as described in
00014| :ref:`error-logging-tools`, or enable logging and notifications as
00015| described in :doc:`/logging`.
00016| 
00017| If you have access to the server, you could add some code to start an
00018| external debugger if ``request.remote_addr`` matches your IP. Some IDE
00019| debuggers also have a remote mode so breakpoints on the server can be
00020| interacted with locally. Only enable a debugger temporarily.
00021| 
00022| 
00023| The Built-In Debugger
00024| ---------------------
00025| 
00026| The built-in Werkzeug development server provides a debugger which shows
00027| an interactive traceback in the browser when an unhandled error occurs
00028| during a request. This debugger should only be used during development.
00029| 
00030| .. image:: _static/debugger.png
00031|    :align: center
00032|    :class: screenshot
00033|    :alt: screenshot of debugger in action
00034| 
00035| .. warning::
00036| 
00037|     The debugger allows executing arbitrary Python code from the
00038|     browser. It is protected by a pin, but still represents a major
00039|     security risk. Do not run the development server or debugger in a
00040|     production environment.
00041| 
00042| The debugger is enabled by default when the development server is run in debug mode.
00043| 
00044| .. code-block:: text
00045| 
00046|     $ flask --app hello run --debug
00047| 
00048| When running from Python code, passing ``debug=True`` enables debug mode, which is
00049| mostly equivalent.
00050| 
00051| .. code-block:: python
00052| 
00053|     app.run(debug=True)
00054| 
00055| :doc:`/server` and :doc:`/cli` have more information about running the debugger and
00056| debug mode. More information about the debugger can be found in the `Werkzeug
00057| documentation <https://werkzeug.palletsprojects.com/debug/>`__.
00058| 
00059| 
00060| External Debuggers
00061| ------------------
00062| 
00063| External debuggers, such as those provided by IDEs, can offer a more
00064| powerful debugging experience than the built-in debugger. They can also
00065| be used to step through code during a request before an error is raised,
00066| or if no error is raised. Some even have a remote mode so you can debug
00067| code running on another machine.
00068| 
00069| When using an external debugger, the app should still be in debug mode, otherwise Flask
00070| turns unhandled errors into generic 500 error pages. However, the built-in debugger and
00071| reloader should be disabled so they don't interfere with the external debugger.
00072| 
00073| .. code-block:: text
00074| 
00075|     $ flask --app hello run --debug --no-debugger --no-reload
00076| 
00077| When running from Python:
00078| 
00079| .. code-block:: python
00080| 
00081|     app.run(debug=True, use_debugger=False, use_reloader=False)
00082| 
00083| Disabling these isn't required, an external debugger will continue to work with the
00084| following caveats.
00085| 
00086| -   If the built-in debugger is not disabled, it will catch unhandled exceptions before
00087|     the external debugger can.
00088| -   If the reloader is not disabled, it could cause an unexpected reload if code changes
00089|     during a breakpoint.
00090| -   The development server will still catch unhandled exceptions if the built-in
00091|     debugger is disabled, otherwise it would crash on any error. If you want that (and

In Production
-------------

**Do not run the development server, or enable the built-in debugger, in
a production environment.** The debugger allows executing arbitrary
Python code from the browser. It's protected by a pin, but that should
not be relied on for security.

Use an error logging tool, such as Sentry, as described in
:ref:`error-logging-tools`, or enable logging and notifications as
described in :doc:`/logging`.

If you have access to the server, you could add some code to start an
external debugger if ``request.remote_addr`` matches your IP. Some IDE
debuggers also have a remote mode so breakpoints on the server can be
interacted with locally. Only enable a debugger temporarily.

00010| Version 2.3.2
00011| -------------
00012| 
00013| Released 2023-05-01
00014| 
00015| -   Set ``Vary: Cookie`` header when the session is accessed, modified, or refreshed.

00019| Version 2.3.1
00020| -------------
00021| 
00022| Released 2023-04-25
00023| 
00024| -   Restore deprecated ``from flask import Markup``. :issue:`5084`
00025| 
00026| 
00027| Version 2.3.0
00028| -------------
00029| 
00030| Released 2023-04-25
00031| 
00032| -   Drop support for Python 3.7. :pr:`5072`
00033| -   Update minimum requirements to the latest versions: Werkzeug>=2.3.0, Jinja2>3.1.2,
00034|     itsdangerous>=2.1.2, click>=8.1.3.
00035| -   Remove previously deprecated code. :pr:`4995`
00036| 
00037|     -   The ``push`` and ``pop`` methods of the deprecated ``_app_ctx_stack`` and
00038|         ``_request_ctx_stack`` objects are removed. ``top`` still exists to give
00039|         extensions more time to update, but it will be removed.
00040|     -   The ``FLASK_ENV`` environment variable, ``ENV`` config key, and ``app.env``
00041|         property are removed.
00042|     -   The ``session_cookie_name``, ``send_file_max_age_default``, ``use_x_sendfile``,
00043|         ``propagate_exceptions``, and ``templates_auto_reload`` properties on ``app``
00044|         are removed.
00045|     -   The ``JSON_AS_ASCII``, ``JSON_SORT_KEYS``, ``JSONIFY_MIMETYPE``, and
00046|         ``JSONIFY_PRETTYPRINT_REGULAR`` config keys are removed.
00047|     -   The ``app.before_first_request`` and ``bp.before_app_first_request`` decorators
00048|         are removed.
00049|     -   ``json_encoder`` and ``json_decoder`` attributes on app and blueprint, and the
00050|         corresponding ``json.JSONEncoder`` and ``JSONDecoder`` classes, are removed.
00051|     -   The ``json.htmlsafe_dumps`` and ``htmlsafe_dump`` functions are removed.
00052|     -   Calling setup methods on blueprints after registration is an error instead of a
00053|         warning. :pr:`4997`
00054| 
00055| -   Importing ``escape`` and ``Markup`` from ``flask`` is deprecated. Import them
00056|     directly from ``markupsafe`` instead. :pr:`4996`
00057| -   The ``app.got_first_request`` property is deprecated. :pr:`4997`
00058| -   The ``locked_cached_property`` decorator is deprecated. Use a lock inside the
00059|     decorated function if locking is needed. :issue:`4993`
00060| -   Signals are always available. ``blinker>=1.6.2`` is a required dependency. The
00061|     ``signals_available`` attribute is deprecated. :issue:`5056`
00062| -   Signals support ``async`` subscriber functions. :pr:`5049`
00063| -   Remove uses of locks that could cause requests to block each other very briefly.
00064|     :issue:`4993`
00065| -   Use modern packaging metadata with ``pyproject.toml`` instead of ``setup.cfg``.
00066|     :pr:`4947`
00067| -   Ensure subdomains are applied with nested blueprints. :issue:`4834`
00068| -   ``config.from_file`` can use ``text=False`` to indicate that the parser wants a
00069|     binary file instead. :issue:`4989`
00070| -   If a blueprint is created with an empty name it raises a ``ValueError``.
00071|     :issue:`5010`
00072| -   ``SESSION_COOKIE_DOMAIN`` does not fall back to ``SERVER_NAME``. The default is not
00073|     to set the domain, which modern browsers interpret as an exact match rather than
00074|     a subdomain match. Warnings about ``localhost`` and IP addresses are also removed.
00075|     :issue:`5051`
00076| -   The ``routes`` command shows each rule's ``subdomain`` or ``host`` when domain
00077|     matching is in use. :issue:`5004`
00078| -   Use postponed evaluation of annotations. :pr:`5071`
00079| 
00080| 
00081| Version 2.2.5

00835| def find_package(import_name: str):
00836|     """Find the prefix that a package is installed under, and the path
00837|     that it would be imported from.
00838| 
00839|     The prefix is the directory containing the standard directory
00840|     hierarchy (lib, bin, etc.). If the package is not installed to the
00841|     system (:attr:`sys.prefix`) or a virtualenv (``site-packages``),
00842|     ``None`` is returned.
00843| 
00844|     The path is the entry in :attr:`sys.path` that contains the package
00845|     for import. If the package is not installed, it's assumed that the
00846|     package was imported from the current working directory.
00847|     """
00848|     root_mod_name, _, _ = import_name.partition(".")
00849|     package_path = _find_package_path(root_mod_name)
00850|     py_prefix = os.path.abspath(sys.prefix)
00851| 
00852|     # installed to the system
00853|     if package_path.startswith(py_prefix):
00854|         return py_prefix, package_path
00855| 
00856|     site_parent, site_folder = os.path.split(package_path)
00857| 
00858|     # installed to a virtualenv
00859|     if site_folder.lower() == "site-packages":
00860|         parent, folder = os.path.split(site_parent)
00861| 
00862|         # Windows (prefix/lib/site-packages)
00863|         if folder.lower() == "lib":
00864|             return parent, package_path
00865| 
00866|         # Unix (prefix/lib/pythonX.Y/site-packages)
00867|         if os.path.basename(parent).lower() == "lib":
00868|             return os.path.dirname(parent), package_path
00869| 
00870|         # something else (prefix/site-packages)
00871|         return site_parent, package_path
00872| 
00873|     # not installed
00874|     return None, package_path

import pytest

import flask


def test_explicit_instance_paths(modules_tmpdir):
    with pytest.raises(ValueError) as excinfo:
        flask.Flask(__name__, instance_path="instance")
    assert "must be absolute" in str(excinfo.value)

    app = flask.Flask(__name__, instance_path=str(modules_tmpdir))
    assert app.instance_path == str(modules_tmpdir)

00723|     even create your own script for sourcing that activates a virtualenv
00724|     and exports the development configuration for you.
00725| -   Use a tool like `fabric`_ in production to push code and
00726|     configurations separately to the production server(s).  For some

00728|     :doc:`/patterns/fabric` pattern.
00729| 
00730| .. _fabric: https://www.fabfile.org/
00731| 
00732| 
00733| .. _instance-folders:
00734| 
00735| Instance Folders
00736| ----------------
00737| 
00738| .. versionadded:: 0.8
00739| 
00740| Flask 0.8 introduces instance folders.  Flask for a long time made it
00741| possible to refer to paths relative to the application's folder directly
00742| (via :attr:`Flask.root_path`).  This was also how many developers loaded
00743| configurations stored next to the application.  Unfortunately however this
00744| only works well if applications are not packages in which case the root
00745| path refers to the contents of the package.
00746| 
00747| With Flask 0.8 a new attribute was introduced:
00748| :attr:`Flask.instance_path`.  It refers to a new concept called the
00749| “instance folder”.  The instance folder is designed to not be under
00750| version control and be deployment specific.  It's the perfect place to
00751| drop things that either change at runtime or configuration files.
00752| 
00753| You can either explicitly provide the path of the instance folder when
00754| creating the Flask application or you can let Flask autodetect the
00755| instance folder.  For explicit configuration use the `instance_path`
00756| parameter::
00757| 
00758|     app = Flask(__name__, instance_path='/path/to/instance/folder')
00759| 
00760| Please keep in mind that this path *must* be absolute when provided.
00761| 
00762| If the `instance_path` parameter is not provided the following default
00763| locations are used:
00764| 
00765| -   Uninstalled module::
00766| 
00767|         /myapp.py
00768|         /instance
00769| 
00770| -   Uninstalled package::
00771| 
00772|         /myapp
00773|             /__init__.py
00774|         /instance
00775| 
00776| -   Installed module or package::
00777| 
00778|         $PREFIX/lib/pythonX.Y/site-packages/myapp
00779|         $PREFIX/var/myapp-instance
00780| 
00781|     ``$PREFIX`` is the prefix of your Python installation.  This can be
00782|     ``/usr`` or the path to your virtualenv.  You can print the value of
00783|     ``sys.prefix`` to see what the prefix is set to.
00784| 
00785| Since the config object provided loading of configuration files from
00786| relative filenames we made it possible to change the loading via filenames
00787| to be relative to the instance path if wanted.  The behavior of relative
00788| paths in config files can be flipped between “relative to the application
00789| root” (the default) to “relative to instance folder” via the
00790| `instance_relative_config` switch to the application constructor::
00791| 
00792|     app = Flask(__name__, instance_relative_config=True)
00793| 
00794| Here is a full example of how to configure Flask to preload the config
00795| from a module and then override the config from a file in the instance
00796| folder if it exists::
00797| 
00798|     app = Flask(__name__, instance_relative_config=True)
00799|     app.config.from_object('yourapplication.default_settings')
00800|     app.config.from_pyfile('application.cfg', silent=True)
00801| 
00802| The path to the instance folder can be found via the
00803| :attr:`Flask.instance_path`.  Flask also provides a shortcut to open a
00804| file from the instance folder with :meth:`Flask.open_instance_resource`.
00805| 
00806| Example usage for both::
00807| 
00808|     filename = os.path.join(app.instance_path, 'application.cfg')
00809|     with open(filename) as f:
00810|         config = f.read()
00811| 
00812|     # or via open_instance_resource:
00813|     with app.open_instance_resource('application.cfg') as f:
00814|         config = f.read()
00815|

00052| class JSONEncoder(_json.JSONEncoder):
00053|     """The default Flask JSON encoder. This one extends the default
00054|     encoder by also supporting ``datetime``, ``UUID``, ``dataclasses``,
00055|     and ``Markup`` objects.
00056| 
00057|     ``datetime`` objects are serialized as RFC 822 datetime strings.
00058|     This is the same as the HTTP date format.
00059| 
00060|     In order to support more data types, override the :meth:`default`
00061|     method.
00062|     """
00063| 
00064|     def default(self, o):
00065|         """Implement this method in a subclass such that it returns a
00066|         serializable object for ``o``, or calls the base implementation (to
00067|         raise a :exc:`TypeError`).
00068| 
00069|         For example, to support arbitrary iterators, you could implement
00070|         default like this::
00071| 
00072|             def default(self, o):
00073|                 try:
00074|                     iterable = iter(o)
00075|                 except TypeError:
00076|                     pass
00077|                 else:
00078|                     return list(iterable)
00079|                 return JSONEncoder.default(self, o)
00080|         """
00081|         if isinstance(o, datetime):
00082|             return http_date(o.utctimetuple())
00083|         if isinstance(o, date):
00084|             return http_date(o.timetuple())
00085|         if isinstance(o, uuid.UUID):
00086|             return str(o)
00087|         if dataclasses and dataclasses.is_dataclass(o):
00088|             return dataclasses.asdict(o)
00089|         if hasattr(o, "__html__"):
00090|             return str(o.__html__())
00091|         return _json.JSONEncoder.default(self, o)

00139|     The latest JSON standard (:rfc:`8259`) suggests that only UTF-8 is
00140|     accepted. Older documents allowed 8, 16, or 32. 16 and 32 can be big
00141|     or little endian. Some editors or libraries may prepend a BOM.

00152|         return "utf-8"

00154|     if head in (codecs.BOM_UTF32_BE, codecs.BOM_UTF32_LE):
00155|         return "utf-32"
00156| 
00157|     if head[:2] in (codecs.BOM_UTF16_BE, codecs.BOM_UTF16_LE):
00158|         return "utf-16"
00159| 
00160|     if len(head) == 4:
00161|         if head[:3] == b"\x00\x00\x00":
00162|             return "utf-32-be"
00163| 
00164|         if head[::2] == b"\x00\x00":
00165|             return "utf-16-be"
00166| 
00167|         if head[1:] == b"\x00\x00\x00":
00168|             return "utf-32-le"
00169| 
00170|         if head[1::2] == b"\x00\x00":
00171|             return "utf-16-le"
00172| 
00173|     if len(head) == 2:
00174|         return "utf-16-be" if head.startswith(b"\x00") else "utf-16-le"
00175| 
00176|     return "utf-8"
00177| 
00178| 
00179| def dumps(obj, app=None, **kwargs):
00180|     """Serialize ``obj`` to a JSON-formatted string. If there is an
00181|     app context pushed, use the current app's configured encoder
00182|     (:attr:`~flask.Flask.json_encoder`), or fall back to the default
00183|     :class:`JSONEncoder`.
00184| 
00185|     Takes the same arguments as the built-in :func:`json.dumps`, and
00186|     does some extra configuration based on the application. If the
00187|     simplejson package is installed, it is preferred.
00188| 
00189|     :param obj: Object to serialize to JSON.
00190|     :param app: App instance to use to configure the JSON encoder.
00191|         Uses ``current_app`` if not given, and falls back to the default
00192|         encoder when not in an app context.
00193|     :param kwargs: Extra arguments passed to :func:`json.dumps`.
00194| 
00195|     .. versionchanged:: 1.0.3
00196| 
00197|         ``app`` can be passed directly, rather than requiring an app
00198|         context for configuration.
00199|     """
00200|     _dump_arg_defaults(kwargs, app=app)
00201|     encoding = kwargs.pop("encoding", None)
00202|     rv = _json.dumps(obj, **kwargs)
00203|     if encoding is not None and isinstance(rv, str):
00204|         rv = rv.encode(encoding)
00205|     return rv
00206| 
00207| 
00208| def dump(obj, fp, app=None, **kwargs):
00209|     """Like :func:`dumps` but writes into a file object."""
00210|     _dump_arg_defaults(kwargs, app=app)
00211|     encoding = kwargs.pop("encoding", None)
00212|     if encoding is not None:
00213|         fp = _wrap_writer_for_text(fp, encoding)
00214|     _json.dump(obj, fp, **kwargs)
00215| 
00216| 
00217| def loads(s, app=None, **kwargs):
00218|     """Deserialize an object from a JSON-formatted string ``s``. If
00219|     there is an app context pushed, use the current app's configured
00220|     decoder (:attr:`~flask.Flask.json_decoder`), or fall back to the
00221|     default :class:`JSONDecoder`.
00222| 
00223|     Takes the same arguments as the built-in :func:`json.loads`, and
00224|     does some extra configuration based on the application. If the
00225|     simplejson package is installed, it is preferred.
00226| 
00227|     :param s: JSON string to deserialize.
00228|     :param app: App instance to use to configure the JSON decoder.
00229|         Uses ``current_app`` if not given, and falls back to the default
00230|         encoder when not in an app context.
00231|     :param kwargs: Extra arguments passed to :func:`json.dumps`.
00232| 
00233|     .. versionchanged:: 1.0.3
00234| 
00235|         ``app`` can be passed directly, rather than requiring an app
00236|         context for configuration.
00237|     """
00238|     _load_arg_defaults(kwargs, app=app)
00239|     if isinstance(s, bytes):
00240|         encoding = kwargs.pop("encoding", None)
00241|         if encoding is None:
00242|             encoding = detect_encoding(s)
00243|         s = s.decode(encoding)
00244|     return _json.loads(s, **kwargs)
00245| 
00246| 
00247| def load(fp, app=None, **kwargs):
00248|     """Like :func:`loads` but reads from a file object."""
00249|     _load_arg_defaults(kwargs, app=app)
00250|     fp = _wrap_reader_for_text(fp, kwargs.pop("encoding", None) or "utf-8")

00254| def htmlsafe_dumps(obj, **kwargs):
00255|     """Works exactly like :func:`dumps` but is safe for use in ``<script>``
00256|     tags.  It accepts the same arguments and returns a JSON string.  Note that
00257|     this is available in templates through the ``|tojson`` filter which will
00258|     also mark the result as safe.  Due to how this function escapes certain
00259|     characters this is safe even if used outside of ``<script>`` tags.
00260| 
00261|     The following characters are escaped in strings:
00262| 
00263|     -   ``<``
00264|     -   ``>``
00265|     -   ``&``
00266|     -   ``'``
00267| 
00268|     This makes it safe to embed such strings in any place in HTML with the
00269|     notable exception of double quoted attributes.  In that case single
00270|     quote your attributes or HTML escape it in addition.
00271| 
00272|     .. versionchanged:: 0.10
00273|        This function's return value is now always safe for HTML usage, even
00274|        if outside of script tags or if used in XHTML.  This rule does not
00275|        hold true when using this function in HTML attributes that are double
00276|        quoted.  Always single quote attributes if you use the ``|tojson``
00277|        filter.  Alternatively use ``|tojson|forceescape``.
00278|     """
00279|     rv = (
00280|         dumps(obj, **kwargs)
00281|         .replace("<", "\\u003c")
00282|         .replace(">", "\\u003e")
00283|         .replace("&", "\\u0026")
00284|         .replace("'", "\\u0027")
00285|     )
00286|     if not _slash_escape:
00287|         rv = rv.replace("\\/", "/")
00288|     return rv
00289| 
00290| 
00291| def htmlsafe_dump(obj, fp, **kwargs):
00292|     """Like :func:`htmlsafe_dumps` but writes into a file object."""
00293|     fp.write(str(htmlsafe_dumps(obj, **kwargs)))
00294| 
00295| 
00296| def jsonify(*args, **kwargs):
00297|     """This function wraps :func:`dumps` to add a few enhancements that make
00298|     life easier.  It turns the JSON output into a :class:`~flask.Response`
00299|     object with the :mimetype:`application/json` mimetype.  For convenience, it
00300|     also converts multiple arguments into an array or multiple keyword arguments
00301|     into a dict.  This means that both ``jsonify(1,2,3)`` and
00302|     ``jsonify([1,2,3])`` serialize to ``[1,2,3]``.
00303| 
00304|     For clarity, the JSON serialization behavior has the following differences
00305|     from :func:`dumps`:
00306| 
00307|     1. Single argument: Passed straight through to :func:`dumps`.
00308|     2. Multiple arguments: Converted to an array before being passed to
00309|        :func:`dumps`.
00310|     3. Multiple keyword arguments: Converted to a dict before being passed to
00311|        :func:`dumps`.
00312|     4. Both args and kwargs: Behavior undefined and will throw an exception.
00313| 
00314|     Example usage::
00315| 
00316|         from flask import jsonify
00317| 
00318|         @app.route('/_get_current_user')
00319|         def get_current_user():
00320|             return jsonify(username=g.user.username,
00321|                            email=g.user.email,
00322|                            id=g.user.id)
00323| 
00324|     This will send a JSON response like this to the browser::
00325| 
00326|         {
00327|             "username": "admin",
00328|             "email": "admin@localhost",
00329|             "id": 42
00330|         }
00331| 
00332| 
00333|     .. versionchanged:: 0.11
00334|         Added support for serializing top-level arrays. This introduces
00335|         a security risk in ancient browsers. See :ref:`security-json`
00336|         for details.
00337| 
00338|     This function's response will be pretty printed if the
00339|     ``JSONIFY_PRETTYPRINT_REGULAR`` config parameter is set to True or the
00340|     Flask app is running in debug mode. Compressed (not pretty) formatting
00341|     currently means no indents and no spaces after separators.
00342| 
00343|     .. versionadded:: 0.2
00344|     """
00345| 
00346|     indent = None
00347|     separators = (",", ":")
00348| 
00349|     if current_app.config["JSONIFY_PRETTYPRINT_REGULAR"] or current_app.debug:
00350|         indent = 2
00351|         separators = (", ", ": ")
00352| 
00353|     if args and kwargs:
00354|         raise TypeError("jsonify() behavior undefined when passed both args and kwargs")
00355|     elif len(args) == 1:  # single args are passed directly to dumps()
00356|         data = args[0]
00357|     else:
00358|         data = args or kwargs
00359| 
00360|     return current_app.response_class(
00361|         f"{dumps(data, indent=indent, separators=separators)}\n",
00362|         mimetype=current_app.config["JSONIFY_MIMETYPE"],
00363|     )
00364| 
00365| 
00366| def tojson_filter(obj, **kwargs):
00367|     return Markup(htmlsafe_dumps(obj, **kwargs))
00368|

00022|     matched endpoint and view arguments.

00029|     provides all of the attributes Werkzeug defines plus a few Flask
00030|     specific ones.

00034|     #: useful to inspect which methods are allowed for the URL from
00035|     #: a before/after handler (``request.url_rule.methods``) etc.
00036|     #: Though if the request's method was invalid for the URL rule,
00037|     #: the valid list is available in ``routing_exception.valid_methods``
00038|     #: instead (an attribute of the Werkzeug exception
00039|     #: :exc:`~werkzeug.exceptions.MethodNotAllowed`)
00040|     #: because the request was never internally bound.
00041|     #:
00042|     #: .. versionadded:: 0.6
00043|     url_rule = None
00044| 
00045|     #: A dict of view arguments that matched the request.  If an exception
00046|     #: happened when matching, this will be ``None``.
00047|     view_args = None
00048| 
00049|     #: If matching the URL failed, this is the exception that will be
00050|     #: raised / was raised as part of the request handling.  This is
00051|     #: usually a :exc:`~werkzeug.exceptions.NotFound` exception or
00052|     #: something similar.
00053|     routing_exception = None
00054| 
00055|     @property
00056|     def max_content_length(self):
00057|         """Read-only view of the ``MAX_CONTENT_LENGTH`` config key."""
00058|         if current_app:
00059|             return current_app.config["MAX_CONTENT_LENGTH"]
00060| 
00061|     @property
00062|     def endpoint(self):
00063|         """The endpoint that matched the request.  This in combination with
00064|         :attr:`view_args` can be used to reconstruct the same or a
00065|         modified URL.  If an exception happened when matching, this will

00068|         if self.url_rule is not None:
00069|             return self.url_rule.endpoint

00288| is provided by both the standard library as well as extension, Flask will
00289| try simplejson first and then fall back to the stdlib json module.  On top
00290| of that it will delegate access to the current application's JSON encoders
00291| and decoders for easier customization.
00292| 
00293| So for starters instead of doing::
00294| 
00295|     try:
00296|         import simplejson as json
00297|     except ImportError:
00298|         import json
00299| 
00300| You can instead just do this::
00301| 
00302|     from flask import json
00303| 
00304| For usage examples, read the :mod:`json` documentation in the standard
00305| library.  The following extensions are by default applied to the stdlib's
00306| JSON module:
00307| 
00308| 1.  ``datetime`` objects are serialized as :rfc:`822` strings.
00309| 2.  Any object with an ``__html__`` method (like :class:`~flask.Markup`)
00310|     will have that method called and then the return value is serialized
00311|     as string.
00312| 
00313| The :func:`~htmlsafe_dumps` function of this json module is also available
00314| as a filter called ``|tojson`` in Jinja2.  Note that in versions of Flask prior
00315| to Flask 0.10, you must disable escaping with ``|safe`` if you intend to use
00316| ``|tojson`` output inside ``script`` tags. In Flask 0.10 and above, this
00317| happens automatically (but it's harmless to include ``|safe`` anyway).
00318| 
00319| .. sourcecode:: html+jinja
00320| 
00321|     <script type=text/javascript>
00322|         doSomethingWith({{ user.username|tojson|safe }});
00323|     </script>
00324| 
00325| .. admonition:: Auto-Sort JSON Keys
00326| 
00327|     The configuration variable :data:`JSON_SORT_KEYS` can be set to
00328|     ``False`` to stop Flask from auto-sorting keys. By default sorting
00329|     is enabled and outside of the app context sorting is turned on.
00330| 
00331|     Notice that disabling key sorting can cause issues when using
00332|     content  based HTTP caches and Python's hash randomization feature.
00333|

00002| ============
00003| 
00004| 
00005| Python Version
00006| --------------
00007| 
00008| We recommend using the latest version of Python. Flask supports Python
00009| 3.6 and newer.
00010| 
00011| 
00012| Dependencies
00013| ------------
00014| 
00015| These distributions will be installed automatically when installing Flask.
00016| 
00017| * `Werkzeug`_ implements WSGI, the standard Python interface between
00018|   applications and servers.
00019| * `Jinja`_ is a template language that renders the pages your application
00020|   serves.
00021| * `MarkupSafe`_ comes with Jinja. It escapes untrusted input when rendering
00022|   templates to avoid injection attacks.
00023| * `ItsDangerous`_ securely signs data to ensure its integrity. This is used
00024|   to protect Flask's session cookie.
00025| * `Click`_ is a framework for writing command line applications. It provides
00026|   the ``flask`` command and allows adding custom management commands.
00027| 
00028| .. _Werkzeug: https://palletsprojects.com/p/werkzeug/
00029| .. _Jinja: https://palletsprojects.com/p/jinja/
00030| .. _MarkupSafe: https://palletsprojects.com/p/markupsafe/
00031| .. _ItsDangerous: https://palletsprojects.com/p/itsdangerous/
00032| .. _Click: https://palletsprojects.com/p/click/
00033| 
00034| 
00035| Optional dependencies
00036| ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
00037| 
00038| These distributions will not be installed automatically. Flask will detect and
00039| use them if you install them.
00040| 
00041| * `Blinker`_ provides support for :doc:`signals`.
00042| * `SimpleJSON`_ is a fast JSON implementation that is compatible with
00043|   Python's ``json`` module. It is preferred for JSON operations if it is
00044|   installed.
00045| * `python-dotenv`_ enables support for :ref:`dotenv` when running ``flask``
00046|   commands.
00047| * `Watchdog`_ provides a faster, more efficient reloader for the development
00048|   server.
00049| 
00050| .. _Blinker: https://pythonhosted.org/blinker/
00051| .. _SimpleJSON: https://simplejson.readthedocs.io/
00052| .. _python-dotenv: https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv#readme
00053| .. _watchdog: https://pythonhosted.org/watchdog/
00054| 
00055| 
00056| Virtual environments
00057| --------------------
00058| 
00059| Use a virtual environment to manage the dependencies for your project, both in
00060| development and in production.
00061| 
00062| What problem does a virtual environment solve? The more Python projects you
00063| have, the more likely it is that you need to work with different versions of
00064| Python libraries, or even Python itself. Newer versions of libraries for one
00065| project can break compatibility in another project.
00066| 
00067| Virtual environments are independent groups of Python libraries, one for each
00068| project. Packages installed for one project will not affect other projects or
00069| the operating system's packages.
00070| 
00071| Python comes bundled with the :mod:`venv` module to create virtual
00072| environments.
00073| 
00074| 
00075| .. _install-create-env:
00076| 
00077| Create an environment
00078| ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
00079| 
00080| Create a project folder and a :file:`venv` folder within:
00081| 
00082| .. code-block:: sh
00083| 
00084|     $ mkdir myproject
00085|     $ cd myproject
00086|     $ python3 -m venv venv
00087| 
00088| On Windows:
00089| 
00090| .. code-block:: bat
00091| 
00092|     $ py -3 -m venv venv
00093| 
00094| 
00095| .. _install-activate-env:
00096| 
00097| Activate the environment
00098| ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
00099| 
00100| Before you work on your project, activate the corresponding environment:
00101| 
00102| .. code-block:: sh
00103| 
00104|     $ . venv/bin/activate
00105| 
00106| On Windows:
00107| 
00108| .. code-block:: bat
00109| 
00110|     > venv\Scripts\activate
00111| 
00112| Your shell prompt will change to show the name of the activated
00113| environment.
00114| 
00115| 
00116| Install Flask
00117| -------------
00118| 
00119| Within the activated environment, use the following command to install
00120| Flask:
00121|
