00541|     path correctly.
00542| -   Changed logic of before first request handlers to flip the flag
00543|     after invoking. This will allow some uses that are potentially
00544|     dangerous but should probably be permitted.
00545| -   Fixed Python 3 bug when a handler from
00546|     ``app.url_build_error_handlers`` reraises the ``BuildError``.
00547| 
00548| 
00549| Version 0.10.1
00550| --------------
00551| 
00552| Released 2013-06-14
00553| 
00554| -   Fixed an issue where ``|tojson`` was not quoting single quotes which
00555|     made the filter not work properly in HTML attributes. Now it's
00556|     possible to use that filter in single quoted attributes. This should
00557|     make using that filter with angular.js easier.
00558| -   Added support for byte strings back to the session system. This
00559|     broke compatibility with the common case of people putting binary
00560|     data for token verification into the session.
00561| -   Fixed an issue where registering the same method twice for the same
00562|     endpoint would trigger an exception incorrectly.
00563| 
00564| 
00565| Version 0.10
00566| ------------
00567| 
00568| Released 2013-06-13, codename Limoncello
00569| 
00570| -   Changed default cookie serialization format from pickle to JSON to
00571|     limit the impact an attacker can do if the secret key leaks.
00572| -   Added ``template_test`` methods in addition to the already existing
00573|     ``template_filter`` method family.
00574| -   Added ``template_global`` methods in addition to the already
00575|     existing ``template_filter`` method family.
00576| -   Set the content-length header for x-sendfile.
00577| -   ``tojson`` filter now does not escape script blocks in HTML5
00578|     parsers.
00579| -   ``tojson`` used in templates is now safe by default due. This was
00580|     allowed due to the different escaping behavior.
00581| -   Flask will now raise an error if you attempt to register a new
00582|     function on an already used endpoint.
00583| -   Added wrapper module around simplejson and added default
00584|     serialization of datetime objects. This allows much easier
00585|     customization of how JSON is handled by Flask or any Flask
00586|     extension.
00587| -   Removed deprecated internal ``flask.session`` module alias. Use
00588|     ``flask.sessions`` instead to get the session module. This is not to
00589|     be confused with ``flask.session`` the session proxy.
00590| -   Templates can now be rendered without request context. The behavior
00591|     is slightly different as the ``request``, ``session`` and ``g``
00592|     objects will not be available and blueprint's context processors are
00593|     not called.
00594| -   The config object is now available to the template as a real global
00595|     and not through a context processor which makes it available even in
00596|     imported templates by default.
00597| -   Added an option to generate non-ascii encoded JSON which should
00598|     result in less bytes being transmitted over the network. It's
00599|     disabled by default to not cause confusion with existing libraries
00600|     that might expect ``flask.json.dumps`` to return bytes by default.
00601| -   ``flask.g`` is now stored on the app context instead of the request
00602|     context.
00603| -   ``flask.g`` now gained a ``get()`` method for not erroring out on
00604|     non existing items.
00605| -   ``flask.g`` now can be used with the ``in`` operator to see what's
00606|     defined and it now is iterable and will yield all attributes stored.
00607| -   ``flask.Flask.request_globals_class`` got renamed to
00608|     ``flask.Flask.app_ctx_globals_class`` which is a better name to what
00609|     it does since 0.10.
00610| -   ``request``, ``session`` and ``g`` are now also added as proxies to
00611|     the template context which makes them available in imported
00612|     templates. One has to be very careful with those though because
00613|     usage outside of macros might cause caching.
00614| -   Flask will no longer invoke the wrong error handlers if a proxy
00615|     exception is passed through.
00616| -   Added a workaround for chrome's cookies in localhost not working as
00617|     intended with domain names.
00618| -   Changed logic for picking defaults for cookie values from sessions
00619|     to work better with Google Chrome.
00620| -   Added ``message_flashed`` signal that simplifies flashing testing.
00621| -   Added support for copying of request contexts for better working
00622|     with greenlets.
00623| -   Removed custom JSON HTTP exception subclasses. If you were relying
00624|     on them you can reintroduce them again yourself trivially. Using
00625|     them however is strongly discouraged as the interface was flawed.
00626| -   Python requirements changed: requiring Python 2.6 or 2.7 now to
00627|     prepare for Python 3.3 port.
00628| -   Changed how the teardown system is informed about exceptions. This
00629|     is now more reliable in case something handles an exception halfway
00630|     through the error handling process.

00001| """
00002| Tagged JSON
00003| ~~~~~~~~~~~
00004| 
00005| A compact representation for lossless serialization of non-standard JSON
00006| types. :class:`~flask.sessions.SecureCookieSessionInterface` uses this
00007| to serialize the session data, but it may be useful in other places. It
00008| can be extended to support other types.
00009| 
00010| .. autoclass:: TaggedJSONSerializer
00011|     :members:
00012| 
00013| .. autoclass:: JSONTag
00014|     :members:
00015| 
00016| Let's see an example that adds support for
00017| :class:`~collections.OrderedDict`. Dicts don't have an order in JSON, so
00018| to handle this we will dump the items as a list of ``[key, value]``
00019| pairs. Subclass :class:`JSONTag` and give it the new key ``' od'`` to
00020| identify the type. The session serializer processes dicts first, so
00021| insert the new tag at the front of the order since ``OrderedDict`` must
00022| be processed before ``dict``.
00023| 
00024| .. code-block:: python
00025| 
00026|     from flask.json.tag import JSONTag
00027| 
00028|     class TagOrderedDict(JSONTag):
00029|         __slots__ = ('serializer',)
00030|         key = ' od'
00031| 
00032|         def check(self, value):
00033|             return isinstance(value, OrderedDict)
00034| 
00035|         def to_json(self, value):
00036|             return [[k, self.serializer.tag(v)] for k, v in iteritems(value)]
00037| 
00038|         def to_python(self, value):
00039|             return OrderedDict(value)
00040| 
00041|     app.session_interface.serializer.register(TagOrderedDict, index=0)
00042| """
00043| from base64 import b64decode
00044| from base64 import b64encode
00045| from datetime import datetime
00046| from uuid import UUID
00047| 
00048| from jinja2 import Markup
00049| from werkzeug.http import http_date
00050| from werkzeug.http import parse_date
00051| 
00052| from ..json import dumps
00053| from ..json import loads
00054| 
00055| 
00056| class JSONTag:
00057|     """Base class for defining type tags for :class:`TaggedJSONSerializer`."""
00058| 
00059|     __slots__ = ("serializer",)
00060| 
00061|     #: The tag to mark the serialized object with. If ``None``, this tag is
00062|     #: only used as an intermediate step during tagging.
00063|     key = None
00064| 
00065|     def __init__(self, serializer):
00066|         """Create a tagger for the given serializer."""
00067|         self.serializer = serializer
00068| 
00069|     def check(self, value):
00070|         """Check if the given value should be tagged by this tag."""
00071|         raise NotImplementedError
00072| 
00073|     def to_json(self, value):
00074|         """Convert the Python object to an object that is a valid JSON type.
00075|         The tag will be added later."""
00076|         raise NotImplementedError
00077| 
00078|     def to_python(self, value):
00079|         """Convert the JSON representation back to the correct type. The tag
00080|         will already be removed."""
00081|         raise NotImplementedError
00082| 
00083|     def tag(self, value):
00084|         """Convert the value to a valid JSON type and add the tag structure
00085|         around it."""
00086|         return {self.key: self.to_json(value)}
00087| 
00088| 
00089| class TagDict(JSONTag):
00090|     """Tag for 1-item dicts whose only key matches a registered tag.
00091| 
00092|     Internally, the dict key is suffixed with `__`, and the suffix is removed
00093|     when deserializing.
00094|     """
00095| 
00096|     __slots__ = ()
00097|     key = " di"
00098| 
00099|     def check(self, value):
00100|         return (
00101|             isinstance(value, dict)
00102|             and len(value) == 1
00103|             and next(iter(value)) in self.serializer.tags
00104|         )
00105| 
00106|     def to_json(self, value):
00107|         key = next(iter(value))
00108|         return {f"{key}__": self.serializer.tag(value[key])}
00109| 
00110|     def to_python(self, value):
00111|         key = next(iter(value))
00112|         return {key[:-2]: value[key]}
00113| 
00114| 
00115| class PassDict(JSONTag):
00116|     __slots__ = ()
00117| 
00118|     def check(self, value):
00119|         return isinstance(value, dict)
00120| 
00121|     def to_json(self, value):
00122|         # JSON objects may only have string keys, so don't bother tagging the
00123|         # key here.
00124|         return {k: self.serializer.tag(v) for k, v in value.items()}
00125| 
00126|     tag = to_json
00127| 
00128| 
00129| class TagTuple(JSONTag):
00130|     __slots__ = ()
00131|     key = " t"
00132| 
00133|     def check(self, value):
00134|         return isinstance(value, tuple)
00135| 
00136|     def to_json(self, value):
00137|         return [self.serializer.tag(item) for item in value]
00138| 
00139|     def to_python(self, value):
00140|         return tuple(value)
00141| 
00142| 
00143| class PassList(JSONTag):
00144|     __slots__ = ()
00145| 
00146|     def check(self, value):
00147|         return isinstance(value, list)
00148| 
00149|     def to_json(self, value):
00150|         return [self.serializer.tag(item) for item in value]
00151| 
00152|     tag = to_json
00153| 
00154| 
00155| class TagBytes(JSONTag):
00156|     __slots__ = ()
00157|     key = " b"
00158| 
00159|     def check(self, value):
00160|         return isinstance(value, bytes)
00161| 
00162|     def to_json(self, value):
00163|         return b64encode(value).decode("ascii")
00164| 
00165|     def to_python(self, value):
00166|         return b64decode(value)
00167| 
00168| 
00169| class TagMarkup(JSONTag):
00170|     """Serialize anything matching the :class:`~flask.Markup` API by
00171|     having a ``__html__`` method to the result of that method. Always
00172|     deserializes to an instance of :class:`~flask.Markup`."""
00173| 
00174|     __slots__ = ()
00175|     key = " m"
00176| 
00177|     def check(self, value):
00178|         return callable(getattr(value, "__html__", None))
00179| 
00180|     def to_json(self, value):
00181|         return str(value.__html__())
00182| 
00183|     def to_python(self, value):
00184|         return Markup(value)
00185| 
00186| 
00187| class TagUUID(JSONTag):
00188|     __slots__ = ()
00189|     key = " u"
00190| 
00191|     def check(self, value):
00192|         return isinstance(value, UUID)
00193| 
00194|     def to_json(self, value):
00195|         return value.hex
00196| 
00197|     def to_python(self, value):
00198|         return UUID(value)
00199| 
00200| 
00201| class TagDateTime(JSONTag):
00202|     __slots__ = ()
00203|     key = " d"
00204| 
00205|     def check(self, value):
00206|         return isinstance(value, datetime)
00207| 
00208|     def to_json(self, value):
00209|         return http_date(value)
00210| 
00211|     def to_python(self, value):
00212|         return parse_date(value)
00213| 
00214| 
00215| class TaggedJSONSerializer:
00216|     """Serializer that uses a tag system to compactly represent objects that
00217|     are not JSON types. Passed as the intermediate serializer to
00218|     :class:`itsdangerous.Serializer`.
00219| 
00220|     The following extra types are supported:
00221| 
00222|     * :class:`dict`
00223|     * :class:`tuple`
00224|     * :class:`bytes`
00225|     * :class:`~flask.Markup`
00226|     * :class:`~uuid.UUID`
00227|     * :class:`~datetime.datetime`
00228|     """
00229| 
00230|     __slots__ = ("tags", "order")
00231| 
00232|     #: Tag classes to bind when creating the serializer. Other tags can be
00233|     #: added later using :meth:`~register`.
00234|     default_tags = [
00235|         TagDict,
00236|         PassDict,
00237|         TagTuple,
00238|         PassList,
00239|         TagBytes,
00240|         TagMarkup,
00241|         TagUUID,
00242|         TagDateTime,
00243|     ]
00244| 
00245|     def __init__(self):
00246|         self.tags = {}
00247|         self.order = []
00248| 
00249|         for cls in self.default_tags:
00250|             self.register(cls)
00251| 
00252|     def register(self, tag_class, force=False, index=None):
00253|         """Register a new tag with this serializer.
00254| 
00255|         :param tag_class: tag class to register. Will be instantiated with this
00256|             serializer instance.
00257|         :param force: overwrite an existing tag. If false (default), a
00258|             :exc:`KeyError` is raised.
00259|         :param index: index to insert the new tag in the tag order. Useful when
00260|             the new tag is a special case of an existing tag. If ``None``
00261|             (default), the tag is appended to the end of the order.
00262| 
00263|         :raise KeyError: if the tag key is already registered and ``force`` is
00264|             not true.
00265|         """
00266|         tag = tag_class(self)
00267|         key = tag.key
00268| 
00269|         if key is not None:
00270|             if not force and key in self.tags:
00271|                 raise KeyError(f"Tag '{key}' is already registered.")
00272| 
00273|             self.tags[key] = tag
00274| 
00275|         if index is None:
00276|             self.order.append(tag)
00277|         else:
00278|             self.order.insert(index, tag)
00279| 
00280|     def tag(self, value):
00281|         """Convert a value to a tagged representation if necessary."""
00282|         for tag in self.order:
00283|             if tag.check(value):
00284|                 return tag.tag(value)
00285| 
00286|         return value
00287| 
00288|     def untag(self, value):
00289|         """Convert a tagged representation back to the original type."""
00290|         if len(value) != 1:
00291|             return value
00292| 
00293|         key = next(iter(value))
00294| 
00295|         if key not in self.tags:
00296|             return value
00297| 
00298|         return self.tags[key].to_python(value[key])
00299| 
00300|     def dumps(self, value):
00301|         """Tag the value and dump it to a compact JSON string."""
00302|         return dumps(self.tag(value), separators=(",", ":"))
00303| 
00304|     def loads(self, value):
00305|         """Load data from a JSON string and deserialized any tagged objects."""
00306|         return loads(value, object_hook=self.untag)

00019| @LocalProxy
00020| def wsgi_errors_stream():
00021|     """Find the most appropriate error stream for the application. If a request
00022|     is active, log to ``wsgi.errors``, otherwise use ``sys.stderr``.
00023| 
00024|     If you configure your own :class:`logging.StreamHandler`, you may want to
00025|     use this for the stream. If you are using file or dict configuration and
00026|     can't import this directly, you can refer to it as
00027|     ``ext://flask.logging.wsgi_errors_stream``.
00028|     """
00029|     return request.environ["wsgi.errors"] if request else sys.stderr
00030| 
00031| 
00032| def has_level_handler(logger):
00033|     """Check if there is a handler in the logging chain that will handle the
00034|     given logger's :meth:`effective level <~logging.Logger.getEffectiveLevel>`.
00035|     """
00036|     level = logger.getEffectiveLevel()
00037|     current = logger
00038| 
00039|     while current:
00040|         if any(handler.level <= level for handler in current.handlers):
00041|             return True
00042| 
00043|         if not current.propagate:
00044|             break
00045| 
00046|         current = current.parent
00047| 
00048|     return False
00049| 
00050| 
00051| #: Log messages to :func:`~flask.logging.wsgi_errors_stream` with the format
00052| #: ``[%(asctime)s] %(levelname)s in %(module)s: %(message)s``.
00053| default_handler = logging.StreamHandler(wsgi_errors_stream)
00054| default_handler.setFormatter(
00055|     logging.Formatter("[%(asctime)s] %(levelname)s in %(module)s: %(message)s")
00056| )
00057| 
00058| 
00059| def create_logger(app):
00060|     """Get the ``'flask.app'`` logger and configure it if needed.
00061| 
00062|     When :attr:`~flask.Flask.debug` is enabled, set the logger level to
00063|     :data:`logging.DEBUG` if it is not set.
00064| 
00065|     If there is no handler for the logger's effective level, add a
00066|     :class:`~logging.StreamHandler` for
00067|     :func:`~flask.logging.wsgi_errors_stream` with a basic format.
00068|     """
00069|     logger = logging.getLogger("flask.app")
00070| 
00071|     if app.debug and logger.level == logging.NOTSET:
00072|         logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
00073| 
00074|     if not has_level_handler(logger):
00075|         logger.addHandler(default_handler)

00077|     return logger

00103| class Flask(_PackageBoundObject):
00104|     """The flask object implements a WSGI application and acts as the central
00105|     object.  It is passed the name of the module or package of the
00106|     application.  Once it is created it will act as a central registry for
00107|     the view functions, the URL rules, template configuration and much more.
00108| 
00109|     The name of the package is used to resolve resources from inside the
00110|     package or the folder the module is contained in depending on if the
00111|     package parameter resolves to an actual python package (a folder with
00112|     an :file:`__init__.py` file inside) or a standard module (just a ``.py`` file).
00113| 
00114|     For more information about resource loading, see :func:`open_resource`.
00115| 
00116|     Usually you create a :class:`Flask` instance in your main module or
00117|     in the :file:`__init__.py` file of your package like this::
00118| 
00119|         from flask import Flask
00120|         app = Flask(__name__)
00121| 
00122|     .. admonition:: About the First Parameter
00123| 
00124|         The idea of the first parameter is to give Flask an idea of what
00125|         belongs to your application.  This name is used to find resources
00126|         on the filesystem, can be used by extensions to improve debugging
00127|         information and a lot more.
00128| 
00129|         So it's important what you provide there.  If you are using a single
00130|         module, `__name__` is always the correct value.  If you however are
00131|         using a package, it's usually recommended to hardcode the name of
00132|         your package there.
00133| 
00134|         For example if your application is defined in :file:`yourapplication/app.py`
00135|         you should create it with one of the two versions below::
00136| 
00137|             app = Flask('yourapplication')
00138|             app = Flask(__name__.split('.')[0])
00139| 
00140|         Why is that?  The application will work even with `__name__`, thanks
00141|         to how resources are looked up.  However it will make debugging more
00142|         painful.  Certain extensions can make assumptions based on the
00143|         import name of your application.  For example the Flask-SQLAlchemy
00144|         extension will look for the code in your application that triggered
00145|         an SQL query in debug mode.  If the import name is not properly set
00146|         up, that debugging information is lost.  (For example it would only
00147|         pick up SQL queries in `yourapplication.app` and not
00148|         `yourapplication.views.frontend`)
00149| 
00150|     .. versionadded:: 0.7
00151|        The `static_url_path`, `static_folder`, and `template_folder`
00152|        parameters were added.
00153| 
00154|     .. versionadded:: 0.8

00156|        added.

00158|     .. versionadded:: 0.11
00159|        The `root_path` parameter was added.
00160| 
00161|     .. versionadded:: 1.0
00162|        The ``host_matching`` and ``static_host`` parameters were added.
00163| 
00164|     .. versionadded:: 1.0
00165|        The ``subdomain_matching`` parameter was added. Subdomain
00166|        matching needs to be enabled manually now. Setting
00167|        :data:`SERVER_NAME` does not implicitly enable it.
00168| 
00169|     :param import_name: the name of the application package
00170|     :param static_url_path: can be used to specify a different path for the
00171|                             static files on the web.  Defaults to the name
00172|                             of the `static_folder` folder.
00173|     :param static_folder: the folder with static files that should be served
00174|                           at `static_url_path`.  Defaults to the ``'static'``

00180|         Defaults to False.

00757|     def create_jinja_environment(self):
00758|         """Create the Jinja environment based on :attr:`jinja_options`
00759|         and the various Jinja-related methods of the app. Changing
00760|         :attr:`jinja_options` after this will have no effect. Also adds
00761|         Flask-related globals and filters to the environment.
00762| 
00763|         .. versionchanged:: 0.11
00764|            ``Environment.auto_reload`` set in accordance with
00765|            ``TEMPLATES_AUTO_RELOAD`` configuration option.
00766| 
00767|         .. versionadded:: 0.5
00768|         """
00769|         options = dict(self.jinja_options)
00770| 
00771|         if "autoescape" not in options:
00772|             options["autoescape"] = self.select_jinja_autoescape
00773| 
00774|         if "auto_reload" not in options:
00775|             options["auto_reload"] = self.templates_auto_reload
00776| 
00777|         rv = self.jinja_environment(self, **options)
00778|         rv.globals.update(
00779|             url_for=url_for,
00780|             get_flashed_messages=get_flashed_messages,
00781|             config=self.config,
00782|             # request, session and g are normally added with the
00783|             # context processor for efficiency reasons but for imported
00784|             # templates we also want the proxies in there.
00785|             request=request,
00786|             session=session,
00787|             g=g,
00788|         )
00789|         rv.filters["tojson"] = json.tojson_filter
00790|         return rv
00791| 
00792|     def create_global_jinja_loader(self):

00794|         override just the loader and keeping the rest unchanged.  It's
00795|         discouraged to override this function.  Instead one should override
00796|         the :meth:`jinja_loader` function instead.

00798|         The global loader dispatches between the loaders of the application
00799|         and the individual blueprints.
00800| 
00801|         .. versionadded:: 0.7
00802|         """
00803|         return DispatchingJinjaLoader(self)

00805|     def select_jinja_autoescape(self, filename):
00806|         """Returns ``True`` if autoescaping should be active for the given
00807|         template name. If no template name is given, returns `True`.
00808| 
00809|         .. versionadded:: 0.5
00810|         """
00811|         if filename is None:
00812|             return True
00813|         return filename.endswith((".html", ".htm", ".xml", ".xhtml"))

00815|     def update_template_context(self, context):
00816|         """Update the template context with some commonly used variables.
00817|         This injects request, session, config and g into the template
00818|         context as well as everything template context processors want
00819|         to inject.  Note that the as of Flask 0.6, the original values
00820|         in the context will not be overridden if a context processor
00821|         decides to return a value with the same key.
00822| 
00823|         :param context: the context as a dictionary that is updated in place
00824|                         to add extra variables.
00825|         """
00826|         funcs = self.template_context_processors[None]
00827|         reqctx = _request_ctx_stack.top
00828|         if reqctx is not None:
00829|             bp = reqctx.request.blueprint
00830|             if bp is not None and bp in self.template_context_processors:
00831|                 funcs = chain(funcs, self.template_context_processors[bp])
00832|         orig_ctx = context.copy()
00833|         for func in funcs:
00834|             context.update(func())
00835|         # make sure the original values win.  This makes it possible to
00836|         # easier add new variables in context processors without breaking
00837|         # existing views.
00838|         context.update(orig_ctx)

00840|     def make_shell_context(self):

00842|         application.  This runs all the registered shell context
00843|         processors.

00845|         .. versionadded:: 0.11
00846|         """
00847|         rv = {"app": self, "g": g}
00848|         for processor in self.shell_context_processors:
00849|             rv.update(processor())
00850|         return rv

00885|     def run(self, host=None, port=None, debug=None, load_dotenv=True, **options):
00886|         """Runs the application on a local development server.
00887| 
00888|         Do not use ``run()`` in a production setting. It is not intended to
00889|         meet security and performance requirements for a production server.
00890|         Instead, see :ref:`deployment` for WSGI server recommendations.
00891| 
00892|         If the :attr:`debug` flag is set the server will automatically reload
00893|         for code changes and show a debugger in case an exception happened.
00894| 
00895|         If you want to run the application in debug mode, but disable the
00896|         code execution on the interactive debugger, you can pass
00897|         ``use_evalex=False`` as parameter.  This will keep the debugger's
00898|         traceback screen active, but disable code execution.
00899| 
00900|         It is not recommended to use this function for development with
00901|         automatic reloading as this is badly supported.  Instead you should
00902|         be using the :command:`flask` command line script's ``run`` support.
00903| 
00904|         .. admonition:: Keep in Mind
00905| 
00906|            Flask will suppress any server error with a generic error page
00907|            unless it is in debug mode.  As such to enable just the
00908|            interactive debugger without the code reloading, you have to
00909|            invoke :meth:`run` with ``debug=True`` and ``use_reloader=False``.
00910|            Setting ``use_debugger`` to ``True`` without being in debug mode
00911|            won't catch any exceptions because there won't be any to
00912|            catch.
00913| 
00914|         :param host: the hostname to listen on. Set this to ``'0.0.0.0'`` to
00915|             have the server available externally as well. Defaults to
00916|             ``'127.0.0.1'`` or the host in the ``SERVER_NAME`` config variable
00917|             if present.
00918|         :param port: the port of the webserver. Defaults to ``5000`` or the
00919|             port defined in the ``SERVER_NAME`` config variable if present.
00920|         :param debug: if given, enable or disable debug mode. See
00921|             :attr:`debug`.
00922|         :param load_dotenv: Load the nearest :file:`.env` and :file:`.flaskenv`
00923|             files to set environment variables. Will also change the working
00924|             directory to the directory containing the first file found.
00925|         :param options: the options to be forwarded to the underlying Werkzeug
00926|             server. See :func:`werkzeug.serving.run_simple` for more
00927|             information.
00928| 
00929|         .. versionchanged:: 1.0
00930|             If installed, python-dotenv will be used to load environment
00931|             variables from :file:`.env` and :file:`.flaskenv` files.
00932| 
00933|             If set, the :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` and :envvar:`FLASK_DEBUG`
00934|             environment variables will override :attr:`env` and
00935|             :attr:`debug`.
00936| 
00937|             Threaded mode is enabled by default.
00938| 
00939|         .. versionchanged:: 0.10
00940|             The default port is now picked from the ``SERVER_NAME``
00941|             variable.
00942|         """
00943|         # Change this into a no-op if the server is invoked from the
00944|         # command line. Have a look at cli.py for more information.
00945|         if os.environ.get("FLASK_RUN_FROM_CLI") == "true":
00946|             from .debughelpers import explain_ignored_app_run
00947| 
00948|             explain_ignored_app_run()
00949|             return
00950| 
00951|         if get_load_dotenv(load_dotenv):
00952|             cli.load_dotenv()
00953| 
00954|             # if set, let env vars override previous values
00955|             if "FLASK_ENV" in os.environ:
00956|                 self.env = get_env()
00957|                 self.debug = get_debug_flag()
00958|             elif "FLASK_DEBUG" in os.environ:
00959|                 self.debug = get_debug_flag()
00960| 
00961|         # debug passed to method overrides all other sources
00962|         if debug is not None:
00963|             self.debug = bool(debug)
00964| 
00965|         _host = "127.0.0.1"
00966|         _port = 5000
00967|         server_name = self.config.get("SERVER_NAME")
00968|         sn_host, sn_port = None, None
00969| 
00970|         if server_name:
00971|             sn_host, _, sn_port = server_name.partition(":")
00972| 
00973|         host = host or sn_host or _host
00974|         # pick the first value that's not None (0 is allowed)
00975|         port = int(next((p for p in (port, sn_port) if p is not None), _port))
00976| 
00977|         options.setdefault("use_reloader", self.debug)
00978|         options.setdefault("use_debugger", self.debug)
00979|         options.setdefault("threaded", True)
00980| 
00981|         cli.show_server_banner(self.env, self.debug, self.name, False)
00982| 
00983|         from werkzeug.serving import run_simple
00984| 
00985|         try:
00986|             run_simple(host, port, self, **options)
00987|         finally:
00988|             # reset the first request information if the development server
00989|             # reset normally.  This makes it possible to restart the server
00990|             # without reloader and that stuff from an interactive shell.
00991|             self._got_first_request = False

00993|     def test_client(self, use_cookies=True, **kwargs):
00994|         """Creates a test client for this application.  For information
00995|         about unit testing head over to :ref:`testing`.
00996| 
00997|         Note that if you are testing for assertions or exceptions in your
00998|         application code, you must set ``app.testing = True`` in order for the
00999|         exceptions to propagate to the test client.  Otherwise, the exception
01000|         will be handled by the application (not visible to the test client) and
01001|         the only indication of an AssertionError or other exception will be a
01002|         500 status code response to the test client.  See the :attr:`testing`
01003|         attribute.  For example::
01004| 
01005|             app.testing = True
01006|             client = app.test_client()
01007| 
01008|         The test client can be used in a ``with`` block to defer the closing down
01009|         of the context until the end of the ``with`` block.  This is useful if
01010|         you want to access the context locals for testing::
01011| 
01012|             with app.test_client() as c:
01013|                 rv = c.get('/?vodka=42')
01014|                 assert request.args['vodka'] == '42'
01015| 
01016|         Additionally, you may pass optional keyword arguments that will then
01017|         be passed to the application's :attr:`test_client_class` constructor.
01018|         For example::
01019| 
01020|             from flask.testing import FlaskClient
01021| 
01022|             class CustomClient(FlaskClient):
01023|                 def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
01024|                     self._authentication = kwargs.pop("authentication")
01025|                     super(CustomClient,self).__init__( *args, **kwargs)
01026| 
01027|             app.test_client_class = CustomClient

00003| Logging
00004| =======
00005| 
00006| Flask uses standard Python :mod:`logging`. All Flask-related messages are
00007| logged under the ``'flask'`` logger namespace.
00008| :meth:`Flask.logger <flask.Flask.logger>` returns the logger named
00009| ``'flask.app'``, and can be used to log messages for your application. ::
00010| 
00011|     @app.route('/login', methods=['POST'])
00012|     def login():
00013|         user = get_user(request.form['username'])
00014| 
00015|         if user.check_password(request.form['password']):
00016|             login_user(user)
00017|             app.logger.info('%s logged in successfully', user.username)
00018|             return redirect(url_for('index'))
00019|         else:
00020|             app.logger.info('%s failed to log in', user.username)
00021|             abort(401)
00022| 
00023| 
00024| Basic Configuration
00025| -------------------
00026| 
00027| When you want to configure logging for your project, you should do it as soon
00028| as possible when the program starts. If :meth:`app.logger <flask.Flask.logger>`
00029| is accessed before logging is configured, it will add a default handler. If
00030| possible, configure logging before creating the application object.
00031| 
00032| This example uses :func:`~logging.config.dictConfig` to create a logging
00033| configuration similar to Flask's default, except for all logs::
00034| 
00035|     from logging.config import dictConfig
00036| 
00037|     dictConfig({
00038|         'version': 1,
00039|         'formatters': {'default': {
00040|             'format': '[%(asctime)s] %(levelname)s in %(module)s: %(message)s',
00041|         }},
00042|         'handlers': {'wsgi': {
00043|             'class': 'logging.StreamHandler',
00044|             'stream': 'ext://flask.logging.wsgi_errors_stream',
00045|             'formatter': 'default'
00046|         }},
00047|         'root': {
00048|             'level': 'INFO',
00049|             'handlers': ['wsgi']
00050|         }
00051|     })
00052| 
00053|     app = Flask(__name__)
00054| 
00055| 
00056| Default Configuration
00057| `````````````````````
00058| 
00059| If you do not configure logging yourself, Flask will add a
00060| :class:`~logging.StreamHandler` to :meth:`app.logger <flask.Flask.logger>`
00061| automatically. During requests, it will write to the stream specified by the
00062| WSGI server in ``environ['wsgi.errors']`` (which is usually
00063| :data:`sys.stderr`). Outside a request, it will log to :data:`sys.stderr`.
00064| 
00065| 
00066| Removing the Default Handler
00067| ````````````````````````````
00068| 
00069| If you configured logging after accessing
00070| :meth:`app.logger <flask.Flask.logger>`, and need to remove the default
00071| handler, you can import and remove it::
00072| 
00073|     from flask.logging import default_handler
00074| 
00075|     app.logger.removeHandler(default_handler)
00076| 
00077| 
00078| Email Errors to Admins
00079| ----------------------
00080| 
00081| When running the application on a remote server for production, you probably
00082| won't be looking at the log messages very often. The WSGI server will probably
00083| send log messages to a file, and you'll only check that file if a user tells
00084| you something went wrong.
00085| 
00086| To be proactive about discovering and fixing bugs, you can configure a
00087| :class:`logging.handlers.SMTPHandler` to send an email when errors and higher
00088| are logged. ::
00089| 
00090|     import logging
00091|     from logging.handlers import SMTPHandler
00092| 
00093|     mail_handler = SMTPHandler(
00094|         mailhost='127.0.0.1',
00095|         fromaddr='server-error@example.com',
00096|         toaddrs=['admin@example.com'],
00097|         subject='Application Error'
00098|     )
00099|     mail_handler.setLevel(logging.ERROR)
00100|     mail_handler.setFormatter(logging.Formatter(
00101|         '[%(asctime)s] %(levelname)s in %(module)s: %(message)s'
00102|     ))
00103| 
00104|     if not app.debug:
00105|         app.logger.addHandler(mail_handler)
00106| 
00107| This requires that you have an SMTP server set up on the same server. See the
00108| Python docs for more information about configuring the handler.
00109| 
00110| 
00111| Injecting Request Information
00112| -----------------------------
00113| 
00114| Seeing more information about the request, such as the IP address, may help
00115| debugging some errors. You can subclass :class:`logging.Formatter` to inject
00116| your own fields that can be used in messages. You can change the formatter for
00117| Flask's default handler, the mail handler defined above, or any other
00118| handler. ::
00119| 
00120|     from flask import has_request_context, request
00121|     from flask.logging import default_handler
00122| 
00123|     class RequestFormatter(logging.Formatter):
00124|         def format(self, record):
00125|             if has_request_context():
00126|                 record.url = request.url
00127|                 record.remote_addr = request.remote_addr
00128|             else:
00129|                 record.url = None
00130|                 record.remote_addr = None
00131| 
00132|             return super().format(record)
00133| 
00134|     formatter = RequestFormatter(
00135|         '[%(asctime)s] %(remote_addr)s requested %(url)s\n'
00136|         '%(levelname)s in %(module)s: %(message)s'
00137|     )
00138|     default_handler.setFormatter(formatter)
00139|     mail_handler.setFormatter(formatter)
00140| 
00141| 
00142| Other Libraries
00143| ---------------
00144| 
00145| Other libraries may use logging extensively, and you want to see relevant
00146| messages from those logs too. The simplest way to do this is to add handlers
00147| to the root logger instead of only the app logger. ::
00148| 
00149|     from flask.logging import default_handler
00150| 
00151|     root = logging.getLogger()
00152|     root.addHandler(default_handler)
00153|     root.addHandler(mail_handler)
00154| 
00155| Depending on your project, it may be more useful to configure each logger you
00156| care about separately, instead of configuring only the root logger. ::
00157| 
00158|     for logger in (
00159|         app.logger,
00160|         logging.getLogger('sqlalchemy'),
00161|         logging.getLogger('other_package'),
00162|     ):
00163|         logger.addHandler(default_handler)
00164|         logger.addHandler(mail_handler)
00165| 
00166| 
00167| Werkzeug
00168| ````````
00169| 
00170| Werkzeug logs basic request/response information to the ``'werkzeug'`` logger.
00171| If the root logger has no handlers configured, Werkzeug adds a
00172| :class:`~logging.StreamHandler` to its logger.
00173| 
00174| 
00175| Flask Extensions
00176| ````````````````
00177| 
00178| Depending on the situation, an extension may choose to log to
00179| :meth:`app.logger <flask.Flask.logger>` or its own named logger. Consult each
00180| extension's documentation for details.
00181|

Logging
=======

Flask uses standard Python :mod:`logging`. All Flask-related messages are
logged under the ``'flask'`` logger namespace.
:meth:`Flask.logger <flask.Flask.logger>` returns the logger named
``'flask.app'``, and can be used to log messages for your application. ::

    @app.route('/login', methods=['POST'])
    def login():
        user = get_user(request.form['username'])

        if user.check_password(request.form['password']):
            login_user(user)
            app.logger.info('%s logged in successfully', user.username)
            return redirect(url_for('index'))
        else:
            app.logger.info('%s failed to log in', user.username)","truncated":false},"time":{"start":1770025458630,"end":1770025458669}}}}

00270|     variables from ``.env`` and ``.flaskenv`` files if python-dotenv is
00271|     installed. :pr:`2416`
00272| -   When passing a full URL to the test client, the scheme in the URL is
00273|     used instead of :data:`PREFERRED_URL_SCHEME`. :pr:`2430`
00274| -   :attr:`Flask.logger` has been simplified. ``LOGGER_NAME`` and
00275|     ``LOGGER_HANDLER_POLICY`` config was removed. The logger is always
00276|     named ``flask.app``. The level is only set on first access, it
00277|     doesn't check :attr:`Flask.debug` each time. Only one format is

00297| -   A single trailing slash is stripped from the blueprint

00002| """
00003|     flask.jsonimpl
00004|     ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
00005| 
00006|     Implementation helpers for the JSON support in Flask.
00007|

00011| import io
00012| import uuid
00013| from datetime import date
00014| from .globals import current_app, request
00015| from ._compat import text_type, PY2
00016| 
00017| from werkzeug.http import http_date
00018| from jinja2 import Markup
00019| 
00020| # Use the same json implementation as itsdangerous on which we
00021| # depend anyways.
00022| try:
00023|     from itsdangerous import simplejson as _json
00024| except ImportError:
00025|     from itsdangerous import json as _json
00026| 
00027| 
00028| # Figure out if simplejson escapes slashes.  This behavior was changed
00029| # from one version to another without reason.
00030| _slash_escape = '\\/' not in _json.dumps('/')
00031| 
00032| 
00033| __all__ = ['dump', 'dumps', 'load', 'loads', 'htmlsafe_dump',
00034|            'htmlsafe_dumps', 'JSONDecoder', 'JSONEncoder',
00035|            'jsonify']
00036| 
00037| 
00038| def _wrap_reader_for_text(fp, encoding):
00039|     if isinstance(fp.read(0), bytes):
00040|         fp = io.TextIOWrapper(io.BufferedReader(fp), encoding)
00041|     return fp
00042| 
00043| 
00044| def _wrap_writer_for_text(fp, encoding):
00045|     try:
00046|         fp.write('')
00047|     except TypeError:
00048|         fp = io.TextIOWrapper(fp, encoding)
00049|     return fp
00050| 
00051| 
00052| class JSONEncoder(_json.JSONEncoder):
00053|     """The default Flask JSON encoder.  This one extends the default simplejson
00054|     encoder by also supporting ``datetime`` objects, ``UUID`` as well as
00055|     ``Markup`` objects which are serialized as RFC 822 datetime strings (same
00056|     as the HTTP date format).  In order to support more data types override the
00057|     :meth:`default` method.
00058|     """
00059| 
00060|     def default(self, o):
00061|         """Implement this method in a subclass such that it returns a
00062|         serializable object for ``o``, or calls the base implementation (to
00063|         raise a :exc:`TypeError`).
00064| 
00065|         For example, to support arbitrary iterators, you could implement
00066|         default like this::
00067| 
00068|             def default(self, o):
00069|                 try:
00070|                     iterable = iter(o)
00071|                 except TypeError:
00072|                     pass
00073|                 else:
00074|                     return list(iterable)
00075|                 return JSONEncoder.default(self, o)
00076|         """
00077|         if isinstance(o, date):
00078|             return http_date(o.timetuple())
00079|         if isinstance(o, uuid.UUID):
00080|             return str(o)
00081|         if hasattr(o, '__html__'):
00082|             return text_type(o.__html__())
00083|         return _json.JSONEncoder.default(self, o)
00084| 
00085| 
00086| class JSONDecoder(_json.JSONDecoder):
00087|     """The default JSON decoder.  This one does not change the behavior from
00088|     the default simplejson decoder.  Consult the :mod:`json` documentation
00089|     for more information.  This decoder is not only used for the load
00090|     functions of this module but also :attr:`~flask.Request`.
00091|     """
00092| 
00093| 
00094| def _dump_arg_defaults(kwargs):
00095|     """Inject default arguments for dump functions."""
00096|     if current_app:
00097|         kwargs.setdefault('cls', current_app.json_encoder)
00098|         if not current_app.config['JSON_AS_ASCII']:
00099|             kwargs.setdefault('ensure_ascii', False)
00100|         kwargs.setdefault('sort_keys', current_app.config['JSON_SORT_KEYS'])
00101|     else:
00102|         kwargs.setdefault('sort_keys', True)
00103|         kwargs.setdefault('cls', JSONEncoder)
00104| 
00105| 
00106| def _load_arg_defaults(kwargs):
00107|     """Inject default arguments for load functions."""
00108|     if current_app:
00109|         kwargs.setdefault('cls', current_app.json_decoder)
00110|     else:
00111|         kwargs.setdefault('cls', JSONDecoder)
00112| 
00113| 
00114| def dumps(obj, **kwargs):
00115|     """Serialize ``obj`` to a JSON formatted ``str`` by using the application's
00116|     configured encoder (:attr:`~flask.Flask.json_encoder`) if there is an
00117|     application on the stack.
00118| 
00119|     This function can return ``unicode`` strings or ascii-only bytestrings by
00120|     default which coerce into unicode strings automatically.  That behavior by
00121|     default is controlled by the ``JSON_AS_ASCII`` configuration variable
00122|     and can be overridden by the simplejson ``ensure_ascii`` parameter.
00123|     """
00124|     _dump_arg_defaults(kwargs)
00125|     encoding = kwargs.pop('encoding', None)
00126|     rv = _json.dumps(obj, **kwargs)
00127|     if encoding is not None and isinstance(rv, text_type):
00128|         rv = rv.encode(encoding)
00129|     return rv
00130| 
00131| 
00132| def dump(obj, fp, **kwargs):
00133|     """Like :func:`dumps` but writes into a file object."""
00134|     _dump_arg_defaults(kwargs)
00135|     encoding = kwargs.pop('encoding', None)
00136|     if encoding is not None:
00137|         fp = _wrap_writer_for_text(fp, encoding)
00138|     _json.dump(obj, fp, **kwargs)
00139| 
00140| 
00141| def loads(s, **kwargs):
00142|     """Unserialize a JSON object from a string ``s`` by using the application's
00143|     configured decoder (:attr:`~flask.Flask.json_decoder`) if there is an
00144|     application on the stack.
00145|     """
00146|     _load_arg_defaults(kwargs)
00147|     if isinstance(s, bytes):
00148|         s = s.decode(kwargs.pop('encoding', None) or 'utf-8')
00149|     return _json.loads(s, **kwargs)
00150| 
00151| 
00152| def load(fp, **kwargs):
00153|     """Like :func:`loads` but reads from a file object.
00154|     """
00155|     _load_arg_defaults(kwargs)
00156|     if not PY2:
00157|         fp = _wrap_reader_for_text(fp, kwargs.pop('encoding', None) or 'utf-8')
00158|     return _json.load(fp, **kwargs)
00159| 
00160| 
00161| def htmlsafe_dumps(obj, **kwargs):
00162|     """Works exactly like :func:`dumps` but is safe for use in ``<script>``
00163|     tags.  It accepts the same arguments and returns a JSON string.  Note that
00164|     this is available in templates through the ``|tojson`` filter which will
00165|     also mark the result as safe.  Due to how this function escapes certain
00166|     characters this is safe even if used outside of ``<script>`` tags.
00167| 
00168|     The following characters are escaped in strings:
00169| 
00170|     -   ``<``
00171|     -   ``>``
00172|     -   ``&``
00173|     -   ``'``
00174| 
00175|     This makes it safe to embed such strings in any place in HTML with the
00176|     notable exception of double quoted attributes.  In that case single
00177|     quote your attributes or HTML escape it in addition.
00178| 
00179|     .. versionchanged:: 0.10
00180|        This function's return value is now always safe for HTML usage, even
00181|        if outside of script tags or if used in XHTML.  This rule does not
00182|        hold true when using this function in HTML attributes that are double
00183|        quoted.  Always single quote attributes if you use the ``|tojson``
00184|        filter.  Alternatively use ``|tojson|forceescape``.
00185|     """
00186|     rv = dumps(obj, **kwargs) \
00187|         .replace(u'<', u'\\u003c') \
00188|         .replace(u'>', u'\\u003e') \
00189|         .replace(u'&', u'\\u0026') \
00190|         .replace(u"'", u'\\u0027')
00191|     if not _slash_escape:
00192|         rv = rv.replace('\\/', '/')
00193|     return rv
00194| 
00195| 
00196| def htmlsafe_dump(obj, fp, **kwargs):
00197|     """Like :func:`htmlsafe_dumps` but writes into a file object."""
00198|     fp.write(text_type(htmlsafe_dumps(obj, **kwargs)))
00199| 
00200| 
00201| def jsonify(*args, **kwargs):
00202|     """This function wraps :func:`dumps` to add a few enhancements that make
00203|     life easier.  It turns the JSON output into a :class:`~flask.Response`
00204|     object with the :mimetype:`application/json` mimetype.  For convenience, it
00205|     also converts multiple arguments into an array or multiple keyword arguments
00206|     into a dict.  This means that both ``jsonify(1,2,3)`` and
00207|     ``jsonify([1,2,3])`` serialize to ``[1,2,3]``.
00208| 
00209|     For clarity, the JSON serialization behavior has the following differences
00210|     from :func:`dumps`:
00211| 
00212|     1. Single argument: Passed straight through to :func:`dumps`.
00213|     2. Multiple arguments: Converted to an array before being passed to
00214|        :func:`dumps`.
00215|     3. Multiple keyword arguments: Converted to a dict before being passed to
00216|        :func:`dumps`.
00217|     4. Both args and kwargs: Behavior undefined and will throw an exception.
00218| 
00219|     Example usage::
00220| 
00221|         from flask import jsonify
00222| 
00223|         @app.route('/_get_current_user')
00224|         def get_current_user():
00225|             return jsonify(username=g.user.username,
00226|                            email=g.user.email,
00227|                            id=g.user.id)
00228| 
00229|     This will send a JSON response like this to the browser::
00230| 
00231|         {
00232|             "username": "admin",
00233|             "email": "admin@localhost",
00234|             "id": 42
00235|         }
00236| 
00237| 
00238|     .. versionchanged:: 1.0
00239|        Added support for serializing top-level arrays. This introduces a
00240|        security risk in ancient browsers. See :ref:`json-security` for details.
00241| 
00242|     This function's response will be pretty printed if it was not requested
00243|     with ``X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest`` to simplify debugging unless
00244|     the ``JSONIFY_PRETTYPRINT_REGULAR`` config parameter is set to false.
00245|     Compressed (not pretty) formatting currently means no indents and no
00246|     spaces after separators.
00247| 
00248|     .. versionadded:: 0.2
00249|     """
00250| 
00251|     indent = None
00252|     separators = (',', ':')
00253| 
00254|     if current_app.config['JSONIFY_PRETTYPRINT_REGULAR'] and not request.is_xhr:
00255|         indent = 2
00256|         separators = (', ', ': ')
00257| 
00258|     if args and kwargs:
00259|         raise TypeError('jsonify() behavior undefined when passed both args and kwargs')
00260|     elif len(args) == 1:  # single args are passed directly to dumps()
00261|         data = args[0]
00262|     else:
00263|         data = args or kwargs
00264| 
00265|     return current_app.response_class(
00266|         (dumps(data, indent=indent, separators=separators), '\n'),
00267|         mimetype='application/json'
00268|     )
00269| 
00270| 
00271| def tojson_filter(obj, **kwargs):
00272|     return Markup(htmlsafe_dumps(obj, **kwargs))
00273|

00032| class TestJSON(object):
00033| 
00034|     def test_post_empty_json_adds_exception_to_response_content_in_debug(self):
00035|         app = flask.Flask(__name__)
00036|         app.config['DEBUG'] = True
00037|         @app.route('/json', methods=['POST'])
00038|         def post_json():
00039|             flask.request.get_json()
00040|             return None
00041|         c = app.test_client()
00042|         rv = c.post('/json', data=None, content_type='application/json')
00043|         assert rv.status_code == 400
00044|         assert b'Failed to decode JSON object' in rv.data
00045| 
00046|     def test_post_empty_json_wont_add_exception_to_response_if_no_debug(self):
00047|         app = flask.Flask(__name__)
00048|         app.config['DEBUG'] = False
00049|         @app.route('/json', methods=['POST'])
00050|         def post_json():
00051|             flask.request.get_json()
00052|             return None
00053|         c = app.test_client()
00054|         rv = c.post('/json', data=None, content_type='application/json')
00055|         assert rv.status_code == 400

00101|     def test_jsonify_basic_types(self):

00206|     def test_json_customization(self):
00207|         class X(object):
00208|             def __init__(self, val):
00209|                 self.val = val
00210|         class MyEncoder(flask.json.JSONEncoder):
00211|             def default(self, o):
00212|                 if isinstance(o, X):
00213|                     return '<%d>' % o.val
00214|                 return flask.json.JSONEncoder.default(self, o)
00215|         class MyDecoder(flask.json.JSONDecoder):
00216|             def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
00217|                 kwargs.setdefault('object_hook', self.object_hook)
00218|                 flask.json.JSONDecoder.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
00219|             def object_hook(self, obj):
00220|                 if len(obj) == 1 and '_foo' in obj:
00221|                     return X(obj['_foo'])
00222|                 return obj
00223|         app = flask.Flask(__name__)
00224|         app.testing = True
00225|         app.json_encoder = MyEncoder
00226|         app.json_decoder = MyDecoder
00227|         @app.route('/', methods=['POST'])
00228|         def index():
00229|             return flask.json.dumps(flask.request.get_json()['x'])
00230|         c = app.test_client()
00231|         rv = c.post('/', data=flask.json.dumps({
00232|             'x': {'_foo': 42}
00233|         }), content_type='application/json')
00234|         assert rv.data == b'"<42>"'

00380|             with catch_deprecation_warnings() as captured:
00381|                 f = StringIO('Test')

00383|                 rv.direct_passthrough = False
00384|                 assert rv.data == b'Test'
00385|                 assert rv.mimetype == 'application/octet-stream'

00387|             # etags
00388|             assert len(captured) == 1
00389|             with catch_deprecation_warnings() as captured:
00390|                 class PyStringIO(object):
00391|                     def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
00392|                         self._io = StringIO(*args, **kwargs)
00393|                     def __getattr__(self, name):
00394|                         return getattr(self._io, name)

00398|                 rv.direct_passthrough = False
00399|                 assert rv.data == b'Test'
00400|                 assert rv.mimetype == 'text/plain'
00401|                 rv.close()
00402|             # attachment_filename and etags

00404|             with catch_deprecation_warnings() as captured:
00405|                 f = StringIO('Test')
00406|                 rv = flask.send_file(f, mimetype='text/plain')
00407|                 rv.direct_passthrough = False
00408|                 assert rv.data == b'Test'
00409|                 assert rv.mimetype == 'text/plain'
00410|                 rv.close()
00411|             # etags
00412|             assert len(captured) == 1
00413| 
00414|         app.use_x_sendfile = True
00415|         with catch_deprecation_warnings() as captured:
00416|             with app.test_request_context():
00417|                 f = StringIO('Test')
00418|                 rv = flask.send_file(f)
00419|                 assert 'x-sendfile' not in rv.headers
00420|                 rv.close()

00422|             assert len(captured) == 1

00645| class TestNoImports(object):
00646|     """Test Flasks are created without import.
00647| 
00648|     Avoiding ``__import__`` helps create Flask instances where there are errors
00649|     at import time.  Those runtime errors will be apparent to the user soon
00650|     enough, but tools which build Flask instances meta-programmatically benefit
00651|     from a Flask which does not ``__import__``.  Instead of importing to
00652|     retrieve file paths or metadata on a module or package, use the pkgutil and
00653|     imp modules in the Python standard library.
00654|     """
00655| 
00656|     def test_name_with_import_error(self, modules_tmpdir):
00657|         modules_tmpdir.join('importerror.py').write('raise NotImplementedError()')
00658|         try:
00659|             flask.Flask('importerror')

00025| class SessionMixin(object):
00026|     """Expands a basic dictionary with an accessors that are expected
00027|     by Flask extensions and users for the session.
00028|     """
00029| 
00030|     def _get_permanent(self):
00031|         return self.get('_permanent', False)
00032| 
00033|     def _set_permanent(self, value):
00034|         self['_permanent'] = bool(value)
00035| 
00036|     #: this reflects the ``'_permanent'`` key in the dict.
00037|     permanent = property(_get_permanent, _set_permanent)
00038|     del _get_permanent, _set_permanent
00039| 
00040|     #: some session backends can tell you if a session is new, but that is
00041|     #: not necessarily guaranteed.  Use with caution.  The default mixin
00042|     #: implementation just hardcodes ``False`` in.
00043|     new = False
00044| 
00045|     #: for some backends this will always be ``True``, but some backends will
00046|     #: default this to false and detect changes in the dictionary for as
00047|     #: long as changes do not happen on mutable structures in the session.
00048|     #: The default mixin implementation just hardcodes ``True`` in.
00049|     modified = True
00050| 
00051| 
00052| def _tag(value):
00053|     if isinstance(value, tuple):
00054|         return {' t': [_tag(x) for x in value]}
00055|     elif isinstance(value, uuid.UUID):
00056|         return {' u': value.hex}
00057|     elif isinstance(value, bytes):
00058|         return {' b': b64encode(value).decode('ascii')}
00059|     elif callable(getattr(value, '__html__', None)):
00060|         return {' m': text_type(value.__html__())}
00061|     elif isinstance(value, list):
00062|         return [_tag(x) for x in value]
00063|     elif isinstance(value, datetime):
00064|         return {' d': http_date(value)}
00065|     elif isinstance(value, dict):
00066|         return dict((k, _tag(v)) for k, v in iteritems(value))
00067|     elif isinstance(value, str):
00068|         try:
00069|             return text_type(value)
00070|         except UnicodeError:
00071|             from flask.debughelpers import UnexpectedUnicodeError
00072|             raise UnexpectedUnicodeError(u'A byte string with '
00073|                 u'non-ASCII data was passed to the session system '
00074|                 u'which can only store unicode strings.  Consider '
00075|                 u'base64 encoding your string (String was %r)' % value)

00079| class TaggedJSONSerializer(object):
00080|     """A customized JSON serializer that supports a few extra types that
00081|     we take for granted when serializing (tuples, markup objects, datetime).
00082|     """
00083| 
00084|     def dumps(self, value):
00085|         return json.dumps(_tag(value), separators=(',', ':'))
00086| 
00087|     def loads(self, value):
00088|         def object_hook(obj):
00089|             if len(obj) != 1:
00090|                 return obj
00091|             the_key, the_value = next(iteritems(obj))
00092|             if the_key == ' t':
00093|                 return tuple(the_value)
00094|             elif the_key == ' u':
00095|                 return uuid.UUID(the_value)
00096|             elif the_key == ' b':
00097|                 return b64decode(the_value)
00098|             elif the_key == ' m':
00099|                 return Markup(the_value)
00100|             elif the_key == ' d':
00101|                 return parse_date(the_value)
00102|             return obj
00103|         return json.loads(value, object_hook=object_hook)

00134| class SessionInterface(object):

00136|     default session interface which uses werkzeug's securecookie
00137|     implementation.  The only methods you have to implement are

00139|     useful defaults which you don't need to change.

00141|     The session object returned by the :meth:`open_session` method has to
00142|     provide a dictionary like interface plus the properties and methods
00143|     from the :class:`SessionMixin`.  We recommend just subclassing a dict
00144|     and adding that mixin::

00147|             pass

00151|     if the session support cannot work because some requirement is not
00152|     fulfilled.  The default :class:`NullSession` class that is created
00153|     will complain that the secret key was not set.

00156|     is to assign :attr:`flask.Flask.session_interface`::

00179|         real session support could not be loaded due to a configuration
00180|         error.  This mainly aids the user experience because the job of the

00198|     def get_cookie_domain(self, app):

00290| class SecureCookieSessionInterface(SessionInterface):
00291|     """The default session interface that stores sessions in signed cookies
00292|     through the :mod:`itsdangerous` module.

00295|     #: signing of cookie based sessions.

00298|     digest_method = staticmethod(hashlib.sha1)

00300|     #: is hmac.
00301|     key_derivation = 'hmac'

00304|     #: such as datetime objects or tuples.

00308|     def get_signing_serializer(self, app):
00309|         if not app.secret_key:
00310|             return None
00311|         signer_kwargs = dict(
00312|             key_derivation=self.key_derivation,
00313|             digest_method=self.digest_method
00314|         )
00315|         return URLSafeTimedSerializer(app.secret_key, salt=self.salt,
00316|                                       serializer=self.serializer,
00317|                                       signer_kwargs=signer_kwargs)

00319|     def open_session(self, app, request):
00320|         s = self.get_signing_serializer(app)
00321|         if s is None:
00322|             return None
00323|         val = request.cookies.get(app.session_cookie_name)
00324|         if not val:
00325|             return self.session_class()
00326|         max_age = total_seconds(app.permanent_session_lifetime)

00328|             data = s.loads(val, max_age=max_age)

00333|     def save_session(self, app, session, response):

00342|                 response.delete_cookie(app.session_cookie_name,

00357|         secure = self.get_cookie_secure(app)

00359|         val = self.get_signing_serializer(app).dumps(dict(session))

00361|                             expires=expires, httponly=httponly,
00362|                             domain=domain, path=path, secure=secure)
